3 Palestinians Die Of Gunshot Wounds In Fights With Army &gt;
LEAD: Three Palestinian demonstrators died today as a result of gunshot wounds sustained in clashes with Israeli troops.
It was the highest death toll in several weeks.


Two Other Candidates Widen the Selection
LEAD: To the Editor:


Bush Pledges Efforts to Clean Up Air and Water
LEAD: With a revived Lake Erie as a backdrop, Vice President Bush today pledged to increase government efforts to improve air and water quality, including strengthening the Environmental Protection Agency.


New Los Angeles Office
LEAD: Campbell-Mithun-Esty, Minneapolis, has opened a Los Angeles office, the agency's fifth full-service office, and appointed James Brady general manager.
Initially, the new shop will work exclusively on the $20 million Chrysler Jeep/Eagle account, but has plans to seek new business aggressively, especially marketing aimed at Hispanic audiences.


Environmentalists Say Either Bush Or Dukakis Will Be an Improvement
LEAD: The next President of the United States will be more aggressive in protecting the environment than President Reagan has been, judging by the campaign pledges and positions of both candidates.

Irwin A. Hyman, a professor of school psychology at Temple University in Philadelphia and the director of the National Center for the Study of Corporal Punishment and Alternatives in the

Can Back Bay Elegance Find Success at 57th and Lex?
LEAD: Not long ago, Murray Pearlstein received a crystal apple from Clifford Grodd, the president of Paul Stuart, the men's clothier.
It was Mr.
Grodd's sporting way of welcoming Mr.
Pearlstein and his clothing store, Louis, Boston, to New York.


Carlyle Investors Lifts Oakite Stake
LEAD: A unit of the Carlyle Group Inc., a Washington investment firm, has raised its stake in Oakite Products Inc. to 12.2 percent, from 9.9 percent.
The unit, Carlyle Investors V L.P., last week sweetened its offer for Oakite to $45.50 a share in cash.
The firm's earlier $44-a-share bid had been rejected by the board of the chemical company, based in Berkeley Heights, N.J.


New Yorkers Roll Up the Welcome Mat
LEAD: ASK a New Yorker, ''My place or yours?'' and the reply often will be an emphatic ''Neither.'' The excuses given for not inviting people home are legion.
Lack of space, a reality of New York living, is a principal one.
A highly cultivated desire for privacy, for retiring to a hideaway, is another.
Logistics - you are in TriBeCa, I am at 96th and Second

U.S. TIES ARMS DEAL TO A SOVIET RADAR
LEAD: The Reagan Administration said today that it would complete no new arms control agreements with the Soviet Union until Moscow agreed to dismantle a disputed radar station.

Power, Lynn to Tigers
LEAD: The Detroit Tigers, trying to hold on to first place in the American League East, obtained a pitcher, Ted Power, from the Kansas City Royals and Fred Lynn, an outfielder, from the Baltimore Orioles yesterday a few hours before the midnight deadline for postseason eligibility.
Lynn was acquired for three minor league players to be named.

Blast at Apartheid Foes' Office
LEAD: The headquarters of the South African Council of Churches and several leading civil rights groups was destroyed in a bombing early today in which 23 people were wounded.


Mets Stumble On Bases In Defeat
LEAD: Sid Fernandez left the game after the first inning with a tender left knee.
Gregg Jefferies left two innings later with a badly bruised right ankle.
The two injuries turned out to be regrettable, but not really serious.
The same could be said of the rest of the Mets' afternoon.


Ambulance Workers Say E.M.S. Underestimates Response Times
LEAD: New York City's Emergency Medical Services drew sharp criticism at a hearing yesterday from some of its employees, who said the agency consistently underestimates how long it takes ambulances to reach patients.


Boyd's Season Ends
LEAD: Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd, a right-handed pitcher for the Boston Red Sox, said yesterday in a television interview that he is finished pitching for the rest of the season.
He said the doctors had determined that he has a blood clot in the same spot that knocked him out of the pitching rotation twice and put him on the disabled list from July 29 to Aug.


Electoral Dynamite
LEAD: The Environment Yesterday in Michigan, George Bush started to talk about something serious.
Diversions about the Pledge of Allegiance or Mr.
Dukakis's alleged lack of patriotism were laid aside.
Mr.
Bush addressed the mounting evidence of deterioration in the environment and promised to convene a global conference to discuss remedies.


CANADA'S COMMONS BACKS TRADE PACT
LEAD: As protesters on the opposition benches and in the galleries waved Maple Leaf flags and sang ''O Canada,'' the House of Commons today approved a free-trade agreement with the United States that would end more than a century of economic nationalism in Canada.


Bond and Note Prices Edge Up
LEAD: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes inched higher in another sluggish trading session yesterday.


Review/Theater; Life, Death and Gossip
LEAD: Reaching for metaphor, ''Dreamland'' embraces pretension.
The play, at Theater for the New City, was written by Bina Sharif, who, as an actress, shares the stage with Cameron Foord.
As directed by Rolf Johannsmeier, ''Dreamland'' begins gravely on an earth-filled landscape.
Two wraith-like, white-gowned figures writhe on the ground and then rise as if returning from the dead.

Barbara E. Carter, Author, 63
LEAD: Barbara E. Carter, an author, died of complications of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, commonly known as Lou Gehrig's disease, Sunday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y.
She was 63 years old and lived in Yonkers.


Iran Is Said to Use 'Pressure' on Iraqi Captives
LEAD: A United Nations report on prisoners in the Persian Gulf war accuses Iran of using ''mental pressure'' to turn Iraqi captives into pro-Khomeini militants who could riot if forced to return home.

Beatrice Bond Prices Dip
LEAD: Prices of the Beatrice Company's high-yield bonds dipped 1 to 2 percentage points yesterday in response to a published report that the company might pay its equity investors special dividends totaling as much as $800 million.


Nicholas Cortland, Actor, 47
LEAD: Nicholas Cortland, a stage, film and television actor, died of AIDS on Aug. 21 at his home in Manhattan.
He was 47 years old.

LEAD: Michael S. Dukakis arrived in California tonight and immediately assailed Vice President Bush's environmental record, charging that Mr.

Corrections
LEAD: An article Tuesday on the changing field of sociology misidentified the author of a major history of sociology, who was quoted as saying that 75 percent of sociologists are still ''on an old-fashioned path'' while the other 25 percent ''tend to ideologize.'' He is Lewis A. Coser.


Corrections
LEAD: A report in the TV Notes column of Aug. 22 about a documentary on Doris Lessing incorrectly identified the producer of ''The South Bank Show,'' on which she appeared.
The producer is London Weekend Television.


Dow, on Rising Volume, Drops by 6.58, to 2,031.65
LEAD: Both the Dow Jones industrial average and the broader stock market finished lower yesterday as trading volume increased from the preceding three sessions.

44 Wild Horses Killed
LEAD: The Federal Bureau of Land Management said today that as many as 44 wild horses were shot to death in a remote area north of Austin.
The state Commission for the Preservation of Wild Horses has offered a reward for information leading to the arrests and convictions of the killers.


OPPOSITION CALLS FOR STABLE CHILE
LEAD: Beginning their campaign to defeat Gen.
Augusto Pinochet in a presidential plebiscite, opposition parties promised today not to let Chile fall into a power vacuum or instability if they succeed.


Review/Television; Workers and Players of Atlantic City
LEAD: Few would consider Atlantic City the jewel of the North Atlantic, but the glint from one of its facets has caught the eye of Channel 5, which will show what it saw in an hourlong documentary tonight at 8 o'clock.


Koch and Jackson Meet in a Peace Parley Refereed by Cuomo
LEAD: Mayor Koch and the Rev.
Jesse Jackson met yesterday and, despite signs of strain, told 200 reporters and photographers that they had pledged to put aside past bitterness in a common effort to elect Michael S. Dukakis.
But they made it clear that much still divided them, and they left Mr.
Jackson's role in the mayoral election next year unclear.


Tree Cutting Brings Charges
LEAD: A Federal grand jury has indicted a homeowner accused of chopping down trees in a national park to get a better view of the Potomac River, then boasting of the home's ''river view'' in real estate advertisements.


Brighter Oriental Rugs
LEAD: ''NEVER, never should anyone send an Oriental rug to a dry cleaner,'' said Elizabeth Nelle, the manager of Doris Leslie Blau, an antique-rug dealer on East 57th Street.
Instead, she said, the rugs should be cleaned by a professional rug cleaner.
That may be more costly, but it will prolong the life of the rug.

LEAD: From the porch of the shop where she works, Carol Montana looked out over the Old Faithful geyser and up at a stunning red and orange sunset.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q. The previous owners of my brick ranch house painted it white.
I would like to get rid of this see-through paint, but I am concerned about damaging the brick or mortar joints.
Is there a safe, inexpensive way to do this, or should I just live with it?
A.
Removing paint from brick is never inexpensive or easy.

LEAD: The Soviet Union confirmed today that it had sent planes from Soviet territory to bomb guerrilla positions around Kunduz, Afghanistan, but it denied American accusations that the combat missions were a violation of the Geneva accords on ending the Afghan war.

Environmental Hazards; After Years of Cleanup, Lead Poisoning Persists As a Threat to Health
LEAD: Despite steady progress in reducing lead hazards, millions of Americans are still absorbing unhealthy amounts of lead from air, dust, water, food and peeling paint found in older buildings, according to a recent authoritative report and experts in the field.


FINANCE BRIEFS
LEAD:  Debt


Six-Month Makeover: A House on the Dunes Is Transformed
LEAD: UP on the bluff, a blue and white Sea Spray flag flutters gracefully in the breeze.
Two Ferraris dot the circular tan gravel driveway, and towels embroidered with the Sea Spray logo are neatly folded on the roomy chaises that line the pristine swimming pool.
The tennis net is exactly on axis to the Tennessee orchard stone steps that lead ceremoniously up to the porte-cochere.

Boeing-Short Bros.
LEAD: The Boeing Company said it was not interested in buying Short Brothers P.L.C. of Belfast, Northern Ireland. ''We have now completed our evaluation, and we do not have an interest in purchasing all or part of Shorts,'' said Frank A. Shrontz, Boeing's chairman.
Shorts is a state-owned manufacturer of aircraft parts, which supplies Boeing with parts for its 737, 747 and 757 aircraft.

LEAD: An oil painting featuring the Walt Disney characters Donald Duck and Scrooge McDuck has been sold for $75,000, it was announced today.

LEAD: Raphael Robles, who was convicted of killing a 9-year-old girl, Jessica Febus, and hiding her body in the basement of their apartment building in the East New York section of Brooklyn, received the maximum sentence of 25 years to life in prison yesterday.

50% of Colon-Rectal Cancers Tied to Genetic Predisposition
LEAD: An inherited predisposition contributes to more than half of all cases of colon and rectal cancer, a new study has found.


Singer Agrees to Sell Kearfott Guidance Unit
LEAD: The Singer Company announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Kearfott Guidance and Navigation Division to the Astronautics Corporation of America for $285 million.


Volek an Islander
LEAD: The Islanders announced yesterday that they had come to contract terms with David Volek, a right wing from Czechoslovakia who defected to the United States on July 25.
The 22-year-old Volek, who was drafted four years ago by the Islanders, agreed to a multiyear contract at financial terms that were not announced by Bill Torrey, the Islanders' president and general manager.


Choosing the Unknown Over Pinochet
LEAD: Gen.
Augusto Pinochet, Chile's dictator since 1973, now asks voters to extend his term until 1997 by voting ''yes'' in an October plebiscite.
He is given a fair chance of winning, in what many opponents expect to be an honest ballot, despite his regime's ugly record of terrorism and abuse of liberties.


I.R.A. Syas 3 Slain Were on Mission
LEAD: The Irish Republican Army said today that three men killed by British soldiers in Northern Ireland on Tuesday were I.R.A. members ''on active service.'' The group uses the phrase to refer to a guerrilla mission.


Ananda Journal; Commune Flourishes, As Does Neighborliness
LEAD: The swami drives a Chevy, writes on a computer and wears hiking boots.
His disciples sell fancy women's fashions.

Among Mr.
Loewy's selections were a whisk broom, a Christmas ornament, two bullets, a ball of twine, the Canada Dry bottle, an American flag and, not immodestly, the Lucky Strike pack he himself had designed in 1940.

Argentina Wants Talks
LEAD: Argentina wants to meet foreign bankers next week to start talks on financing part of its $56 billion debt, a senior Argentine official said Tuesday.
The Central Bank Director, Daniel Marx, said Argentina had worked out its negotiating stance and wanted to reach a quick but lasting agreement.
If accepted by the bank steering committee that negotiates on behalf of Argentina's 480 commercial creditors, next week's talks would concentrate on the nation's financing needs through next year.

Review/Operetta; A Retouching of Herbert's 'Naughty Marietta'
LEAD: Victor Herbert's ''Naughty Marietta'' has been a mainstay of the New York City Opera, but apart from the sets, everything about the run that opened Tuesday night is new.
The book and lyrics have been retouched (inoffensively) by Theodore Pappas; as director and choreographer, Mr.
Pappas has brought the ensemble to a new level of execution, and all members of the cast are fresh in their roles.


Home Improvement
LEAD: CARTRIDGE faucets, found in many newer kitchens and bathrooms, are easy to repair.
Such faucets are turned on with a single lever or knob.
They can be readily distinguished from other single-control faucets: a rotating-ball faucet, for example, has a dome-shaped top; a tipping-valve faucet has a spindle-shaped control handle at the rear; a disk faucet has a short control lever that is part of a stubby, large-diameter cap covering the top of the faucet.

Varity Discusses Fruehauf Purchase
LEAD: The Varity Corporation, a Toronto-based equipment manufacturer, said it was discussing the possible purchase of the Fruehauf Corporation, the Detroit-based transportation equipment maker.
Varity said it would like to retain the Kelsey-Hayes Company, Fruehauf's automobile parts unit, and would consider spinning off Fruehauf's trailer business.

First Olympic Gold May Be NBC's
LEAD: It will be another two weeks before the Olympic Games begin in Seoul, South Korea, but NBC is already counting itself among the winners.
The top-rated network has sold 98 percent of the advertising time available on the 179 hours of programming it will broadcast from the Games and expects to meet its goal of $550 million in gross advertising revenue.


Review/Music; Bernstein-Gould Tribute
LEAD: To end this summer's Out-of-Doors series, Lincoln Center offered a joint birthday tribute to Leonard Bernstein, who celebrated his 70th last week, and Morton Gould, whose 75th is in December.
Having been rained out on Monday, the performance by the Harmonie Ensemble, directed by Steven Richman, took place on Tuesday evening at the Damrosch Park Band Shell.


U.S. Open; One Down, Six to Go for Graf
LEAD: Steffi Graf's magic number is now six, the number of matches she must win to become the United States Open champion and complete the Grand Slam.
For those who are hoping this will provide the Open with two weeks of added excitement, the drama and suspense building, then the opposition will have to be made of sterner stuff than Elizabeth Minter, the personable Australian who was steamrolled by Graf in a first-round match yesterday.

Gondrezick Signs
LEAD: Grant Gondrezick, a guard who was implicated in the drug scandal involving the Phoenix Suns in 1986, signed a one-year contract yesterday to play with the Los Angeles Clippers of the National Basketball Association.
Gondrezick played last season with a team in Caen, France.
Gondrezick, after being charged in the Phoenix case with three drug counts, pleaded guilty to tampering with a witness and was fined $200 and placed on three years' probation.


Absurd Lengths for a Mob Trial
LEAD: How could the Government spend 21 months trying a case against the Mafia - and then fall flat on its face?
That's what happened in the case of 20 alleged members of the Lucchese crime family in New Jersey.
A jury found the case so lacking in merit, one juror said, that it acquitted all the defendants without even discussing the evidence.

Marriage Is Chancier 2d Time Around
LEAD: ABOUT 40 percent of the women who separated while in their 30's will never remarry, nor will about 70 percent of the women who separated when they were older than 40, a new study projects.
And while 72 percent of the women will eventually remarry, half will still be single seven years after their separations, the study found.

Drugs Linked to Stomach Ulcers in Elderly
LEAD: A new study has added to evidence that many pain killing anti-inflammatory drugs, in addition to aspirin, are causing severe, even life-threatening stomach problems in elderly people.
A high incidence of abdominal complications from these drugs was found in patients who died of gastric or duodenal ulcers or bleeding from the stomach or upper portion of the intestines.

Corporate Prison Term For Allegheny Bottling
LEAD: In an unusual ruling, a Federal district judge has sentenced the Allegheny Bottling Company to three years' imprisonment and a fine of $1 million for a price-fixing scheme involving soft-drink bottling companies between 1982 and 1985.


U.S. Court Backs Orchestra In Canceling Redgrave Pact
LEAD: A Federal appeals court ruled today that the Boston Symphony Orchestra did not violate the civil rights of Vanessa Redgrave, the actress, when it canceled her performances.
The orchestra took the action in 1982 after threats of protest against the actress's support for the Palestine Liberation Organization.


Jets Cleared on Powell
LEAD: An arbitrator has found that the Jets were not acting out of ''anti-union animus'' in 1986 when they released and then traded Marvin Powell, who was president of the National Football League Players Association at the time.


Tokyo Bank's Bid Is Backed by Fed
LEAD: The Federal Reserve Board has approved the takeover of the Union Bank of Los Angeles by the Bank of Tokyo Ltd., as a majority of board members overruled objections by Martha R. Seger.
The Fed governor said that she had voted against the application because American banks would not be allowed to make a similar acquisition in

LEAD: Nick Melisse, a customer service representative at Eastern Airlines for 14 years, stood outside the huge reservation center here handling a white carnation that symbolized the end of his career at Eastern.

Dale Pon Starts Agency With Media Emphasis
LEAD: Dale Pon, 43 years old, has decided to leave his post as executive vice president at Lois Pitts Gershon Pon/ GGK to start his own venture, Dale Pon Advertising, at 1 Fifth Avenue.
Mr.
Pon, who most recently was president of the entertainment division and a director at the agency, will gear his new shop toward broadcast and cable promotion as well as music and entertainment.


Cram Injured
LEAD: Steve Cram, the star British miler, suffered a leg injury in a track meet in Rieti, Italy, and an Italian doctor who treated him said there were serious doubts that Cram could run at the Seoul Olympics.
The 27-year-old star walked from the track and said he thought the injury was far less serious than first feared.


Postal Account To Rubicam
LEAD: The United States Postal Service has again turned to Young &amp; Rubicam, its agency of 14 years, to handle its advertising.
The budget is $40 million, 60 percent of it going to broadcast and print advertising.


Hungary-Rumania Rift Unresolved
LEAD: The Hungarian Communist Party spokesman acknowledged Tuesday night that a meeting last Sunday between the Hungarian and Rumanian party chiefs, the first such encounter in 11 years, had disappointed most Hungarians.


Greenspan to Visit Japan
LEAD: The Federal Reserve Board's chairman, Alan Greenspan, will visit Tokyo in mid-October to hold talks with senior Japanese monetary officials, a Bank of Japan spokesman said today.
He declined to comment on the agenda.
It will be Mr.
Greenspan's first visit to Japan as the Fed's chairman.

Competition Winners On Radio Music Series
LEAD: ''The Winners Circle,'' a series of eight one-hour programs of performances by young winners of recent international music competitions, will be broadcast on WQXR AM (1560) and FM (96.3), starting Tuesday at 7 P.M.
Each program will consist of a 15-minute interview conducted by Robert Sherman and a 45-minute performance.

Hormel Layoffs
LEAD: Geo.
A.
Hormel &amp; Company has informed nearly half of the workers at its plant in Fremont, Neb., that they will be laid off in a year.
The notices, given 52 weeks before the expected layoffs, are required by the collective bargaining agreement between the meatpacker and Local 22 of the United Food and Commercial Workers union.


Gynecology; Allergies in Sex Linked to Some Vaginitis Cases
LEAD: Allergic reactions set off by sexual intercourse may be responsible for a significant number of cases of recurrent vaginitis, including some in which yeast infections are found, recent studies indicate.

Serenading Sculptures
LEAD: THE sounds of summer fill the almost clean air here at the beach in Santa Monica: crashing waves, laughing children, screeching gulls, singing beach chairs.
Singing beach chairs?
Looking for all the world like a pair of pastel-colored highchairs, the 14-foot-high musical chairs, each backed with five slotted pipes, serenade beachgoers with mournful sounds when the wind blows.


Thieves Drive Into a Window To Rob a Store
LEAD: Thieves built a plywood ramp up to the window of a fur salon yesterday, rammed a stolen van through the steel security gate and window, and escaped with about 60 coats, the police said.

Addenda
LEAD: *
Premiere, a movie magazine that is owned by Hatchette S.A. of France and Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, will raise both its rate base and circulation 50 percent as of January.
Circulation will rise to 375,000, from 250,000.


End Game for Yonkers
LEAD: The city of Yonkers and four of its councilmen are nearing the end of their Federal court fight over housing discrimination.
If the U.S.
Supreme Court allows contempt charges and crippling fines to remain in place, the city faces financial ruin and the councilmen face jail.





Presidio Oil to Buy Energy Properties
LEAD: The Presidio Oil Company has agreed to buy a group of oil and gas properties from the Standard Oil Production Company of Houston for Presidio common stock and cash estimated at $55 million, the two companies said.
The acquisitions include proven reserves of six million barrels of oil and 22 billion cubic feet of natural gas as well as 30,000 acres of non-producing lease acreage.

LEAD: The intrepid hero of ''The Deceivers'' is played by Pierce Brosnan, who is seen getting the best of a wild tiger during one of the film's early scenes.
Obviously, this William Savage - a fictionalized version of one William Sleeman, a British officer living in the India of the 1820's - is quite a fellow.


Correction
LEAD: A front-page picture caption yesterday misidentified a man who appeared at a news conference with the Rev.
Jesse Jackson and Mayor Koch.
Stanley Hill is executive director of District Council 37, the municipal workers' union, not an aide to Mr.
Jackson.


Gretzky Pact Extended
LEAD: Wayne Gretzky, who was acquired by the Los Angeles Kings from the Edmonton Oilers last month, reached an agreement with the Kings to extend his contract past the four years remaining, the Kings announced yesterday.


Correction
LEAD: An article Aug. 25 on the new logotype for Lincoln Center incompletely attributed the design of the NBC symbol.
The network's current peacock logo was designed by Chermayeff &amp; Geismar Associates, but the original peacock logo was designed by John J. Graham and Herbert Lubalin.

LEAD: The Dallas Cowboys will wear the initials of Arthur Rooney Sr. on their helmets Sunday when they play the Steelers in Pittsburgh.

Brookhurst Trims Its Stake in Zenith
LEAD: Brookhurst Partners L.P., a partnership controlled by the New York arbitragers Herbert B. Abelow and Nicholas L. Ilasz, has lowered its stake in the Zenith Electronics Corporation to 6.1 percent, from 7.1 percent.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Brookhurst said that it ''has engaged in discussions on several occasions with a potential acquirer of Zenith's computer products, systems and components group'' but that no agreements had been reached.

Leonor K. Sullivan, 86, Democrat of Missouri
LEAD: Leonor K. Sullivan, a 12-term Democratic member of the House of Representatives, the only woman ever elected to Congress from Missouri, died today of heart failure.

Two Fined for Stunt at Falls
LEAD: Two college students who tried to go over the Horseshoe Falls in a makeshift barrel almost two years ago have been fined $4,725 each by the Coast Guard.
The two, Harry Kallet of Bridgeport, N.Y., and Michael Viscosi of Schenectady, N.Y., had hoped to be the first two-man team to go over the falls, but they abandoned the effort after their craft sprang a leak.

LEAD: Lawrence Taylor's agent, Gary Kovach, said earlier this week that the Giants' linebacker might undergo drug rehabilitation beginning sometime soon, after it was disclosed Monday that he had failed a drug test.
No starting date for treatment has been set, however, and Kovach would not accept telephone calls yesterday.


9 Are Held After Raids on Seafood Houses in South
LEAD: Federal and state agents raided wholesale seafood houses in South Carolina, Florida and Louisiana today in a move to curb interstate selling of oysters and clams from polluted waters.

Tennis Federation Rejects Tour Plan
LEAD: The International Tennis Federation and the Grand Slam tournaments held a news conference yesterday to reject publicly the proposal by the Association of Tennis Professionals to organize its own international tour in 1990.

Dr. Hans Lewy, 83, Mathematics Profesor
LEAD: Hans Lewy, a professor emeritus of mathematics at the University of California at Berkeley, died of leukemia Aug. 23 in Berkeley, where he lived.
He was 83 years old.


Alaska Journal; Marketing Glacier Ice Is a Hot New Industry
LEAD: About 100,000 glaciers cover nearly 5 percent of this vast state.
It's hard to see the ice cubes for the bergs.


At the Bar
LEAD: ''Freedom of association,'' the right to belong to groups of one's choosing, is nowhere mentioned in the Constitution.
It is a concept often read into the First Amendment by lawyers, argued by lawyers, written and refined by lawyers, expanded and expounded by lawyers.
But now the principle has been applied to lawyers and the legal profession is aghast.

Dukakis and Jackson: Still Apart
LEAD: The Rev.
Jesse Jackson said in Atlanta that he wanted no big job in the Democratic campaign and no title.
What he wanted was respect - to be accepted as a man with useful advice and as a politician capable of delivering a constituency.
Apparently he's still a long way from achieving these objectives.


Auctions
LEAD: There were some who looked askance when Sotheby's held its first auction devoted to rock-and-roll memorabilia in December 1981.
But rock has always been an enormous money maker, and as collectors have long realized, one doesn't have to be a performer, manager, record executive or merchandiser to reap the profits.


Ralf Ralf: Gibberish as an Art Art
LEAD: Two men meet in ''The Summit,'' which will be performed by Ralf Ralf at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater this weekend.
Dressed in drab business suits, they are participants at an international conference.
Representing opposite sides at the conference table, they hector and cajole each other in a stream of political discourse that ends with fleeting moments of closeness before the battle lines are drawn again.


CONCERN ON MEESE PROMPTS TRIP BAN
LEAD: The Justice Department said today that Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, concerned over a recent trip to Japan by former Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d and five department officials, would impose a new policy to bar official trips unless they relate directly to an employee's work.


Israeli's Remark That Palestinians Look to P.L.O. Turns Some Heads
LEAD: The director general of Israel's Foreign Ministry has caused political ripples here and in Israel by saying that Palestinians see the Palestine Liberation Organization as their ''national organization'' and that there is no replacement for it.
Israel has steadfastly refused to deal with the P.L.O., which it deems a terrorist organization.


Leader Booed in Mexican Congress
LEAD: Interrupted repeatedly by the jeers and chants of newly strengthened opposition parties, President Miguel de la Madrid delivered his final state-of-the-nation address today.
He defended the disputed presidential election in July as totally ''in accordance with the Constitution and the electoral laws of the republic.

Restaurants
LEAD: The Polo is a plush and patrician refuge in the Westbury Hotel on East 69th Street that has gone through dramatic changes in recent years.
Long known as a comfortable if undistinguished Continental dining room, it made a serious commitment to fine dining about four years ago when it created a top-notch Provencal-style French menu under the chef Patrice Boely.

The production is to be given in Spanish with an English synopsis; there also are performances scheduled for Sept.

Corn and Soybeans Gain On Reports of Soviet Buying
LEAD: Grain and soybean futures gained moderately yesterday for the third straight day on the Chicago Board of Trade because of what brokers called real and rumored improvements in foreign demand.


Homeless Live on Upper East Side Now
LEAD: To the Editor:


Car Sales Rise in Japan
LEAD: Sales of vehicles in Japan increased 14.5 percent in August from a year earlier, to 263,629, according to preliminary figures released today by the Japan Automobile Dealers Association.
The rise was the 16th straight year-to-year gain.
The August figures, which are compiled from vehicle registrations, were much lower than the 485,549 of July, which was 7.7 percent more than a year earlier.


BURMA RULES OUT NEW CONCESSIONS
LEAD: Confrontation between the Burmese Government and its people intensified today as huge crowds filled the streets to demand democratic elections and the President responded on radio that no further concessions would be made.


Sale Terms Set On Texaco Unit
LEAD: Texaco Inc. took another step toward selling its 78 percent interest in Texaco Canada by announcing that it had reached an agreement with the subsidiary on procedures that would protect the interests of minority shareholders.


Burundi Official in Brussels Seeking Aid From Europeans
LEAD: Foreign Minister Cyprien Mbonimpa of Burundi visited Belgian and European Community officials today seeking aid for his country, which has been torn by tribal bloodshed.


Peete Leads Southern Cal in 34-7 Rout
LEAD: Rodney Peete opened his Heisman Trophy campaign impressively tonight in leading Southern Cal to an easy victory over Boston College, 34-7, at Alumni Stadium.


Teamsters Resume Talks With Hollywood Producers
LEAD: Contract talks between teamsters drivers and Hollywood producers resuumed today, one day after the union overwhelmingly rejected the producers' most recent offer.

APPEAL BY WALESA FAILS TO RESOLVE ALL POLISH STRIKES
LEAD: Striking Polish workers, voicing strong misgivings about the results of talks between the Government and Lech Walesa, the Solidarity founder, were deeply divided today over whether to heed his appeal that they end their strikes and return to work.


U.S. to End Bond Plan
LEAD: The Treasury Department said Wednesday that it would scrap a four-month-old program that offered investors a 24-hour, toll-free telephone number to buy United States Savings Bonds with a credit card.
Investors used the program to buy $4.5 million in bonds from its inception on May 3 through mid-August.

Cadbury Posts Profit Increase
LEAD: The British candy and soft-drink company Cadbury-Schweppes P.L.C. announced today that pretax profits for the first six months of 1988 rose by 28.3 percent.
The company's chairman, Sir Adrian Cadbury, said he expected further growth this year.


Chrysler Venture With Mitsubishi
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation and the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation began producing cars in a joint venture that auto analysts say will pull Chrysler even with its United States competitors in the race for Japanese expertise.
Chrysler is the last of the Big Three to open a domestic auto plant with a Japanese company.


Somebody Else Saw It, Too
LEAD: One of the side benefits of the baseball collusion decisions is that some of us can stop wondering if we're nuts.
Nobody likes to be the only person who sees the emperor is not wearing any clothing, or that the baseball owners must be conspiring to not sign free agents.


Airline Sues Over Sales Of Flier Miles
LEAD: American Airlines has filed lawsuits against four ticket brokers, accusing them of buying frequent-flier mileage from American's passengers and reselling it to people who cash it in for airline tickets.

Punjab Land Mine Kills 2
LEAD: A land mine exploded under a police jeep on a highway north of Amritsar today, killing two constables and wounding three others, the police said.
The explosion was believed to the be work of Sikh militants, an official said.
It was the first reported incident of Sikh radicals using land mines in their campaign for an independent homeland in the Punjab.

LEAD: It seems more a tactic than tact, but Mayor Koch has an improbable new style: he is trying to be, well, nice.


Cubans Talked Secretly With the Angolan Rebels
LEAD: Cuban officials and American-backed Angolan rebels held secret face-to-face meetings for the first time last weekend, both sides said today, and State Department officials and rebel representatives characterized the encounter as a welcome development in the 13-year-old Angolan conflict.

U.S. Won't Recall Samurai
LEAD: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration denied a request today by the Center for Auto Safety that it recall the Suzuki Samurai utility vehicle, which critics have said is likely to tip over in abrupt maneuvers.


Hotel Bomb Kills 2 in Namibia
LEAD: A bomb exploded this evening at a downtown hotel frequented by blacks, killing 2 people and injuring 10, the police said.


Productivity Fell by 1.4% In 2d Quarter
LEAD: The efficiency of nonfarm businesses in producing goods and services dropped at an annual rate of 1.4 percent in the second quarter, an improvement over the 1.7 percent decline originally reported for the quarter.
It was the first quarterly decline since 1986.


Louis Effrat, Sportswriter, 78
LEAD: Louis Effrat, a sports reporter for The New York Times for nearly 50 years, died yesterday at the Royal Manor Nursing home near his home in Royal Palm Beach, Fla..
He was 78 years old and had recently suffered a heart attack.

LEAD: While Brian C. Beazer continues to seek buyers for the chemical operations of his newly acquired Koppers Company, the Pittsburgh concern's engineering department announced Wednesday that it was breaking away to form a consulting firm.
The new Chemtech Consultants Inc. will employ about 30 people, 18 of whom will be investors.

Chrysler Names Head Of Technologies Unit
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation's board yesterday named Paul E. Wright to the new post of chairman of Chrysler Technologies, which encompasses the company's aerospace and military businesses.


Amoco Completes Takeover of Dome
LEAD: A Canadian unit of the Amoco Corporation completed the largest corporate takeover in Canada's history: the acquisition, worth $5.5 billion (Canadian), or about $4.4 billion, of the once-high-flying oil explorer Dome Petroleum Ltd.
Amoco will gain the huge Canadian oil and gass assets of Dome, which was brought low by debt and plunging oil prices, but will also take on Dome's debt of $6 billion

British Tourism A Record in '87
LEAD: A record 15.4 million foreign tourists visited Britain last year, the British Tourist Authority said today.


Harold S. Mohler Is Dead at 69; Long a Leader in Hershey Foods
LEAD: Harold S. Mohler, former chief executive of the Hershey Foods Corporation, died of cardiac arrest Wednesday at the Milton S. Hershey Medical Center in Hershey, Pa.
He was 69 years old and lived in Hershey.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Times Co. Purchases Sailing World Magazine
LEAD: The New York Times Company said yesterday that it had purchased Sailing World, a monthly boating magazine that focuses on racing and high performance, from the North American Publishing Company.
The Times Company did not disclose how much it paid for the magazine, whose circulation is 53,000.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ketchum Buys Health Agency
LEAD: Ketchum Communications Inc., Pittsburgh, has acquired Botto, Roessner, Horne &amp; Messinger, a $22 million health care agency, which will continue to operate under its name and with its current management.


Family Law: Battleground in Social Revolution
LEAD: Family law, long a professional backwater, has become a new constitutional battleground on which the social revolutions in family structure, childbearing and personal relationships are being fought.


Pop/Jazz; Music With Distant Roots Takes Hold
LEAD: Some popular music aims to make the whole world dance, and to do so it seeks a national and international common denominator.
Other music, however, maintains ties to a local community even when it's heard a long way from home.
In the 1980's, many listeners have begun to prize music that refuses to be uprooted -and this weekend, two musicians who can conjure their hometowns with just a few notes are bringing San Antonio and Rio de Janeiro north to New York

Rose's Son Signs
LEAD: Pete Rose 2d, the son of Manager Pete Rose of the Cincinnati Reds, has signed a minor league contract with the Baltimore Orioles, the team announced yesterday.
The younger Rose, an 18-year-old third baseman, was the Orioles' 12th-round draft selection in the June draft.
He will report to the Orioles' West Palm Beach affiliate in the Florida Instructional League.


Bush, in Enemy Waters, Says Rival Hindered Cleanup of Boston Harbor
LEAD: Vice President Bush, saying he was tired of taking verbal ''sludge'' from Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis on the environment, took a boat ride across Boston Harbor today and accused his Democratic rival of neglecting its pollution and hindering its cleanup.

Dollar and Pound Drop; Gold Falls
LEAD: The dollar weakened slightly yesterday, as speculative trading in New York subsided in advance of the Labor Day holiday and today's report on the nation's employment.

LEAD: At a time of widespread interest in Dutch painting, ''Dutch and Flemish Paintings From Private New York Collections,'' at the National Academy of Design, makes sense.
Because it has more to do with demonstrating the strength of Old Master collections in New York than with formulating themes and arguments, it is low key.

Congas in the Night
LEAD: A Night of Congas, part of the New York Salsa Festival, will feature Eddie Palmieri and his Latin Jazz Ensemble, Daniel Ponce and Arawe and the guest conga soloist Giovanni Hidalgo.
Shows begin tonight at 9:30 and at 12:30 A.M. at the Village Gate, 160 Bleecker Street, at Thompson Street (475-5120).


Hatch Says Democrats 'Party of Homosexuals'
LEAD: A day after referring to Democrats as ''the party of homosexuals,'' Senator Orrin Hatch said today he never intended to brand all Democrats as such.
But Democrats quickly pounced on the Utah Republican's remarks as unbelievable and insulting.


Money Fund Assets Fall
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 449 money market mutual funds decreased $2.01 billion, to $267.04 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 126 institutional funds decreased $637.6 million, to $69.04 billion.
Assets of the 221 general-purpose funds declined $333.8 million, to $85.04 billion.

A Rapid Drop In Soviet Lake Called a Crisis
LEAD: The Soviet Union's Aral Sea, once the fourth-largest lake in the world, is rapidly drying up because nearly all the water in its tributaries is being diverted for irrigation.
By the end of the century, an American geographer has concluded, the lake could become lifeless and briny, leading to widespread ecologic and economic blight.

LEAD: New Jersey


Library Gets A Big Music Collection
LEAD: One of the world's larger and more wide-ranging private collections of musical manuscripts, letters and documents has been given to the Music Division of the Library of Congress in Washington.

LEAD: (Seedings in parentheses.) STADIUM Morning 11 A.M.: Jimmy Connors (6) vs.
Gilad Bloom.


Crazy Eddie Stake
LEAD: The Baupost Group Inc., an investment partnership based in Cambridge, Mass., has acquired the equivalent of a 9.2 percent stake in Crazy Eddie Inc. as part of a refinancing by the troubled chain of electronics stores.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Baupost said it was holding the Crazy Eddie debentures for investment purposes only.


New Hershey Product
LEAD: The Hershey Foods Corporation today announced a powdered chocolate mix that will be shipped to stores.
Earlier this summer, Hershey withdrew its 32-year-old entry in the $200 million a year powdered-chocolate market, Hershey's Instant.
The company said it planned a large television and direct mail advertising campaign.


Cuomo Signs Bill on AIDS Confidentiality
LEAD: Doctors will soon be able to tell needle-sharing or sexual partners of AIDS-infected people that they are in danger of contracting the fatal disease under provisions of a bill signed into law today by Governor Cuomo.

Treasuries Flat in Listless Session
LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were little changed at the close of a listless trading session yesterday, as the credit market marked time in advance of this morning's August employment report and the start of the long Labor Day weekend.

LEAD: There are enough carefully researched period artifacts to stock a claustrophobically crowded museum.
Scene after scene, shot in golden light and crammed with nicely homely faces, looks as if it came straight out of a Norman Rockwell portfolio.
But fine performances take hold about a third of the way through ''The Wizard of Loneliness,'' which opens today at the 57th Street Playhouse, and this chronicle of a lonely, bratty young boy adrift in a friendly


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Policy Shift By Hispanic Broadcasters
LEAD: HARD-LIQUOR advertising, while never seen on the major broadcast networks or on most local stations, has never been totally banned from television.
Most broadcasters have long respected a policy of not accepting liquor commercials, although no legal bar exists to showing them.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Perestroika's Perilous Spinoffs
LEAD: Passions over empire and nationalism stir in Eastern Europe once again.
Twice before in this century, such conflicts plunged the world into total war.
Much has changed since 1945.
But it would be hazardous to underestimate the significance of the forces now at play.
For the most part, they have been unleashed by the positive initiatives of Mikhail


Dining Out Guide: Near Shopping and Movies
LEAD: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times.
Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars.
Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.
Alo Alo  ** (June 21, 1985), 1030 Third Avenue, at 61st Street (838-4343) - Alo Alo's wraparound glass walls invite people-watching after a day of shopping or an evening at the movies.


F.C.C. Fights Cable Piracy
LEAD: Federal Communications Commission agents have seized illegal satellite unscrambling devices from businesses in four states in a drive to end cable piracy, the F.C.C. said today.


Horse Racing Notebook; It's Post Time in Oklahoma
LEAD: There will never be a sloppy track at the new Remington Park in Oklahoma City because there will never be any slop.


Man Dies in Air Show Crash; Germany Puts the Toll at 49
LEAD: A man died early today of burns suffered in the air show disaster here Sunday, and West German officials gave the first breakdown by nationality of the dead and injured.


Fire and Toxic Cloud in Canada Cause Alarm and Recrimination
LEAD: Health officials and politicians are debating how to deal with one of Canada's worst environmental disasters, a fire at a Quebec warehouse that released toxic chemicals known as PCB's and forced the evacuation of more than 3,300 people.


WEEKENDER GUIDE
LEAD:  Friday  LIFE CAN BE FUNNY


Man Held for Not Giving Jury Tompkins Sq. Tape
LEAD: In a swift strike by the Manhattan District Attorney's office, an artist who videotaped police and demonstrators clashing in Tompkins Square Park was arrested yesterday and charged with contempt of court for refusing to turn over the tape.


Rock Double Bill
LEAD: Mofungo and Ritual Tension will play an avant-rock double bill tonight at 9 and midnight at the Knitting Factory, 47 East Houston Street (219-3055).
Tickets are $7.


On Piano and Bass
LEAD: The duo of Bill Mays on piano and Red Mitchell on bass will perform tonight and tomorrow at Bradley's, 70 University Place (228-6440).
Music begins at 9:30 P.M.; there is a $5 cover and an $8 minimum.


For 11 Tenants, Perseverance Brings a Victory
LEAD: Housing they can afford is so scarce that 11 tenants at 49 Prospect Street clung to their apartments through two winters, even when their ceilings fell on them and pets froze to death and the mailman no longer delivered because of sewage in the mailroom.
They felt their new landlord had hired ''goons'' to remove their doors, cut off their heat and water and force them from their $300-a-month rent-controlled apartments.


German Copy of 1939 Baltic Protocol Preserved
LEAD: To the Editor:


Paris Bank Branch Offers 10% Notes
LEAD: The New York branch of Banque Nationale de Paris is offering $200 million of 10 percent notes due in 1998, at a price of par, to yield about three-quarters of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.


CHILE ENDS EXILE OF ALLENDE FAMILY
LEAD: President Augusto Pinochet today ended the enforced exile of many relatives and close associates of former President Salvador Allende Gossens, the Marxist overthrown by the armed forces 15 years ago.


Andersen And Utility In Inquiry
LEAD: The tax and accounting practices of the Oglethorpe Power Corporation, an Atlanta-based electric cooperative, are the focus of a long-running criminal investigation, the Government official leading the inquiry said yesterday.


Saudis to Cut Wheat Aid
LEAD: Saudi Arabia has decided to reduce subsidies for the 1989 wheat crop, an Agriculture Department report said Wednesday.
Saudi Arabia has been subsidizing exports of wheat surpluses since 1985-86.


A Baseball Club Tells Truth; Even Accepts Consequences
LEAD: In all honesty, the Detroit Tigers did what they could.
But it was the honesty that did them in.


Market Place; The Downturn In Steel Stocks
LEAD: INVESTOR enthusiasm for steel stocks seems to be waning.
Armco Inc., at $$11.125 a month ago, closed yesterday at $10.
Bethlehem Steel is now at $20.50, down from $25.125 at the end of July.
And Inland Steel, which was at $38.25 at that time, is now at $37.

LEAD:  John Scofield Trio


New Date for Tyson Bout
LEAD: Mike Tyson's next title defense, against Frank Bruno in London, will take place Oct. 22.
That was the determination made yesterday after Tyson's injured right hand was examined by Dr.
David Chiu.

Crew Discussed Engine Problem Before Jet Crash
LEAD: The crew of the Delta Air Lines jet that crashed in Texas Wednesday spoke of an engine problem in the seconds after it took off and before it fell back to the ground and skidded to a flaming stop 3,000 feet past the end of the runway, a Government official said yesterday.

And in the end, it will not have taken as long to renew the landmark as it did to build it in the first place; that took 15 years.

For Children
LEAD: Shows, Nature, Museums  TRICKSTER STORIES, a collection of American Indian tales told by Diane Wolkstein, 11 A.M. tomorrow at the Hans Christian Andersen statue, near 72d Street and Fifth Avenue in Central Park.
Free.
FAMILY NIGHT, a performance by the Marie Brooks Dance Theater, a troupe of youngsters who will present a program of Caribbean and African dance and drumming, tonight at 7 at the Brooklyn Children's Museum, 145 Brooklyn Avenue.


Mostly Mozart, and Worse
LEAD: At an uptown subway station, commuters wait with special desperation for a light at the end of the tunnel.
On the stuffy platform, a man plays an electronically amplified flute, a noise that invades every corner.
The music is Mozart; the flautist, first rate.
Why is it so offensive?
Because it's nine o'clock in the morning - an hour when most recently awakened people prefer to read or have a few moments to themselves before being swept into the business of the day.


Parkers Are Told Fast-Meter Alibis Won't Work Anymore
LEAD: Anxiety over parking tickets has long provided New York City drivers with a reason to jump out of bed early, speed along avenues in reverse, or plan a midnight drive from one side of the street to the other.


Review/Operetta; Making a Virtue Out of Marietta's Lack of Same
LEAD: A dollop of inconsequential frippery can be a good thing on occasion, particularly in these few weeks between the end of the summer festivals and the start of the regular season.
In recent years, the New York City Opera has been doing its share in the light entertainment department by way of its operetta series, and the one currently on display is Victor Herbert's ''Naughty Marietta.


LABOR DAY REVELS IN 3 STATES
LEAD: THE summer season traditionally comes to an end with Labor Day, a misnamed holiday distinguished by the decided absence of work and a day that is actually stretched into several days over a weekend that starts today and concludes Monday evening.
It is a day so identified with the somewhat saddening exit of summer languor that it is easy to overlook a weekend calendar so filled with activity that little time may remain to mourn the low-key, if humidly deadening, months behind us.


Jefferies, in a Short Time, Makes a Big Impression
LEAD: Darryl Strawberry tore open his payroll envelope Wednesday and smiled.
Check in hand, he suddenly had an idea.
Strawberry walked across the clubhouse and handed the check to Gregg Jefferies.


Bangladesh Flood Toll Up to 680 in Monsoon
LEAD: Office workers in small boats and banana-plant rafts sailed to work through flooded streets in the capital today as the Burhi Ganga River reached its highest level in 34 years - more than 23 feet.


TV Weekend; Going One on One With America, Soviet Style
LEAD: In case of a shakeup of Soviet journalists, Vladimir Dunayev should be able to get a job as a stand-up comedian on American television.
He can be seen in a debut of sorts on Sunday at 10 P.M. on Channel 13, in a half-hour documentary entitled ''Dear Comrades: A Channel 3, Moscow Special.''


Curfew On, and Off Again
LEAD: Hours after announcing yesterday that the city would re-impose a late-night curfew in the parks next week, Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern said he and Mayor Koch had had second thoughts and postponed the action ''until cooler weather.''

Music begins at 9 P.M.; there is a $5 cover and a two-drink minimum.


Dow Drops By 29.34, To 2,002.31
LEAD: Stock prices plunged across a broad front yesterday, leaving the Dow Jones industrial average barely above the 2,000 mark.


Bridge
LEAD: Soon after World War II, two brilliant young Italians devised a bizarre bidding method, far ahead of its time, that they used with success in international championships in the 50's.
They were Mario Franco and Michele Giovine, and their system, named from the first halves of their first names, was ''Marmic.

Luis W. Alvarez, Nobel Physicist Who Explored Atom, Dies at 77
LEAD: Luis W. Alvarez, winner of the 1968 Nobel Prize in Physics who was a member of the team that developed the atomic bomb, died yesterday in Berkeley, Calif., after a long bout with cancer.
He was 77 years old.


Man Is Shot to Death As a Gunman Fires Into a Concert Crowd
LEAD: One man was killed and four people were wounded yesterday, one critically, when a gunman fired into a crowd of 350 outside a memorial rap concert in Brooklyn, the police said.

It is not without irony that the Rockwells have been named, since their picture-perfect happy family tableau harkens back to a simpler time.

No Survivors Found in Mexican Plane Crash
LEAD: Rescuers climbed to the wreckage of a commuter plane today and found no survivors among the 20 people who were aboard when it crashed in rugged mountains in the western Sierra Madre, a military official said.


Alexander Gerber, Cardiologist, 76
LEAD: Dr.
Alexander Gerber, an internist who specialized in cardiology and who did early work in the use of steroids in chemotherapy and organ transplants, died of a heart attack at Central Vermont Hospital in Berlin, Vt., while on vacation.
He was 76 years old and lived in Atlantis, Fla.

Jewish Settler Shoots Troops By Mistake in Chasing Arab
LEAD: The police detained a Jewish settler in the occupied West Bank after he accidentally shot and wounded two Israeli soldiers while chasing a Palestinian who hurled a firebomb at his car, officials said today.


Slump at Retailers Continued for August
LEAD: The nation's largest general retailers were unable to break out of their 18-month-old slump in August as weather conditions and continuing problems in apparel lines depressed sales for yet another month.

Ex-Firestone President Takes Post at Whirlpool
LEAD: Albert E. Suter, who left the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company this summer after a short stint as its president and chief operating officer, was named to similar posts yesterday at the Whirlpool Corporation.


REviews/Art; Reading Messages in Conceptualism Exhibition
LEAD: While many might argue that art should be seen, not heard (or read), the loquaciousness of the visual is clearly on the rise.
Language has played an important role in much 20th-century art, but never more so than since the late 1960's.
At that time, Conceptual art loosened a flood of words - used singly, in provocative phrases and long texts - into what has become, increasingly, the mainstream.


Economic Scene; How Well Off Are Workers?
LEAD: LABOR DAY 1988 is bound to yield a great deal of partisan oratory on the economic status of American working men and women and how to improve it.
The Republicans will focus on the long spell of economic expansion since 1982, the lowest rate of unemployment in 14 years, the increase in the number of workers employed and the huge increase in employment that lies ahead.


Goodman Fielder Ends Bid for Ranks
LEAD: Australia's largest food company, Goodman Fielder Ltd., dropped its bid to buy Ranks Hovis McDougall P.L.C., one of Britain's biggest bakers.
The offer of $:1.7 billion ($2.85 billion) had been under study by Britain's Monopolies and Mergers Commission.
Ranks Hovis is one of the two main bakers of bread in Britain, and the Department of Trade and Industry had said it was worried about how the takeover would affect competition.


Red Sox Cut Tigers' Lead to One Game
LEAD: Larry Parrish's two-run home run keyed a four-run sixth inning that lifted the Boston Red Sox to a 4-2 victory over the California Angels tonight.


Guilty Plea in Vernon Case
LEAD: The former Dallas real estate consultant Jack D. Franks agreed today to plead guilty to one count of aiding and abetting bank fraud at the Vernon Savings and Loan Association as part of a plea agreement granting him immunity from other criminal charges, Federal investigators said.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Publix Super Markets Shifts Account to West
LEAD: Publix Super Markets Inc., Lakeland, Fla., has switched agencies for its $15 million in advertising spending.
The account goes from Louis Benito Advertising, Tampa's largest agency, to West &amp; Company in Jacksonville, which already handles marketing for Publix.

Jackson Disclaims Reports of a Curb
LEAD: The Rev.
Jesse Jackson today publicly disclaimed reports by his advisers that Michael S. Dukakis's campaign officials had asked him not to campaign for the Democratic Presidential ticket in certain states, for fear that he would alienate more potential supporters than he would attract.


Credit Agreement By Cable Operator
LEAD: The Century Communications Corporation, New Canaan, Conn., which owns and operates cable television systems, said yesterday that it had concluded a $600 million long-term credit agreement with about eight banks led by Citibank.
The agreement includes a competitive-bid commercial paper facility.


Review/Art; Nachume Miller's Turbulent, Syncopated Dreams
LEAD: In several works on view at the Museum of Modern Art, Nachume Miller makes a virtue of obsessive drawing.
The West German-born artist, now living in New York, nearly overwhelms large wood panels and sheets of paper with dense, complex webs of swirling lines that suggest tumultuous landscapes and unfathomable calamities.


Toon Suffers Injury; May Miss Opener
LEAD: Al Toon, the Jets' most consistent player and Pro Bowl receiver, has suffered a groin injury that will probably keep him out of the season opener against the Patriots Sunday.


Videotape Collection
LEAD: The National Archives, repository of such precious papers as the Constitution and Declaration of Independence, appears to be acutely attentive, as well, to the value of modern documentary resources such as videotape recordings.
Recently the Archives signed an agreement with the Cable Satellite Public Affairs Network to deposit 200 cubic feet of videotaped programs from the years 1979 to 1983.

LEAD: The last thing New York City should want is to discourage enterprise, especially among those hard to employ.
But Mayor Koch is right about the need to curtail ''squeegee men,'' who wash windshields of stopped cars and then ask for tips.

Review/Film; A Nation Disillusioned
LEAD: Of course John Sayles begins ''Eight Men Out'' with a little boy, with the kid who is the purest and most hopeful of baseball fans, the one whose subsequent plea, ''Say it ain't so, Joe!'' went down in history. ''Eight Men Out'' is the story of the 1919 World Series-fixing scheme that shattered the faith of this boy and so many others.


Idetta to Perform
LEAD: Odetta, the folk singer, will perform tonight and tomorrow at Speakeasy, 107 McDougal Street (598-9670).
Sets are at 8:30 and 11 P.M., with Peter Spencer opening tonight and Buddy Mondlock tomorrow; admission is $10 with a two-drink minimum.


Knight-Ridder Deal
LEAD: Knight-Ridder Inc. completed its $353 million purchase of the Lockheed Corporation's Dialog Information Services Inc. on Wednesday.
Dialog maintains the world's largest computer-based data bank, with more than 320 data bases serving 92,000 subscribers in 86 countries.


U.S. and Soviet Work Out the Basics For Expanding Student Exchanges
LEAD: Federal officials said yesterday that they had completed the framework of a program to permit the Soviet Union and the United States each to exchange up to 1,500 high school students a year by 1991.
Until now, such exchanges had been limited to 50 students a year.


Correction
LEAD: An article yesterday about American demands that the Soviet Union dismantle a disputed radar station misstated the year in which the Antiballistic Missile Treaty came into force.
It was 1972.

Bass Group Gets Extra Day To Reach Savings Unit Deal
LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today that it would extend until Friday its exclusive negotiations with the Robert M. Bass Group of Fort Worth over the purchase of the nation's largest insolvent savings institution, the American Savings and Loan Association of Stockton, Calif.


2 Arrested in Check-Cashing Scheme
LEAD: Two Brooklyn men were arrested Wednesday and charged with stealing more than $500,000 in a fraudulent check-cashing scheme that spread to about 150 bank branches across New York City over a two-year period.


Panama Paid Quayle Adviser, Campaign Says
LEAD: Stuart Spencer, a longtime political adviser to President Reagan who is now the guiding force of Senator Dan Quayle's Vice-Presidential campaign, was paid for a year and a half as a consultant by the Panamanian Government ''to improve Panama's image worldwide,'' a Quayle campaign spokesman said today.

Brazil Votes Limit on Rates
LEAD: Brazil's Congress has voted to fix inflation-adjusted interest rates at 12 percent a year under the country's new constitution, despite protests from bankers and business executives that the measure will not work.

LEAD: Conversations revolve around Steffi Graf's bid for the Grand Slam, Martina Navratilova's renewed efforts to stop her, the promise of Gabriela Sabatini and the perseverance of Chris Evert.
But for Pam Shriver, this year's United States Open was another wasted opportunity, even briefer than most, the 11th annual chapter in her bid to win a major championship that seems more elusive than ever.

LEAD: The New York Stock Exchange and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange yesterday filed proposals with regulatory agencies that would provide for trading to be halted when markets are falling rapidly.

LEAD: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations said today that no substantive progress had been possible in the Iran-Iraq peace talks because of the deep mistrust between the two warring neighbors.


Real Computer Glitch Halts A Simulated Shuttle Mission
LEAD: A real computer crash today halted a mock space shuttle mission in its final hours just before the five Discovery astronauts were preparing to simulate landing on a flat tire.

LEAD: The last four days have been unsettling for the Giants, to say the least.


F.C.C. Sets Technical Guidelines For High-Definition TV in 1990's
LEAD: The Federal Communications Commission announced technical guidelines today that will bring high-definition television to the American public in the 1990's.
The technology is expected to provide television pictures twice as clear as they are now.

LEAD: In the midst of the worst fire season in decades, officials in two Western states took measures yesterday to keep hunters, fishers and campers out of forests over the Labor Day weekend.

LEAD: Americans hoping to buy their first homes face the worst conditions in 10 years, the National Association of Realtors said in a report released Wednesday.

LEAD: With Japanese stocks hovering near their all-time highs, one of the biggest gambles for anyone playing in the world's largest stock market is how long to linger.
When the opening bells ring Saturday morning on the Tokyo and Osaka stock exchanges, investors will have their first opportunity to protect themselves against the day when the joyride is finally over.


A Multifarious Approach To Sound
LEAD: Clarence (Gatemouth) Brown, who performed at the Lone Star Cafe on Tuesday night, is one of those odd American creations that arrive, style fully formed, completely assured of their relevancy.
The 68-year-old Mr.
Brown, a guitarist, violinist and harmonica player, was among the first musicians to mix the sound of a roaring big band with a new instrument, the electric guitar, which in his hands took on a lacerating, savage character.

LEAD: Ellis &amp; Everard P.L.C. said it had conditionally agreed to acquire United Chemicals Inc., a wholly owned United States subsidiary of Sanitas Inc., for $36 million.
The deal should be completed in mid-October.
United is a chemical distributor operating in several states, with revenues of $87.6 million for the latest fiscal year.

Philippines' Debt Rises
LEAD: The Philippines' foreign debt rose to a record $28.95 billion at the end of April, from the previous high of $28.65 billion at the end of March, Central Bank statistics showed today.
No explanation was given for the increase.
The debt will reach $34 billion by 1992, said the Economic Planning Minister, Solita Monsod.

LEAD: Kenny Miller, the basketball player who led the National Collegiate Athletic Association in rebounding last season as a freshman, will apparently not be returning to Loyola of Chicago.

In Poland, Hope Again
LEAD: It isn't the clear triumph of Aug. 31, 1980, when Lech Walesa announced that Poland's Communist Government had recognized an independent trade union.
But the Aug. 31, 1988, meeting between Solidarity's Mr.
Walesa and Gen.
Czeslaw Kiszczak, the Interior Minister, was still a major breakthrough.
That 1980 announcement was followed, 16 months later, by martial law and the subsequent banning of Solidarity.

3 Water Mains Break, Slowing Morning Traffic
LEAD: Three cast-iron water mains, all at least a century old, broke yesterday in Lower Manhattan near the Holland Tunnel, causing traffic delays, buckled streets and headaches for area delicatessen owners and residents who were without water for most of the day.

LEAD: Thomas Gallin, president of the John Gallin Construction Company of Manhattan, died at New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital on Thursday, after a brief illness.
He was 58 years old and lived in Larchmont, N.Y.

Rising Tide, Sinking Boats
LEAD: A new Census Bureau report offers discouraging news: the poverty rate among minorities increased and the already high rate among children did not improve.
That far overshadows the slight decline in the number of whites living in poverty.


Taylor Entering Rehabilitation
LEAD: Lawrence Taylor's agent, Gary Kovach, said yesterday that a rehabilitation program for the All-Pro linebacker is scheduled to begin next week. ''I believe he is going to start next Wednesday,'' Kovach said in a telephone interview from Houston.


Costly Challenge
LEAD: Rich Gossage's altercation earlier this week with the Chicago Cubs' manager, Don Zimmer, has cost the reliever his job as the team's closer.
Drew Hall will replace him during late innings for the remainder of this season.
Gossage, who challenged Zimmer while being removed from a game Tuesday, met yesterday with the Cubs' general manager, Jim Frey, and said later: ''If I want to get my job back as the closer on this team, it's all up to me.


Navy Officer Acquitted in Recruit's Death
LEAD: A Navy court-martial panel has found the former commander of the Navy Rescue Swimmer School here not guilty on two charges of dereliction of duty in the drowning of a recruit rescue swimmer.

LEAD: When two New York lawyers sued over a default of the Washington Public Power Supply System a couple of years ago, they shared a Seattle apartment for more than a year.

LEAD:  International 2-5  Oil prices may drop steeply as Iran and Iraq make peace, experts believe.
Oil fell below $15 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Increased production and reserves may also drive down prices.

Holiday on Monday
LEAD:  Labor Day will be observed on Monday.
Following are holiday schedules.
NEW YORK  Parade: Starts at 11 A.M. at 44th Street and Fifth Avenue, travels north to 72d Street, then east to Third Avenue.
Government offices: Closed.
Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only; main post office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue.

LEAD: A secret satellite was fired into space today in an unannounced launch that the Air Force called a success, but a source close to the program said the powerful Titan 34D rocket had failed to put the satellite into a high enough orbit.

Mortgage Rates Mixed
LEAD: The average interest rate for a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage dropped to 10.65 percent for the week ended today, from 10.67 percent the previous week, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation reported today.
The average adjustable-rate mortgage rose to 8.16 percent, from 8.06 percent the previous week, it said.

LEAD: A Federal appeals court in Washington tonight stayed an injunction that had barred Eastern Airlines from dismissing 4,000 employees, a company spokeswoman said.

LEAD: Richard Green took over as New York City's Schools Chancellor six months ago with a record as an accomplished educator.
He has articulated laudable goals.

Meanwhile, the schools are a disgrace, and getting worse.

LEAD: State Department officials said today that Cuba had sent substantial amounts of military equipment to Angola in recent weeks, and they estimated that there were more than 50,000 Cuban troops in Angola.

LEAD: A California Air National Guard helicopter crashed in a Mojave Desert mountain range Thursday, killing all six people aboard, the authorities said.

LEAD: When Dr.
Vartan Gregorian takes up residence in Rhode Island as president of Brown University next April, he will leave a void as big as the vast excavations now under way in Bryant Park behind the New York Public Library.
In seven years as the library's president, he revived an empire of learning that is more than ever a national treasure.

Birth Control Order Is Overturned
LEAD: A judge today reversed her order that a teen-age mother who left her two sons alone in a sweltering apartment for three days, practice birth control throughout her child-bearing years, saying the ruling was unenforceable.


United Scientific Ends Varo Offer
LEAD: United Scientific Holdings P.L.C. dropped its months-long effort to acquire Varo Inc., a maker of night-vision systems, clearing the way for Imo Delaval Inc., which has agreed to buy the company for $113 million.
United Scientific, a British holding company, said the decision reflected Varo's rejection of its offer of $26 a share, or $117.5 million, in a negotiated transaction.

Remote Call-Forward Devices
LEAD: Two New Jersey companies received patents this week on devices that allow people with call-forwarding telephone service to change the forwarding number from remote sites.


Wyatt Cafeterias
LEAD: The board of directors of Wyatt Cafeterias Inc. has rejected an offer by Furr's/Bishop's Cafeterias L.P. of $89 in cash and $2.25 in securities per share, Furr's/ Bishop's said.
The offer, which totaled $188 million, was the second by Furr's/Bishop's.
Last week the Dallas-based Wyatt rejected the partnership's first offer of $179.3 million, or $87 a share, in favor of a proposed employee stock ownership plan valued at $84 a share.

Corrections
LEAD: An obituary of the physicist Luis W. Alvarez yesterday misidentified the superior who recommended that Dr.
Alvarez not testify at a hearing on the loyalty of J. Robert Oppenheimer.
He was Dr.
Ernest Lawrence.
It also gave an incorrect date for the hearing; it was in 1954.

Plunge in Price of Oil Is Predicted If Gulf Peace Adds to Oversupply
LEAD: A sharp drop in oil prices may be in the offing, industry experts say, as Iran and Iraq move toward peace and full production.
World oil stocks remain glutted, and the price of crude oil dropped below $15 a barrel yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

His guitar rang away with chiming overtones as he chorded an imagined country melody, while Terri Lyne Carrington set her drums percolating as if she were playing with the John Coltrane group of the mid-1960s.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on Thursday about a theft from a Manhattan fur salon misstated the length of the Chevrolet Astro van.
The van, which the police said was used to crash through the front window of the store, is 14.7 feet long.


British Petroleum
LEAD: The British Petroleum Company said it planned to move as many as 500 exploration division employees from London to Britoil P.L.C.'s offices in Glasgow.
British Petroleum, a leading oil and gas exploration concern that took control of Britoil earlier this year, said in a statement that the transfer would begin later this year and be completed within 12 months.


Henry Hudson Wreck Kills 1 And Driver Flees the Scene
LEAD: One person was killed early yesterday when a car overturned on a Henry Hudson Parkway exit ramp, and the driver of the vehicle was seen fleeing the wreck and escaping in another car, the police said.

Simple Ways to Make the Most of Fresh Summer Vegetables
LEAD: OUR local organic produce stand has the same small display of summer vegetables every day now: tomatoes, summer squash, green beans and basil.

What a good idea.'' Several years went by.


A Minimalist Singing A One-Note Tune
LEAD: When does a composer's style turn into a straitjacket?
At what point do we say that an artist is no longer extending and developing an idiom, but instead rehashing it - unconsciously, because a way of working has become automatic, or cynically, because he knows it will bring success, or helplessly, because he's trapped and can't find a way out?


In the Fold
LEAD: The Cincinnati Bengals' first-round draft pick, Rickey Dixon, has come to terms with the team, ending a long contract dispute, the club announced yesterday.


Exchange Program Features Services
LEAD: LONG ISLAND court cases brought on behalf of people who cannot afford private lawyers may seem an unlikely basis for the study of international law.
But Gustavo Fares, a young lawyer from Argentina, says the Suffolk County court system and the Nassau-Suffolk Law Services in Bay Shore, both of which he has recently observed, are ''excellent models'' of responsiveness and flexibility.


Red River Redux
LEAD: ''DEAR BULLDOG,'' the letter saluted me.
Dear Bulldog?
I had to laugh, being long past caring (or pretending to care) how the Bulldogs fared against their rivals.
But Altus, home of the Bulldogs, I do care about.
Altus, Okla., is the lived longest; the place that in personal mythology stands for home.


Question Of the Week How Will The Giants And Jets Do in '88?
LEAD: If Mark Gastineau, the most often-quoted spokesman for the Jets, is any indication of what we can expect, jettison the Jets.
Bill Parcells is already making excuses for his team, saying they aren't ready.
The Meadowlands will produce a crop of thorns in the side of New York fans.
JOAN MARY MACEY  Binghamton, N.Y.


Answering the Mail
LEAD: Q. When our house was built in 1959 we had a large walk-in cedar closet built in for clothing storage.
Now the smell is gone.
Is the wood still a deterrent against moths, and if it isn't can the wood be treated to restore the odor and the mothproof qualities?

INDIA NEWSPAPERS PROTEST NEW BILL
LEAD: A defamation law rushed through the lower house of Parliament last week by the Government of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi has provoked nationwide protests from newspaper editors who say it will severely curtail India's traditional freedom of the press.


Ireland
LEAD: To the Editor: Christine S. Cozzen's article on Ireland's Achill Island (Travel, June 26) brought to mind two wonderful summer vacations I spent in the village of Curraun on the mainland just across Achill Sound.
At the time, Curraun had a rudimentary telephone system.
The local operator's intervention was needed to make any call, local or long distance, from our simple black box of a telephone.

Don't go out unless you've got a broken leg.'' The restorative power of that somewhat pungent lecture was shown Friday night when Jefferies, bruised foot and all, slashed three more hits.

Getting Faster by Getting Simpler
LEAD: Historically, the conventional path to more processing power has been through increased complexity.
In the last week, though, a flurry of activity has surrounded a countervailing trend - higher performance through simplification.
The technology in the news is called RISC, for reduced instruction set computer.

Smaller Teeth, Smaller Troubles
LEAD: Look in a mirror.
Say ''cheese.'' What do you see?
You see teeth, most of which are probably real and none of which could be called humongous.
But they would have been if sometime around the end of the ice age somebody hadn't figured out that the wisest way to eat a flash-frozen mammoth was to thaw it over a fire.

Nirvana Deluxe In Lotus Land
LEAD: THE NAME AND ADDRESS YIELD a delightful polyglot: Hsi Lai Buddhist Temple, Hacienda Heights, Calif.
The ''west-coming'' temple, now being constructed by the Fo Kuang Shan Buddhist society, based in Taiwan, consists of 10 buildings on 15 acres in a suburban community 20 miles east of Los Angeles.
The complex, which includes shrines, a monastery and a Buddhist museum, constitutes the largest Buddhist temple in North America.

The Editorial Notebook; At Home With the Homeless
LEAD: The St.
Francis Residence in Manhattan's Chelsea section has a steam-cleaned 19th-century brick exterior, lovely oak doors, a spotless hallway and 80 guests.
Having a room at this hotel may be the best luck most of them have ever known.
If they were not here, they would probably be living on a park bench, over a hot-air grating or in a bus station - the usual haunts of those who are both homeless and mentally ill.

Thrift in Tokyo
LEAD: To the Editor: For those who find eating in the hotels in Tokyo too expensive ($8 for tea and toast!), I suggest trying the cafeterias that exist in many office buildings.
Our family of four ate quite inexpensively ($3 for a delicious beef stew).
We stayed at the Tokyo Hilton International Hotel, and the office buildings were across the street from the hotel.

I do wish, however, that he would lend me his ear.
In fact, I wish he would come visit me in Miami.
I'd like to take him on a trip down Memory Lane.

Autumn's Palette May be Muted

WHEN LESS IS MORE
LEAD: S FASHION DESIGNERS CONTINUE to open stores along the world's major shopping streets, a trend has begun to emerge: minimalism in retailing.
These shops have a deliberately spare look, not just in their architecture, but in the small amount of merchandise on display. ''There is a direction on the part of retailers to show less but show it better,'' says the London architect David Chipperfield.

Challenger Stakes a Claim
LEAD: Michael Fay drove his white Porsche up to the toll booth at the entrance to the San Diego-Coronado Bay Bridge last week.
He was about to pass through the gate when the operator asked him for a dollar.
Fay looked puzzled, then reminded the worker that cars with two or more passengers are allowed to pass for free.
