A Movie That Cannily Celebrates The American Businessman As a Hero
LEAD: If you build a better mousetrap than your neighbor, you are quite liable to get your fingers caught in it.
In 1946 Preston Tucker set out to produce the car of his dreams, the ''Tucker Torpedo'' - a vehicle that in terms of design, performance and safety was far in advance of its period.
By the time he went out of business, in 1948, he had been forced into bankruptcy and put on trial for fraud: he was acquitted, but his great days were over.

Celebrating the Bland but Influential People of Connecticut
LEAD: BEING from Connecticut is like being from Canada: nobody cares.
The very idea of the place leaves people disoriented.
Perhaps no other state in the Union is as colorless.
Say Maine, and people think of lobsters and fishermen in long yellow slickers.
Say California, and they think of giant redwoods and Hollywood.

Revere Beach
LEAD: To the Editor: The name of the narrow-gauge railroad mentioned in the article on Revere Beach (Travel, May 15) and by some of your readers was the Boston, Revere Beach &amp; Lynn.
As late as the 1920's it was an incredibly busy and well-patronized transportation system.
The trains were numerous and fast and ran on frequent schedules.

Aloof Museums
LEAD: To the Editor: Michael Brenson's essay was, sad to say, a quite accurate portrayal of the museums of today.
As a frequent visitor to museums I've had experiences with loud, inaccurate lecturers, an absence of chairs, and the horrendous crowds of the blockbuster shows.

The Latest Big Wave of Little Consumers
LEAD: THE prognosticators were wrong.
The number of births in the United States would drop in 1987, they predicted.
Instead, an estimated 3.8 million births were recorded, 3 percent more than in 1986, according to the Department of Health and Human Services.
And the number is expected to increase slightly this year, too.


Hello, Hello. Who's Calling?
LEAD: The position of the Public Advocate respecting New Jersey Bell Caller ID (''New Jersey Bell Seeks to Add New Services,'' Aug. 14) has no merit for the simple reason that once an individual has invaded the privacy of another by calling him on the telephone, he has given up any claim to anonymity.

Improving On Paradise In Hawaii
LEAD: GUESTS at the $360-million Hyatt Waikoloa Beach Resort, which just opened on the Big Island of Hawaii, have a choice of three routes to their rooms: A bullet-nosed rapid-transit tram in the lobby can take them to one of three hotel towers via a monorail.
Nearby, a fleet of boats in the lobby can ferry them to their rooms over a mile-long system of canals.

LEAD: Prof.

Correction
LEAD: Because of a transcription error, an article on Aug. 28 about Poland misstated the amount of a fine said to have been imposed against a supporter of the outlawed Solidarity trade union.
The amount was 50,000 zlotys, which is about $125.

Correction
LEAD: An article in the Sports section last Sunday on a Costa Rican swimmer misspelled her given name.

Paris Temple
LEAD: To the Editor: The so-called Roman temple illustrated in Steven Greenhouse's reference to the Parc Monceau (What's Doing in Paris, July 17) is in fact just an assemblage of French Renaissance columns taken from the unfinished tomb of Henry II and recycled in the form of a classical naumachie, a picturesque stage set.

The tariffs are low, the rooms basic and clean, and the old-time island atmosphere is kamaaina (relaxed and friendly).

The Counter-Gap Play
LEAD: This play, effective for so long for the Redskins, is now being adopted by more N.F.L. teams.  1.
Backs take a counter-step in opposite direction of play; three linemen block that way, too.  2.
Backs reverse direction; left guard and tackle pull and help tight end clean out right side, as does the H-back.

The Ordeal of the Credit Fraud Victim
LEAD: IT is a different kind of household theft.
The thief might be a nurse's aide or a cleaning person; the loot Social Security numbers, credit card account data and other confidential information.
The thief then applies by mail for new credit cards, lines of credit and checking accounts in the name of the victim, giving a mail drop as the current address and the victim's actual address as the former residence.

Traveling Children
LEAD: To the Editor: I was quite interested in Betsy Wade's article about children flying alone (Practical Traveler, July 24) - and aghast at the huge number - for I flew alone from San Francisco to Chicago in 1939, at the age of 6.

WORDS AND MUSIC
LEAD: Martin Gottfried criticizes my ''so usually impeccable'' rhyming by citing the rhyme of ''liaisons'' with ''raisins'' in ''A Little Night Music.'' He misses the point.
As is clearly indicated by the normal (i.e. Anglicized French) pronunciation of ''liaisons'' throughout the rest of the lyric to which he refers, it is a deliberately false rhyme, meant to express the wry contempt of the character who sings it (meant, too, to get a laugh, which it usually did).

LEAD: James N. Black, a jazz drummer who played with such musicians as Lionel Hampton, Cannonball Adderley, John Coltrane and Dr.
John, died Tuesday.
He was 48 years old.
The cause of death was not announced, pending the result of an autopsy.

LEAD:  Auto Racing  Gant Wins 2d in Row: Harry Gant won his second straight Grand National Gatorade 200 race yesterday at Darlington International Raceway in South Carolina and became the 17th different winner on the circuit in 24 races this season.


A School for Pedal Pushers
LEAD: KNEES flexed, weight slung back, we neophytes poised at the top of the beginners' hill at Mount Snow, Vt., and prepared for our first descent.
From the bottom, the slope had looked like a gentle rise.
Now from above, it was a different matter entirely.
This wasn't a downhill.
This was a crater.
Waved down by the instructor, we pushed off one by one and soon were fishtailing through the thick grass and rocks, squeezing the bike's hand brakes for dear life.


Delay in Fuel Aid Program
LEAD: The state's fuel assistance program that helps poor families heat their homes will start a month later this year and end a month earlier because of a lack of funds.
The program will begin on Nov. 1, instead of Oct. 1, and will distribute money through March instead of April, Susan Merrow-Kehoe, the program director, said.

A Brilliant Tactician
LEAD: GARY Kasparov knows what's good for him when he takes his turn with the black pieces - semi-open games.
The games not only provide the best situations for a brilliant tactical imagination like Kasparov's, but they demand it.
Especially in the set of positions where kings are castled on opposite sides of the board, routine play is fatally slow.


Doors and Windows: Shelter From the Storm
LEAD: If your home lacks storm doors or storm windows or you wish to replace existing ones, you can save money by installing them yourself.
Doing so is usually a simple procedure.
The easiest doors and windows to install are pre-hung - that is, mounted in their frames.
Pre-hung storm doors and windows are made to fit nearly all standard door and window openings.

Bulldozers, helicopters and backfires were used to stall a 118,000-acre fire as it moved toward West Yellowstone, Mont., a town near the park.

Jane Austen
LEAD: To the Editor: Readers of ''At Home with Jane Austen'' (Travel, Aug. 7) will be interested to know that there is an active New York chapter of the Jane Austen Society of North America.

Information about the New York chapter is available from its president, Elsa Solender (212-737-5531).

WHAT'S DOING IN: Athens
LEAD: There seem to be two sides to everything in the Cradle of Democracy.
Athens abounds in history, but suffers from unchecked modern development: On the Acropolis, the 2,500-year-old Parthenon stands above a television antenna-dotted skyline.
The city is renowned for openness and hospitality, but the noise and congestion would try the patience of Hercules.

A Choice Encounter
LEAD: IT WAS 1973 and Ansley J. Coale was fed up with academia.
So he bought 2,000 acres in Ukiah, Calif., in Mendocino County.
It's only two hours north of Berkeley, where he'd been teaching Greek and Roman history, but - emotionally at least - it's about as far from faculty meetings as it's possible to get.

Packing Without Angst: Making a Priority List
LEAD: A FRIEND used to suffer from packer's block, which is like writer's block, if less fashionable.
An episode usually begins when the suitcase is opened preparatory to travel.
The victim abruptly seizes on some other problem, like alphabetizing the medicine cabinet or waxing the kitchen floor.
My friend, unable to get the first pair of socks into the valise, would call at bizarre hours on Friday nights to get help.

LEAD: Sanford Weill is getting back in the brokerage business.

Primerica, the former American Can Company, has been transformed into a financial services conglomerate by Gerald Tsai Jr., who made a fortune during the stock market's ''go-go'' years of the 1960's.

Rushing to (Mis)Judgment
LEAD: Five years after a Soviet fighter shot down Korean Air Lines Flight 007, and two months after the U.S.S.
Vincennes shot down an Iranian Airbus, America has yet to come to grips with the common elements in these two tragedies.
The Reagan Administration rushed to deny that there could be any.
Indeed, the incidents were not parallel, but there were important similarities in the way the parties involved responded.

Headliners; Back in the U.S.S.R.?

The Russian writer, who was expelled in 1974 as an enemy of the people and now resides in Vermont, was invited last week to join a Soviet committee supervising the building of a memorial honoring the victims of Stalin-era repression.

LEAD: Two and a half years after Guatemalans elected a civilian President in an effort to end decades of military dominance, progress toward democracy is slow, and frustration is increasing.
Although trade unionists and other protesters have greater freedom to organize than they did in the past, men in uniform still exercise ultimate political authority.

Seoul Shoes
LEAD: To the Editor: The article ''What's Doing in Seoul'' (Travel, July 24) states that Reebok shoes are available in the Itaewon shopping district in Seoul for $15.
This is, unfortunately, a perfect example of the old adage that something that appears to be too good a bargain generally is.
All shoes that are available in Itaewon at this price are counterfeit.

LEAD: WITH the concert season in its end-of-the-summer doldrums, the moment seems right to look ahead to some of the music awaiting us in the fall, remembering that the early concert subscriber not only gets better seats and lower prices, but can also avoid the sold-out signs sure to appear when such stars as James Galway, Dave Brubeck and Canadian Brass come to town.

LEAD: An article in the Sports section last Sunday on a rule change in college football did not mention the number of points a defensive team can score on conversion attempts.
It is 2 points.

Truth Eludes Fact and Fiction
LEAD: One reason why the feature-length documentary has lately been in decline is that the fiction feature has subsumed its role.
We're as apt to get our facts from lightly embroidered versions of real events as from the events themselves.
The television movie, which can proudly base itself on a true story and then touch up the story to suit the audience's taste, has paved the way for this development, but television drama in itself is rarely alarming.

Doors and Windows: Shelter From the Storm
LEAD: If your home lacks storm doors or storm windows or you wish to replace existing ones, you can save money by installing them yourself.
Doing so is usually a simple procedure.
The easiest doors and windows to install are pre-hung - that is, mounted in their frames.
Pre-hung storm doors and windows are made to fit nearly all standard door and window openings.

LEAD: State officials hoped to include thousands of football fans in a new recycling campaign at Monday night's season opener at the Meadowlands between the Washington Redskins and New York Giants.
To help comply with a 1987 state law that calls for a 25-percent reduction in the state's waste flow, the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority has set up 60 recycling bins for glass bottles and cans at the parking lot of Giants Stadium.

Yachting Terms
LEAD:  Nautical mile: International unit of measurement for air and sea navigation; equal to 6076.12 feet or 1.15 miles.
Knot: Unit of speed of one nautical mile an hour.
Upwind: Sailing toward the direction of the wind.
Tack: Direction in which a boat is moving in relation to the position of the sails.

LEAD: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, faced with protests from the press, the legal profession and members of his own party over a new defamation law, said today that the bill would not be put before the upper house of Parliament on Monday as planned.

Rescue Move in Kansas
LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board Friday placed the troubled Valley Federal Savings and Loan Association of Hutchinson, Kan., in conservatorship.
Valley Federal, under the appointed conservator, will conduct business as usual, maintaining its name and normal operating hours.
Valley Federal has $238.7 million in assets and $252.2 million in liabilities, giving it a negative net worth of $13.5 million, the bank board said.

LEAD: A restaurant chain will pay $15,000 each to 23 people who sued, alleging they were denied service because of their race or ethnicity.

Correction
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about a Geneva conference to review compliance with the Antiballistic Missile Treaty misstated the American position on a disputed Soviet radar.
The United States said it would consider declaring the Soviet Union in ''material breach'' of the treaty if it did not dismantle the radar; it was not the first such warning, and the United States did not say it would necessarily take the action.

N.F.L. Notebook; A Tough Week For Quarterbacks
LEAD: The season's first week reminded several teams of an ugly lesson already learned: no matter how much preparation goes into preseason, no method prevents the havoc injury can bring.
Especially at quarterback.
Ask Joe Montana, the San Francisco 49er quarterback.
Montana threw three third-quarter touchdown passes against the New Orleans Saints and then had to leave the game due to a bruised elbow on his right, or throwing, arm.

LEAD: The Town of Hempstead started its crackdown on June 25.
There were reports that a man was bringing his own chair to the town beach at Atlantic Beach Estates, a clear-cut violation of 78-41!
Town law requires that anyone at that beach who wants a chair must rent said chair from the concessionaire.
Or else!

Manila Is Said to Reject U.S. Proposal on Bases
LEAD: The United States has offered to more than double its aid commitment to the Philippines in exchange for guarantees on the use of American military bases there for the next two years, a State Department official said today.
But the official said the Government in Manila had rejected the offer, which amounted to about $360 million a year, and was seeking an annual aid package of $1.2 billion.

3 Governors Visit Japan
LEAD: Three United States Governors met with Japanese officials today and appealed for more investment in their states.
Bill Clinton of Arkansas, Buddy Roemer of Louisiana and Ray Mabus of Mississippi said their states' economies have been damaged by declines in manufacturing and the oil industry.
But they emphasized that the region is rich in assets Japan needs.

LEAD: Taiwan said today that it would buy four passenger airlines from the McDonnell Douglas Corporation to help lower Taiwan's trade surplus with the United States.
A spokesman for the Civil Aeronautics Administration said the Government would sign a contract on Tuesday with the St.
Louis-based company for four MD-11 aircraft worth $450 million.


Where's the Budget Deficit Issue?
LEAD: Does the budget deficit really matter?
The Presidential candidates have certainly been told by their advisers that a failure to bring down the deficit will make it far more difficult to steer a safe course between inflation and recession in coming years.
But neither George Bush nor Michael Dukakis seems to see political advantage in advancing a realistic proposal for deficit reduction.


Computers Create Electronic 'Cadavers' For Anatomy Lessons
LEAD: IN a novel approach to teaching the intricate details of human anatomy, some medical schools are experimenting with advanced computer-imaging techniques to create electronic ''cadavers.'' Systems are being designed so that young medical students can ''dissect'' electronic images, rather than using real cadavers for their initial lessons.


No Escape of Radiation Seen In Fire at a Lithuanian Plant
LEAD: A nuclear power plant caught fire in Lithuania today, but automatic safety systems put out the flames before radiation was released, the official Tass press agency reported.
Tass said no one was injured in the blaze, which began at 12:50 A.M. in a control cable of the second reactor at the Ignalina nuclear power plant, about 60 miles northeast of Vilnius, the capital of the Lithuanian Republic.

I'm Dr.

How may I help you?'' The caller began his story.

What had happened?
What should he do?

Her band members, resonating cool, were dressed in suits that would have looked fine for the mid-1950's Miles Davis group.

LEAD: A musical memorial service for the jazz bassist Slam Stewart, who died last Dec. 7, is to be held tonight at 7 P.M. at St.
Peter's Lutheran Church, 619 Lexington Avenue, at 54th Street.
The Rev.
John Gensell is to officiate, with music organized by Major Holley, a bassist and associate of Mr.

Ainslee Cox, 52, A Longtime Leader Of Goldman Band
LEAD: Ainslee Cox, the longtime conductor of the Goldman Concert Band, died of complications arising from Hodgkins disease on Monday afternoon at the St.
Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan.
He was 52 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: To the Editor:


First Boston Wins Hertz Note Issue
LEAD: In competititve bidding yesterday, the First Boston Corporation led a group of underwriters that won $75 million of Hertz Corporation notes.


Corrections
LEAD: An article in some editions of Business Day on Friday, about the awarding by the International Business Machines Corporation of its advertising account, incompletely described the status of Charles Moss, the former chief creative officer of Wells, Rich, Greene.
He is now the agency's corporate creative director.


Enserch to Sell Its Pool Unit
LEAD: The Enserch Corporation, a diversified energy company, said today that it had decided to dispose of its flagging oilfield service subsidiary, the Houston-based Pool Company, and would take an after-tax write-down of $220 million in the third quarter.
Pool, which has more than 4,000 employees worldwide, carried assets valued between $300 million and $350 million, the company said.


Bush Gets Harsh Reception at Shipyard in Oregon
LEAD: Vice President Bush got far more than he gave today as his message of economic prosperity was engulfed by a wave of boos and obscenities from rank-and-file union members at a shipyard here.


Squeeze on U.S. Agency Seen As Result of Savings Rescues
LEAD: The flurry of rescues of savings institutions in the last three weeks may have left the insurance fund of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board in a troubling cash squeeze.


Bahrain Airline's Plans
LEAD: Gulf Air, a Bahrain-based regional airline, reportedly plans to more than double its fleet, to 42 planes from 20, in five years.
Bahrain's daily newspaper, Akhbar Al Khaleej, quoted the island's industry minister, Youssef Shirawi, in Monday's issue as saying the company would also gradually replace its old planes.


INSIDE
LEAD:  Concern at the First Bell


Sallie Mae Selling Short-Term Notes
LEAD: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $350 million of floating-rate notes due March 9, 1989, at par through various securities dealers.


Andrew Ragona, 79, Ex-Director Of Ad Production at Times, Dies
LEAD: Andrew Ragona, director of advertising production and publication for The New York Times for two decades until his retirement in 1974, died of liver cancer yesterday at Mercy Hospital in Rockville Centre, L.I.
He was 79 years old and lived in Valley Stream, L.I.


Dukakis Speech Marred by Clash Over Abortion
LEAD: A speech by Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis turned into an angry confrontation between anti-abortion protesters and members of the audience today, with bitter chants and counter-chants and repeated outbreaks of shoving and scuffling.


Government Buildings Are Looted in Burma
LEAD: Looters plundered Government buildings and factories today, and troops newly deployed in the capital made no attempt to stop the destruction.


A $200 Million Offering Of Chrysler Extension Notes
LEAD: The Chrysler Financial Corporation, a unit of the Chrysler Corporation, is offering $200 million of 9 5/8 percent extension notes with final maturity in 2008.
Morgan Stanley &amp; Company heads the underwriters.


Woman Drowns in Cave Dive
LEAD: A 21-year-old woman drowned Sunday while diving in a water-filled cave when her air tanks ran out after she panicked and swam in the wrong direction, the police said.
Her body was found Monday in a dead-end corridor in a cave at Orange Grove Sink.
The police said that the woman and a partner had been following a marked course but lost sight of the line and drifted apart.


Savings Unit To Get a Buyer
LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today that it would provide $19.6 million to allow a private group to buy the insolvent First Federal Savings Bank of Roger, Ark.

LEAD: For most of her 10 years, Juliana Ines Trevino has known that she was adopted, but loving parents never told her about the shadow that hung over her country, Argentina, at the time of her birth.


Jet Lands After Malfunction
LEAD: A jetliner carrying 283 people on a flight from Houston made an emergency landing at Los Angeles International Airport after the crew manually lowered the landing gear, the authorities said today.
Continental Airlines Flight 475, an Airbus A-300, landed safely at 8:46 p.m.
Monday, said Fred O'Donnell, a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration.


Dukakis Agrees to Only Two Debates With Bush
LEAD: Michael S. Dukakis's campaign gave ground today in the debate over debates, grudgingly agreeing that there might be only two debates between the Presidential candidates, instead of three or four.


Lack of Offense Foils Ojeda
LEAD: The Mets, who stop hitting when Bob Ojeda starts pitching, stopped hitting again tonight.
They scored two runs for Ojeda, as they have done in 16 of the 27 games he has started this year.
And Ojeda suffered the predictable result: a 3-2 loss to the Pittsburgh Pirates.

A New Approach to Programming
LEAD: In the early 1970's the Xerox Corporation's Palo Alto Research Center developed a computer language for children that sought to bypass the abstract thinking often necessary in computer programming.
The idea was that children would write programs by stringing together individual pieces of software, each of which did a specific, easily understandable task.

Vacation's Over, but the Mind Still Wanders
LEAD: VACATION lag occurs when you return home and part of your brain is still on vacation.
It occurs most often after a refreshing, happy holiday, and the consensus is that the sensation may be pleasant, curious or hellish, depending on your perspective.


By the River, Refuge but Little Relief
LEAD: Clustered on a riverbank, more than 8,000 residents of this town in Bangladesh, about 100 miles south of Dhaka,were forced today to take shelter any way they could.


Eastern Job Hearings Set
LEAD: Attorneys for Eastern Airlines' unions learned today that they will return to Federal court later this month to argue their case against the elimination of 4,000 jobs.


Experts Debate Cuomo's Stand In Yonkers Case
LEAD: After the United States Supreme Court suspended contempt fines against four Yonkers City Councilmen last week but reimposed fines on the city, Governor Cuomo said that the court's decision ''raised troublesome legal questions'' about removing the Councilmen from office and that, for the time being at least, he would not act against them.


Sports People; Nets Re-Sign Bagley
LEAD: John Bagley, the 6-foot point guard who was the only Net to appear in all 82 games last season, has been re-signed to a multiyear contract.
Terms were not announced.
The 28-year-old Bagley will be playing his second season with the Nets since joining the team with Keith Lee from the Cleveland Cavaliers in the eight-player three-team deal that sent Darryl Dawkins and James Bailey to the Utah Jazz and Cavaliers, respectively.

LEAD: The authorities today ordered the evacuation of all 150 residents of two small canyon communities bordering Yellowstone National Park after wind threatened to drive a wall of flame through the towns.

Yale Dean to Stay On
LEAD: Lloyd Richards's term as dean of the Yale School of Drama and artistic director of the Yale Repertory Theater has been extended for two years, through the 1990-91 academic year.
Mr.
Richards's term was to have expired next June.
The announcement was made last Thursday by Yale's president, Benno C.


Air Show Toll Reaches 53
LEAD: The toll in the Ramstein air show disaster Aug. 28 rose to 53 with the death of a West German man, officials said today.
Jurgen Dietzen, a spokesman for Rhineland-Palatinate state, where the United States Air Force's Ramstein Air Base is located, identified the victim as a 53-year-old man from Baden-Wurttemberg.


Man Jailed for Refusing To Give Up Melee Tape
LEAD: Defying a court order and disdaining professional legal help, a Manhattan artist refused again yesterday to surrender his videotape of police officers and demonstrators clashing in Tompkins Square Park and was jailed for contempt.


Poland's Legion of Homeless Miners
LEAD: They call the gray stucco apartment block the bullpen.
Officially, it is a workers' hotel; actually, it is more like a cage for young men.


Bridge
LEAD: Some of the rare specimens of the zoological world are never imported into North America, and the same is true of the bridge world.
Bizarre bidding ideas originate on other continents but are barred from these shores by the vigilant officials of the American Contract Bridge League.


Tyson-Bruno Fight Is Off Again
LEAD: Mike Tyson's heavyweight title defense against Frank Bruno, scheduled for Oct. 22 in London, has been postponed again on the advice of the physicians who have monitored Tyson since he was hospitalized following an automobile accident in Catskill, N.Y., Sunday morning.


Suspect Admits Guilt In Wells Fargo Case
LEAD: A defendant in the $7 million Wells Fargo robbery case pleaded guilty yesterday to conspiring to transport several thousand dollars in stolen money to Hartford to pay for a toy giveway for Puerto Rican children in 1985.

LEAD: ''Bangladesh is one vast swamp and what you're confronted with is rebuilding a country.

Sales Executive Leaving Lotus
LEAD: Vincent G. Kelly, vice president of North American sales at the Lotus Development Corporation, said yesterday that he was resigning to take a position as vice president at Corporate Software Inc., a Westwood, Mass., reseller of software and hardware that had revenues of $60 million in 1987.


MACK EASILY WINS IN FLORIDA PRIMARY
LEAD: Representative Connie Mack 3d defeated a former United States Attorney, Robert Merkle, in Florida's Republican Senate primary yesterday, while Democrats were headed for a runoff to decide their nominee to succeed Senator Lawton Chiles.

LEAD: Dennis Conner plans to wear a good luck charm from New Zealand.
By most predictions - not including Conner's own - he won't need it.


Sumitomo Sale Of 9.40% Notes
LEAD: The New York branch of Sumitomo Bank Ltd. is offering $100 million of 9.40 percent notes due in 1993 at par through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.


Wall St. Firms Subpoenaed On Contributions to Regan
LEAD: The United States Attorney in Manhattan, Rudolph W. Giuliani, has subpoenaed State Comptroller Edward V. Regan and at least five Wall Street brokerage houses in connection with contributions they made to Mr.
Regan's re-election campaigns.


Newmont to Sell Interests to Mobil
LEAD: As part of a previously announced restructuring, the Newmont Mining Corporation said it had agreed to sell its United States oil and gas interests to the Mobil Corporation and a group of Dallas-based investors for about $170 million.
Newmont, whose primary activities are gold and coal mining, said Mobil would buy all of its domestic oil and gas working interests.


A.T.&amp;T. Raises Holdings in Sun
LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has raised its stake in Sun Microsystems Inc. to 9.7 percent, or 3.5 million shares, from 7.1 percent.


Small Hay Crop Is Seen
LEAD: Largely because of widespread drought, the 1988 hay crop is expected to be the smallest in 12 years, and prices are likely to be the highest since the Agriculture Department began keeping annual figures in 1909.
Preliminary figures show that hay prices at the farm in August averaged $83.10 a ton, up 35 percent from $61.60 a ton a year ago.


Georgia-Pacific's $250 Million Issue
LEAD: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation entered the debt market yesterday with a $250 million offering of 10 1/4 percent debentures due in 2018 at a price of 99.25 to yield 10.526 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

LEAD: Janice Groman, a former member of the New York City Ballet and American Ballet Theater who later founded a chamber dance company, died at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx on Friday after a long illness.
She was 51 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: John Caggiano, once an executive vice president and creative director of Doyle Dane Bernbach, who has been freelancing since becoming a victim of its merger with Needham Harper Worldwide, has now gone into business with Siebel/Mohr, a 19-year-old sales promotion firm.
Each is half owner of Caggiano &amp; Siebel

LEAD: The Patten Corporation, a big developer of rural land, has named Warren Van Genderen as chief operating officer reporting directly to Patten's founder, president and chief executive, Harry S. Patten.

LEAD: Apollo Computer Inc., striving for a comeback, said the International Business Machines Corporation had bought a license to use some of its computer networking software.
Although not an important contribution to Apollo's revenue, the deal with I.B.M. helps to establish the credibility of Apollo's Network Computing System.

PPG Drops Offer To Acquire Grow
LEAD: PPG Industries terminated its plans to acquire Grow Group Inc., a manufacturer of paint and chemical coatings based in New York, for $300 million, sending the stock tumbling on Wall Street.
PPG gave no reason for the surprise decision.


Tokyo Journal; A Real Estate Market No One Can Afford Anymore
LEAD: The real estate boom here has been long been out of control, but many people were still shocked when a Government-affiliated research group calculated a few months ago that the book value of all the land in Japan - $13.47 trillion and change at current exchange rates -easily exceeded the value of all the land in the United States.

LEAD: Jim Bakker, the former leader of the PTL television ministry, who is offering a $172 million plan to regain control of the ministry and its religious theme park. received a two-day extension today to produce a $3 million line of credit supporting his bid.


Wyatt Clears Buyout Plan
LEAD: The board of Wyatt Cafeterias Inc. said today that it and the company's shareholders had approved an employee stock ownership buyout plan worth $173 million, or $84 a share in cash, of which a portion will remain in escrow.


Returning Congress Pressured by Clock, Budget and Politics
LEAD: With barely a month remaining to tie up the legislative loose ends of the 100th Congress, lawmakers are returning to Capitol Hill to do battle less with one another than with the clock and budget constraints in the highly partisan atmosphere of the election campaign.


Sports People; Boy, 11, Swims Channel
LEAD: An 11-year-old English boy crawled ashore in Dover yesterday after setting a record as the youngest person to swim the English Channel, the Channel Swimming Association said.
Thomas Gregory, age 11 years and 333 days, broke the record set in 1979 when Marcus Hooper made the 21-mile crossing from France at age 12 years 53 days.


Latest in 'Chat Lines:' Hookups by Computer
LEAD: With so-called chat lines, the faddish party-line hookups that allow socializing by telephone, declining in popularity nationally, a French company has added a high-technology wrinkle, computer party lines whose users are billed by the telephone company.


Education; Lessons
LEAD: A favorite indoor sport among educational pundits in recent years has been to predict how many private colleges will be folding because of the declining number of 18-year-olds in the population.

LEAD: For the first 98 years of its history, Kubota Ltd., Japan's largest manufacturer of agricultural machinery, never made anything more technologically sophisticated than a tractor.

LEAD: AFTER more than four years of coaxing furniture and fixture manufacturers across the East River to showroom space carved out of old factory buildings in Long Island City, the developers of the huge design center there expect to sign a lease soon that will bring the first office tenant to the complex.


Minnesota Mining To Buy Spontex
LEAD: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company agreed to buy Spontex, a Paris-based supplier of household and commercial cleaning products, for about $182 million in cash. ''It's part of our strategy to expand in Europe by acquisition by 1992,'' a 3M spokesman said, referring to the European Community's plan to remove all trade barriers by 1992.


Drop in Dollar May Signal An End to Summer Rally
LEAD: The dollar fell against major currencies yesterday, and some traders said they were wondering whether the summer rally was finally over.


Police Confiscate Tape Of Defiant Tutu Sermon
LEAD: The police today seized a tape of a sermon in which Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu defied the Government and called for a boycott of October elections, a spokesman for the Archbishop said.


Olympics; A New Craze in South Korea
LEAD: South of here on Route 1 toward Pusan, the crazy-quilt urban patterns of new office buildings and old kiosks begin to melt away into farm land and rice fields.
Along the way, exit signs mark directions to nearby towns and villages, some visible from the highway.
But for the most part, the road slices through only a verdant countryside, with mountains off in the distance at either side.

It is at 57th Street and Lexington Avenue.

Pop Ephemera Auction: Elton John's Collection
LEAD: An enthusiastic gathering of bidders, spectators and fans, many suitably dressed for a Wembley Stadium rock concert, filled a London auction house today and paid tribute to the pop singer Elton John, buying everything from his rhinestone-studded spectacles to his diamond-studded earrings.


Auto Sales in Late August Called Brisk Despite Drop
LEAD: Sales of new American-made cars and light trucks remained brisk in late August, industry analysts said, although the auto makers reported an estimated 2.1 percent decline from the comparable period last year.


BENTSEN SUPPORTS MORE SCHOOL DAYS
LEAD: Senator Lloyd Bentsen said that today he believed American public school students should spend more days a year in classthan they do now, so as to assure the nation's economic future and to compete successfully with more disciplined foreign countries.


Agriculture Still Another Casualty of Afghan War
LEAD: A series of reports circulating in Western embassies here offers a brutal portrait of the effects of the war in Afghanistan and of what is termed the ''systematic destruction'' of livestock, irrigation systems and farms.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Agency Is Hoping for Lightning to Strike
LEAD: ''THIS is an agency waiting to explode!'' exclaimed the energetic Mel (for Melvin) Ciociola, chief executive and creative director of Ciociola &amp; Company, who is looking hard for the fuse.


Bonn Reports Growth Rate At High 3.9%
LEAD: West Germany today reported a lively growth in its gross national product for the first half of 1988, at an annualized rate of 3.9 percent.
That offered strong support for the latest Government predictions that the economy would grow by at least 3 percent this year.


District Attorney Won't Charge Yonkers Councilmen
LEAD: The Westchester District Attorney refused today to prosecute four Yonkers Councilmen whose votes blocking a court-ordered housing desegregation plan have incurred growing contempt fines against the city.

LEAD: He batted a tennis ball high into the stands, a practice he began earlier this year.
Then Andre Agassi took a spare pair of denim shorts, frayed but clean, he said, and threw them to a cluster of fans maneuvering for position.
But when he walked off the Stadium court at Flushing Meadows last night, Agassi was still wearing his baggy white shirt.

Market Place; Polaroid Battle And Kodak Suit
LEAD: THE smart money on Wall Street is increasingly beginning to feel that the outcome of Roy E. Disney's slowly simmering takeover battle for the Polaroid Corporation depends more on the Eastman Kodak Company than on Mr.

Schools Open With Focus On Chancellor
LEAD: Students begin returning to New York City's public schools today in an atmosphere of intense public concern over whether the school system will improve or whether that is even possible.


Rig Count Falls in Week
LEAD: The number of rigs searching for oil in the United States fell by 2 last week, to 933, and was down sharply from 1,099 a year ago, Baker Hughes Inc. said yesterday.
Among individual states, the biggest change came in Texas, where the number of rigs rose by 14.
The count of American rigs working offshore fell by 3, to 122, while the number of rigs working in shallow inland waters fell by 8, to 18, the Houston-based oil services company said.


EVACUATIONS RULE OF N.R.C. IS UPHELD
LEAD: Rejecting the latest challenge to the Seabrook nuclear plant, a Federal appeals court ruled today that the Nuclear Regulatory Commission may accept emergency evacuation plans developed by utilities when state and local governments refuse to submit them.

7-Story Village Mural of Stars of the Left
LEAD: An all-star cast of the international left - Karl Marx, Mother Jones, Fidel Castro, Lenin, Malcolm X and other leaders of the working class -is appearing in a new but very old-fashioned political wall painting.
The huge work, known as ''The Pathfinder Mural,'' is nearing completion on the side of a building at West and Charles Streets in Greenwich Village, and its creators are braced for controversy.

LEAD: HERE is a suggestion for a wine lover who has nothing to do this month or next: come to France for the Ledoyen wine auction.
Ledoyen, a Paris landmark, closed a year ago this month.
It had been a restaurant since Antoine-Nicolas Doyen opened it in 1792, in almost the same location in the flower-filled gardens at the foot of the Champs

MICROWAVE COOKING
LEAD: ONE of the nicest attributes of a microwave oven is the way it can make everyday fare of the grains and cereals that normally take a long time to cook and that must usually be stirred with jealous attention.


Review/Television; The Earliest Americans, From 15,000 Years Ago
LEAD: The first immigrants to our hemisphere arrived on foot about 15,000 years ago over a land bridge that then traversed the region between present-day Siberia and Alaska.
They walked thousands of miles and hundreds of years, over the generations, to settle the Americas, and it may be something of a commentary in itself to note that we can learn about this migration on television, sitting at home and not moving a muscle more than those needed to flip a dial.

Wardair Buys Fokkers
LEAD: Wardair Canada will purchase 24 Fokker 100 jet aircraft from N. V. Fokker, the Dutch manufacturer, it was announced today.
Financial details were not disclosed.
The aircraft, powered by twin Rolls-Royce engines, seats 84 to 107 passengers.
It entered service with Swissair in April.
Wardair's purchase brings to 110 the number of Fokker 100's sold.

Federal Express
LEAD: The British-Dutch giant Unilever N.V. said that the Federal Express Corporation would acquire its West German Elbe Transport Group and its Dutch Binfuerst Autotransport and Algemeen Vrachtkantoor B.V. transport operations.
Unilever did not disclose the terms of the transaction.
Federal Express, a major package delivery company, is based in Memphis.

Wise Bet on Zimbabwe
LEAD: Zimbabwe, self-conscious torchbearer for the nonaligned third world, can be a very prickly friend.
Yet it is also a heartening example of racial coexistence and sensible economic management in a troubled region and a victim of the dislocations brought about by the struggle against apartheid in South Africa.


Prague Gives Dubcek a Visa For First Time Since Ouster
LEAD: Alexander Dubcek, the former Czechoslovak Communist Party chief who led the short-lived period of liberalization in 1968 known as Prague Spring, is to travel abroad for the first time in two decades to visit Italy, a Government spokesman said today.


The Editorial Notebook; Like the Brain of a Bee
LEAD: An intriguing computing structure known as a neural network is attracting a growing circle of fans.
Darpa, the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, is the latest recruit and plans a large investment in the field.
The prize is better understanding of the human brain, and devices better able to mimic certain of its functions.


Steel Output Up 3.6%
LEAD: Steel production rose to 1.918 million tons in the week ended Saturday, an increase of 3.6 percent from the previous week's 1.851 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
The industry's production amounted to 89.9 percent of capacity during the week, compared with 86.8 percent in the previous week.


Ramona, Okla.
LEAD: DORIS BANKES sometimes receives mail addressed simply to ''The Herb Lady in Ramona, Okla.'' What she and her husband, Virgil, started as a hobby in the greenhouse of their Tulsa home became a thriving business, the Growin Things Herb Farm, by 1983, just two years after they started.
To meet the demand for fresh herbs, they moved to a farm near Ramona, in northeastern Oklahoma, in 1984.

LEAD: The crisis of the Soyuz TM-5 is only the latest in the history of space flight.

LEAD: As the nation gropes for weapons to fight the interconnected problems of AIDS, drug abuse and crime, medical experts and many in Congress are pushing for a broad expansion of programs to treat drug addicts.

LEAD: Oil prices fell 55 cents a barrel, or nearly 4 percent, in futures trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday, as dealers grew increasingly apprehensive about the rise in oil output made possible by the end of the Iran-Iraq war.

Sports People; Average Pay: $433,000
LEAD: The average salary of major league baseball players this year will reach a record $433,000, according to the Player Relations Committee's executive director, Barry Rona.
The figure represents an increase of $31,000 over the 1987 average.
The official average is computed from the Aug. 31 roster.
The Major League Baseball Players Association will issue its report of average salary later in the year.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q. I have a screened room on the side of the house that has a vinyl roof.
On sunny days this room gets hot and uncomfortable.
Would the room be cooler if it had an insulated wood roof, with regular shingles that matched the rest of the house?
A.
It probably would.
However, you may also get a good deal of relief by installing vents or louvers in the existing roof - the kind that will let the hot air escape but will not allow rain to come in.


Cowboys Seek Buyer
LEAD: H. R. (Bum) Bright, who has been unsuccessful in his efforts to sell the Dallas Cowboys, has asked the team's general manager, Tex Schramm, to find a buyer.
Schramm performed a similar role for the club's original owner, Clint Murchison, when Murchison sold the club to a group headed by Bright in 1984.

The street soon became a sort of unofficial headquarters for the music that grew out of Harlem in the 1920's and 30's.

LEAD: The advertisements for exercise clothing and fitness classes would have you believe that physical activity is exclusively pursued by people with beautiful bodies for the sole purpose of keeping them that way.

Arrangements That Tease the Viewer
LEAD: THE word scrim mostly has to do with the theater.
A scrim is a thin gauze curtain behind which actors and scenery can be seen when lights are on them.
But they are seen as if in a mist, which softens their outlines and causes them to lose definition.

Consumers Say No To Machines That Talk
LEAD: LOCKED away in a laboratory in Benton Harbor, Mich., far from the ring-around-the-collar crowd, is an ordinary-looking clothes dryer.

It dries clothes as fast as any other dryer: 30 minutes for permanent-press fabrics, 60 minutes for terry-cloth towels.

Home Improvement
LEAD: WOOD paneling adds warmth and charm to a room.
But conventional paneling, consisting of individual boards of the desired wood, is usually expensive and requires much skill and time to install.
An alternative is veneer-covered plywood paneling.
This is made of ordinary plywood to which a thin layer of desirable wood has been bonded.

LEAD: AS an artist, Philip Guston was blessed with two successful careers, two equally defined identities.

Its United States subsidiary, based in New York, will change its name from Seidman &amp; Seidman BDO to BDO Seidman, the firm said.

LEAD: As a young girl in Virginia, Helen Elmore, the daughter of a slave, took care of people's children; as an adult in New York, she pressed clothes in laundries.
Finally, with ''dimes and quarters'' she had so painstakingly saved from her labors, she fulfilled one dream: although she was nearly 70 years old, she bought a house in Jamaica,


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD: GOLF  Pavin and Barr Share Lead: Corey Pavin and Dave Barr shared the lead by a stroke yesterday after the opening round of the $700,000 Greater Milwaukee Open.
Pavin, who beat Barr in a four-hole playoff for the 1986 championship, used a string of four birdies on holes 13 through 16 to finish the opening round at six-under-par 66 on the 7,030-yard Tuckaway Country Club course.


Yanks Recover; Mets' Hitters Wake Up; Mets 13, Cubs 6
LEAD: The Mets, who have pined and whined over their missing bats all season, got them back today with a clatter that produced 13 runs, 20 hits, 4 home runs, the season's best offense and a 13-6 hammering of the Chicago Cubs.


Museum of Moving Image Celebrates All Video Forms
LEAD: The American Museum of the Moving Image, which bills itself as the first museum in the United States devoted to chronicling the history of producing, promoting and exhibiting movies, television and video art, opens tomorrow in Astoria, Queens.


B.Y.U. Wins, 47-6
LEAD: Sean Covey passed for 323 yards and 2 touchdowns as Brigham Young (1-1) routed Texas (0-1), 47-6, tonight.
Texas was without the tailback Eric Metcalf, who sat out a one-game suspension mandated by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.


Ex-SS Man Loses Citizenship
LEAD: Stefan Reger, a 62-year-old Yardville resident, lost his United States citizenship today after his lawyers, in a telephone conference, did not rebut Federal Justice Department claims that he served as a Nazi death-camp guard during World War II.
Federal prosecutors said Mr.
Reger, a native of Filipovo, Yugoslavia, has admitted being a member of the SS Death's Head Battalion but denied their contention that he was a guard at the Auschwitz II concentration camp known as Birkenau.

Israeli Soldiers Kill a Palestinian In a Clash With Arab Protesters
LEAD: Soldiers shot and killed a Palestinian man and critically wounded a second in the West Bank today in what the army described as a clash between a military patrol and a group of masked Arab demonstrators with knives, clubs and stones.


Opposition in Burma Announces Formation of Provisional Regime
LEAD: A Burmese opposition group led by the former Prime Minister, U Nu, has announced the formation of a provisional government and called for new elections, diplomats said today.
They said there was no immediate response from the country's beleaguered leadership.

Irving Gives Data To Several Banks
LEAD: At a board meeting late Wednesday, the directors of the Irving Bank Corporation unanimously endorsed a plan to ''seek the best possible financial transaction for Irving shareholders.'' Maintaining that it could obtain a better price for shareholders than the Bank of New York has so far offered, Irving said it had provided information to several banks, which it did not name.

The carnivals are colorful, the music lively, and the natives are friendly - even the bottom-pinching dictator and the diabolical, scheming chief of police.

LEAD: The Major League Baseball Players Association, taking the first step in the remedy phase of Collusion II, submitted a proposal to the Player Relations Committee yesterday dealing with a possible second-chance free agency for players involved in the case.
Lauren Rich, an association lawyer, declined to provide details of the plan but said if the owners' lawyers reject the proposal, the union would present it to George Nicolau, the arbitrator, next week.

There are four races in which nomination will be tantamount to election.
In each, at least one candidate has been charged with or convicted of a crime.

SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
LEAD:  Power Tools


Denver Symphony Asks Pay Cuts
LEAD: Another American orchestra, the Denver Symphony, faces crisis if not disbandment because of economic quarrels between its board of directors and musicians.
A week ago, the board estimated a budget shortfall of as much as $744,000 as of June 30, 1989, and asked the musicians to accept cuts of $325,000 in salary and benefits, Josi Callan, the symphony director of development, said yesterday.


Poufs May Be 'Out,' but Everybody Loves Campeau
LEAD: A black-tie crowd of 250 powerful New Yorkers filed through a receiving line at the Metropolitan Museum of Art last night to pump the hand of a powerful Canadian whose name every third one of them seemed to mispronounce.
The name was Campeau (pronounced COMP-oh) as in Robert Campeau, the real estate and retailing magnate who came from the north to pull off two of the biggest takeovers in the history of American business - and who has just been rated one of Canada's 10 sexiest men by


N.F.L. Matchups; Week 2 Could Be Surprising
LEAD: Week One in the National Football League unfolded pretty much according to plan.
Except for the Buffalo Bills' 13-10 toppling of the Minnesota Vikings and the Seattle Seahawks' 21-14 victory over Denver in Mile High Stadium, where the Broncos seldom wilt, few results were surprises.


Jazz for Dessert In Club-Restaurants Where Music Is on the Menu
LEAD: AS much as New Yorkers take jazz clubs for granted, noticing them only when they close, they are one of the things that make New York distinct among the world's cities.
An integral part of the cultural life, the clubs are also one of the city's better faces.
So there's good news: New York, in the midst of a miserable year for clubs and restaurants, has seen, in the last six months, a small explosion of new rooms featuring jazz.


Soviets Buy More Corn
LEAD: United States grain exporters said today that the Soviet Union had bought 250,000 metric tons of American corn in the last 24 hours, bringing its total purchases since last week to 2.25 million tons.

LEAD: President Reagan today dispatched a Cabinet-level team to the West to see what additional Federal help was needed in fighting forest fires.
The White House said that the number of troops on the fire line was likely to be increased.

LEAD: The Taubman Company yesterday confirmed reports that it had put up for sale its two retail chains: Woodward &amp; Lothrop of Washington and John Wanamaker of Philadelphia.
The two department store companies are leading retailers that aim at relatively affluent customers in their metropolitan areas.

LEAD: With a new campaign aimed at younger car buyers, the General Motors Corporation's Oldsmobile division predicted sales would increase 5 to 10 percent in the 1989 model year.
G.M. executives also said they planned an aggressive advertising campaign for the model with the theme, ''It's not your father's Oldsmobile,'' aimed at lowering the average age of their buyers, currently about 50 years old.

INSIDE
LEAD:  Soviet Spacecraft Adrift


What's Behind The Dollar's Rise?
LEAD: THE great surprise in world financial markets this summer has been the sharp rally of the dollar.
Few economists had expected it after private foreign investment dried up last year and the United States had to depend on foreign central banks to finance its external deficit.
But, after dropping more than 15 percent against a trade-weighted average of other currencies in the latter half of 1987, the dollar stabilized and then took off this summer.


Horse Racing Notebook; Filly's Return Will Be Tough
LEAD: It looked as if the only way that Winning Colors could beat Personal Ensign in the Maskette Mile at Belmont tomorrow would be if she stole off to an early, easy lead.
Shug McGaughey, Personal Ensign's trainer, took care of that possibility yesterday when he also entered Cadillacing, who will help set an honest pace for her undefeated stablemate.

Martha Bruner, 86, Ex-Foundation Chief
LEAD: Martha Bruner, a philanthropist and former foundation president, died of a stroke on Aug. 28 at Long Island Jewish Hospital.
She was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan before moving recently to Tucson, Ariz.

LEAD: Governor Kean today signed two automobile-insurance bills that he called ''a first step'' toward offering motorists relief from high premiums, and the State Assembly passed a new package of bills aimed at making further insurance changes.


Seven-Mile Walk
LEAD: The New York City Stride, a seven-mile noncompetitive walk through lower Manhattan, will take place on Sunday, beginning at 9:30 A.M. at the World Trade Center Plaza.
The walk, sponsored by City Sports Magazine, will include turns around Battery Park City, Battery Park and the South Street Seaport, as well as trips to and from Brooklyn, by way of the Brooklyn Bridge.


Lloyd's Expects Huge Loss
LEAD: Underwriters at Lloyd's of London will be hit by record losses because of the hurricane that hit England last October and the explosion of an oil rig in the North Sea in July, the group announced today in its annual report.

Stories of Death Row, Most With Happy Endings
LEAD: In 1972, the 102 men on San Quentin's death row got a new lease on life when a landmark court decision reversed the juries in all their cases and commuted their sentences to life imprisonment.
Forty of them have since been paroled, and several of the parolees are the subjects of ''Life After Death Row,'' which will be broadcast tonight at 9 o'clock on Channel 7.

Corrections
LEAD: The television highlights listing on Wednesday carried an erroneous entry for ''The Big Sleep.'' The film, on Channel 5, was the 1978 television remake of the Raymond Chandler mystery novel, starring Robert Mitchum; it was not the 1946 Howard Hawks film starring Humphrey Bogart.


Afghanistan Says Guerrillas Shot Down Plane, Killing 16
LEAD: Moslem guerrillas shot down an Afghan military transport plane on Wednesday, killing all 16 people aboard, including two army generals, Afghanistan's Government radio said today.

LEAD: Caspar W. Weinberger, the former Defense Secretary, will become the publisher of Forbes magazine, Malcolm S. Forbes, chairman and editor in chief, announced yesterday.


Barge Spill in Mississippi
LEAD: A barge ran aground and cracked open near Natchez, Miss., early today, spilling about 42,000 gallons of styrene, an flammable liquid, into the Mississippi River, the Coast Guard said.
The Coast Guard closed a 50-mile stretch of the river to shipping.

U.S. Awards Job To Westinghouse
LEAD: The Department of Energy said it had awarded a contract valued at $6.7 billion to the Westinghouse Electric Corporation to manage and operate the department's Savannah River Plant, near Aiken, S.C.
The department said the contract is for an initial period of five and a half years.
Westinghouse will replace the Du Pont Company as the contractor.

Allende Widow Plans Return To Chile for Oct. 5 Plebiscite
LEAD: The widow of Salvador Allende Gossens said today she will return to Chile later this month to help defeat the military regime that overthrew her husband's presidency.


Five-Time Olympian
LEAD: He is 35 years old now, but Pietro Mennea of Italy will become the first sprinter to enter five Olympics.
That was made certain yesterday when Mennea was surprisingly included on the Italian track team for the Seoul Olympic Games, which open in eight days.
Mennea, who holds a world record of 19.72 seconds in the 200 meters, will run at that distance.


Soviet Mars Craft Failing to Respond
LEAD: An unmanned Soviet spacecraft headed for Mars is apparently wobbling out of control, its power and its ability to receive commands limited because it is having trouble orienting itself with the Sun.
But Soviet space officials said yesterday that they should be able to regain control in three to four weeks.

LEAD: When workers lose out in a merger or corporate restructuring, what do their employers owe them?


Winning Freedom
LEAD: There was good news for the Religious Action Center of Reform Judaism this week when it was learned that a political prisoner in whom the center took a strong interest had been released from a South African jail.


Tempers Flare at a Hearing On Yonkers Fund Transfers
LEAD: The tension that has been building in City Hall over mounting contempt fines and the layoffs of city workers required to pay them exploded today in the City Council chamber over a seemingly routine transfer of funds.

M.S. Hooper, 41, Rights Lawyer
LEAD: Michael Stone Hooper, a lawyer and advocate for Haitian refugees, died of skin cancer yesterday at the New York University Medical Center.
He was 41 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Evert to Face Graf Today
LEAD: With Martina Navratilova no longer posing a threat, the popular opinion is that the United States Open championship and Grand Slam will be a formality for Steffi Graf.
But any of the three remaining players in the Stop Graf Movement - Chris Evert, Zina Garrison and Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina - are potentially dangerous opponents, not to be taken lightly.

LEAD:  The Drexel Case


Yonkers Syndrome Permeates Northeast From S.I. to Boston
LEAD: To the Editor:


Dukakis Campaign Fights Slump With New Look and Sharper Edge
LEAD: For days senior aides to Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis have been meeting from morning to midnight in a struggle to salvage a Presidential campaign that has seen little but trouble for the better part of a month.
The Dukakis aides have said they think they have no more than two weeks to get his campaign back on track.


National Policy Urged to Combat Adult Illiteracy
LEAD: Describing the inability of millions of Americans to read and write as a ''a root cause of a wide range of social problems,'' a coalition of 11 educational groups today called on the next President to start a systematic national effort to combat adult illiteracy.


Bridge
LEAD: For the layman, the word ''split'' can indicate an ice-cream treat, a parting from home or a resort in Yugoslavia.
For the bridge player, it can be the division of a suit in the opposing hands or, more significantly, a second-hand play with touching high cards.


Study Sees Link Between Genital Ulcers and AIDS
LEAD: Male homosexuals who have had genital ulcers from syphilis and herpes are much more likely to become infected with the AIDS virus than men with similar sexual histories who have not had such ulcers, according to a new study.

Conferees on Welfare Bill Report Accord on a Work Requirement
LEAD: Enmeshed in Presidential politics, welfare legislation made some progress today as the chairmen of House and Senate conferees agreed on two key issues.


College Football Notebook; Penn State to Decide Soon on Thomas
LEAD: Penn State will open its 102d season tomorrow night against Virginia in Charlottesville with Tom Bill at quarterback but without Blair Thomas at tailback.


Warships in Gulf Get New Radios To Guard Against Air Disasters
LEAD: In response to the accidental downing of an Iranian airliner by a warship in the Persian Gulf on July 3, the Navy has issued new radios to ships in the region so that they can monitor transmissions by civilian aircraft and air traffic control towers.


2 Municipal Issuers Raise $300 Million
LEAD: The State of Massachusetts and Dade County, Fla., tapped the municipal bond market for about $300 million in general obligation debt yesterday.


While Europe Unites, U.S. Is Flying Apart
LEAD: To the Editor:


Joseph John Fried, Ophthalmologist, 91
LEAD: Dr.
Joseph John Fried, an ophthalmologist, died of complications of pneumonia Wednesday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 91 years old.


Review/Art; Angular Sculptures With Multiple Meanings
LEAD: Garth Evans is an abstract sculptor from Cheshire, England, who has definitely not been swept along on the current wave of interest in British sculpture.
He is 54 years old, a generation younger than Anthony Caro and a generation older than Tony Cragg and Richard Deacon, one of his former students.


7,000 Acres of Urban Wilderness
LEAD: There is a 7,000-acre miracle of nature scattered about the concrete platform that is New York City.
Parceled out among the five boroughs, these enclaves of untouched wilderness are the unmanicured segments of the 26,000 acres under the domain of the Department of Parks and Recreation.


At Risk: A Treasure Of the Law
LEAD: Over the last 150 years, the City Bar Association has collected more than 120 million pages of legal briefs from appellate cases, preserving the words and evolving ideas of the Cardozos, the Brandeises and the lawyers whose names have been forgotten by history.


The Two Faces of South Korea's Capital City: Rumpled and Olympic-Tidy
LEAD: There are two Seouls - the everyday one that screeches and blares and laughs out loud, and the sanitized one that is being polished and buffed for the world to see.


Downtown Grazing: A Taste of the Big Apple
LEAD: Hamburger Harry's will serve just what you'd expect - two kinds of burgers, and also a grilled chicken sandwich.
Schaller &amp; Weber will bring the bratwurst, and Bahama Mama will be there with conch gazpacho and Jamaican meat patties.
Tavern on the Green will be there, too, even though the setting will be Battery Park, not Central Park, and


Parking Rules
LEAD: Because of Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended in New York City on Monday and Tuesday.
Other regulations remain in effect.


Cuban Jumps Record 7-11 1/2
LEAD: Javier Sotomayor Sanabria of Cuba broke the world record for the men's high jump in a minor track and field meet today.


Mercury Found In Proposed Site Of Nature Area
LEAD: The United States Fish and Wildlife Service said here today that high levels of mercury, a deadly poison, had been found in a proposed national wildlife refuge within the New Orleans city limits.


Treasury Official Appears To Back the Dollar's Drop
LEAD: A top Treasury official said yesterday that the Reagan Administration continued to believe that a ''destabilizing'' rise in the dollar ''could be counterproductive,'' and at the same time, the official noted that the dollar had fallen from the highs it reached in August.


Tyson Denies Making a Suicide Attempt
LEAD: In his first interview since his auto accident last weekend, Mike Tyson, the heavyweight champion, yesterday denied reports that he tried to commit suicide, underwent mental treatment or beat his wife.


Acquisition Set By Ultramar
LEAD: Ultramar P.L.C., a British-based petroleum exploration and development company, said today that it had agreed to buy a California oil refinery owned by the Union Pacific Corporation for $440 million.


U.S. Wheat Exports
LEAD: An expected 11 percent drop in wheat exports in 1988-89 will cut into the United States share of the world wheat trade, Agriculture Department analysts said today. ''World market share may fall from 43 percent in 1987-88 to about 40 percent,'' the department's Economic Research Service said.


Protest at the Guggenheim
LEAD: A demonstration billed as a 30th birthday party for the Guggenheim Museum was held yesterday across the street from the museum at 89th Street and Fifth Avenue.
Pickets opposing a proposed addition to the museum paraded around a birthday cake made in the shape of the museum.


Live TV Performances From Around the World
LEAD: ''Wrap Around the World,'' a 90-minute live television broadcast featuring performances and other events produced simultaneously from 10 countries in Europe and Asia, will be broadcast tomorrow at 10:30 A.M. on Channel 13.


Angolans Strive for Military Victory
LEAD: Angola's leadership appears determined to press for a military victory in the country's 13-year-old civil war, despite African, American and Soviet appeals for a negotiated settlement.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an Executive Changes listing in Business Day yesterday misstated the retirement date of James Q. Riordan, vice chairman and chief financial officer of the Mobil Corporation.
It is Oct. 1, 1989.
But Lucio A. Noto will succeed him this Jan. 1 as chief financial officer.


Let Congress Do Justice on Military Contractors
LEAD: To the Editor:


Harold G. Rosson, 93, 'Oz' Cinematographer
LEAD: Harold G. Rosson, the cinematographer who filmed ''The Wizard of Oz'' and ''The Asphalt Jungle'' during a 52-year Hollywood career, died Tuesday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla.
He was 93 years old.


American Academy Names a New President
LEAD: Adele Chatfield-Taylor, a national authority on historic preservation and urban design, has been appointed president of the American Academy in Rome, beginning Dec. 1.


Lawrence Brown Is Dead at 81; Was Trombonist With Ellington
LEAD: Lawrence Brown, a trombonist with the Duke Ellington orchestra for several decades, died Monday at his home in Los Angeles.
He was 81 years old.
Mr.
Brown had recently had a stroke, his brother, Harold, said.


People
LEAD: *
Doreen Fox, Stephanie Pierson, Michael Lawlor, Howard Benson and Helio Gonzalez have been promoted to group creative directors at Backer Spielvogel Bates Worldwide.
Mr.
Benson and Mr.
Gonzalez were also promoted to senior vice president; the others already held that title.


New Hearing Is Held On Coloring Movies
LEAD: Hollywood returned to Washington today for another round in the continuing drama about coloring old black-and-white films.


The Election Board's Arrogance
LEAD: Betty Dolen, executive director of New York City's troubled Board of Elections, doesn't plan to retire until December - ample time for the 10-member Board to conduct a serious national search for her successor.
Yet the Board instead moved quietly this week to appoint Mrs.
Dolen's deputy, Daniel DeFrancisco, to the $72,000-a-year post.

Long-Expected Move Barely Affects 'Junk Bonds'
LEAD: For the last two years, many investors had worried that the market in ''junk bonds,'' which was established by Drexel Burnham Lambert's bond wizard, Michael Milken, in the 1970's, would crack if the Government pressed charges of securities law violatons against the firm.


Hawaii's History
LEAD: ''Behold Hawaii,'' 40 minutes of Hawaiian history seen through the eyes of a young man seeking his heritage, will be presented at the Naturemax Theater of the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West and 79th Street, starting today.
Sharing the bill will be ''Dance of Life,'' a view of Indonesia's art, religion and mythology.


First U.S. Missiles Destroyed as Part of Nuclear Treaty With Soviets
LEAD: Two Pershing missile engines were destroyed at an Army ammunition plant here today in the United States' first elimination of nuclear weapons of short and medium range under the new Soviet-American treaty.


Ward Sending Unit To Tompkins Square To Fight Drug Trade
LEAD: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward said yesterday that he planned to assign a special group of officers to Tompkins Square Park similar to one that rid Washington Square Park of heavy drug trafficking last year.

Money Fund Assets Off
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 452 money market mutual funds decreased by $239.9 million, to $266.93 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 126 institutional funds decreased by $104 million, to $68.73 billion.
Assets of the 223 general-purpose funds were down by $172.2 million, to $84.98 billion.


French Strike Felt Here
LEAD: If you were planning to call or visit any of France's 12 consulates in this country, its embassy in Washington or its mission to the United Nations in New York today, you might do well to pay attention here.


Nabisco, Zenith Labs Give Jobs to F.D.&amp; M.
LEAD: Without affecting the regular agencies working for the Nabisco Foods Company on individual brands, Franznick, Deutsch &amp; Molligo is going to be doing an advertising campaign for both consumer and trade publications that includes all the company's non-cookie products.


Judge Scolds Koch in Court For Blaming 'Little People'
LEAD: Mayor Koch traveled to a Brooklyn courtroom yesterday, announcing that he would try to persuade a judge to jail a group of former collection agents who stole thousands of dollars from parking meters.
Instead, the judge ignored his plea and scolded him for blaming ''little people'' for a city government failure.


Senate Panel Backs Tax Changes
LEAD: The Senate Finance Committee approved a package of tax changes today, including a ''bill of rights'' for taxpayers involved in disputes with the Internal Revenue Service.


Apple Held Ready To Display Model
LEAD: Apple Computer Inc. is preparing to introduce a more powerful version of its popular Macintosh II Computer on Sept. 19, reports in several industry trade newspapers said.
The upgraded Macintosh will be based on Motorola's 68030 microprocessor, a chip that more than doubles the performance of the 68020 microprocessor used in the current Mac II.


Review/Film; 'Running on Empty,' A Family Underground
LEAD: The Pope family knows things that other families don't.
For instance, the Popes know how to leave town forever on a moment's notice, abandoning everything, even the family dog.
The parents, Arthur (Judd Hirsch) and Annie (Christine Lahti), know how to find new jobs that don't require much experience or attract much attention.


Comings and Goings
LEAD: Lupe Aquino, a former World Boxing Council superwelterweight champion, pleaded not guilty yesterday to two counts each of vehicular manslaughter and drunken driving arising from a San Diego Freeway accident Aug. 14 in which two people were killed.
A preliminary hearing was set for Oct. 27 in West Los Angeles Municipal Court.


Brezhnev's Son-in-Law Admits Abuses
LEAD: The son-in-law of Leonid I. Brezhnev, the former Soviet leader, pleaded guilty today to abusing his powers when he was First Deputy Soviet Interior Minister, but denied that he had accepted bribes while in office.


Blacks Hit Hard by Proposition 48, Survey Shows
LEAD: The majority of college football recruits disqualified because of Proposition 48 this year are black, according to a survey by The Associated Press.
The survey also found that the overall number of academically ineligible recruits has stabilized.


Flood-Ravaged Bangladesh Seeks Plan to Control Rivers
LEAD: The Government of Bangladesh, reacting to what may be the worst flood of the country's history, called today for an international panel of experts to devise plans to control the rivers of South Asia.

U.S. Open; A Look at Old and New Times
LEAD: Up on the top tier of the bleachers, the tanning enthusiasts outnumbered the tennis enthusiasts.
A steady stream of people swarmed past on their way to watch Ivan Lendl play, ignoring the players who toiled on lesser courts for lower pay, or no pay at all.
A few patrons studied today's tennis schedule like a racing form, but most were oblivious to the nonstar matches.

Aides to Bush and Dukakis Agree to a Sept. 25 Debate
LEAD: The Presidential campaigns of George Bush and Michael S. Dukakis agreed today to hold debates on Sept. 25 and either Oct. 13 or 14, a victory in the Bush camp's efforts to keep the debates confined to a middle period in the fall campaign already crowded with major televised sports events.

The Hispanic Factor
LEAD: If either Presidential candidate can carry both California and Texas, with their total of 76 electoral votes, he will just about have wrapped up the election.


Ruling Due Next Week On Detroit Papers' Deal
LEAD: Detroit's two daily newspapers won a promise from a Federal judge today that he would decide by next week whether to allow them to merge their business operations.
A merger between The Detroit Free Press and The Detroit News would put an end to an eight-year battle for dominance in the nation's fourth-largest market.


Growth in Consumer Credit Slowed in July
LEAD: Americans took out $2.6 billion more in consumer credit than they paid off in July, a sharp slowdown from the pace of growth during the first half of the year.

Dr.
Martin Luther King Jr.'s methods and philosophy in New York schools and colleges.

About Real Estate; Residential Use of Jersey Industrial Land
LEAD: Vacant industrial land may seem an unlikely place for a large low-rise condominium development with a health club, tennis courts and jogging trails.
But just such a project, the Hampton Club with 650 units, is under construction in an industrial park in New Brunswick, N.J.


Chances of New Insider Law Look Better
LEAD: The chances that Congress will pass legislation this year to increase the penalties for violating insider trading laws have improved, now that civil charges have been filed against Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., senior Congressional aides said today.


Threat of Yonkers Layoffs Jolts Foes of Housing Plan
LEAD: As contempt fines against Yonkers passed $1 million and one-fourth of the city work force faced layoffs in two days, even steadfast opponents of a court-ordered housing desegregation plan seemed jolted today, and pressure grew for city officials to resolve the crisis.


Solar Power Plant Planned for California
LEAD: In a landmark in the development of solar power, a company that currently makes patio lights powered by the sun said yesterday that it would build a $125 million plant in the desert near Los Angeles to make large amounts of electricity directly from sunlight.

LEAD: Is the Federal Government shortchanging the nation's hospitals?
Or has Washington merely tightened its purse strings in an effort to persuade the hospitals to follow suit?


Times Raising Price To 35/ on Sept. 19
LEAD: The New York Times will raise the suggested newsstand price of its weekday issues to 35 cents, from 30 cents, within 75 miles of New York City and on all of Long Island starting Monday, Sept. 19.

LEAD: It's hardly news when the director general of the Israeli Foreign Ministry says he opposes creating a Palestinian state on the occupied West Bank.

Court Review of V.A. Claims Backed
LEAD: A bipartisan group on the House Veterans Affairs Committee signaled today that they would support limited access to the courts for appeals of Government decisions on veterans' disability and pension benefits.


The Man Who Dreamed Benzene Rings
LEAD: To the Editor:


Newman Photographs
LEAD: Portraits of 20th-century personages and experiments in photographic abstraction are the main parts of a retrospective of 150 works by the photographer Arnold Newman, opening today at the New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, at 77th Street.
The show will run through Oct. 30.
Hours are 10 A.M.


Our Towns; East Side Story: The Long Trail Of Housing Bias
LEAD: As the pressure mounts on the four Yonkers Councilmen holding out, hardly a night goes by when they are not seen on TV making the same two points.
First, they say, Federal officials have unfairly singled out Yonkers.
Second, they say, people on Yonkers's white East Side don't mind living beside middle-class blacks, they just don't want the welfare types who would come in because of the court order to build low-income units.

SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
LEAD:  The Sound of Sugar


Leonard S. Brown, Accountant, 58
LEAD: Leonard S. Brown, an educator and accountant, died of lung cancer Aug. 31 at his home in Wayne, N.J.
He was 58 years old.


Single Advertiser Set For Times Section
LEAD: The second part of this Sunday's Sports section in The New York Times, covering the opening of the Summer Olympics in Seoul, South Korea, will have a single advertiser: the Nynex Corporation.


An Unpeaceable 'Kingdom' Where Loners Dwell
LEAD: There is a curious morning-after quality about ''Doc's Kingdom,'' the new Robert Kramer movie that opens today at the Public Theater.
The night before was 20 years ago, when Doc, the protagonist, was involved in the passionate upheavals of the 1960's that promised, perhaps threatened, to make the world anew.


Griffin Wins Case
LEAD: The plan by the entertainer Merv Griffin to buy Resorts International Inc. moved a step closer to completion.
The Delaware Chancery Court found Wednesday that the $36-a-share offer to holders of class A shares ''is both generous and fair and that the settlement must be approved.''


A.T.&amp;T. to Pursue More Cost-Cutting
LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company is pursuing earnings growth with a new sense of urgency, its chairman, Robert Allen, told the Boston Security Analysts Society.
Mr.
Allen said that he was ''encouraged but not satisfied'' with A.T.&amp;T.'s financial performance this year and that the New York-based company needed to cut costs further.

Red Sox Hitting Stops Indians, 7-4
LEAD: Mike Greenwell hit a two-run triple in the first inning, and Wade Boggs had a home run and a double tonight as the Boston Red Sox beat the Cleveland Indians, 7-4.
The Red Sox took a two-and-a-half-game lead over Detroit in the American League East.
The second-place Tigers lost to the Yankees, 3-2.


Jerusalem Book Fair Is Set
LEAD: The Jerusalem International Book Fair, which is held every other year, is scheduled for the week of March 12, 1989, it was announced yesterday by Mayor Teddy Kollek.


Boeing Jet Orders Rise $421 Million
LEAD: The Boeing Company announced orders for seven 767 passenger jets for at least $421 million. increasing the company's total jetliner orders for the year to more than $21 billion.
Statements issued by Boeing said four 767-300 extended-range aircraft had been ordered by Gulf Air, the national carrier of Bahrain, Oman, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates, for delivery in April, May and June.
