LEAD: The PTL bankruptcy trustee today extended indefinitely the deadline to accept bids for the ministry and said Jim Bakker had provided no proof he has the money to support his $172 million offer to buy back the television network and religious theme park he founded.

Avery C. Manchester performed the service at the First Church of Round Hill.

LEAD: The Mets changed stadiums, cities and even countries tonight, but kept blazing away with their bats, hitting three more home runs, knocking out 14 more hits and hammering the Montreal Expos, 7-3.

LEAD: The location of the world's fastest bridge game is distinctly debatable.

Confusion Causes a Run
LEAD: A case of mistaken identity spurred a $2 million run on a Chinatown savings institution Thursday.
Hundreds of customers lined up at the Elmhurst Federal Savings and Loan Association to withdraw money after confusing the association with a financially troubled bank in the suburb of Elmhurst.
The assets of that institution, the United Security Bank, were frozen by a judge last week.

LEAD: Months ago, Mary Rogers, a single parent and assistant custodian for the Yonkers Public Library, finally wrested herself from four years of dependence on welfare.
Friday was to have been her last day of work, not because she gave up or failed at her job, but because the city was to dismiss her, and hundreds of others, to pay its mounting contempt fines.

Canada Jobless Rate Up
LEAD: Canada's unemployment rate edged up to 8 percent in August from 7.9 percent the previous month, the Government's statistical agency reported today.
But Statistics Canada said there was little change on the labor front in August.
On a seasonally adjusted basis, about 12,000 were added to the jobless rolls for a total of 1,069,000 unemployed.

Car repairs are done right the first time.

Newspapers stop making errors.
Because of their overall superiority, Detroit automobiles become the biggest-selling item in Japan since raw fish.

Schmidt, 39 years old, underwent arthroscopic surgery on his right shoulder Wednesday.

DNA Probe Detects Sex of Cattle Embryo
LEAD: For several years, the cattle industry has used embryo-transfer techniques to enhance breeding.
Typically, high-quality cows are fertilized through artificial insemination, and the embryos are then transferred to less well-bred surrogate mothers.
With this technique, high-quality cows can produce an almost infinite number of offspring without enduring the strain of carrying calves.

LEAD: Following is the 57-to-32 roll-call vote by which the Senate today approved new curbs on textile, apparel and non-rubber footwear imports.
A vote in favor was a vote to impose the import restraints, while a vote against the measure was a vote not to impose them.
Voting yes were 40 Democrats and 17 Republicans.

LEAD: Experts on Burma portray the upheaval there as a spontaneous revolution by people craving democracy, and they say the only mystery is why it took the Burmese so long to rise up against an oppressive, authoritarian Government.

Blackout Tied To Contractor
LEAD: A four-and-a-half-day blackout in the downtown area was caused by a sidewalk contractor who accidentally drove a piling into underground power cables, the city-owned electric company has reported.
The contractor had asked for plans showing where cables were, but the Seattle City Light maps did not show the service line that was hit, Gerald Garman, Assistant Superintendent of the utility, said Wednesday.

Whither Oil Prices?
LEAD: Since the cease-fire between Iran and Iraq, world oil prices have softened, as oil production has risen.
In spite of growing overcapacity, a number of OPEC members are pressing for larger production quotas.
Some analysts think this will drive prices down sharply, while others believe OPEC will reassert discipline among members at the November meeting.


The Games, From Archery to Yachting: Synchronized Swimming
LEAD: The era of synchronized swimming as a frilly exhibition event has ended.
Most competitors now spend at least six hours in the pool six days a week.
They no longer wear real flowers in their hair; they slick it back with gel to allow for easy head movement.
They run and ride bicycles to build lung capacity, since half of the competition is performed completely underwater without any contact with the bottom of the pool.


Those Eyes, That Smile
LEAD: SHE IS KNOWN AS THE ''Mona Lisa of Roman Palestine.'' The portrait is part of a mosaic floor, dating to the third century - nearly 30 feet long and more than 20 feet wide - revealed in an excavation of the ancient city of Sepphoris, once the capital of Galilee, in what is now northern Israel.
Discovered in August 1987 by an expedition led by two Duke University professors, Eric and Carol Meyers, and Ehud Netzer, an archaeologist at Hebrew University in Jerusalem, the mosaic was re-interred over the winter while financing was sought for its preservation.

To Miter Joints, Use a Backsaw
LEAD: FOR molding to present a neat appearance, individual pieces must be joined skillfully.
The technique most often used to accomplish this is mitering (cutting the ends of pieces off at an angle and joining them by placing the angled ends together).
Creating professional-looking miter joints requires practice; however, by working patiently with appropriate tools, even beginners can produce excellent miter joints after only a few tries.

LEAD: ON THE RIO GRANDE -The thermometer rises effortlessly to 100 degrees.
The only shade is the halftone cast by the lighting crew's silk screen, a kind of trampoline cocked in the air to deaden the glare for the camera.
You try to hunker in this half-shade and cannot because the entire shadow is occupied by thorn bushes.

It remains so, in spite of its recent troubles.
In Tompkins Square, the dress mode is good-natured anarchy.
The exuberant group that troops through the park may be giving a collective nose-thumb to more conventional styles, but it's done with a smile, not a smirk.

Worldwide Guide to Vacation Home Rentals
LEAD: RENTING a home - an English cottage, Caribbean villa or Parisian apartment - can offer vacationers privacy, flexibility and sometimes even economy.
On the other hand, you may or may not have someone coming in to make the bed every day; room service as such is rarely available, and there's no tour desk to arrange your sightseeing.

Max Eitingon: Further Views
LEAD: To the Editor:


Corrections
LEAD: The Personal Finance column on Aug. 21 about tax planning misstated the cutoff point for the exemption to the Alternative Minimum Tax.
For a married couple filing a joint return, the exemption is reduced at the rate of 25 cents for each $1 of alternative minimum taxable income above $150,000 ($112,500 for single taxpayers).

MUSIC: Avant-garde to Zydeco, By Way of Texas
LEAD: Nobody thought avant-garde music could pay a club's rent until the Knitting Factory came along.
A few months after it opened, it had become a center for improvisational music, at the nexus of risky, format-defying new jazz, new rock and the postmodern assemblages of downtown composers - the tumultuous piano solos of Cecil Taylor, the quick-change artistry of John Zorn, the geometrically proportioned slabs of noise composed by Elliott Sharp, the dreamlike performance-rock of Hugo Largo or the skewed, clattery funk of Curlew.


A Few Tips for Buyers of Hardy Spring Bulbs
LEAD: HOUSE plants should be moved back indoors; first, check plants for mealybugs, spiders, slugs and other unwanted invaders; second, wash leaves and stems with a forceful spray of water; third, use a stiff brush to scrub pots clean.
Christmas cactus and jade plants can remain outdoors until a light frost occurs to induce flowering.

Behind Barbed Wire
LEAD: Last month, President Reagan signed into law a national act of contrition for a grievous lapse in this country's cherished standards of liberty almost half a century ago: The wartime incarceration of more than 100,000 Japanese-American citizens and Japanese resident aliens in concentration camps.
The legislation provided for recompense of $20,000 to each surviving internee, whether citizen or alien, and, more significantly, an unprecedented apology by the United States Government.

Vietnam Aide a Crash Victim
LEAD: Vietnam's Health Minister was among 75 people killed when a Vietnamese airliner crashed while approaching Bangkok through a rainstorm, a Vietnamese diplomat said today.
The health official, Dang Hoi Xuan, died when the Soviet-made Air Vietnam Tu-134 airliner slammed into a rice field Friday, a spokesman at the Vietnamese Embassy said.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Golf  King Leads by One: Betsy King, winner of last week's Rail Charity Classic, took the second-round lead by one stroke yesterday at the $250,000 Cellular One-Ping Championship in Portland, Ore.
King, who started the day at one-under par, shot a two-under 70 for a two-day total of 141 over the 6,285-yard course at Riverside Golf and Country Club.


The Games, From Archery to Yachting: Yachting
LEAD: The yachting competition will be held off Pusan, a port city about 200 miles south of Seoul.
The conditions are expected to be windy; sailors who gathered there last September for a pre-Olympic regatta encountered breezes that ranged mostly from 15 to 25 knots.


To Miter Joints, Use a Backsaw
LEAD: FOR molding to present a neat appearance, individual pieces must be joined skillfully.
The technique most often used to accomplish this is mitering (cutting the ends of pieces off at an angle and joining them by placing the angled ends together).
Creating professional-looking miter joints requires practice; however, by working patiently with appropriate tools, even beginners can produce excellent miter joints after only a few tries.


Bruins Trounce Cornhuskers
LEAD: U.C.L.A. gave Nebraska a taste of California flash and a 41-28 trouncing before 84,086 tonight in the Rose Bowl.


Breaking Out of the Biotech Pack
LEAD: WHEN kidney dialysis patients taking part in the clinical trials of Amgen Inc.'s erythropoietin talk about the drug's impact on their lives, they tend to use words like ''wonderful'' and ''dramatic,'' with all the restraint of a carnival barker hawking snake oil.


TENSE TALK
LEAD: Reading Ben Yagoda's article brought back memories of my medical internship, when I was astounded to discover that even brain surgery is not that difficult.
Neurosurgery is more like real estate.
There are only three important things to remember in the human brain: location, location, location.
Once the skull is open, the tumor is resectable or not; the hematoma can be evacuated or not.

LEAD:  WRIGHTSTOWN AIR SHOW  The Thunderbirds, the Air Force aerial demonstration team and their F-16 fighters, will be the stars today of McGuire Air Force Base's annual air show, which last year drew 400,000 spectators.

THE WORLD'S ATHLETES UNITE IN A DIVIDED LAND
LEAD: IN the quiet of his office in Lausanne, Switzerland, not long ago, Juan Antonio Samaranch tried to remember how many countries he had visited in his tenure as president of the International Olympic Committee.
The total approached the number of nations invited to the Games of the XXIV Olympiad in Seoul, South Korea, and he seemed slightly embarrassed that he had not yet reached all 167.


Baseball Movies Turn Men to Mush
LEAD: The less one knows about baseball - and I happen to know less than almost anybody - the more one is apt to notice in movies about the game.
It can be wonderfully liberating to have little idea whether the rookie is really any good, whether the aging manager stands a chance of breathing new life into his career or whether the team has any hope of winning the pennant, since the attention is thus freed to concentrate on more pressing matters.

Senate Candidate Is Chosen
LEAD: Samuel S. Beard defeated Delaware's Lieutenant Governor tonight in a Democratic primary election for the right to challenge the Republican incumbent, Senator William V. Roth Jr.
Mr.
Beard won 53 percent of the vote to Lieutenant Governor S.B.
Woo's 47 percent.
Mr.
Beard runs a nonprofit company that helps attract grants and designs plans to attract economic development.


The Games, From Archery to Yachting: Table Tennis
LEAD: Table tennis, the newest Olympic sport, is hardly an obscure game.
Ping-Pong, as it is generally called in the United States, is believed to be the second most popular participation sport in the world after soccer, and even in the United States it is the most popular racquet sport, with an estimated 20 million players.

MILAN TONES DOWN
LEAD: Invention has traditionally been the operative word at the Salone Internazionale del Mobile, the world's most important furniture fair, which is held in Milan each September.
It is here that the latest designs from all over the world are previewed.
And it is at these fairgrounds and at showrooms in the center of Milan that store buyers and design experts look for the latest trends the market has to offer.

Bank Board Solves A Huge Problem
LEAD: Federal rescuers took care of their biggest ailing savings institution, committing $2 billion to a deal in which Robert M. Bass will take over the American Savings and Loan Association of California.
Mr.
Bass, a 40-year-old billionaire from Fort Worth, will put up $550 million to acquire American's viable parts, like $14 billion in deposits from 1 million depositors, 185 branch offices throughout California and $10 billion of good real-estate loans.

Car Companies Must Obey the Law
LEAD: RARELY have so many news reports strengthened the case for strong implementation of the Energy Policy and Conservation Act of 1975, which gave auto companies 10 years to reach an average fleet mileage level of 27.5 miles per gallon.


The Games, From Archery to Yachting: Weight Lifting
LEAD: In weight lifting, there are separate competitions in 10 body-weight classes in which competitors weight from 114 pounds to over 242 pounds.
Competition in each weight class involves two kinds of lifts: one is the snatch, in which the bar is raised overhead in a single, unbroken motion; the other is the clean and jerk, in which the bar is first raised to chest level and then lifted overhead.


Ibram Lassaw: The Sculptor as Explorer
LEAD: The 60-year survey of the sculpture of Ibram Lassaw currently on view at the Guild Hall Museum sums up a body of work that will never rank very high in the annals of 20th-century art history.
At the same time, this show, which is titled ''Ibram Lassaw: Space Explorations,'' presents a long, dedicated career worthy of attention.

No More Bandits
LEAD: After four decades, Taiwan has modified the practice of referring to the People's Republic of China as a ''bandit'' regime.
Until August, all goods imported from the mainland had to be labeled as ''bandit goods.'' Now, according to the Free China Journal, they will be called ''products from the Chinese mainland'' or ''products from Communist China.

MUSIC: Operas and Organ Recitals
LEAD: When Harvey Lichtenstein opened the refurbished Majestic Theater last fall, two blocks from the Brooklyn Academy of Music, it was perceived as a New York home for Peter Brook and other innovative theater directors.
But now it is emerging as a concert hall and opera house as well.
Pierre Boulez's appearances there in June with the Ensemble Intercontemporain proved the excellence of its acoustics, and now a number of other musical and operatic events are being negotiated, not the least of which are the Metropolitan Opera's Brooklyn experimental seasons, starting in 1991.

Views From Family Tables
LEAD: I USED to be a model tourist: I ordered coffees or Cokes and watched passers-by from sidewalk tables in cafes on Boulevard St.-Germain and Via Veneto; bargained gently for watches and cameras in Hong Kong or rugs and copper pots in North African souks.
Then I got better jobs and stayed in hotels that got starrier and starrier till one day I made it to the top of the firmament: a five-star deluxe.

Even Chicago Is Not Immune To Fashion
LEAD: For more than a decade now this city in which architecture is a subject of everyday conversation has been in a kind of identity crisis.
Chicago has always prided itself on being America's great city of modern architecture - the city in which the average person knew who Louis Sullivan and Frank Lloyd Wright and Mies van der Rohe were and the average real-estate developer was expected as a matter of course to put up first-class modern buildings.

SIENESE GOLD
LEAD: Siena sprawls across three rolling hills, a sleepy Italian city centuries past its prime.

Amtrak
LEAD: To the Editor: Amtrak's cross-country service may be enchanting for William Borders and Nancy M. Debevoise, but for the commuter on Amtrak's crowded Northeast Corridor Boston to New York route, the ride is at best an inconvenience.
During the 1987 holiday season, Amtrak passengers who had paid the full $40-plus fare were forced to take commuter trains; I saw elderly citizens and families with small children endure the five-hour trip sitting on bags in the aisles.

About Books; Honk if You Love Lighthouses
LEAD: A couple of weeks ago I read in the newspaper that the 11 lighthouses in the United States that are still tended by keepers will be automated by the fall of 1989.
Well, I thought, there goes the last symbol.
There'll be no more ''To the Lighthouse,'' just as there'll be no more Don Quixote, because the windmills too are gone.

Bush as a Texan either, since by background he's obviously a Connecticut Yankee.

THE FROZEN ROOM
LEAD: A number of recent studies confirm that autopsies still discover unexpected major findings about 10 percent of the time.
The reason fewer of these examinations are done is that autopsies are not reimbursed by third-party payers.
Second, in these litigious times, when any less- than-perfect result can lead to years of involvement with the medicolegal system, many doctors prefer to bury their mistakes, and who can blame them?

Heritage Hills: Another View
LEAD: Your article of Aug. 21 on Heritage Hills  [ ''The View From: Heritage Hills'' ]  gave an unbalanced description of life in this semiretirement complex.
As more and more young people purchase homes here this is a mixture of working and nonworking residents.
Certainly there are many here who think they have died and gone to heaven because of the availability of free tennis and swimming and other carefree activities but there are also many who, as volunteers, are giving much time and effort in hospitals, libraries, to people who are homebound, to literacy programs and other selfless activities.

IDEAS &amp; TRENDS: When Minutes Matter; How a Soviet Capsule Became Stuck in Space
LEAD: A Soviet and an Afghan astronaut were stranded in space last week when a malfunctioning navigation system interfered with the split-second calculations required for a successful landing.
On the third attempt, the Soyuz TM-5 capsule touched down safely in the Soviet Republic of Kazakhstan, leaving Soviet and American scientists to reconstruct the sequence of errors that led to a harrowing 25 hours.

Review/Music; Eclectix Performs New Works
LEAD: With two brief exceptions, Friday's program by Eclectix at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church offered music about other music.
In keeping with its title, this new-composers group takes its styles where it finds them, but it does seem to be looking in a few specific places.
Thus most of this repertory grew out of a tonal, melody-accompaniment tradition, and a lot of it by way of American popular culture.

Many Need 2 Jobs for One Life's Bills
LEAD: FOR many jobholders, for many reasons, one is not enough.
A schoolteacher by day becomes a theater usher by night.
A secretary from 8:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. becomes a nurse's aide from 6 P.M. to midnight.
A full-time firefighter is also a part-time coffee grinder.
And the list goes on.
There are thousands of Connecticut residents who moonlight - work a part-time job in addition to a full-time job - in order to make ends meet or maintain their styles of life.

Having Money Does Not Make One 'Nice'
LEAD: I have to take exception to the article ''Full Life, Empty Values'' by Linda Gass (Opinion page, Aug. 21).
I, too, live in the same community as Ms.
Gass.
However, I do not feel the same way she does.
My children have been taught, not that appearances are important, but rather that if they work hard and try to be good people they have a better chance of achieving their goals and dreams than if they think everything just comes to them on a silver platter.

Frankfurt and Tokyo Take Control
LEAD: THE United States has lost control of its financial markets to foreigners and has run out of easy policy options to regain it.
The American financial tune is no longer being called in New York, but rather in Tokyo, London and Frankfurt.
In fact, this loss of control had a lot to do with the timing of the stock market crash last fall.

To Miter Joints, Use a Backsaw
LEAD: FOR molding to present a neat appearance, individual pieces must be joined skillfully.
The technique most often used to accomplish this is mitering (cutting the ends of pieces off at an angle and joining them by placing the angled ends together).
Creating professional-looking miter joints requires practice; however, by working patiently with appropriate tools, even beginners can produce excellent miter joints after only a few tries.

An Affable Provocateur

The Games, From Archery to Yachting: Team Handball
LEAD: It's not like one-wall handball in a Brooklyn playground or four-wall handball in an exclusive Manhattan club.
The Olympic sport of handball, also known as team handball, is an indoor sport in which the idea is to throw a ball into a net.
It has been called hockey without ice or sticks, water polo without water, indoor soccer without kicking.

In 1984, they tied Ygoslavia for first place and lost the gold because of a tie-breaking rule (goal differential) that has since been abolished.

Raising the Odds
LEAD: WINNING MONEY, fame and status in Hollywood is never easy.
The quickest overnight success usually takes years.
But there are always a few actors, directors, producers - and even a few movie executives - who insist on making it harder.
They handicap themselves by making unconventional choices.
Those who depart from whatever formulas are in fashion may end up with terrible mistakes, but their movies won't be boring.

Practical Traveler; Cash or Credit? Saving Money On Bills Abroad
LEAD: WHAT'S the most economical way to pay your expenses on an overseas trip?
The answer is parallel to the old saw about success in the stock market: Buy low, sell high.
That is to say, when considering whether to convert dollars or traveler's checks into the local currency to buy things, or to use a credit card and pay later, your goal should be to pay at the moment when the dollar is worth the most in terms of the currency involved.

The Amazon's Kettle of Fish
LEAD: THE vast web of waterways that make up the Amazon - rivers, lakes, swamps, streams, waterfalls, bayous and igapos or flooded forest land - are, as Brazilians put it, peixoso or full of fish.
Fish is the principal source of protein for Indians living in the Amazon region as well as for the caboclos, descendants of a mixed population of Europeans and Indians who farm and fish in the more populated and accessible areas near Manaus, the capital city of the state of Amazonas.

LEAD:  SOUL OF THE TIGER: Searching for Nature's Answers in Exotic Southeast Asia.
By Jeffrey A. McNeely and Paul Spencer Wachtel. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The rural people of Southeast Asia believe that a close spiritual tie binds wildlife with humans.

LEAD: SOMETIMES you can't win.

LEAD: Scott Erney passed for 239 yards and 2 touchdowns, and Doug Kokoskie made a key fumble recovery today as Rutgers stunned 15th-ranked Michigan State, 17-13, in the opener for both teams today.


Rehnquist's Court: Tuning Out the White House
LEAD: CHIEF JUSTICE WILLIAM HUBBS REHNQUIST stared stonily out at the crowd in the marble-columned chamber from the Supreme Court's center chair, the chair in which Ronald Reagan had put him two years before.
It was June 29, the last day of the Court's 1987-88 term, and one decision remained to be handed down - the big one.


As Dollar Falls, Markets Rise in the East
LEAD: TWO years ago, Curtis Instruments in Mount Kisco began shipping its electronic instruments for forklift trucks to a Japanese customer.


Message to a Faltering Campaign
LEAD: Labor Day marks the beginning of the Presidential campaign.
The conventions are over, the lazy days of August past.


THE FROZEN ROOM
LEAD: I enjoyed John Stone's article ''The Frozen Room'' (Body and Mind: Aug. 7), but I strongly disagree with his statement that autopsies are less needed now that ''more accurate premortem diagnosis is possible.'' The data don't bear that out.
It is only through the autopsy that we test the accuracy of our premortem diagnosis, see the additional diagnoses that we didn't think of, and maintain our humility.


On Emergency Care For Injured Pets
LEAD: In the article ''Emergency Pet Care'' [ Aug. 21 ] , it was stated that the County Animal Clinic provided the only 24-hour emergency care in Westchester for injured pets.
This statement is far from accurate.
Dr.
Theodore Hoch and Dr.
Arnold Remson provide 24-hour emergency service at the Yorktown Animal Hospital, at 271 Veterans Road in Yorktown Heights.


Car Stereo Trolls for a Shapely Bass
LEAD: The unconventional Lord Berners (1883-1950) - quite an accomplished English composer - had the cows on his estate painted different colors for different seasons.
He also had a harpsichord built into his chauffeured Rolls-Royce, because he liked to have music on his travels.
No doubt he would have delighted in a modern car stereo system bringing him highway Haydn or


Civil Rights Groups Are Redefining Their Job
LEAD: THE National Association for the Advancement of Colored People still sometimes engages in battles that recall the height of the civil rights era.
Last week, for example, its Mississippi branch picketed and boycotted schools in Greenville in protest of policies it believes are racist.

LEAD:  THE PSYCHOLOGY OF EVERYDAY THINGS  By Donald A. Norman.
Illustrated. 257 pp.
New York:  Basic Books. $19.95.


The Games, From Archery to Yachting: Judo (Men's)
LEAD: The modern form of judo, consisting of throws, hold-downs, choking techniques and armlocks, was introduced in Japan in 1882 by Jigaro Kano, a student of jujitsu, the martial art that predated judo.
In 1964 judo became an Olympic sport in - appropriately - Tokyo.
The Japanese have dominated the sport until recently, when several European countries and South Korea began to produce formidable competitors.


Miss McGovern Becomes Bride In Connecticut
LEAD: Calvary Episcopal Church in Stonington, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Elizabeth Laird McGovern, the daughter of Mrs.
William B. Cutler of Stonington and James W. McGovern of New York, to Philip MacLaren Johnstone, a son of Rodney S. Johnstone of Stonington and Frances D. Johnstone of Worcester, Mass.


Pope Backs Sanctions for South Africa
LEAD: At the start of a five-nation tour of Africa, Pope John Paul II today offered his approval of the strict economic sanctions against South Africa now under consideration by the United States Congress.
He said such measures are morally acceptable as a last resort in the struggle against apartheid.


Staci M. Berman Weds J. R. Barber
LEAD: Staci M. Berman, a lawyer, and John Robert Barber, a corporate vice president in the syndicate department at Drexel Burnham Lambert, were married last evening at the Harvard Club in New York by Rabbi Gerald Zelizer.


A Different View Of 'Verona'
LEAD: Having seen and thoroughly enjoyed the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival's delightful production of ''Two Gentlemen of Verona,'' I was appalled at the half-hearted, ''damning with faint praise'' review by Alvin Klein (Theater: ''Fun and Games in Verona,'' Aug. 14).


Elizabeth Glazer, Lawyer, Marries
LEAD: Elizabeth Glazer and William George Montgomery, 1986 graduates of the Columbia University School of Law, were married yesterday in the Central Park Conservatory Garden by Judge Ruth Bader Ginsburg of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.


Headliners; A Complaint
LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission let the other shoe drop with a vengeance last week on Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and Michael Milken, the head of its junk bond department.
After a two-year investigation, both Mr.
Milken and the firm, one of the fastest growing investment houses on Wall Street, were named in a 184-page civil complaint.


Pressed at Home, British Unions Are Looking to Europe for Gains
LEAD: The battle lines have shifted in Britain's long internal struggle over its membership in the European Community.


CHINA PRODUCING NEW WAVES OF YOUNG DIVERS
LEAD: A GENERATION gap has formed in diving; the age of world-class talent has been dropping precipitously, so that suddenly veterans with two decades of training - and the maturity and grace that come with it - are finding themselves upset by tiny acrobats barely half their age.


Critic of the Sandinistas Quits Business Post
LEAD: After more than five years as the principal spokesman for private business in Nicaragua, Enrique Bolanos Geyer relinquished his post this week but promised to remain in Nicaragua and continue his anti-Sandinista militance.


The Joys and Hassles Of Remodeling a Home
LEAD: SOONER or later it seems to happen to most middle-class house owners.
The kitchen looks dingy and old-fashioned, the house gets smaller as the kids get bigger, and anyway, a lot of the neighbors seem to be adding new familiy rooms off the living room, sun rooms off the master bedroom and decks off the dining room.

But a consultant becoming a corporate chief?


Milestone Near for Coach
LEAD: Howard University doesn't even have to match its 9-1 won-lost record of last year for Coach Willie Jeffries to join the ranks of college football coaches with 100 victories this season.


RAIL LINE IS FINED OVER TOXIC WASTE
LEAD: New York State's top environmental official fined the Metro-North Commuter Railroad $100,000 today for illegally storing toxic wastes in a pond and in leaky barrels at its maintenance yard bordering the Hudson River at Croton-on-Hudson.

LEAD: WHEN Red Bank (N.J.) Regional High School began paying potential dropouts $5 a day to attend school regularly, some other students and teachers became upset.

Tiny Trees Pose Big Job for Keepers
LEAD: On a quiet wooded hilltop high above the bustle and the politicking, a handful of experts and devoted amateurs toil at an exacting task that began half a world away and many lifetimes ago - nurturing the National Bonsai Collection.


PERFORMANCE ART: Rooms for Experiment
LEAD: Gusto House is a feisty and atmospheric little club in the great ''Hey, kids, let's put on a show'' tradition of the Lower East Side.
It is housed in a loft that serves as home to Andy Kollmorgen, Daniel Cohen and Bill Callihan, writers and performers who founded the Gusto.
The first floor is cut away -originally to accommodate the printing presses of The Guardian, a radical newspaper - to reveal a stage below.

LEAD: Bobby Humphrey, the senior tailback, ran for 91 yards and a touchdown as Alabama opened its season with a 37-0 rout of Temple tonight.

THE WORLD: The Left's Loss; Where Liberation Was a Dream, Other Visions Ascend
LEAD: A QUARTER of a century ago, revolutionary Algeria, having wrenched its independence from France in a bloody armed struggle, was a heroic beacon to those fighting for freedom elsewhere.
As colonial empires in Africa and Asia were dismantled, third world leaders, often drawing inspiration from Marx, Lenin and Mao Zedong, vowed to create a New Man out of the cauldrons of national liberation struggles.


CALIFORNIA ABSTRACT
LEAD: Richard Diebenkorn is by general consent a painter much loved and not like any other, but he does not look like most people's idea of an artist.
If we were told that he was the head of the department of moral philosophy at an ancient and low-key university, we would have no trouble believing it.
He has the large, heavy-framed glasses, the well-cut tweed jackets (neither old nor new), the corduroy pants of standard cut, the capacious and comfortable shoes and a general air of continuous but soundless rumination.


Israel Imposes Curfew After Nablus Stabbing
LEAD: The Israeli Army imposed a curfew and other restrictions today in Nablus, the largest city in the occupied West Bank, after a Palestinian was fatally stabbed and troops reportedly shot and wounded 14 other Arabs.


Answering The Mail
LEAD:  Q. We have a ceramic tile floor in our bathroom consisting of one-inch square tiles.
The floor is even and in good condition, but it is not attractive, and so we would like to put down new ceramic tile.
Can we put new tile on top of the existing tile, or must we rip up all the old tile first?


The Games, From Archery to Yachting: Demonstration Sports - Judo (Women's)
LEAD: Women's judo became an Olympic sport largely through the efforts of a Brooklyn woman, Rusty Kanokogi, who, after her marriage to a Japanese judoka - a judo fighter - in 1964, became a crusader for women in the sport.
She organized the first world championships for women, a prerequisite for consideration on the Olympic agenda, in 1980 with 149 athletes from 27 countries.


Abundance of Seafood in Sayville
LEAD: LONG ISLAND should have a multitude of restaurants like Stevie Ray's Seafood Restaurant in Sayville.
This casual shopping-center spot has a selection of fish that puts some big-city seafood emporiums to shame.

Correction
LEAD: A subheading with an article in Business Day last Monday about the Village Gate nightclub misstated the club's hours.
It is not open all night; it closes at 3 A.M.

Reviews/Television; A Global Hookup on 13
LEAD: The video artist Nam June Paik returned to Channel 13 on Saturday for another of his ambitious exercises in live global hookups.
In 1984, Mr.
Paik produced ''Good Morning, Mr.
Orwell.'' In 1986, it was ''Bye Bye Kipling.'' This time, beginning at 10:30 in the morning, ''Wrap Around the World'' spent 90 minutes hopping among a total of 10 countries, including Ireland, Israel, China and the Soviet Union.

Shooter's Age Is Hot Target Of Discussion

Or so we are told.

Reading the fine print may take longer, but it should have more meaning.

LEAD: GOLF  United States Takes Team Event: The United States, led by Carol Thompson and Pearl Sinn, defeated Sweden by one stroke yesterday to win the women's World Amateur Golf Team Championship in Stockholm.

Washington Talk: Briefing; The First Constitution
LEAD: In the mid-16th century, five northeastern Indian tribes - Mohawk, Seneca, Onondaga, Oneida and Cayugaa - formed the Iroquois Confederacy, joined later by the Tuscarora tribe.
They adopted a constitution, reflecting concepts of checks and balances and separation of powers that impressed such later Americans as Washington, Franklin and other Founding Fathers.

In Judging Polls, What Counts Is When and How Who Is Asked What
LEAD: The high season for public opinion polls has arrived once again, and with it, quite a bit of public confusion about their meaning.
Expectations of a close Presidential contest in 1988, combined with a proliferation of polling organizations in recent years, all but guarantee that each week of the fall campaign will see the release of several new polls, telling somewhat different stories.

Editorial; The Naval Gap in the Persian Gulf
LEAD: The Navy played a critical role in ending the Iran-Iraq war.
By blocking Iran's move to intimidate Iraq's allies in the Persian Gulf, it reinforced the stalemate that led Iran to the negotiating table.
Over all, the Navy performed a difficult mission with distinction.
But there are lessons to be learned from the various mishaps.

Washington Talk: Briefing; A Touch of Classroom
LEAD: You can take the professor out of the classroom, but you can't take the classroom out of the professor.

Tax Watch; Small Businesses Face a Deadline
LEAD: OWNERS of certain closely held corporations may achieve significant tax savings if they liquidate and distribute their companies' assets to shareholders or make other basic changes in their companies' structure before the end of the year.
Jerry Joszef, tax manager for Laventhol &amp; Horwath in New York, calls this perhaps the single most important tax-planning consideration of 1988 for owners of small businesses.

Planning a Musical Pastiche By a Rarely Heard Master
LEAD: In a certain sense all of Marc Blitzstein's music is ''rarely heard,'' since he is one of those composers whose artistic credo and place in history are far better known than his actual scores.
But ''The Harpies'' and ''I've Got the Tune'' are true rarities, even for Blitzstein enthusiasts.
They are short dramatic works, composed in 1931 and 1937 respectively; the first is a satirical bit of neo-classicism in what has been described as a ''soft

LEAD: THE new trade agreement between the United States and Canada contains a surprise for those who consider themselves to be journalists: unless they have finished college and have practiced their craft for three years, they do not qualify for the privileged immigration status accorded other working professionals.

An Embattled Albert Goldman Defends His Book on John Lennon
LEAD: Albert Goldman's new biography, ''The Lives of John Lennon,'' which portrays the former Beatle as a violent, schizophrenic drug addict, leaped into the No. 2 position on the New York Times best-seller list shortly after publication.
But it has also generated considerable controversy and has been denounced as ''trash'' by two of the people who knew the former Beatle best - his widow, Yoko Ono, and his former bandmate and collaborator, Paul McCartney, both of whom have urged a boycott of the book.

Talking Business; with Batts of the Trucking Association; Trucking Safety And Deregulation
LEAD: The trucking industry has been adjusting to deregulation since 1980.
Truckers are finding it easier to enter the business and they have more pricing flexibility.
But rate bureaus, which are legally protected cartels, still exist to set prices.
Meanwhile, various state laws often blunt the intent of letting the industry operate more freely.


Gold Reaches 17-Month Low Before Recovering Slightly
LEAD: Gold prices ended little changed yesterday after falling during a volatile session to their lowest level in 17 months.


Financial-Aid Partnership Keeps Higher Education Within Reach
LEAD: To the Editor:


Yonkers Is Still the Governor's Problem
LEAD: A change of two votes in the Yonkers City Council finally brought the city into compliance with a Federal court order for low- and moderate-income housing.
That eases the crisis but does not end it: now the housing needs to be built.
The duty of Governor Cuomo and other state officials - who have kept a low profile - remains to take an active and public leadership role in carrying out the court's decision and in healing wounds.


On Horse Racing; Alysheba Returns to Site of a Big Failure
LEAD: When Alysheba goes to the post in the Woodward Stakes at Belmont Park Saturday, he will be returning to the site of his greatest failure and racing in a state that has brought him nothing but defeat and disrepute.


Market Place; Analysts Bullish On MCI Outlook
LEAD: SHARES of the MCI Communications Corporation rallied last week as investors' concerns eased about an expected ruling by the Federal Communications Commission on the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's plan to offer special discount prices to business customers.

U S Sprint To Cut Loss In 3d Period

NEWS SUMMARY
LEAD:  INTERNATIONAL A3-14  Charges that Iraq used poison gas against Kurdish rebels have prompted the United States and several allies to ask Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar to send a team to Iraq to investigate.
Page A1


For an Unpredictable Season, Clothes to Count On
LEAD: This is a between-times season, a period of transition when midsummer clothes are not quite substantial enough and fall clothes are a bit much.
What's the answer?
Well, the women pictured here have struck just the right note with coolly functional, classic clothing.
They've chosen to face the unpredictability of late summer with cardigan sweaters, double-breasted blazers, crisp white shirts (now long-sleeved, not short) and pleated slacks in familiar colors like beige, navy, camel, gray and black.


Record Sales at Jaguar
LEAD: The luxury car maker Jaguar P.L.C. said today that it had achieved a record monthly sales total in August,with 5,781 cars being sold worldwide.
This was nearly 11 percent higher in volume terms than the previous record month, August 1987.
A Jaguar spokeswoman said the group's sales in the first eight months climbed 8.4 percent, to 33,631 vehicles, from 31,018 in the 1987 period.


Apple Raises Prices for Its Macintosh Computer
LEAD: Responding to increased component costs and continued strong demand for its products, Apple Computer Inc. today announced major price increases on several models of the Macintosh personal computer.


Home Loan Banks To Set Bond Prices
LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Banks plan to price today a total of $3.6 billion in bonds consisting of a one-year floating-rate issue, a one-year fixed-rate issue, a three-year issue and a five-year security that features an optional principal redemption, meaning that it is callable after a specified period of time.


U.S. Issues Dip in Light Trading
LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds fell slightly in very light trading yesterday as market participants sold securities after a sharp rally in oil prices.


European Insurers To Form Alliance
LEAD: Two leading European insurance companies, Union des Assurances de Paris of France and the Sun Life Assurance Society P.L.C. of Britain, plan an alliance to expand their activities.
The deal is the latest among European companies leading up to 1992, when the European Community intends to abolish internal trade barriers.


India, Breaking Its Silence, Backs Government Opponents in Burma
LEAD: India has thrown its support behind the opposition forces in Burma and broken a monthlong silence on the uprising shaking its eastern neighbor.

LEAD: * John W. Bartelme named vice president of marketing of Holly Farms Foods Inc.


Retirement Rock
LEAD: Rock-and-roll began as a defiant, musical shaking of the fist at adult values, the older generation and the very notion of mortality.
Now, however, many of the early rock-and-rollers are facing old age and some who were present at the creation worry about retirement.

Bayer USA Plans Merger of 3 Units
LEAD: Bayer USA Inc., a unit of Bayer A.G. of West Germany, said it would merge its subsidiaries - Agfa-Gevaert Inc., the Compugraphic Corporation and the Matrix Corporation -into one corporation at the end of the year.
Bayer USA said the new subsidiary, the Agfa Corporation, would be based at Agfa-Gevaert's current headquarters in Ridgefield Park, N.J.


New Stadium Recommended
LEAD: The 60-year-old Chicago Stadium, home of the Chicago Blackhawks and the Chicago Bulls, is structurally sound, but it is obsolete because it doesn't have luxury boxes and should be replaced instead of refurbished, a consulting company has reported.


Reuters to Cut Work Force To Protect Financial Health
LEAD: The British news and electronic-market data publisher Reuters Holdings P.L.C. announced plans yesterday to reduce its work force in North America as part of an effort to protect the company's financial position in 1989.

Inmate Numbers at a Record
LEAD: The Federal and state prison population grew by 4 percent in the first six months of 1988 to a record 604,824 inmates, with female prisoners increasing at a far faster rate than males, the Government reports.

Japan Trade Surplus Cut
LEAD: Japan's trade surplus fell 3.9 percent in August from a year ago and 31 percent from the previous month, the Finance Ministry announced today.


Singapore's Currency
LEAD: Singapore has managed to convince the United States that there is no need for the Singapore dollar to appreciate, its Finance Minister, Richard Hu, said today. ''That pressure is now off of us,'' he said in an interview. ''I think they've accepted our arguments.'' Last year Washington strongly maintained that Singapore, Hong Kong, South Korea and Taiwan were keeping their currencies artificially low to improve their ability to compete.


Metro Datelines; Writ Is Left in Place Against Rail Union
LEAD: A Federal judge left a temporary restraining order in place yesterday against Metro-North Commuter Railroad track workers who staged a brief strike last week.


Reviews/Music; The Band Power Tools Blends Sounds of Jazz
LEAD: It's odd how contradictory impulses sometimes find themselves on the same bandstand.
Power Tools, a jazz-ish supergroup that includes Bill Frisell on guitar, Melvin Gibbs on bass and Ronald Shannon Jackson on drums, manages to blend the esthetics of jazz fusion with those of free improvisation.
The tension between clean predictability and noisy randomness serves as a good symbol of how the group works.


Drug-Related Fire Kills 2 Girls
LEAD: A house fire Sunday that killed an infant girl and her 4-year-old sister and critically injured a third child was caused by a drug-related firebombing, the authorities said today.
The attack was directed at a man who lived in the house, a police official said.
The dead children were identified as the infant, Erica Butler, 1 year old, and Ashley Evans, 4.


The Torme Story, as Told by Himself
LEAD: Almost every veteran entertainer can recall a moment when the normally unthinkable notion of quitting show business became an excruciating possibility.
For Mel Torme, who has earned belated recognition as one of the country's greatest pop-jazz singers, that moment arrived in 1956 with the advent of rock-and-roll.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q. What star or standard is used when rating the apparent brightness of stars?
A.
Ancient astronomers first relied on their own eyes in comparing the brightness of stars and classified them in six orders of magnitude, each about two and a half times as bright as the next.

Have Rap Concerts Become Inextricably Linked to Violence?
LEAD: In recent years, concerts of rap music have gained a reputation for violence.
A concert Saturday night at Nassau Coliseum on Long Island featuring Eric B. and Rakim, Kool Moe Dee, Doug E. Fresh and other rappers was the scene of robberies, stabbings and a homicide, violence that led to a ban on rap concerts at the coliseum.

Chip Industry Orders Dip

LEAD: Some designers explode on the fashion scene, their names becoming as familiar as those of movie stars, while others go along quietly year after year, making clothes for women who buy what they like and don't care about the name on the label.

Willis Grandy Lipscomb, Airline Executive, 87
LEAD: Willis Grandy Lipscomb, a former airline executive, died of cardiac arrest Friday at his home in Glen Cove, L.I.
He was 87 years old.


New Factor Affecting Climate: The Golf-Course Effect
LEAD: IN a world that is generally getting warmer, the asphalt and concrete of cities absorb and store radiant energy to send temperatures even higher in relation to nearby suburban and rural areas.
Cities are thus ''heat islands.'' By contrast, climatologists report, human development may also be responsible for the creation of ''cool islands.

Defeat Has Giants Still Wondering
LEAD: The atmosphere in the Giants' locker room was discernably downbeat this afternoon.
Most of the players remained off limits to reporters, either in the lounge area or the training room, while others dressed quietly in front of their stalls.


Review/Television; Toontown, Behind The Scenes
LEAD: The Roger Rabbit machine remains in high gear.
The highly successful film ''Who Framed Roger Rabbit'' is already being translated into lucrative marketing packages of toys, games and clothing logos.
Now, tonight at 8, CBS is offering ''Roger Rabbit and the Secrets of Toontown.'' It can be approached as either a behind-the-scenes documentary or an hourlong commercial for Roger and friends.


Students Protest in Panama
LEAD: The riot police fired tear gas at rock-throwing student demonstrators today, and dockworkers went on strike to protest Panama's economic crisis.

He demanded a list of names, promptly supplied by the White House personnel chief, Frederic V. Malek.
Later Mr.

Britain's Postal Strike Ends With a Settlement
LEAD: The British post office and the Union of Communication Workers agreed today to settle a strike that has stopped mail deliveries throughout most of the country, but postal officials said it would take a week or two to break up a backlog of 150 million letters and packages.


Chess
LEAD: The Brooklyn grandmaster Dmitry Gurevich triumphed over a strong field to win the United States Open Championship, held in Boston Aug. 7-20 at the Lafayette Swiss Hotel.


August Truck Sales Up
LEAD: August retail truck sales by franchised dealers of United States manufacturers rose 4.7 percent, to 375,302, from 358,365 in August 1987, the Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association said today.

Sears-Pirelli Tire
LEAD: Sears, Roebuck &amp; Company, the nation's largest retailer, said the Pirelli Tire Corporation, the United States subsidiary of Pirelli S.p.A. of Italy, would be the first manufacturer to have its tires sold at the retailer's tire centers.
Beginning Oct. 1, more that 400 Sears stores will offer a limited range of Pirelli's radial tires.

She was 89 years old.

BRIEFS
LEAD:  Debt


Radon: Where It Originates and What Can Be Done About It
LEAD: Radon is a colorless, odorless gas produced by the breakdown of uranium in the earth's crust.
In some houses, depending on factors such as internal air pressure and ventilation, the radioactive gas can build up, causing a severe long-term health hazard.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Big Changes For Knapp's Magazines
LEAD: KNAPP COMMUNICATIONS in Los Angeles has three national magazine titles, Architectural Digest, Bon Appetit and Home, and next month it is inaugurating major changes in the latter two publications.
The changes should make the magazines more attractive to a broader universe of advertisers.

32 Seats Open in New York Primary
LEAD: Since many legislative races in New York are decided long before the general election, learning to fend off a primary challenge is one of the first lessons of incumbency.
Judging from the ballots for this Thursday's primary race, most incumbents have learned this lesson well; although all 211 state legislators are up for election in November, there are primary contests in only 6 of the state's 61 state senate districts and 26 of its 150

LEAD: Mario Biaggi, who was one of New York City's most powerful Congressmen before his two convictions on racketeering and other Federal charges, remains an important factor in Thursday's Democratic primary for the House of Representatives seat he resigned in disgrace.

LEAD: The New York State Mortgage Agency is tentatively offering $175 million of homeowner mortgage revenue bonds through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs &amp; Company.


MAJOR RADON PERIL IS DECLARED BY U.S. IN CALL FOR TESTS
LEAD: Citing new evidence that the threat of cancer-causing radon is more widespread than previously recognized, the Government today issued a national public health advisory urging that most homes be tested for the naturally occurring radioactive gas.


Japan to Remove Sanctions Against North Korea
LEAD: Just four days before the start of the Olympic Games in Seoul, Japan said today that it would lift a package of sanctions against North Korea.
The sanctions were imposed earlier this year after the bombing last November of a South Korean jet in which 115 people died.


Lawrence Orton, 89, New York City Planner
LEAD: Lawrence M. Orton, a planner and former member of the New York City Planning Commission, died of Alzheimer's disease Saturday at the Hartwyck West Nursing Home in Cedar Grove, N.J.
He was 89 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: The major changes proposed for a housing desegregation plan, pivotal in persuading the City Council to approve the plan last weekend, were described today as deeply flawed and unlikely to gain approval.

Praising a Cheaper Chip
LEAD: IS the 80286, the chip used in AT-class personal computers, dead?
Is it a mistake to buy a PC based on the aging chip, now that the more-powerful 80386 chip is widely available and falling in price?


Mexicans Say They Can't Lose No Matter Who Wins the White House
LEAD: With their own presidential election now behind them, Mexicans are avidly following the American race, their interest intensified by the presence on both the Democratic and Republican tickets of candidates with unusually strong personal and business links to this country.

LEAD: ''I'm being tried by the media,'' said Gene Upshaw, the N.F.L.
Players Association executive director in response to an article in The Boston Globe on Sunday that quoted unidentified sources as saying Upshaw was being investigated for allegations of misusing union money.
The columnist Wil McDonough, quoting ''unidentified Washington sources,'' said Upshaw was reported to have received a salary increase with the knowlege of union board members, without revealing it and without paying taxes on it.


Voodoo Voters
LEAD: Everybody is being analyzed and criticized in this Presidential election except the voters and the non-voters, who are performing in their usual mysterious ways.
Vice President Bush is trying to persuade them by trickery and Governor Dukakis by evasion, and they do so for the simple reason that they think it works.

LEAD: The after-tax profits of manufacturing companies dropped to an average of 5.8 percent of sales between April and June from 6.3 percent in the first quarter, the Commerce Department said today.

U.S. Unseals Complaints In Ashland Papers Case
LEAD: The United States Attorney's Office in Manhattan yesterday unsealed complaints charging Orin E. Atkins, the former chairman of the Ashland Oil Inc., and Roy Furmark, a former consultant to Ashland, with the interstate transportation of stolen property.


Sports People; Rangers Sign Patrick
LEAD: The Rangers announced yesterday that they have signed James Patrick, a defenseman, to a multiyear contract.
Details of the contract were not released, but a source close to the Rangers said Patrick was getting a substantial raise.
The source, who requested anonymity, said that Lucien DeBlois would be ''signed, sealed and delivered'' today.


Buyback at Lotus
LEAD: The Lotus Development Corporation said it would repurchase up to 15 percent, or about 6.7 million shares, of its common stock outstanding.
The shares of the company, based in Cambridge, rose $1 each today, to $18, in over-the-counter trading.

By Design; Women's Clothes, Men's Fabrics
LEAD: A few years ago designers were on an androgynous kick, suggesting that women deck themselves in man-tailored clothes made of men's wear tweeds and flannels.
Then they did an about-face to sexy clothes in slinky jerseys, often with a smidgen of spandex to make the fabric cling to the body.
Clothes have now loosened up, and fashion appears to be entering a phase of offering feminine clothes in men's wear fabrics.


West German Hostage Is Released in Lebanon
LEAD: A West German hostage who had been held captive for 20 months was released in Moslem-controlled West Beirut on Monday, Lebanese and West German Embassy officials said today.


50 Savings Units Face U.S. Action
LEAD: Federal regulators expect to close or merge 50 more ailing savings and loan associations by the end of the month, M. Danny Wall, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, said today The action shows that the bank board is moving to deal more quickly with troubled savings institutions.
So far this year, 102 institutions have been closed or merged.


Verity Cautious On a Japan Pact
LEAD: Commerce Secretary C. William Verity Jr. said today that an American-Japanese free-trade agreement would not be the best way to solve the two countries' trade disputes.

Sports People; In Serious Condition
LEAD: Hospital officials said that Hank Stram was still in serious but stable condition at Methodist Hospital in Indianapolis yesterday after experiencing dizziness and being hospitalized on Saturday.
The 65-year-old Stram, former coach of the Kansas City Chiefs and the New Orleans Saints, had been scheduled to broadcast the Dallas Cowboys-Phoenix Cardinals game last night on CBS radio, but was replaced as color commentator by Bill Wilkerson, from KMOX in St.


What Drove the Kurds Out of Iraq?
LEAD: Although questions linger over accusations by Iraqi Kurdish dissidents of chemical-weapons attacks, what is clear after visits to several camps is that something happened inside Iraq that was sufficiently frightening to make the guerrillas and their families take flight.


Drought Has Eased, U.S. Reports; Small Food Price Rise Seen for '88
LEAD: The worst of the drought is over, the Agriculture Department said today, standing by its prediction that grain production will fall 31 percent this year.


First Pershing Missiles Leave Germany


Grand Met Files Complaint
LEAD: The European Community Commission will study a complaint by Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. about Pernod Ricard S.A.'s bid to win control of Irish Distillers Group P.L.C., an aide to the community's competition commissioner, Peter Sutherland, said today.


Control to Shift At Playboy
LEAD: Hugh M. Hefner, the founder, chairman and chief executive of Playboy Enterprises Inc., announced today that he would not run for re-election to the company's board of directors and would pass full command to his daughter.


Steel Production Rises
LEAD: Steel production rose to 1.921 million tons in the week ended Saturday, an increase of two-tenths of a percent from the previous week's 1.918 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
The industry's production amounted to 90.1 percent of capacity during the week, compared with 89.9 percent in the previous week.


Reviews/Music; 'Lo Schiavo,' a Rarity From Brazil
LEAD: Antonio Carlos Gomes was a Brazilian composer of considerable gifts who patterned his operatic idiom on that of middle-period Verdi and who had great successes in Italy and South America in the last quarter of the 19th century.
The Amato Opera Company's revival of ''Lo Schiavo'' (''The Slave''), which opened Saturday night at the Marymount Manhattan Theater, serves notice that the score well merits circulation.

LEAD: The pilot of a T.W.A. jet hijacked in 1985 testified in a West German court today that it was the defendant at the trial, Mohammed Ali Hamadei, who killed an American hostage and who was the more savage of two men who seized the plane.

Airline Experience A Key for DHL Chief
LEAD: Tapping a veteran of the airline and hotel industries, the DHL Corporation Inc. yesterday named Patrick Foley chairman, president and chief executive officer of DHL and its major subsidiary, DHL Airways.
He will also be chief executive for the Western Hemisphere of the DHL Worldwide Express network, effective immediately.


George Alpert, 90, Ex-President Of New Haven Line and a Lawyer
LEAD: George Alpert, the former president of the New York, New Haven &amp; Hartford Railroad Company, which served the northeast corridor until 1969, died of pneumonia Sunday at his home in Cohasset, Mass.
He was 90 years old.


Monsanto Stock Plunges on Copper-7 Case
LEAD: The price of the Monsanto Company's shares plunged $7.125 today, after a jury decision against the company's G.D.
Searle subsidiary over its Copper-7 intrauterine birth-control device.

Michael S. Dukakis.


RESTART APPROVED AT NUCLEAR PLANT
LEAD: Federal regulators have decided that the staff managing the Pilgrim nuclear power plant is ready to handle a restart under intense monitoring, an inspector said today.
The Government ordered the plant shut down in 1986.


Irish Seeking Rest Of First Maryland
LEAD: Allied Irish Banks P.L.C., the largest bank in Ireland, said it planned to take control of First Maryland Bancorp, the second-largest bank in Maryland.
Allied, which owns 49.7 percent of the company, said it was offering $340 million, or $35.25 a share, for the rest of the Baltimore-based banking group.

LEAD: Prospects for this year's grain harvest in the Soviet Union have deteriorated somewhat because of a drop in some yields, the Agriculture Department said today.

LEAD: Robert E. Bedingfield, a business and financial news reporter and editor with The New York Times for 23 years until his retirement in 1976, died of leukemia Sunday at Addison Gilbert Hospital in Gloucester, Mass.

U.S. Would Ease Bone Labeling Rule for Meat
LEAD: The Agriculture Department today proposed allowing hot-dogs, bologna and other prepared meats to contain as much as 10 percent ground bone and other meat remnants from a mechanical process without identifying the ingredients in product labels.

Calls of Concern Deluge Radon Experts
LEAD: Specialists in reducing household radon contamination said yesterday they had been overwhelmed by reaction to the Government's warning about the nationwide health effects of the gas.
While radon buildup is a serious health hazard, they said, it is easy to detect with do-it-yourself kits costing as little as $10, and in most cases fairly inexpensive to correct.

About Education
LEAD: More than three million children are starting kindergarten this month, and for many it will be the first opportunity to fail.
Depending on their district, it is estimated that 10 to 60 percent of those 5-year-olds will not be allowed to enter first grade a year from now.
They will remain in kindergarten for a second year.

Tomb in Peru Yields Stunning Pre-Inca Trove
LEAD: Archeologists in Peru have uncovered what they describe as the richest cache of pre-Columbian artifacts ever found in the Americas, a burial site containing finely crafted gold jewelry and implements and a wealth of ceramics.


A Modern Computer Chip Is Born
LEAD: In the early years, creating an integrated circuit began with a designer guiding a group of draftsmen who painstakingly mapped out a circuit on drafting paper.
Today, the draftsmen are gone and circuit designers sit in front of powerful engineering work stations.
They lay out and test a new chip design on a computer screen before storing the design on a special tape for transmission to a semiconductor factory.


Emerson Unit Sale
LEAD: The Whirlpool Corporation said it had agreed to acquire the Emerson Electric Company's dishwasher and trash compactor manufacturing business for $17.4 million.
Terms include a long-term agreement between Kitchenaid and Emerson for the continued supply of dishwashers to Emerson's In-Sink-Erator division.

Sometimes cooks erroneously equate fricassee with stew, but the two are fundamentally different.

3 Opposition Leaders in Burma Reject Election Plan
LEAD: Three prominent figures in the Burmese opposition told the Government today that they rejected its plan for free elections, in a sign of growing unity among the people who have stepped forward to lead the country's broad-based protest movement.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Monday about the ap-pointment of C. David Burgin as editor of The Houston Post and a correction in this space yesterday misstated Mr.
Burgin's previous positions at The Washington Star.
He was sports editor of The Star from 1971 to 1973, metropolitan editor until 1975 and assistant managing editor for weekends from 1976 to 1977.


2 More Engineers Sue Shuttle Rocket Maker
LEAD: Two former safety engineers working for Morton Thiokol Inc., maker of the booster rocket whose failure touched off the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger, have sued the company, charging that their work had been blocked and that important safety information about the shuttle booster rockets had been kept from the space agency.

St. Peter's Coach Out
LEAD: Jim Gilrain resigned yesterday as the football coach at St.
Peter's College just three days before the Peacocks' opener against Iona.
Gilrain did not give a reason for quitting, said Jim Hague, sports-information director at the school.
Three assistant coaches -Joe Dolinski, Bob Thomas and Ben Scholz - will run the team in the interim, Hague said, adding that a new coach will be appointed shortly.

Miss America Tops Ratings
LEAD: The Miss America Pageant drew 50 million to 55 million viewers for NBC on Saturday night to take No. 1 in the weekly television ratings, according to figures released today by the A. C. Nielsen Company.


Mideast Oil for Pretoria
LEAD: Seventeen cargoes of crude oil reached South Africa in the first eight months of 1987 from the Middle East despite an embargo by producers in that area, the Shipping Research Bureau, a Dutch private monitoring group, reported today.
It said the cargoes, totaling 4.3 million metric tons, represented 45 percent of South Africa's import needs in that period.

Hurricane Spurs Price Rise On Oil and Cotton Contracts
LEAD: Prices of cotton futures soared on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday on fears that heavy rains from Hurricane Gilbert could damage the Texas cotton crop.


Club Doors Are Open, But Women Draw Back
LEAD: FOR years after Muriel Siebert became the first woman to buy a seat on the New York Stock Exchange she could not find one in the dining rooms of many of New York's leading private clubs.
Yet Ms.
Siebert, who bought her seat in 1967 and who now runs a brokerage, recently turned down an invitation to join the University Club, which voted to admit women in August 1987.

Review/Architecture; Chicago Art Institute's Addition Retains Links to the Beaux-Arts
LEAD: As a building, the Art Institute of Chicago has always been an accurate barometer of this city's architectural temperature.
In 1893, as Chicago's rising ambitions found expression in the lavish architecture of the Beaux-Arts, the institute opened its main building, an elaborate Renaissance pile by Shepley, Rutan &amp; Coolidge, on Michigan Avenue.


Move to Stop Iraq
LEAD: The deafening silence of governments on Iraq's use of chemical weapons has provoked serious concern among defense experts.
A major thesis that emerged from the annual conference of the International Institute for Strategic Studies here last weekend was that wars in the third world are not likely to diminish if the East-West conflict wanes, but increase in scope and intensity as sophisticated weaponry spreads.

Wrong Radar - and Wrong Remedy
LEAD: The White House is using peculiarly self-defeating tactics in these final months of its strategic arms negotiations with Moscow.
It has threatened to declare an illegal Soviet radar to be a ''material breach'' of the Antiballistic Missile Treaty, the diplomatic prelude to scrapping the treaty.
It has even declared that it will sign no new treaties reducing nuclear arms until the radar is torn down.

LEAD: From welfare offices to municipal ambulance services, New York City is feeling the pinch of expanding demands and increasingly limited resources.

LEAD: The captain of the Delta Air Lines jet that crashed as it took off in Dallas two weeks ago told investigators yesterday that there was no sign of trouble until the airplane left the ground, Federal officials said.

LEAD: His doctors called it strictly routine, but for Hank Stram, the former N.F.L. coach and current broadcast analyst, the four-and-a-half-hour operation at Methodist Hospital in Indianapolis could have been a life-saver.
During the surgery, doctors replaced Stram's main heart valve with an artificial version.

LEAD: The Kroger Company, the nation's second-largest supermarket chain, said today that it was considering a $3.2 billion plan to restructure the company for the second time in two years in order to resist a possible takeover attempt by the Haft family of Maryland.

LEAD: South Korea announced today that it would exchange permanent missions with Hungary, the first step toward diplomatic relations with a Soviet bloc country since South Korea became a separate nation 40 years ago.

Skaggs Sets Retirement
LEAD: L. S. Skaggs, who built the American Stores Company from a regional drugstore chain into a 1,600-store supermarket and drug giant, will retire after a successor is found, the company announced today.
Mr.
Skaggs, who took over the Salt Lake City-based company in 1950 when his father died, recently reached the mandatory retirement age of 65, but has been asked by the board to remain while a committee seeks a new chairman and chief executive.


Campaign Trail; Kemp Taking Post With a Foundation
LEAD: Representative Jack F. Kemp, the conservative New York Republican who ran unsuccessfully this year for the Republican Presidential nomination, has decided to join the Heritage Foundation.
Mr.
Kemp, who announced that he would not seek re-election as a member of Congress, will serve as a ''distinguished fellow'' at the conservative Washington research group and focus on domestic and foreign policy.


Ex-Queens Homeowner Describes Death Threat
LEAD: A former Queens homeowner who had complained to the police about drug trafficking on his block testified yesterday that a man the authorities say is a drug dealer had threatened him and his family with death if they did not move from their house.

Dillon's father was the leader of the Pink Frogs, but he and Dillon's hippie mother died long before their son ever knew them.

LEAD: An independent review board overseeing the redesign of the space shuttle booster rockets said yesterday that it was satisfied that no safety concerns stood in the way of launching the first mission since the Challenger disaster two and a half years ago.

LEAD: The completion of new homes in the United States rose by three-tenths of a percent in July, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.51 million units, after a 3.6 percent increase in June, the Commerce Department said today.

LEAD: Howard G. Smith, 54 years old and a Newsweek man since 1964, has been named publisher of the magazine.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on July 26 about rapids rides at United States amusement parks named the ride builders incompletely.
Rapids rides have been built not only by the Swiss concern of Intamin but also by the Barr Engineering Company of Minneapolis and in some instances by park staff workers and local contractors.


Corrections
LEAD: A report in the TV Notes column on Monday about the first broadcast of ''CE Newsmagazine'' gave an incorrect date.
The program, which is weekly, will have its New York premiere on Oct. 16 at 6:30 P.M. on Channel 13.

Schools Feel Censorship Pressure
LEAD: Schools and libraries face growing pressure to censor the books children read, a report by the American Association of School Administrators says.


An Evolving Burma: Some Major Political Figures
LEAD:  U Ne Win: A 77-year-old former general who took power in a military coup in 1962 and instituted one-party military rule.
His philosophy, ''the Burmese way to socialism,'' was a blend of Marxism, Buddhism, isolationism and whimsy that led the country to economic ruin.
He resigned the Presidency in 1981 and the party chairmanship July 23, but is believed still to be controlling the Government.


Lauris Norstad Dies at 81; Former NATO Commander
LEAD: Gen.
Lauris Norstad, who was commander of United States and North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces in Europe during the Berlin crisis, died of cardiac arrest Monday at the Tucson (Ariz.) Medical Center.
He was 81 years old and lived in Tubac, 40 miles south of Tucson.

LEAD: United States car sales of Audi A.G., a subsidiary of Volkswagen A.G., are finally recovering from adverse publicity about reports of safety defects, Ferdinand Piech, its managing board chairman, said.

LEAD: Loren Schoenberg's big-band show at the Cat Club on Sunday night, a joint production of the Duke Ellington Society and the New York Swing Dance Society, should be judged on how well those on the packed dance floor moved.
The drummer Mel Lewis - helped along by the sturdy walking lines of Peter Washington on bass - propelled the band, throwing in rhythmic kicks to make things more lively.

Soviet Corn Purchase
LEAD: Moscow maintained its brisk buying pace of United States corn this week, purchasing 350,000 more metric tons of corn for shipment this fall, the United States Agriculture Department reported today.

LEAD: Citing sluggish sales at its Burger King subsidiary and a need to invest in that unit, the Pillsbury Company said yesterday that it expected operating results in the first fiscal quarter to be flat compared with the $57 million profit, or 66 cents a share, in the 1987 quarter.

Administration Rethinks Policy On Forest Fires
LEAD: President Reagan said today he had questions about the National Park Service's policy of allowing certain forest fires to burn unattended as it became clear that the Administration plans to reassess the policy.


Polaroid Sets Date On Shamrock Bid
LEAD: The Polaroid Corporation, target of an unsolicited $2.4 billion tender offer by the investor Roy E. Disney, said its directors plan to issue a recommendation on the $42-a-share bid by Sept. 22, when the company is obligated by law to respond.
Polaroid, based in Cambridge, Mass., also postponed the effective date of an anti-takeover measure until at least then.


Bridge
LEAD: The considerations that should guide a player to save at a high level are quite complex, and misjudgments are frequent.
Suppose you are the West player in the deal shown.
Would you bid six spades after the auction shown?
You are playing match-points, your partner has opened four spades and the opponents have found their way to six clubs.


A Game Of Kings Now Has Spokes
LEAD: THOSE who have always longed to fill an afternoon with a chukker or two but have lacked the necessary stable of polo ponies can now take heart.
Polo, the so-called game of kings, has begun galloping - no, make that pedaling - toward the masses.

My Lai Figure Dies a Drifter In a Shooting
LEAD: Robert W. T'Souvas died homeless at the age of 39 years, shot in the head after reportedly quarreling over a bottle of vodka under a downtown bridge.


Lloyd M. H. Francke, A Times Executive, 61
LEAD: Lloyd Mortimer Hastings Francke, director of information sales and services at The New York Times, died of cancer of the bladder yesterday at the New York University Medical Center.
He was 61 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Applied Data Deal
LEAD: Computer Associates International Inc. said it had agreed to acquire Applied Data Research Inc. from the American Information Technologies Corporation for $170 million.
Applied Data, which makes software for data base management and application development systems, had revenues of about $170 million in 1987.


Major Battles Reported in Salvador's North
LEAD: Heavy fighting was reported today in rebel strongholds in northern areas of El Salvador, a military spokesman said.


Eating Well
LEAD: A CLASSIC school lunch -fried chicken, mashed potatoes with gravy, steamed vegetables, cheese biscuits with butter and a peach half with whipped cream - has about as much to do with healthful eating as does the typical fare at fast-food outlets.


Study Shows Teachers Still Feel Left Out on Policy
LEAD: Public school teachers say they are substantially involved in choosing textbooks and instructional materials and in shaping the curriculum but are otherwise excluded from most critical decisions on school policy, a new study has found.


Some Major Changes For Partners &amp; Shevack
LEAD: Calvillo, Shevack &amp; Partners, the Mickelberry Corporation subsidiary that lost Ricardo C. Calvillo last June, has changed its name to Partners &amp; Shevack and is working on a deal to make a portion of the agency's equity available to its work force.


BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:  COMPANIES  Kroger is considering a $3.2 billion restructuring plan in order to resist a possible takeover attempt by the Haft family of Maryland.
The plan would involve payment of a special $40 dividend for each of Kroger's 78.6 million shares of common stock, at a cost of more than $3.1 billion.


Denver Symphony Gets Bankruptcy Reprieve
LEAD: The Denver Symphony, faced last Friday with the prospect of bankruptcy proceedings, has announced a 21-day reprieve during which state, city, business and cultural groups will try to meet a projected shortfall of $655,000 in the orchestra's budget.


Boxing Notebook; In the Tyson Camp, Truce Is Tenuous
LEAD: Two days before Mike Tyson drove into a tree in Catskill, N.Y., Ruth Roper, the mother of Robin Givens, the heavyweight champion's wife, was talking of a thaw in her relationship with Tyson's manager, Bill Cayton.


Checking Out
LEAD: After spending his first season in jail and finding himself on the third string at the start of his third season, Barry Word has retired as a running back for the New Orleans Saints.
The 24-year-old Word, who won extensive praise from Coach Jim Mora for his work in training camp, said he was disappointed that he had not carried the ball once in the Saints' first two games.


E.P.A. Issues New Rules on Underground Tanks
LEAD: The Environmental Protection Agency today issued what it called ''comprehensive and stringent'' rules for protecting water supplies from leaks of petroleum and other toxic substances from underground storage tanks.


Dallas Kicker Is Cut
LEAD: Luis Zendejas, who kicked a 47-yard field goal in a 17-14 National Football League victory over the Phoenix Cardinals Monday night, was released by the Dallas Cowboys and Roger Ruzek was activated.
Ruzek made 22 of 25 field goals last season but got into a contract dispute and was held out of the first two weeks of the season.

LEAD: New York City's decision to empty a large and notorious welfare hotel has, paradoxically, brought as much fear as joy to the families who live there.

LEAD: Poland's Communist leaders and the outlawed Solidarity union appeared deadlocked today in efforts to revive direct talks, after the Government spokesman accused the union of ''pressure tactics and reluctance to compromise.''

LEAD: The price of the Monsanto Company's shares plunged for a second day in response to concerns about its liability for the Copper-7 intrauterine birth-control device, manufactured by its G. D. Searle &amp; Company subsidiary.

LEAD: Central bankers in the European Community took the first steps today toward a European monetary union, but some said creation of a common currency or a European central bank remained distant goals.

LEAD: EVEN as South Korea modernizes and the people adopt Western dining habits - even with Wendy's and Burger Kings dotting Seoul - the native cuisine remains intact.
Visitors to the Olympic Games, which open in Seoul Friday, will find that the dishes served in restaurants and homes are based on recipes hundreds of years old, the cuisine of a culture that dates back some 5,000 years.
