Long Way From Home
LEAD: Joseph F. Salgado is being sworn in as Deputy Secretary of Energy today.
A ho-hum event, you say?
He is taking the oath of office while working in the Soviet Union, monitoring an underground nuclear explosion at Semipalatinsk, the Soviet nuclear testing site.
Troy Wade, the acting Assistant Secretary of Energy for Defense Programs, was deputized to perform the swearing in.

LEAD: The Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, William S. Sessions, announced today that he had suspended three bureau employees and was censuring three others for their involvement in a domestic surveillance campaign aimed at opponents of the Reagan Administration's policies in Central America.

The underwriters are led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

LEAD: A small band of radical students tried to attack runners carrying the Olympic torch Wednesday but were held back by riot policemen.
It was the first time Korean students have directly made a target of any Olympic-related event.

He was 53 years old and a resident of nearby Tustin.

LEAD: The Mets, who seem to have more pitching than they know what to do with, got even more of it last night when Sid Fernandez pitched them to a 3-1 victory over the Chicago Cubs in Shea Stadium.

LEAD: Palestinians stabbed to death an Arab man suspected of collaborating with the Israelis and dumped his pajama-clad body on a West Bank street today, the police and Arab reports said.


Texaco Asset Sales To Total $6 Billion
LEAD: Texaco Inc.'s planned sale of assets should yield more than $6 billion, a figure that would exceed the $5.6 billion required by the company's bankruptcy reorganization plan, its chief executive, James Kinnear, told securities analysts here.
Previously the company had said the restructuring would be worth more than $5 billion.


Cuomo and Kean Join in Sludge Plan
LEAD: New York City and other localities that dump sludge in the ocean would be forced to set aside money to look for alternative dumping sites under a proposal announced jointly yesterday by the Governors of New York and New Jersey.
The proposal calls for a ban on ocean dumping by 1991.

LIFE IN THE 30'S
LEAD: JUST eight weeks ago the cat found a dark place and gave birth to her first litter: three pathetic miniatures of herself, their eyes sealed shut, their voices weak falsettos.
For two weeks the new mother was manic, moving them from place to place because of imagined dangers.
For two weeks more she was solicitous, slipping out for a meal and returning immediately to the writhing pile of fur and blunt faces, grooming them even when they were clean.


Dorothy S. Gerber, 84; Developed Baby Food
LEAD: Dorothy Scott Gerber, the widow of Daniel F. Gerber, who founded the Gerber Products Company, died in her sleep Sunday at her home in Fremont, Mich., according to a company spokesman.
She was 84 years old.


Dukakis Outlines Military Policy And Offers a Challenge to Soviets
LEAD: Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis outlined his military policy today in the greatest detail he has yet offered, endorsing three nuclear arms programs and calling for a major buildup of conventional forces.
He also went beyond Reagan Administration proposals and challenged the Soviet Union to eliminate its biggest and most deadly nuclear missiles.

LEAD: Yasir Arafat startled a news conference today by wishing everyone ''Shana Tova, Shana Tova,'' the traditional Hebrew greeting for the Jewish New Year.

LEAD: In Coral Gables, Fla., the topic of conversation is known as the P-word.

Satellite Rocket Fails in Space
LEAD: An American communications satellite launched last week by Western Europe's Ariane rocket has failed to reach its proper orbit, but flight controllers said Tuesday that there was still hope that small steering rockets might be able to boost it into a working orbit.


Sports People; Bullets Sign Price
LEAD: The Washington Bullets signed a Cleveland Cavaliers' guard, Mark Price, and a veteran free-agent forward, Charles Jones.
Price was signed to an offer sheet, the terms of which were not disclosed.
The Cavaliers have 15 days to match Washington's offer to Price, 24 years old, who was Cleveland's third-leading scorer last season with an average of 16 points a game.

Yesterday, the 57-year-old McKeon accepted a three-year contract as the manager.

LEAD: Reconnaissance flights over remote parts of Jamaica brought back reports today indicating that a hurricane left widespread devastation throughout the country and that 80 percent of the homes on the island had lost their roofs.

Norway Oil Output Cut
LEAD: Norway's North Sea oil production dropped to 1.06 million barrels a day in August from 1.17 million barrels in July because of maintenance work on a production platform, a survey found.
Norway is Western Europe's biggest oil producer after Britain.
Although it is not a member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, Norway has agreed to 7.5 percent cutbacks since February 1987 in support of OPEC's efforts to stabilize prices by limiting supply.

Atlanta Told to Return Files
LEAD: Thousands of documents relating to the slayings of 29 black children in Atlanta must be returned to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, a Federal district judge has ruled.

The Department of Housing and Urban Development, which sold the home to recoup losses, even contributed $3,000 in closing costs.

LEAD: Silicon Graphics Inc., a manufacturer of powerful computer work stations, is expected to announce an arrangement on Friday under which the International Business Machines Corporation would license its technology for making computers whose strength is graphics.


Stram Feeling Better
LEAD: Hank Stram, a former coach of the Kansas City Chiefs, was moved yesterday from the cardiovascular critical care unit to a regular room at Methodist Hospital in Indianapolis. ''He is up and walking around,'' said Jon White, a hospital spokesman.
Stram, 65 years old, underwent open-heart surgery Tuesday to correct a narrowing of the aortic valve.

LEAD:  Shows, Nature, Museums  ''THE SECRET OF THE CARDBOARD ROCKET,'' a sky show about the adventures of two youngsters, for children 6 to 9 years old, noon tomorrow, at the American Museum-Hayden Planetarium, Central Park West at 81st Street.

Michael S. Dukakis's chartered plane headed westward yesterday from Boston, the Democratic candidate wandered up the aisle dressed in khaki pants and a red sweater.

LEAD: The Zayre Corporation said yesterday that it would sell its Zayre discount department stores to its nearest competitor, Ames Department Stores Inc.

LEAD: Governor Cuomo yesterday named a special eight-member state panel to help put a court-ordered housing desegregation plan into effect in Yonkers.

LEAD: The Raiders were stretching before practice today, a line of silver and black, bending knees and backs and chanting cadences between grunts.
Three players, all quarterbacks, stood near the front in bright red jerseys.
Steve Beuerlein was on the left.
Vince Evans was on the right.
Jay Schroeder was in the middle.


Washington Talk: Briefing; Hispanic Gains
LEAD: Not only is the Hispanic population increasing in the United States, but the number of elected Hispanic officials also continues to rise, albeit at a much slower pace.
The number of Hispanic people elected to public office increased 1.3 percent from last year to a total of 3,360, the head of the National Association of Latino Elected and Appointed Officials reported this week.


Appeal Filed in Detroit Deal
LEAD: Opponents of the proposed partial merger of two Detroit newspapers asked an appeals court today to delay the business arrangement until the courts can hold a full hearing on the issue.

LEAD: Patients at Cook County Hospital would have the right to refuse to be treated by workers who carry the AIDS virus under a proposal that has been criticized by AIDS experts and the American Medical Association as misinformed and unnecessary.

Beef From Mr. Dukakis on Defense
LEAD: Michael Dukakis has finally gone beyond campaign oratory on national security issues.
Sure, he has to if he's to counter George Bush's campaign to portray him as weak.
Sure, some of his offerings are confusing, even questionable.
But encouragingly, the Democratic candidate is engaging the subject seriously, and trying to bridge the gap between liberal ends and hard-headed means.

LEAD: Federal investigators today ruled out engine failure as the primary cause of the crash of a Delta Air Lines jetliner last month, saying there was no evidence of a mechanical breakdown before the crash.

'WASP' Stings. It Isn't Amusing.
LEAD: It's past time that the media quit using the jeering word ''WASP'' in their pages.
This ethnic epithet is often employed in print (and conversation) with a prejudice that is intended to sting.
It's a cudgel, though some people do express with it only a sort of playful irony or sloppy abbreviation without sneering intent, as has been the case with similar sobriquets such as ''Mick,'' ''Wop,'' ''Spick,'' ''Kike'' ''Bohunk,'' etc.

Ashe Improving
LEAD: After being hospitalized for a week, Arthur Ashe was released from New York Hospital yesterday.
The former tennis champion underwent tests last week for a condition his agent described as a severe bacterial infection in his head.
The infection put pressure on nerves, causing numbness in Ashe's arm, according to Ted Ewanciw, a spokesman for ProServ, Ashe's agent.

5,000-Cruzado Banknote
LEAD: Brazil's central bank introduced a 5,000-cruzado banknote today in an effort to keep money denominations in line with skyrocketing inflation.
The new bill, worth $16 at the official exchange rate, replaces the 1,000-cruzado note as the country's highest-value banknote.
Independent economists predict that consumer prices will rise by 800 percent this year.


Review/Film; A Loner Rebels in Coal Country
LEAD: The hero of ''The Prince of Pennsylvania'' is a sullen teen-age boy named Rupert Marshetta (Keanu Reeves), who is locked in battle with his father.
Already, there's a problem: the father, a stubborn, difficult, long-suffering coal miner named Gary Marshetta (Fred Ward), is nevertheless a great deal more likable than his loutish and self-involved son.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  GOLF  Two Share Lead: David Frost and Don Hammond, who together have only one victory in a combined 10 years on the PGA Tour, shot 67's yesterday to share the first-round lead in the $600,000 Bank of Boston Classic in Sutton, Mass.
Frost, 14th on this year's money list with $436,140 but seeking his first Tour victory, shot 34,33-67 over the 7,110-yard Pleasant Valley Country Club course.

Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts began a campaign swing through the West today with a careful mix of politics and photo opportunities.


Money Fund Assets Fall
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 452 money market mutual funds decreased by $347.4 million, to $266.58 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 126 institutional funds fell $166.4 million, to $68.56 billion, while the 223 general purpose funds fell $53.5 million, to $84.92 billion, and the 103 broker-dealer funds fell $127.5 billion, to $113.1 billion.

LEAD: Few books are so successful that they have 10 printings, but New York Is Book Country - the once-a-year, outdoor anthology of fact, fiction and fun attended by a quarter-million strolling book lovers - goes into its 10th edition this weekend.

Savings Unit Takeover
LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today that it had arranged the acquisition of the insolvent Coosa Federal Savings and Loan Association of Gadsden, Ala., by the Birmingham-based Secor Savings Bank.
The transaction brought to 103 the number of troubled savings units dealt with this year, 85 of them through federally assisted acquisitions or mergers, the bank board said.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on Wednesday about an American decision to release some overdue payments to the United Nations misidentified the Administration under which Daniel Patrick Moynihan served as American representative at the United Nations.
It was the Ford Administration.

BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:  COMPANIES  Hospital Corporation of America may receive a buyout offer of $47 a share from its senior executives.
The proposal is dependent on the executives' ability to secure financing and would be worth $3.3 billion.
The deal, which would be subject to approval by the company's outside directors, reflects the impact of changes in Federal health-care policies on the hospital industry.


Henry C. Wallich, 74, Dies; Served on Federal Reserve
LEAD: Henry C. Wallich, a longtime member of the Federal Reserve Board and its leading authority on international finance, died today at George Washington University Hospital.
He was 74 years old and had been in failing health since undergoing surgery for a brain tumor in 1985.

To Our Readers
LEAD: Starting on Monday, the suggested newsstand price of The Times on weekdays within 75 miles of New York City, and on all of Long Island, will be increased to 35 cents.
The change is prompted by rising production costs, including an increase in the price of paper.
The newspaper's Sunday price will not change, nor will its weekday price outside the 75-mile area.

Dent and N.F.L. Agree
LEAD: Richard Dent, the Chicago Bears defensive end who has been fighting a 30-day suspension by the National Football League for refusing to submit to a drug test, has reached an agreement with the league, and his suspension has been lifted.
Dent will play Sunday against the Minnesota Vikings.
He was suspended last week, but was allowed to play in the Bears' 17-13 victory over Indianapolis after Steve Zucker, his attorney, went to court to challenge the suspension.

Cadiz, Not Dundee, To Get Ford Plant
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said it would build a $68 million electronics plant near Cadiz, Spain, instead of Dundee, Scotland, where labor uproar killed the project.
The Spanish Government will subsidize roughly one-third of the cost of the plant, which will employ about 350 people.
Construction will begin soon, and production will begin in 1990.

LEAD: The National Collegiate Athletic Association Infractions Committee will review the case against the Kansas basketball program on Sept. 30, sources said today.
Kansas won the national championship in basketball last spring.

Family Decries the Beating of a Union Leader
LEAD: The family and friends of Dolores Huerta, the co-founder of the United Farm Workers, expressed outrage today over what they said was her severe beating by the police.
She suffered broken ribs and the loss of her spleen.

LEAD: Protein Design Labs Inc., a closely held biotechnology company based in Palo Alto, Calif., said today that Shirley Lui Clayton would join the company on Oct. 17 as chief financial officer.
Ms.
Clayton, who is 50 years old , has been vice president and treasurer for Genentech Inc., which she joined in 1981.

A Batus Approval
LEAD: Batus Inc., a unit of Britain's B.A.T.
Industries, received approval from the Idaho Insurance Department for its proposed acquisition of Farmers Group Inc.
Although Farmers agreed in August to be acquired by Batus for $5.2 billion, the transaction is subject to approval by nine states in which the insurance company operates.

LEAD: American and Soviet tracking aircraft flying inside the vortex of Hurricane Gilbert in recent days have found themselves so close at times that they were forced yesterday to begin coordinating flight paths as they whirled through thestorm.

Review/Art; A Penchant for the Past
LEAD: Anyone who spends much time going to galleries finds that exhibitions often group themselves into loosely related clusters.
It can't be helped.
The show of one artist will make you think of the show of another artist; soon you are putting together one and one, and then two and two -and then taking them apart again to see if they really fit.

LEAD: On the heels of an announcement that Young &amp; Rubicam has signed a joint venture agreement with a Soviet Government ad agency to operate in Moscow, Ogilvy &amp; Mather Worldwide has reported that it too has signed a letter of intent for a joint venture in that city.


For Russians, Food Buying Is No Bargain
LEAD: The first aisle of the best grocery store in Klavdiya M. Petrova's neighborhood today offers scrawny chickens, two grades of bony soup beef, some Bulgarian fruit juices, mayonnaise, pickles, cottage cheese, thin yogurt, cherry jam and jars of Rumanian peas.
The fresh produce: garlic, celery greens, apples and green peppers.

LEAD: Ending the first visit by an Israeli Prime Minister to one of the Communist countries that broke relations with Israel in 1967, Yitzhak Shamir said here today that he had obtained the Hungarian leader's promise to ask for better treatment for Soviet Jews.

LEAD: In May 1986, Carnegie Hall closed its doors for a renovation that took 30 weeks and cost $50 million.

His first full-scale American tour since 1984 - a European tour in 1987 was filmed as ''Sign o' the Times'' -charges through a catalogue of songs, styles, attitudes, messages and feats.

'Rasputin' Premiere
LEAD: The New York City Opera is to give the world premiere of Jay Riese's ''Rasputin'' tomorrow evening at 8 o'clock at the New York State Theater.
Christopher Keene will conduct the performance, which is to be sung in English.
The cast includes John Cheek in the title role, Margaret Cusack as Alexandra, Jon Garrison as Nicholas and Henry Price as Prince Felix Yusupov.

LEAD: The American Ambassador to Panama has recommended the elimination of about half of the 160 diplomatic posts at the embassy in Panama City because of concern for their safety, State Department officials said today.

LEAD: Crude oil prices, which soared 84 cents a barrel on Wednesday in very heavy trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, fell 50 cents yesterday.
West Texas Intermediate, the American benchmark crude oil, was trading at $14.90 a barrel for delivery next month.

Two recent exhibitions are typical.

Becker Staying Home
LEAD: Boris Becker will not attend the Olympic Games in South Korea after all, chiefly because some other West German athletes criticized his plans to visit Seoul as a nonparticipant.

Corrections
LEAD: The Eating Well column in The Living Section on Wednesday incorrectly characterized the position of the United States Department of Agriculture on the Federal Dietary Guidelines.
As stated elsewhere in the column, the Agriculture Department has said school lunches should be consistent with the guidelines while questioning whether those guidelines are appropriate for children.


Global Pop, Done in the Soviet Style
LEAD: The Iron Curtain isn't soundproof.
Music makes the East-West or West-East crossing, depending on the vagaries of international diplomacy and commerce, and the not quite untrammeled traffic in culture makes every trip different.
While some musicians pick up ideas from the other side, others ignore them.


G.A.O. Lifts Bailout Estimates by 25%
LEAD: The General Accounting Office said today that it would cost at least 25 percent more than it had estimated to clean up the nation's savings industry.


Odd Doings As 'Mama Turns 100'
''Mama Turns 100'' was shown as part of the 1980 New Spanish Cinema Festival.
Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times Jan. 11, 1980.
The film, in Spanish with English subtitles, opens today at the Bleecker Street Cinema, at La Guardia Place.
The big, airy old country house is not especially handsome but it occupies an imposing site atop a high hill and is clearly in charge of all that it surveys.
In the distance, one sees the blue silhouette of a modern city that, as yet, has not imposed its needs on the people living here.
The family inside the house is not aristocratic but representative of the rich, upper bourgeoisie whose manners and morals have for decades dominated the life of Spain.
Time, as it always is in such fiction, is running out.

LEAD: A suit charging that the Shubert Organization, Broadway's largest theater owner, has had an illegal monopoly on theater-party sales of tickets to the musical ''Phantom of the Opera'' has been dismissed in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

LEAD: American Brands Inc. said that Brooke Partners L.P., which is controlled by Bennett S. Lebow, had filed for Federal antitrust clearance to purchase up to 50 percent of American Brands' voting stock.
The size of Mr.
Lebow's holding in American Brands has not been disclosed.
He is required to notify the Securities and Exchange Commission if his stake reaches 5 percent.

Joseph Gerard, a French missionary who spent 60 years among the Zulu and Basotho people before he died in 1914.

LEAD: Retail sales dropped two-tenths of 1 percent in August, the Commerce Department reported yesterday.

Kroger Holders File 2 Lawsuits
LEAD: Three shareholders of the Kroger Company have sued to block the company's proposed $3.8 billion restructuring aimed at fending off hostile takeovers of the nation's largest supermarket chain.


All Rookies Face Drug Tests in Camp
LEAD: The National Basketball Association and its players union have agreed to test all rookies for drug use during training camps, which begin on Oct. 7.
Under the new agreement, a rookie who tests positive for heroin or cocaine use would be suspended for a year without pay.


Korean War Memorial Will Rise on the Mall
LEAD: A memorial honoring the 5.7 million Americans who served in the Korean War will be placed on the Mall in Washington, near the Lincoln Memorial and opposite the Vietnam Memorial.


Man Pleads Guilty on Cable TV Piracy Ring
LEAD: A man whom Federal officials say ran the biggest cable television piracy ring in the nation and defrauded cable companies of almost $5 million in potential fees pleaded guilty today to mail fraud and income tax evasion.

LEAD: Day in and day out, it is the same trying routine for Ali A. Treiki, chief representative to the United Nations from Libya - forever complaining, explaining and dogmatically disdaining everything from the latest accusation of terrorism to American attacks, verbal and otherwise.
Moreover, it is 5,000 miles from his dusty home.

In S.I. Court, Each Is Fined To Fit Means
LEAD: In the first such organized experiment in this country, the Staten Island Criminal Court has begun a yearlong project in which those convicted of misdemeanors and violations are fined according to their ability to pay.

LEAD: Boris Tabakoff, scientific director at the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism in Bethesda, Md., received a patent this week for a test that identifies people predisposed to alcohol abuse.

Michael S. Dukakis, the Democratic Presidential nominee, had appointed three ''anti-Israeli, pro-Palestinian'' members to the party's ruling body and challenged him to dismiss them.


Bank Robber Takes $60,000
LEAD: A robber brandishing a handgun held up a bank in Long Island City, Queens, yesterday and escaped with $60,000 cash, the police said.
At about 11 A.M., the robber - wearing a grey suit, black tie and a stocking mask - ordered tellers at the European-American Savings Bank at 35-01 Northern Boulevard to fill a plastic bag with cash.

LEAD: Britain today announced its highest annual inflation rate in almost three years.

LEAD: Carlos Santana's show at Pier 84 on Wednesday night was filled with sounds and ideas that wafted in from the past.
Mr.
Santana's guitar tone, tightly distorted, soared above the juicy sounds of Gregg Rolie's organ; combined, they make up a classic sound of the 1960's.
And Mr.
Santana's eclecticism, mixing rock, latin and jazz - and the mainstream popularity to go with it - unfortunately also seemed like something from an earlier, more optimistic age.

A New Method to Kill Salmonella in Poultry
LEAD: The Monsanto Company received a patent this week for a new approach to killing salmonella bacteria in poultry.
Salmonella causes nausea, vomiting and other flu-like symptoms, and more serious illness in people with weakened immune systems.

LEAD: The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia has ordered The Detroit News and The Detroit Free Press to delay their partial merger, which could have begun as early as this weekend, as the judges consider whether the deal should be scrapped altogether.


Mechanical CPR Is Said To Improve Blood Flow
LEAD: Dr.
Ralph D. Lach, a cardiologist in Columbus, Ohio, has invented a mechanical device that provides cardiopulmonary resuscitation, or CPR, to victims of heart attacks.
According to the patent, the device is safer and more effective than conventional CPR, in which a hand is pressed against the victim's chest every few seconds to pump blood through the body.

LEAD: The Federal Communications Commission said yesterday that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company could temporarily match the special discounts on long-distance rates that its smaller rivals offer to large business customers.

To Our Readers
LEAD: Starting on Monday, the suggested newsstand price of The Times on weekdays within 75 miles of New York City, and on all of Long Island, will be increased to 35 cents.
The change is prompted by rising production costs, including an increase in the price of paper.
The newspaper's Sunday price will not change, nor will its weekday price outside the 75-mile area.

41 Homeless to Get $500 Each
LEAD: In a surprise move, the City of Los Angeles has agreed to pay $500 each to 41 homeless people whose belongings were destroyed by the police.
Lawyers filed damage claims against the city in June after the police raided an encampment of homeless people near City Hall.
The possessions of about 50 residents who were away from the camp were removed and buried in a dump.


Doctor Recalls Deaver As 'Alert' in Hospital
LEAD: A doctor who treated Michael K. Deaver for alcoholism in 1985 said that the former aide to President Reagan ''remained quite alert'' in the hospital despite heavy sedation.

Sir Donald Albery Is Dead at 74; Influential British Stage Director
LEAD: Sir Donald Albery, a London theater manager who encouraged the playwrights Samuel Beckett, John Osborne and Brendan Behan, died Wednesday at his home in Monte Carlo, his family reported.
He was 74 years old.


Samuel Burman, 87, A Former Prosecutor
LEAD: Samuel Seidel Burman, a lawyer and former assistant United States attorney in Manhattan, died of emphysema Wednesday at his home in Los Angeles.
He was 87 years old.
Mr.
Burman, who was born in Pinsk, in what is now the Soviet Union, and came to the United States in 1905, received his law degree from New York Law School in 1923.

LEAD: The growth in United States exports will probably slow as many industries reach production capacity, Clayton K. Yeutter, the United States trade representative, said today.

LEAD: THERE is a growing need for long-term health care in America, but all too little provision for it, the experts warn.

The exhibition surveys Giacometti's 40-year career with 51 sculptures, 30 paintings and 24 drawings.

LEAD: The House of Representatives passed three amendments to a major drug bill today, including one that budgets $125 million for grants to states that suspend the drivers' licenses of people arrested on charges of drunken driving after a breath or blood test.

LEAD: ''Seven Hours to Judgment,'' directed by and starring Beau Bridges, is a dim suspense drama about a Crazy Eddie-type of Manhattan appliance merchant who goes certifiably crazy when his wife is murdered by a gang of black and Hispanic muggers.
To get even, he kidnaps the judge who, for legal reasons, was forced to free the criminals, and the judge's wife.

LEAD: If your region is vulnerable to hurricanes, review plans to protect yourself and your property.

LEAD: The news that Yale University has received $1 million from an alumnus to endow the position of football coach invites irreverent speculation.
What's next, a tenured tuba player?
A lifetime annuity for Handsome Dan, the ineffably ugly bulldog who serves as Yale's mascot?
And somebody will surely ask whether the money should not be put to uses more obviously consistent with Yale's larger mission of marinating its students in civilization's highest values.

Europe Missile Job
LEAD: A three-nation West European arms consortium has won contracts worth $:806 million, or about $1.37 billion, to develop antitank systems for the British, French and West German Governments, British Aerospace P.L.C. said.
A company statement said the Governments had jointly agreed on two contracts with Euromissile Dynamics Group to develop a portable antitank missile for infantry and a longer-range system for helicopters.


Merger Talk Lifts Tobacco Issues
LEAD: The stocks of American Brands and Liggett Group Inc. jumped yesterday on speculation that either or both of the companies might become takeover targets.


Correction
LEAD: An article on Sept. 9 about a strike by clerical employees of New York University described the strikers' salary figures incompletely.
The figure given by the union is $17,400, but the university says the average salary is $19,763.

LEAD: Michael S. Dukakis today outlined a battle plan for his war on drugs, saying that as President he would double the number of Federal drug enforcement agents, add 800 Federal prosecutors and send a message to drug kingpins that ''as far as Mike Dukakis is concerned, there's nowhere you can run.''

LEAD: Tom Browning of the Cincinnati Reds tonight pitched the 14th perfect game in major league history as he defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 1-0.

Phuket, Thailand's Resort Island
LEAD: DANGLING like an irregularly shaped pearl in the Andaman Sea off Thailand's far southern peninsula, the island of Phuket has been blessed with jungle-topped mountains, planted on their lower slopes with rubber trees and coconut palms, and valleys patterned with lush rice paddies.
Its coastline is studded with more than a dozen white sand beaches, each on a self-contained bay formed by rocky outcrops that jut into the translucent sea.

POSTINGS: Demolition on Fifth; 'Last Day' at Last
LEAD: Last year a sign in front of the electronics-luggage-carpet store at 565 Fifth Avenue read: ''Going Out of Business - Building Coming Down.'' Much later, the perpetual clearance sale was still on.
Then recently, behind rising scaffolding, a new sign was tacked up: ''Last Two Days.'' In two days the store closed.

LEAD: At the age of 12, Chris Jacobs of Livingston, N.J., tried cocaine for the first time.
At 21, disgusted with the way drinking and drugs had taken over his life, he bought a .357 magnum.
Several times, he sat in a closet, put the barrel in his mouth and cocked the hammer.

LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
LEAD: Back to Colonial Basics FOR some, getting back to the basics in cooking means popping a potato into the wall oven, rather than nuking it in the microwave.
For Alice Ross of Smithtown, getting back to the basics means the basics.
She spends two to three hours feeding wood into a brick and stone oven before she even begins baking that Long Island potato.

LEAD: Canada has been awarded the 1991 world junior hockey championships.
The decision was made at the annual congress of the International Ice Hockey Federation last week on Majorca.


ANSWERING THE MAIL
LEAD: Q. Seven years ago, we built a redwood deck and left it untreated, as we expected it to weather to a uniform gray color.
After the first year, the wood darkened with fungus and moss and there was no graying.
The deck was scrubbed and a gray deck stain applied, but two years later the wood was again dark with fungus and moss.


FICTION
LEAD:  THEN AGAIN.
By Sue McCauley. (Hodder &amp; Stoughton/David &amp; Charles, $22.95.) Even when outcasts find each other, that may be all they find: society has usually closed and locked the door.
In her very good first novel, ''Other Halves,'' the New Zealand writer Sue McCauley vividly portrayed two of society's rejects struggling to build a life in a highly industrialized country that is secretly sick of itself.

LEAD: Secretary of Education William J. Bennett plans to pay his 107th and last official visit to a school on Tuesday in New Hampshire.

WHAT'S DOING IN: Tokyo
LEAD: Perhaps more than ever before, Tokyo these days is about money and power.
With Japan's economy in perpetual overdrive, evidence of the city's affluence is everywhere.
Tiny apartments are still crammed together, and much of the architecture remains a postwar afterthought, but Tokyo is rebuilding every day.

Correction
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the official certification of Carlos Salinas de Gortari as Mexico's President-elect misidentified a group that jeered President Miguel de la Madrid during his State of the Nation address.
The hecklers were from the National Democratic Front, which ran Cuauhtemoc Cardenas for President; they were not from the National Action Party of Manuel Clouthier.

LEAD: President Reagan's choice of Lauro F. Cavazos of Texas to become the nation's next Secretary of Education has been approved by a Senate committee, clearing the way for expected easy confirmation by the full Senate.


An 'Applause' With Some Flair
LEAD: ''APPLAUSE'' is the producer Maynard Sloate's 17th ''tab show'' at the Claridge Casino Hotel's Palace Theater.
Clearly, the Broadway show, in shortened - or tabloid - form, serves a twofold purpose here.
Customers, for whom theatergoing is not priority No. 1 can get on to other diversions in a hurry, and management has the chance to increase grosses by putting on two shows a night.

Wrigley Field: A Baseball Park That Radiates Joy
LEAD: It is not within the power of architecture to guarantee that we have a good time - except, perhaps, at Wrigley Field.
For this extraordinary baseball park, this amiable pile of steel and bricks and concrete that despite careful maintenance still shows every one of its 74 years, seems to radiate more joy than all the domed stadiums of the last generation put together.


Taft Home, Rebuilt, Is Opened to Public
LEAD: The boyhood home of President Taft opened to the public today after a 19-year Federal renovation that cost $3 million in public and private money.


The Worst Beach Pollution Is Routine
LEAD: SYRINGES in the sand and sludge dumped into the sea became symbols this summer for the deterioration of the New York metropolitan region's waters.
But, many marine biologists and environmentalists contend, the worst threat to human health in the shore's waters and the main problem that needs to be addressed now is sewage, not sludge or medical waste.

Hit the Worst, Yucatan Begins a Long Cleanup
LEAD: Nowhere along Hurricane Gilbert's path of destruction did the storm hit with greater force and fury than here in the Yucatan.
When it made its first landfall around dawn on Wednesday, it was with sustained winds of 180 miles an hour as well as gusts of wind measured at 218 miles an hour and waves of 23 feet or more.

Suits From Jackets
LEAD: LIZA JERNOW, a 17-year-old high school senior from Armonk, N.Y., spent her summer vacation snipping sharkskin and shantung for her budding clothing line.
She is now cutting men's and boy's suit jackets in half to make women's suits: bolero jackets and miniskirts with cummerbunds attached.
They are $175 to $275.

Leonard L. Bailey transplanted the heart of a Canadian infant, known as Baby Gabrielle, into the chest of another Canadian baby.
Baby Gabrielle was anencephalic, born without the part of the brain responsible for consciousness, memory and thought, and doomed to a quick death.

Global Warming
LEAD: To the Editor:


BBottle Law: When Can Becomes Can't
LEAD: ME-VT-CT-MA-NY REFUND 5.
When I first encountered this obscure message it did not strike a chill in my heart.
There was no foreboding, only a smug sense of participating in a virtuous and civilized system.
To be precise, the message did not at that time include NY; perhaps it read only ME-VT-CT, or something of the kind.

HANDS-ON STYLE
LEAD: For many men, a manicure is a supreme but necessary indulgence, even an inexpensive thrill.
Some desire short, meticulously groomed nails for professional reasons; others enjoy the soothing qualities of the experience.
For instance, Charlie Rosner, creative director for a New York City advertising agency, favors very short nails for drawing, and delights in his periodic pilgrimages to Manhattan's Gio Hair Stylists because the manicurists there, he says, ''are kind enough to give me half an hour of complete silence once every 10 days to two weeks.

THE AGGRESSORS
LEAD: Just when so many of us had begun to hope that biological determinism had fallen out of fashion, Melvin Konner informs us in ''The Aggressors'' (Body and Mind, Aug. 14) that biological imperatives compel men to behave more violently than women.
It is such a tired argument that one might have assumed it would not be dragged out unless there were new evidence.


My Birth And the Great Hurricane of '38
LEAD: WITH a mighty and explosive burst, the wind split the giant elm, sending it crashing through the garage; the lights went out, the trolleys stopped and my whole birthday party was forced to sleep over.
It was 1945, the night of my seventh birthday.
It was a night of cozy excitement and as the wind whistled, my family sat around the candle-lit kitchen table.

Massachusetts Homeless Backed On Right to Attend Local Schools
LEAD: The Massachusetts Department of Education says communities are responsible for the education of children living within their boundaries, even if they live in temporary shelters, state parks or other temporary situations.





HIS OWN BIG PICTURE
LEAD: Stuart Davis (1892-1964) was an artist whose biography is that of American 20th-century art.
It is not that Davis was at the center of the mainstream art world.
Rather, as we learn in Karen Wilkin's book STUART DAVIS (Abbeville, $85), a lavishly illustrated and handsome coffeetable volume, he was an important and representative figure, one who started in the socially conscious Ashcan School tradition and became an outstanding Cubist.

Ms.
Glass did an excellent job of conveying the flavor of the group experience.

LEAD: Harold Eugene Davis, a Latin American scholar and professor emeritus at American University, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in this Washington suburb.
He was 85 years old Mr.
Davis served on the American University faculty from 1947 until he retired in 1973.
He continued to teach part time until the fall of 1986.

Pre-Abstract Expressionist Artist
LEAD: IF Abstract Expressionism was the atom bomb of art, maybe the revival of artists eliminated by the explosion can be likened to the rebirth of the natural environment.
In any case, they keep coming, these pre-bomb artists, and, as someone recently remarked to the reviewer, it's as if they, or the historians espousing them, are scurrying to beat the deadline of the century's end.

THE NATION: U.S. Plan on Hold; Suddenly, Nuclear Waste Looks Very Visible Again
LEAD: ALMOST half a mile beneath the desert in southern New Mexico, Federal engineers believe they have found a solution for disposing of nuclear waste that is as eternal, as elemental and as invisible as the atom itself.
Since 1983, they have been mining from salt beds the nation's first permanent repository for radioactive garbage, a tomb as vast, splendid and concealed as any ever built.

How Different Are the Famous From the Faces In the Crowd?
LEAD: The famous are different from you and me - they receive more attention.
Looking at them, we are conscious of how many times they have been looked at before.
The images they project are inseparable from our knowledge of what they are; and as their fame grows, their features evolve into something more than faces - into masks, trademarks, icons.

CONNECTICUT GUIDE
LEAD:  BALLADEER OF SENEGAL  Much like Europe's medieval troubadors, Djimo Kouyate - a griot, or balladeer, from Senegal - translates the history, foibles, politics and cultural traditions of West Africa into music, dance and storytelling.
He will give a free performance at 3 P.M. today in the Yale University Art Gallery as part of the gallery's Celebration of African Art and Culture exhibition.

Lessons Learned In Youth Have
LEAD: FOR A DANCE WRITER, ONE OF the unpredictable pleasures of interviewing is that moment when, without fanfare, words tumble out of a dancer or choreographer that offer a fresh or codifying insight into a body of work, a career or dance itself.
Alexander Kolpin, a young principal dancer with the Royal Danish Ballet, Martha Graham and Erick Hawkins are all articulate and, often, poetic.

16 Million Jobs in Eight Years Seems Best We Can Do
LEAD: To the Editor:


Albany Notes; Naming of Battery Park City Head Expected
LEAD: After several weeks of pondering, Governor Cuomo is expected this week to name David Emil, a deputy commissioner at the state's Social Services Department, as president of the Battery Park City Authority.


Policy and Politics
LEAD: European officials, East as well as West, are unusually relaxed about American elections this year.
They don't feel they have a big stake in the outcome, not because U.S. decisions are any less vital to them nowadays but because they don't expect much change whoever wins.


LEFT BEHIND ON BLUE STAR MOINTAIN
LEAD:  FAIR AND TENDER LADIES  By Lee Smith.  316 pp.
New York:  G. P. Putnam's Sons. $17.95.


Reclaiming Taiwan
LEAD: TWO PLACES IN TAIPEI lend themselves perfectly to contemplation of the split personality of modern Taiwan: the National Palace Museum and a night market cum red light district known as Snake Alley.


FICTION
LEAD:  KINGDOM'S END AND OTHER STORIES.
By Saadat Hasan Manto.
Translated by Khalid Hasan. (Verso/Routledge, $18.95.) Saadat Hasan Manto never lived to see his work translated; given the quality of this English edition, he was probably lucky.
Born a Moslem in the Punjab region of India, Manto was forced by the violence that accompanied partition to leave for Pakistan, where he died in 1955 at the age of 43.


Gilbert Said to Be Most Destructive
LEAD: Hurricane Gilbert has cut a 2,500-mile swath of devastation through the Caribbean and Gulf Coast since it formed a week ago, making the extent of its destruction the worst recorded for an Atlantic storm, the director of the National Hurricane Center said today.
At least $10 billion in damage has already been reported in six countries.


India From a Private Rail Car
LEAD: CHASING after the glittering prize of India more than 400 years ago, Mogul invaders used both military might and statecraft to subdue those who stood in their way.
Today the legends surrounding their battles and alliances with the powerful Rajput warlords in north central India are among the most romantic features of the nation's history.


Soccer Rules Are Also for U.S.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:


POSTINGS: Dissecting a Nassau Mansion; A $10 Million, 10-Year Restoration
LEAD: Hempstead House is falling down.
Decay is not visible on the outside, with seemingly immutable granite and limestone walls, or on the inside, with 40 rooms that have served as lavish showcases for prominent designers, but in its crevices, where rain has seeped for 76 years.
In summer, water rusted the building's steel frame.


No Pay, No Fun, but Fight Is On for U.N. Job
LEAD: The job provides a chauffeur-driven limousine but it does not pay a salary.
It means attending innumerable cocktail parties, shaking thousands of hands and sitting for weeks on a podium trying to look bright-eyed and interested as hundreds of orators reel off prepared speeches that more often than not are repetitive and dull.


Steinbrenner Treated Unfairly
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:


As Its Problems Mount, Rio Declares Bankruptcy
LEAD: After quarreling with bankers and creditors for weeks, the Mayor of Rio de Janeiro has publicly declared the city in a state of bankruptcy.


Talking; Convertibles Keeping Options Open
LEAD: Hundreds of borrowers who took out one of the new convertible type of adjustable-rate mortgages will be receiving a letter from their lenders this fall reminding them of the opportunity to convert to a fixed-rate loan.
Some lenders may even follow up the letter with a phone call to help explain the option more fully.

Fixing Garage Doors
LEAD: BECAUSE of their weight and the fact they have many parts, garage doors need periodic lubrication and adjustment - and sometimes repair - to keep them operating smoothly.
The job is usually easy, but some adjustment procedures may require two people.


Player Ends Career
LEAD: Before deciding to play football this season, Chris Thorpe checked with three medical specialists.
That's because Thorpe, a 21-year-old senior safety for Penn State who had missed the 1986 season with a severe neck injury, wanted to make sure he would be at no special risk this year even though he had played in nine games last season.


Review/Opera; Handel in Light Mood, In Omaha 'Partenope'
LEAD: Two-thirds of Opera/Omaha's season looks like that of any American regional company - a musical comedy to entice the faint of heart and then the Romantic repertory aimed at those for whom ''grand'' remains the important constituent of opera.

Being Exclusive Is Nothing Special
LEAD: I RECENTLY RECEIVED a card from Ireland.
It simply said, ''Hello,'' and was not signed.
I suspect it was from a man I was once related to by marriage.
More than 10 years have passed since my divorce from his cousin.
I had met him briefly one night while on a family visit.
He wanted me to feel at home in his country.


Piggott Avoids Club Suspension
LEAD: Lester Piggott, the jockey jailed for three years last October after a conviction for tax fraud, will not face further penalties from the Jockey Club, the sport's ruling body, the club announced today.

In Hong Kong, Early Tea And Strategy
LEAD: THERE'S a lot to do in Hong Kong besides eat, but perhaps nothing so worthy of attention, so all-consuming, nothing that offers as great a share of its everyday life.
The lure of the five- or six-course lunch, followed after a decent interval by a 10-course banquet in the evening, calls for a breakfast strategy.

Midnight Perfection
LEAD: The only time Tom Browning had to work out of trouble was after it was over.
Browning had just retired the last of 27 straight Dodger batters and he remained trapped under a pile of teammates for nearly a minute late Friday night in Cincinnati.
At last he emerged, disheveled and a little disbelieving.


Point O'Woods: Idyllic Monolith?
LEAD: Your article refers to Point O' Woods, Fire Island as an idyllic community.
I gather there are no blacks, there are no jews, there are no gays, there are no hispanics, etc.


A New Zealand Sampler
LEAD: Following is a selective guide to travel in New Zealand.
American citizens visiting the country do not need a visa for stays of less than three months.
They must, however, show that they have onward or return tickets and sufficient money for their stay.
Prices throughout the chart are given in United States dollars, figured at a rate of 2.37 New Zealand dollars to $1.

Streetscapes: The 125th Street Station; Metro-North Plans New Makeup, Not Plastic Surgery, for a Beauty
LEAD: It has been so neglected that it has the air of an abandoned building, even though 3,400 passengers use it daily.
But now the Metro-North Commuter Railroad has put out to bid plans to renovate its 125th Street station at Park Avenue, which was built in 1897.
Sometime next year the exterior will emerge from decades of neglect, but the long-hidden golden oak interior will simply get another coat of paint.

He is at the University of California at San Diego, not the University of San Diego.


Sentimentalizing 60's Radicalism
LEAD: 'RUNNING ON EMPTY'' IS Sidney Lumet's family drama about radicals who, 15 years after blowing up a research laboratory that made napalm, are still on the run.
Why is this idea so undeniably compelling?
In part it's novelty, since Hollywood has left the radicalism of the 1960's relatively unexplored.


MR. EURIPIDES GOES TO WASHINGTON
LEAD: People often talk wishfully of establishing a ''national theater'' in the United States, but they aren't always clear what that cultural incantation means.
Do they have in mind some grand metropolitan institution, an American counterpart of Britain's National Theater or France's Comedie Francaise or Sweden's Royal Dramatic Theater, rooted at Lincoln Center or even the Kennedy Center?

LEAD: The end to a long war for independence for this sparsely populated, largely desert region now hinges on votes, not bullets.

Before It Is Too Late
LEAD: In Jerusalem last June several dozen Israeli and Palestinian writers, artists and academics signed a symbolic peace treaty.
It called for peace between Israel and a Palestinian state in the West Bank and Gaza, each respecting the other's need for security.


Signs of Slowdown Are Well-Received
LEAD: A slowing of the economic pace seemed to be registered in the week's statistics.
Far from being alarmed, most economists welcomed signs that the strong growth of earlier this year, and its potential for inflation, might be easing.
The statistics included a two-tenths of 1 percent drop in retail sales in August.

LEAD: Eric Jones was an efficient general on attack and a superb passer today, just as Vanderbilt has said of its senior quarterback and just as Rutgers knew from last year.

LEAD: APPLES are at their peak in the fall.
Fresh and recently ripened, they have much more flavor than those that have been shipped or stored.
The best are to be found at roadside stands or farmer's markets, where, with any luck, the apples have been picked ripe.

LEAD: With Arthur Dennis returning for his senior year at John Adams after gaining 1,418 yards as a junior, the Spartans were everyone's pick to repeat as the Public Schools Athletic League champion.

Question Of the Week; Should Drug Violators Be Paid for Time Away?
LEAD: No, No, No.
Would they be paid if they worked in private industry?
I doubt it.
Moreover, upon first offense, drug violators should be banned for the season; upon second offense, they should be banned for life.
Perhaps - then and only then - will athletes keep their noses clean.
NICHOLAS D. DeCURTIS  New


Card-Carrying Smears
LEAD: Even in a negative campaign for President, one topic that ought to be off-limits is questioning an opponent's loyalty to country.
The Bush-Quayle campaign has been operating close to the borderline of decency in its carping about the flag and the American Civil Liberties Union.
That such techniques may be working, at least temporarily, does not dignify them.

GEORGE BERNARD SHAW, CUB REVIEWER
LEAD: The Pall Mall Gazette was the center of what Matthew Arnold called ''the New Journalism.'' It was edited by W. T. Stead, who used the paper to produce an emotional bond between himself and the public.
Together with Frank Harris, who edited The Evening News, Stead altered the character of daily journalism in Britain during the mid-1880's.

LEAD: With waterfowling seasons beginning next month, hunters should be aware of the increasing number of states or portions of them that have been zoned for steel shot.
In some instances, the states have moved ahead of the Federal timetable established several years ago for the switch to steel.


Definitive Post-Mortem
LEAD: SIMPLE suit combinations can generate complex post-mortem discussions.
Cover the East-West hands on the diagramed deal and study the heart suit.
How do you play, in the abstract, if you can afford one loser?
Would you make that play in six hearts after an opening lead of the spade ten?

Medical Care Is Poor Public Policy
LEAD: There are 37 million Americans uninsured for health care.
Two-thirds of them are working, or are dependents of those who work.
About 19 percent of all children under the age of 18 are not covered by health insurance.
In addition, an estimated 2 million people suffer from pre-existing or excluded conditions that preclude them from coverage, regardless of their employment or income status.

LEAD: When Governor Cuomo announced the departure of his beleagured Housing Commissioner, William B. Eimicke, last month, the resignation was widely expected.
Mr.
Eimicke had been involved in embarrassing flaps over inflated housing production numbers and the inadequacy of his department's handling of the rent regulation system.

ANSWERING THE MAIL
LEAD: Q. Seven years ago, we built a redwood deck and left it untreated, as we expected it to weather to a uniform gray color.
After the first year, the wood darkened with fungus and moss and there was no graying.
The deck was scrubbed and a gray deck stain applied, but two years later the wood was again dark with fungus and moss.


New &amp; Noteworthy
LEAD:  VELAZQUEZ: Painter and Courtier, by Jonathan Brown. (Yale University, $35.) The masterpieces of Velazquez, including his haunting, self-referential ''Las Meninas,'' were completed while he was becoming increasingly consumed by his duties in the court of King Philip IV, where he was finally knighted in 1659.

Surgical Cinema
LEAD: THE DAY I learned what happened in the operating room while I slept, the season's first snow was falling.
As my neurosurgeon set up the videotape player, I could see flakes the size of half dollars tumble by the window.
I'd known that at New York University Medical Center, as at all academic hospitals, surgeons videotaped their operations as teaching aids.


The Joys of the Beach in Autumn
LEAD: RESEARCH on the autumn beach begins for me on Aug. 31 and continues on into October.
On a typical day in the fall there might be cirrostratus clouds overhead, all streaked and fine, with lumpy little cumulus clouds clumped on the horizon.

THE REGION: Professors at Work; Management 101: Finding Ways To Save Bridges
LEAD: IN the days after the emergency closing of the Williamsburg Bridge last spring, New York City transportation officials pondered how things could have reached such a state.
There was talk of a mysterious rapid-corrosion process in the bridge's 85-year-old steel, of the deleterious effects of road salt and of flawed construction.

Books From The Times
LEAD:  LIVING OUT LOUD.
By Anna Quindlen. (Random House, $17.95.) When Anna Quindlen was 22 years old and wanted to write a column about her life, her editor at the time said she ''hadn't lived enough to be qualified for 'living out loud.' '' This collection from Life in the 30's, Ms.
Quindlen's syndicated New York Times column, is all about ''muddling through the middle,'' her definition of life.

He expected to work there forever.

NONFICTION
LEAD:  WILLIAM EVERSON: The Life of Brother Antoninus.
By Lee Bartlett. (New Directions, $25.95.) The poet William Everson has had a dramatic life.
As a teen-ager in 1930 he started a sexual affair with a girl in his California hometown that lasted eight years before they were married.
But then, fearing his Oedipus complex would make him a bad parent, he had a vasectomy.


The Moscow Blob
LEAD: The State Department's commitment to good architecture for U.S. embassies has raised some beautiful structures in faraway places - they are elegant expressions of America's best.
The embassy in New Delhi is the best known, but there are proud examples in Kuala Lumpur, Lisbon and Nicosia, and another is going up right now in Santiago.

LEAD: Unchallenged and almost untouched, the Mets continued their countdown to the playoff yesterday when they beat the Montreal Expos, 6-2.
And in one afternoon's work, they put the Expos out of the race and put Davey Johnson into the baseball record books.

Greenland
LEAD: To the Editor: Regarding ''Explorations in a Land of Glaciers'' (Travel, Aug. 21): We returned to Narssarssuag in a small boat (someone laughingly called it the Titanic), sailing for three hours amid icebergs, alone in the visible world.
The emergency radio told of a boat accident and subsequent drownings.


Question Of the Week; Should Drug Violators Be Paid for Time Away?
LEAD: Every professional athlete has a moral obligation to honor his contract and do everything possible to perform at his best.
Being involved with drugs, in my opinion, is highly irresponsible and illustrates an individual's disregard for his teammates and his fans.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Golf  Palmer Leads Seniors: Arnold Palmer, five under par for the day after the first five holes, rolled in a 25-foot birdie putt on the final hole yesterday to salvage a four-under-par 68 for a three-shot lead after two rounds of the $325,000 Crestar PGA Seniors Classic in Richmond. ''I kind of pulled it back together,'' said Palmer, who had a 36-hole total of nine-under-par 133.


Pewter of Tin-Rich Malaysia
LEAD: JUST over a century ago, a young pewtersmith named Yong Koon took the tools of his craft and sailed across the South China Sea to join a new settlement of Chinese tin miners at Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.
There, Yong Koon used the tin in fashioning traditional pewter items such as teapots, wine cups and incense burners, which he peddled from door to door.

LINCOLN Starring Henry Fonda.
Directed by John Ford. 1940.

Lincoln,'' he could have settled the Civil War with a jest.

AMERICAN GLAMOUR
LEAD: In the Hollywood of the 1920's through the 40's, a man's clothes were cut to play up his assets - and play down the rest.
And the fashions made popular by the studios' most celebrated leading men conveyed the message that, on celluloid at least, style and substance were synonymous.
It wasn't easy, for example, to separate Robert Montgomery's suave authority from the elegant white dinner jackets he wore in his portraits.

LEAD: NEARLY two years after a Sandinista missile downed a cargo plane and detonated the Iran-contra affair, doubts continue to linger about whether the full story has emerged.

Prospects; A Shrinking Trade Gap?
LEAD: When the Commerce Department released the trade figures for July last week, imports showed an unexpectedly large 8.9 percent drop from the previous month.
The overall deficit, $9.5 billion, also showed improvement over June's dismal showing of $13.2 billion.
Do July's gains signal a closing of the trade gap?


A Guide to Money Matters
LEAD: ONE old Asia hand likes to tell of an encounter at the airport restaurant in Guilin, China.
The left side of the menu was printed in English, the right in Chinese.
Entrees were identical, prices were not.


Whither City Opera Now?
LEAD: THE NEW YORK CITY OPERA'S ANNOUNCEMENT the other day that Christopher Keene would replace Beverly Sills as general director after this season came as a mild surprise, though hardly a shock.
Though some observers had hoped that the board of trustees might choose a career administrator who would share reponsibility with an artistic director, rather in the style of the Metropolitan Opera's team of Bruce Crawford and James Levine, that was not in the cards.


Comings and Goings
LEAD: He lost the United States Open and the No. 1 ranking he had held for 156 weeks, but Ivan Lendl, who is now ranked No. 2 behind Mats Willander, cited another ailment in withdrawing from this week's Volvo-Los Angeles tournament: an injury to his right shoulder joint incurred during the Open.
Other withdrawals from the tournament include Pat Cash, Aaron Krickstein, John Frawley and Eliot Teltscher.

Renewing the United Nations; A Disposable U.N. Rite
LEAD: For most of this decade, Arab members of the United Nations have made a September ritual of asking the General Assembly to expel Israel.
And every year, an increasing U.N. majority disposes of the proposal and hews to the charter's principle of universality.
Last year, 80 nations opposed the Arab move, 39 voted aye and 10 abstained.

Seasonal Flower
LEAD: LAST call to dig, divide and replant spring-summer flowering perennials especially phlox, daylily, astilbe, hosta and columbine.
Seed or sod new lawns; keep moist to speed germination and rooting.
Continue moving house plants indoors; check plants for insects and discard those infested with white flies as these insects are hard to control if taken indoors.

THE GREAT AMERICAN ORIGINALS
LEAD: Fall 1988 marks the coming of age of the American look, an eminently easygoing style whose roots - and influence - stretch across the Atlantic.
A timelessness and a graceful nonchalance define this home-grown way of dressing.
Western boots, a chambray work shirt or, on a more formal note, a three-button suit worn with cordovan brogues are a few of the badges of Yankee style updated for this season.

THE WAR WITHIN
LEAD: I was intrigued and then dismayed by Richard N. Goodwin's article ''The War Within'' (Aug. 21), about Lyndon B. Johnson.
From the depth of his analysis, it sounded as though Mr.
Goodwin was one of the President's closest advisers.
Mr.
Goodwin met or talked with the President 127 times in 1964 and 1965, according to my research using the Presidential daily diaries.

POSTINGS: Empty-Nester Condos; No More Mowing
LEAD: For the buyer whose empty nest must still hold a brood of furniture, a Stamford, Conn., project offers condomium houses.
A $285-to-$325 monthly common charge replaces weekend weed pulling and gutter cleaning, but, unlike a line of town houses or a stack of apartments, large - 3,000 to 3,400 square feet - single-family homes give this condominium cluster a subdivision look.

LEAD: Companies may be under pressure to control costs, but the amount they are spending on meetings continues to rise.

ANSWERING THE MAIL
LEAD: Q. Seven years ago, we built a redwood deck and left it untreated, as we expected it to weather to a uniform gray color.
After the first year, the wood darkened with fungus and moss and there was no graying.
The deck was scrubbed and a gray deck stain applied, but two years later the wood was again dark with fungus and moss.

LEAD: Victims of Mozambique's civil war sat in wheelchairs by an altar today as Pope John Paul II preached reconciliation and nonviolence at one of the largest gatherings of his tour of southern Africa.

The Titanic And Nuclear Power
LEAD: Ben Calderone's letter (The 'Safest' Ship Was the Titanic, Sept. 11) raises two key points in the discussion of public safety.
Even though the Titanic sank, a movement to destroy ocean shipping did not result.
Since then, means to detect and avoid icebergs have been been improved, leading to safer marine transportation.

Peking Duck At the Source
LEAD: BEIJING, which in recent decades seemed content to ignore its dynastic past and culture as somehow corrupt, has, even as it rushes toward modernity, taken to collecting accounts of the customs and mores of the past century from its elderly citizenry.
A recent collection of these reminiscences, ''Talks on Beijing's Recent Past,'' contains the recollections of one Yin Runsheng, who is otherwise unidentified but who remembered the capital's two great duck houses for nostalgic readers.

As Fall Aproaches, an Apple a Day for the Dessert Table
LEAD: APPLES are at their peak in the fall.
Fresh and recently ripened, they have much more flavor than those that have been shipped or stored.
The best are to be found at roadside stands or farmer's markets, where, with any luck, the apples have been picked ripe.

LEAD: AUDIO IS PROBABLY THE only field in which it is always safe to believe what you hear.
Playing it by ear, so to speak, is what audio is all about, and casual listeners rarely go beyond that.
But those who hope to evaluate sound equipment with real critical discernment need more than ephemeral impressions as a basis for judgment.

QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Is Gregg Jefferies The Rookie Of the Year?
LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036.

A Wing and a Prayer
LEAD: ASKED THE OBVIOUS - WHY? -Greg DeWolf says: ''When I was a kid, my father told me work was something that shouldn't make you smile.
I wanted to prove he was wrong.'' DeWolf teaches people more or less how to fly.
He's the founder of Fly America, an organization dedicated to popularizing the sport of hang gliding, all four of whose members are now involved in the first cross-country hang-gliding excursion.


A Duel of Jockeys
LEAD: They could have called it ''Age Against Youth,'' or just maybe, ''Beauty and the Beast,'' but to the officials at Canterbury Downs in Shakopee, Minn., the ''Duel of the Downs,'' match race scheduled for Sunday, Oct. 2, is nothing less than a battle of the sexes.


Travelers Sells Plaza Property
LEAD: The Travelers Corporation has agreed to sell properties in five states, including Constitution Plaza, to the Colonial Realty Company of West Hartford for nearly $235 million.


Review/Music; The Herb Roberts Septet Gives a New Sound to Pop
LEAD: Blues, noise, ostinatos and plain funk all vied for attention on Tuesday at the Knitting Factory.
Herb Roberts, a cellist, led an acrobatic group through long pieces that exposed section after section of different textures, from compressed noise to fragile melodies carefully presented on just cello and trombone.


Question Of the Week; Should Drug Violators Be Paid for Time Away?
LEAD: The drug violator could draw on his or her sick time, and thus continue to be paid.
After that is exhausted, vacation time.
If there is no provision for leave time in the professional athlete's contract, or if such leave time has been exhausted, then that person should go on leave without pay.
Professional athletes are no different from anyone else; they sign a contract to work and they ought not to be coddled.


'Gone With Wind' And a New Battle
LEAD: MARGARET MITCHELL called it ''the dump'' - a Victorian-style building in Atlanta where she lived in a basement apartment from 1926 to 1932 and wrote ''Gone With the Wind.'' In January, when a developer sought a permit to demolish the building as an eyesore, Mayor Andrew Young declined to approve it.

LEAD: ''Euphoria'' is a shack made of castaway shingles and facing an ocean vista from a dune on the easternmost tip of Cape Cod.

ANSWERING THE MAIL
LEAD: Q. Seven years ago, we built a redwood deck and left it untreated, as we expected it to weather to a uniform gray color.
After the first year, the wood darkened with fungus and moss and there was no graying.
The deck was scrubbed and a gray deck stain applied, but two years later the wood was again dark with fungus and moss.

LEAD: Ms.
Gass's article made for very interesting reading.

Shannon's ]  suggestion that information is the opposite of entropy - the principle that can explain why there are islands of order in a universe doomed to increasing randomness by the second law of thermodynamics - caught the imagination of theologians and philosophers.

Zimbabwe Leader Tells of Food Gains
LEAD: President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe sat in his suite at the Helmsley Palace hotel yesterday and described how his nine-year-old nation has confounded the gloomy predictions of old Rhodesia's white rulers by increasing overall agricultural production while leading millions of black peasants from subsistence farming into the commercial food chain.

For the first time in their lives, they have to get real jobs and support themselves, but no one has told them - not parents, friends, or teachers throughout their 16 years of schooling - that without marketable office skills, they are virtually unemployable.

A Vintage New Zealand, Not Yet Tamed

When Reality Begins to Look a Little Unreal
LEAD: NOTHING HAS MORE SIZZLE ON television these days than ''reality.'' Don't bother asking for a coherent definition.
Television's reality formats include everything from the nightly news to talk shows to ''based on fact'' movies to the Summer Olympics to Phil, Oprah and Geraldo.
The only productions definitely not admitted under the reality umbrella are sitcoms and action-adventures.

LEAD: A Superior Court judge ruled today to suppress evidence in a gun-possession case against Charles Barkley of the Philadelphia 76ers.


Open Hearths in a Colonial Inn
LEAD: DINNER at Randall's Ordinary in North Stonington is a unique experience, as close to dining in Colonial times as most of us will ever know.
The dishes served are from authentic 18th- and 19th-century recipes, and most are cooked in the fireplaces of three small, low ceilinged dining rooms with exposed beams.

As Fall Aproaches, an Apple a Day for the Dessert Table
LEAD: APPLES are at their peak in the fall.
Fresh and recently ripened, they have much more flavor than those that have been shipped or stored.
The best are to be found at roadside stands or farmer's markets, where, with any luck, the apples have been picked ripe.

LEAD: The McMillin Theater at Columbia University is dead.
Long live the Kathryn Bache Miller Theater.
Although McMillin, the 64-year-old hall at West 116th Street and Broadway, enjoyed a long and honorable run as a center for campus activities and especially as a home for electronic music and other varieties of contemporary art, it has been in recent decades a depressing place to hear concerts.

Key Limes
LEAD: To the Editor: As one who shares Margaret Shakespeare's enthusiasm for key limes and recently read her Fare of the Country (Travel, May 22), I was sorry she did not note that all limes found in the Keys are not Key limes.
The yellow lime is not a true Key lime.

Reviews/Music; Some Playful Algebra From Anthony Braxton
LEAD: The history of jazz is filled with eccentrics, and the saxophonist Anthony Braxton, who brought a quartet to the Knitting Factory for a rare engagement, qualifies as one of them.
Though he represents jazz's pedagogic side - his liner notes are as arcane and indecipherable as the densest semiotic text; he labels his compositions with line drawings that look algebraic - his music is often playful, with lines shooting out from all angles, and tempos picking up only to slow down.

Its roof caving in and walls askew, the cabin is all that remains of a community that took its name from a gunfight between two fur trappers in the 1920's.

Canada Prices Up 0.3%
LEAD: The Canadian consumer price index rose three-tenths of 1 percent in August, compared with a six-tenths of 1 percent rise in July and a one-tenth of 1 percent increase in August 1987, the Government agency Statistics Canada said Friday.
The August year-to-year rise was 4 percent, compared with a 3.8 percent in the July year-to-year figure.

Pure Knowledge vs. Impure Profit
LEAD: Oscar Wilde could resist everything except temptation.
University presidents, it seems, can resist everything except money.
Last week came news that Carnegie Mellon University and Stanford University have invested in Next Inc., the computer company founded by Apple's Steven Jobs.
Even Harvard, having resisted the apple for eight years, has finally succumbed: it proposes to raise $30 million by joining in a partnership to exploit the ideas of its medical school faculty.

2 Boys Held in Synagogue Fire And 10,000 Mourn 5 Torahs
LEAD: Only hours after two boys, aged 12 and 15, were arrested for vandalizing and setting fire to a Brooklyn synagogue, about 10,000 people gathered on the nearby streets yesterday to attend a funeral service for the five Torah scrolls destroyed in the Sabbath blaze.


Why Mayor Koch Went to Court in Parking-Meter Theft Case
LEAD: To the Editor:


Ida W. Richard, Philanthropist, 86
LEAD: Ida W. Richard, a philanthropist who was active in charities in New York and Cleveland, died Friday at the Margaret Wagner Nursing Home in Cleveland.
She had a severe stroke in early 1987.
She was 86 years old and lived in Cleveland.


Del Tredici to Compose For New York Philharmonic
LEAD: David Del Tredici, the American composer whose extravagant preoccupation with ''Alice in Wonderland'' has led to best-selling records and a Pulitzer Prize, has been appointed composer in residence with the New York Philharmonic for this season and next.


Mozambicans Greet Pope With Frenzy
LEAD: Mothers carrying infants screamed and children cried today when the thousands gathered among the bamboo shacks of a refugee slum surged violently toward a white-robed figure on a little stage.
As with the other crowds that have come to see Pope John Paul II across this devastated land, their enthusiasm was born of despair.


Burton Benjamin, 70, Dies; Former Head of CBS News
LEAD: Burton Benjamin, former vice president and director of CBS News, and a longtime documentary producer who wrote the report about the preparation of the controversial CBS television documentary critical of Gen.
William C. Westmoreland, died of a brain tumor last night at his home in Scarborough, N.Y.


University to Review Its Policy on Alcohol
LEAD: With increasing reports of some students drinking themselves unconscious and others getting drunk and hurting themselves, a University of Connecticut committee will review the campus alcohol policy and consider possible changes including a ban on alcohol, the school officials said.


Louis Quinn, Character Actor, 73
LEAD: Louis Quinn, a veteran gag writer turned character actor who became known to millions of television viewers as Roscoe the horse player on ''77 Sunset Strip,'' died Wednesday of lung cancer.
He was 73 years old.

LEAD:  Carving a Niche


Unseal the Records For Adoptive Parents
LEAD: To the Editor:


Face in Crowd Is Premier's
LEAD: Even after the assassination of Olof Palme two and a half years ago, a Swedish Prime Minister mingles with election crowds here in a way that would be unthinkable for American Presidential candidates.


A Retail Chain May Be Bought
LEAD: The Service Merchandise Company said yesterday that an investor group that includes members of its senior management might acquire the company through a leveraged buyout.
The investors include Raymond Zimmerman, the chairman and chief executive of the Nashville-based catalogue and retail chain.


Walesa Sees a Legalized Union
LEAD: Lech Walesa told 50,000 pilgrims at a workers' Mass today that the Government is close to recognizing Solidarity, the banned independent union movement that he leads.


Review/Rock; Appalachian Echoes: Hornsby and the Range
LEAD: Bruce Hornsby is such an unassuming stage performer that it would be easy to overlook his solid contributions to adult mainstream rock.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Notebook; Lewis Finds Himself Subject of Chase Before Race
LEAD: Sometimes it's hard being a famous athlete . Ask Carl Lewis.


Review/Music; Mad Monk Redux in City Opera's New 'Rasputin'
LEAD: The New York City Opera, which has an honored history of taking chances with new works, tossed the dice bravely on Saturday evening with Jay Reise's ''Rasputin.'' Sorry.
Snake eyes.
The odds against success are always high in such a game, and this time the gamble did not pay off. ''Rasputin,'' which had its world premiere at the New York State Theater, is the 38-year-old composer's first opera and no worse than many a less visible failure.


Oasis on the Mall
LEAD: One of the problems facing the millions of visitors who flock each year to the museums on the Mall is the lack of eating places, a situation alleviated somewhat with the opening last weekend of a huge restaurant at the Smithsonian Institution's National Air and Space Museum, which hopes to feed 9,000 visitors a day.

LEAD: The international storm over Iraq's supposed use of chemical weapons against its Kurdish minority may create new obstacles for the fledgling peace talks under way between Iraq and Iran, Western diplomats and Iraqi Government officials here say.

He is replacing Lois Wyse, who will continue as president of the parent company, of which Marc A. Wyse, her former husband, is chairman.

Horse Racing; Trapp Mountain Takes the Futurity
LEAD: The Futurity Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday had an ugly beginning and a dispiriting finish.
A ragged start may have compromised the favorite's chances, and the entire field then staggered home in unimpressive time, looking like a very ordinary bunch of 2-year-olds.

LEAD: HE'S different from all the other 9,626 athletes in these XXIV Olympic Summer Games.
But he learned to play baseball the same way just about every kid does: playing catch with his father.


McDonald's Awards
LEAD: Phylicia Rashad and Denzel Washington will be the hosts of a celebrity reading Sept. 26 at 8 P.M. at Theater Four of the Negro Ensemble Companyas part of the 1988 McDonald's Literary Achievement Awards.
The winners of the competition will be announced at the fund-raising event for the dance company.


Largent Sets Record
LEAD: Steve Largent broke the National Football League career record for receiving yardage today but the Seattle Seahawks lost to the San Diego Chargers, 17-6.

Falcons' Defense Stuns 49ers, 34-17
LEAD: Chris Miller passed for 130 yards and ran for Atlanta's third touchdown today in a 21-point second-period outburst that carried the Falcons to a 34-17 upset victory over the San Francisco 49ers.


Police Search Mexico Bus Wrecks
LEAD: Rescue workers reported finding 90 drowning victims left behind by the floodwaters spawned by Hurricane Gilbert.
But they said they may never know how many people were on the buses that washed away in a swollen riverbed Saturday.


California Official Fights Grocery Chains' Merger
LEAD: California's Attorney General, John Van de Kamp, has led inquiries on Asian gangs, drug peddlers and fraudulent AIDS remedies.


Police Say Three Deaths In Fire Were Homicides
LEAD: Three people whose bodies were found in a fire were determined to be homicide victims, and the police were searching today for clues in the first murders in this town in nearly four decades.


To Hijack or Fast?
LEAD: ''We could have done other things, maybe hijack an airplane, but we don't think that is nice,'' said Muhyeddin Abdula, a representative of the Kurdistan Democratic Party in the United States and Canada. ''We're trying to do things the nice way, the peace way.''





Priests in Baltimore Asked To Urge Gun Control Backing
LEAD: Roman Catholic priests in the Baltimore Archdiocese were urged use their homilies to encourage support for the state's law controlling pistols.


Haiti's Ordeal: The Years Of Strife
LEAD:  985  November: Although President Jean-Claude Duvalier had announced a series of political reforms earlier in the year, anti-government rioting breaks out when several teen-agers are killed during a demonstration.
December: President Duvalier reshuffles his Government, shifting power to an inner circle of hard-liners.
