LEAD: To the Editor:


Division of NL Will Go Public
LEAD: NL Industries announced Friday that it planned to undertake a restructuring in which its petroleum-services division would become a publicly held company.


Africans Pushing for Peace in Angola
LEAD: The leaders of Angola, Angola's neighbors and South Africa have agreed to meet in coming weeks to discuss peace in Angola, President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire said in an interview here today.


Three Lessons From the U.S. Open
LEAD: SOME of the best tennis lessons you'll ever get about how to play and win matches are those you see during a major championship.
Three matches at this year's United States Open were fine examples of, for lack of a more positive phrase, how not to lose a match.
In two cases, the student lost, and in one case, the student won.


David Alan Jacobs Is Wed To Robin L. Tannenbaum
LEAD: Robin Lesley Tannenbaum, a daughter of Steven Tannenbaum of Great Neck, L.I., and Arlene Reitman of Roslyn Heights, L.I., was married in New York yesterday to David Alan Jacobs, a son of Peter Jacobs of Los Angeles and Marina Engel of New York.
Rabbi Gunter Hirschberg officiated at the Harmonie Club.


Olympic Highlights
LEAD:  SWIMMINGJanet Evans won the United States' first gold medal of the Games in the 400-meter individual medley.
Kristin Otto of East Germany, Adrian Moorhouse of Britain and Duncan Armstrong of Australia also won golds.
BASKETBALLYugoslavia scored a surprisingly easy 92-79 victory over the Soviet Union.


Socialists Retain Power in Sweden
LEAD: Sweden's governing Social Democratic Party retained its dominant position in national elections today, enabling Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson to claim a mandate to go on governing the country for the next three years.


A Portable Boat for the Adventurous Angler
LEAD: Part of the wonder of fishing is being able to get away from it all, but transporting a boat to remote places can be troublesome.
Porta-Bote International, a company based in Mountain View, Calif., claims it has a solution.
The firm markets a collapsible boat, a polypropelene skiff that looks like a banana and folds like an accordian.

The Day When The Book Is King
LEAD: New York City reasserted its claim to literary pre-eminence yesterday, as tens of thousands of books and several hundred thousand of their devotees thronged onto a half-mile of Fifth Avenue and adjacent blocks for the 10th annual New York Is Book Country street festival.
More than 160 publishers and booksellers displayed and sold their wares on the avenue, from 48th to 57th Streets, and four noted authors spoke at a literary brunch at the Plaza Hotel.

Reviews/Music; 'Pianorama' for a 10th Anniversary
LEAD: Merkin Concert Hall in the Abraham Goodman house on West 67th Street opened its 10th anniversary season Saturday night with an event that was as good a specimen as any of what the hall is about: a ''Pianorama'' of little-heard American music played by four excellent nonstar pianists.


Redskins Defense Trips Up Eagles
LEAD: The Washington Redskins defeated the Philadelphia Eagles, 17-10, today in a battle between two of the four 1-1 teams that were leading the National Football Conference's Eastern Division.


College Football; Big Ten's Tumble Continues
LEAD: The Big Ten Conference not only took it on the chin again Saturday but its four best teams - Michigan, Iowa, Ohio State and Michigan State - were beaten.
Six Big Ten teams lost yesterday and only four won, leaving the conference with a 7-15 record against the outside world.


Close-Up; Modern Pentathlon
LEAD:  Day 1 Riding: Entrants ride 600 meters over a 15-obstacle course on a horse drawn by lot.
Riders start with 1,100 points, with deductions for knocking down barriers, falls and balky or slow horses.
A clean ride in 1 minute 43 seconds earns the maximum points.
Day 2 Fencing: One touch of the epee anywhere on the body decides a match.


18th for Gooden As Mets Close In
LEAD: The Mets kept fitting the final pieces into the puzzle yesterday: They defeated the Montreal Expos, 5-3, moved to within a game or two of clinching the Eastern championship of the National League and named Dwight Gooden to open the playoff for the pennant two weeks from tomorrow.


Ready To Play Rough
LEAD: Rarely have so many players skirmished so often in a National Football League game as the Jets and the Oilers did today.


Yugoslav Debt Pact
LEAD: Yugoslavia will sign a new loan and debt-rescheduling package with commercial banks this week, bankers said.
The agreement with commercial banks consists of $300 million in new money and an 18-year rescheduling of about $7 billion of loans dating back to 1983. ''The good news is that because of foreign exchange policies, reserves at the national bank are up substantially,'' said Fulvio Dobrich of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, who is chairman of the bank advisory committee for Yugoslavia.


West Germany's Emphasis on Exports Irritates Its Trading Partners
LEAD: West Germany's trading partners have long urged it to become a locomotive for European economic growth, but now some people are joking that it has become the caboose.


9 Charged, 4 With Murder, in Robbery Spree at L.I. Rap Concert
LEAD: In a weekend sweep, the Nassau County police arrested and charged nine Brooklyn men, four of them with murder, in a robbery spree at a Uniondale rap concert Sept. 10 that left one man dead and 14 injured.


Roundup; Weight Lifting Marks Fall
LEAD: Sevdalin Marinov of Bulgaria set two world records today to win a gold medal in the 114-pound division of weight lifting.


'McSleep' Loses to Big Mc
LEAD: Quality Inns International Inc. must stop using the name ''McSleep Inns'' for the economy hotels it plans because the public would believe the hotels were owned by the McDonald's Corporation, a Federal district judge has ruled.


Walter P. Chrysler Jr., a Collector Of Modern Art and Artifacts, 79
LEAD: Walter P. Chrysler Jr., one of the country's leading art collectors and benefactors whose reputation as a shrewd judge of talent was tainted by suspicions that he knowingly attained forged works, died of cancer Saturday at Sentara Norfolk General Hospital in Norfolk, Va.
He was 79 years old.


2 Hopefuls Sharpen Debate Weapons
LEAD: Next Sunday night America will finally tune in to the 1988 Presidential race.
Millions of voters will be watching, certainly millions more than will see any other single event of this campaign.
Live and on stage, Vice President Bush and Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis will confront each other, or maybe not, in the first of two televised debates.

Did Mr. Regan 'Give and Get'?
LEAD: Edward Regan, New York State's Comptroller, finds himself embattled over serious allegations that he misused his position as sole trustee of the state's $38 billion pension fund.
Whether or not the allegations result in criminal charges, they raise legitimate concerns about Mr.
Regan's integrity and judgment.

LEAD: An off-duty correction officer was shot and wounded in Brooklyn early yesterday while riding in a car, the police said.

Reviews/Music; 'Lammermoor' Changes
LEAD: The New York City Opera's solid production of Donizetti's ''Lucia di Lammermoor'' took on a share of magic at the Saturday matinee performance at the New York State Theater when Sheryl Woods joined the cast in the title role.
This was the soprano's first Lucia with the company, but there was not the slightest tentativeness in her performance.

LEAD: Credit market analysts said that short-term interest rates are likely to move higher during the remainder of the month, without the prodding of the Federal Reserve Board.


Corrections
LEAD: A report in the Finance/New Issues column of Business Day on Friday about a financing backed by boat loans described the underwriting of the issue incorrectly.
Chemical Bank Investment Banking was the lead manager; First Boston was co-manager.


Baseball; Canseco Hits 40th and A's Can Clinch Title Tonight
LEAD: Dave Henderson drew a bases-loaded walk in the 11th inning and Jose Canseco hit his 40th home run today as the Oakland Athletics defeated the Kansas City Royals, 3-2.

All are already executive vice presidents and members of the New York board.

LEAD: A high-stakes board-room drama with all the intrigue, glamour and bold moves of a Hollywood plot has captivated the French business community this summer.


Easy Reading

Letter: On Medicaid; Prenatal Care for the Indigent
LEAD: To the Editor:


Review/Opera; Meyerbeer in San Francisco
LEAD: We are periodically obliged to resurrect the operas of Giacomo Meyerbeer, but one suspects it is more out of a duty to history than flat-out enthusiasm.
People wanting to make their way from opera's origins to the present inevitably find him in their path.
Meyerbeer was a giant figure and is not to be ignored.


Cocaine Raid in Florida
LEAD: United States Customs agents seized 1,000 pounds of cocaine and arrested eight men in a raid of the sport-fishing boat ''What's Up'' Saturday, the Customs Service reported.
A Customs spokesman, Cliff Stallings, said the cocaine was worth about $12 million whosesale.
Also seized were the boat and five vehicles.


Reviews/Music; Love, Nature, Images And Sounds of Vowels
LEAD: Near the end of the first of two shows at the Bottom Line on Friday evening, Toni Childs requested that the lights in the house be extinguished while she lit a candle and sang ''Dreamer,'' a beautiful romantic lament from ''Union,'' her debut album. ''I sometimes run and chase the moon, I just can,'' the singer exclaimed in a half-strangulated shout against a crystalline electronic accompaniment suggesting an amplified autoharp.


China Has Also Been a Dragon of the Seas
LEAD: To the Editor:


Iranian Puts War Death Toll At 134,000; 60,000 Missing
LEAD: Iran said today that it lost 123,220 soldiers and 11,000 civilians in the eight-year war with Iraq.
The announcement marked the first time that Teheran has reported casualty figures for the war.


Review/Theater; A Modern Rendering of Ever-Timely Moliere
LEAD: ''Tartuffe'' is unfailingly timely, especially so whenever those who are outwardly sanctimonious are revealed as inwardly impious.
With hypocrisy flying high in politics as well as in religion, one should be able to turn to Moliere for comic relief.
Unfortunately, R. Jeffrey Cohen's production flattens the play into a one-dimensional cartoon.


Shoreham in Flux; In Seesaw Battle Over Nuclear Plant, A Final Deal Is Far From Imminent
LEAD: In the surreal world of nuclear politics, events often mean little.
A court decision often results in years of additional judicial appeals.
Regulatory actions seem to mean even less.
Nothing, it would appear, is concrete.

U.S. Swimmers Get Needed Help From Evans
LEAD: The United States, which had started badly in Olympic swimming, received a big boost today from 17-year-old Janet Evans, all 5 feet 6 inches and 105 pounds of her.


Zoos Organize to Help Gorillas Start Families
LEAD: Katie and Jimmy, two 15-year-old gorillas, are the big ''item'' here at the San Diego Zoo.
Lovers, the two have been courting for months - climbing together on rock formations in their outdoor enclosure, frolicking in a nearby pool of water, even mating publicly.

LEAD: An article yesterday about a singer who was killed while driving a cab in New York City misstated the inspiration for the movie ''Fame.'' The movie was modeled on the High School for the Performing Arts, not the High School of Music and Art.

Clerical Workers at N.Y.U. Agree to End 3-Week Strike
LEAD: Office workers at New York University, on strike since Aug. 29, began returning to work yesterday after negotiators reached a tentative settlement late Sunday night.
The package, endorsed overwhelmingly at a union meeting yesterday morning, will now be presented to the full membership for ratification by mail ballot.

LEAD: THE Clone Wars have begun again, and if you're confused about which side to support, you're not alone.
The announcement last week by the Clone chieftans that they were banding together against the International Business Machines Corporation is bound to cause consternation among people trying to decide which computer to buy.

Discovery of New Dinosaur Species Reported
LEAD: FOR the second time this year, Robert T. Bakker, a paleontologist at the University of Colorado, has announced that he has discovered a new dinosaur species not by digging out in the field, but by rummaging through a museum collection.

Topics of The Times; The All-Too-Perishable Panda
LEAD: To watch a panda in action - waddling, somersaulting, munching bamboo sprouts and heaving the occasional sigh - is to watch a child's stuffed animal come miraculously to life.
That's precisely why children, and their parents, crowd the nation's zoo whenever one is exhibited.
Pudgy, plushy, with eyes like teardrops: the panda was designed to delight.


Democrat in Nebraska Drops Senate Debates
LEAD: The race for a United States Senate seat in Nebraska between the Republican incumbent, David K. Karnes, and his Democratic challenger, Bob Kerrey, has been disrupted by a third-party candidate, a maverick legislator who was nominated at a convention held in a fast-food restaurant.


U.S. Issues Drop in Profit Taking
LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds slumped in lackluster trading yesterday as market participants chose to take profits rather than hold on to their securities.


Haiti's New Leader Installs A Mostly Civilian Cabinet
LEAD: Haiti's new President, Lieut.
Gen.
Prosper Avril, today swore in a new Government composed almost exclusively of civilians.


Sports People; Umpire Resigns
LEAD: Dave Pallone, a minor league umpire who was hired by the National League in 1979 during a strike of regular umpires, has resigned.
Pallone gained publicity this spring when he ejected Manager Pete Rose from a game in Cincinnati after the two bumped during an argument that sparked an angry crowd reaction, causing Pallone to leave the field.


Dolls and Rattles Recalled
LEAD: Several small dolls and rattles marketed as craft goods are being recalled because they could pose a choking hazard for children, the Consumer Product Safety Commission announced today.
The toys are being recalled by the Fibre Craft Materials Corporation of Niles, Ill., which said the products could be returned to the place of purchase for a refund.


Mounting Junk Piles and the Hazards
LEAD: Along a hilltop in this rustic community of 2,800 people is a 20-yard-long pile of discarded refrigerators, washing machines and other household appliances, a rusting monument to the latest environmental problem facing towns and cities.

Kafka's Manuscript Of 'The Trial' to Go On the Auction Block
LEAD: The manuscript of Franz Kafka's ''Trial,'' written in 1914 and published in 1925, the year after his death, is to be auctioned by Sotheby's in London on Nov. 17.
The auction house, describing the novel as the most important modern literary manuscript ever to be auctioned, estimates it will bring more than $1 million.

LEAD: The profit of New York Stock Exchange member firms doing business with the public more than doubled in the second quarter from the period a year earlier, but 160 of the 386 companies lost money, the exchange said yesterday.

Fuji to Greenstone
LEAD: Greenstone &amp; Rabasca Advertising in Melville, L.I., has picked up the Fuji America bicycle account, which the agency says will bill about $1 million.
According to G.&amp;R. the business was formerly served by Imaginc in Hauppauge, L.I., which has gone out of business.
Fuji has been selling its Japanese-made bicycles in this country since 1971.

Topics of The times; Holy Apostles' Millionth Meal
LEAD: On Sept. 28, the Church of the Holy Apostles' Soup Kitchen will serve its one-millionth meal.
It's an occasion to celebrate the extraordinary efforts of the Rev.
William Greenlaw, the rector of the church, and his dedicated volunteers.
It's also a terrible comment on the rapid increase in the number of New Yorkers who are poor and need to be fed.


Europe Output Rises by 3.5%
LEAD: The index of industrial production in the European Community rose by an estimated 3.5 percent in the first half of 1988 from the corresponding period last year, the community said today.


A Civilian Cast In Haiti Cabinet
LEAD: Saying Haitians ''legitimately want proof'' that the army can ''work in permanent contact'' with civilians, the country's new military leader named a 12-member Cabinet that includes only one military officer.

Gen.
Prosper Avril, also announced the ouster of Brig.
Gen.
Williams Regala, the second in command under Lieut.


Ice Volcanoes Discovered on 2 Uranus Moons
LEAD: ASTRONOMERS at Cornell University say they have discovered ice volcanoes on two moons of Uranus.
If their analysis of satellite photographs is confirmed, it would be the first time such features have been found anywhere in the solar system.


Death of a Spouse
LEAD: While the death of a spouse is one of life's greatest blows, new findings show the survivor to be far more resilient than had been believed.
A study of 13,380 men and women found that those whose spouses had died were as physically and emotionally healthy, as active, had as many friends, and were as outgoing and open to new experiences as were those who were still married.


Review/Theater; Caprice and Melancholy in Marriage
LEAD: In a letter to Arthur Schnitzler, written in 1906, the year after the premiere of ''Intermezzo,'' Sigmund Freud expressed his admiration for the playwright's intuitive discovery of ''that secret knowledge'' about ''psychological and erotic problems.'' Though less familiar than ''Anatol,'' ''La Ronde'' and other of Schnitzler's plays, ''Intermezzo'' is one of the playwright's more provocative examinations of modern marriage - as is clear in Gitta Honegger's production at the Yale Repertory Theater.

It was this year.


Bridge
LEAD: The most successful married partnership in North America, in terms of combined master-points, is Tom and Carol Sanders of Nashville.
Their total is about 25,300, which put them 4,200 ahead of the next best total, that of Vincent and Joan Remey of Southfield, Mich.


Polish Cabinet, Under Fire, Steps Down
LEAD: The Government of Prime Minister Zbigniew Messner resigned today amid sharp criticism of its management of the economy.
It was the first time in Poland's postwar history that the entire Government had stepped down.

On Horse Racing; Change Is Coming So Bettors Beware
LEAD: A new era in the separation of horseplayers from their dollars begins tomorrow at Belmont Park with the advent of parlay betting.
Parlays, as anyone who has ever done business with a bookmaker knows, is sort of a do-it-yourself daily-double.
Pick two horses and if they both win, you win big.
With a parlay, you can pick up to six horses, but all must come through for you to collect.


Asbestos and Cancer
LEAD: Occupational exposure to asbestos, already known to cause cancers of the long colon and lining of the chest and abdomen, has now been linked to acute myelocytic leukemia, a particularly lethal cancer that arises in the bone marrow.

LEAD: Zenith Laboratories Inc., which is operating under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, has cut its staff by 130 employees, to 307, to save more than $2 million a year.

It is a foolish provision, likely to waste money and manpower for the states that must administer it.

Q&amp;A
LEAD: Q. How high can a toy balloon filled with helium rise if you release it?


Beulah M. Donald, 67, Klan Foe
LEAD: Beulah Mae Donald, who won a $7 million judgment against the Ku Klux Klan for the death of her son in a beating, died of natural causes Saturday at a hospital in Mobile, according to the Mobile County Coroner, Leroy Riddick.
She was 67 years old.


NEWS SUMMARY
LEAD:  International A3-13


Steel Output Rises 1.5%
LEAD: Steel production rose to 1.949 million tons in the week ended Saturday, an increase of 1.5 percent from the previous week's 1.921 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
The industry's production amounted to 91.4 percent of capacity during the week, compared with 90.1 percent in the previous week.

Sandinistas and Contras Resume Some Talks
LEAD: Representatives of the Nicaraguan Government met with rebel leaders today for the first time in three months, but both sides remained sharply divided on ways to end seven years of civil war.

Exile Ends for Zaire's Top Political Prisoner
LEAD: Zaire's most prominent dissident returned home today from internal exile, and there were signs that the remaining political prisoners are to be released soon.


Judge Upholds Ban on Surrogate Birth Contracts
LEAD: The nation's first law intended to ban commercial contracts for women to bear children for infertile couples was upheld as constitutional today by a state judge.
However, Michigan's attorney general agreed to an interpretation of the law that will evidently permit surrogacy, as long as the woman does not give up her rights as a parent.


Book-of-the-Month Club Restructures Its Jury
LEAD: The Book-of-the-Month Club has asked three of its five judges to resign at the end of the year, but plans to replace only two of them.


Toned-Down New York Post To Get Ads of 4 Major Stores
LEAD: Six months after its new owner promised to tone down The New York Post's sensationalism, the newspaper's publisher said yesterday that four of New York's most stylish retailers would begin regular advertising.


Review/Recital; An Unusual Piano Urgency
LEAD: Fou Ts'ong, a pianist who was born in Shanghai, trained in Warsaw and lives in London, stopped in New York on Saturday evening to play a concert of music composed in Paris.
He did so in an interesting and compelling way, mingling a stylish refinement of timbre and touch with a current of urgency unusual in the repertory he chose.


Sports People; It Counts Anyway
LEAD: A freshman for the Colorado School of Mines was the first college football player in the country to return an unsuccessful extra point attempt for 2 points under a new rule this season, a National Collegiate Athletic Association historian said.
But the score by Rod Beauchamp, a linebacker for the Golden, Colo., school, should not have been permitted to stand, the historian, Steve Boda.


No-Shows Steal Show At a U.S.-Soviet Parley
LEAD: A Soviet-American conference opened here today with the Soviet hosts publicly smiling their welcomes and privately complaining that the Americans had left their heavy hitters at home.


Whooping Crane Population Is Rebounding
LEAD: The world's whooping crane population, down to 16 in 1941, will probably exceed 200 this winter, perhaps the highest number this century.


Sports People; Browning Is Tops
LEAD: Tom Browning of the Cincinnati Reds, who pitched a perfect game last week, was named the National League Player of the Week yesterday.
While achieving the first perfect game in nearly four years, Browning struck out 7 of the 27 Los Angeles Dodgers that he faced in a 1-0 victory.
Mike Moore, the Seattle right-hander, who yielded only seven hits in two complete games, was named American League Player of the Week.

Olympic Highlights
LEAD:  Basketball: The United States men's team, highly favored to win the gold, had to rely on long-range shooting to turn back Canada, 76-70.
Brazil, which will be the Americans' next oppponent, was paced by 44 points from Oscar Schmidt in a 130-108 victory over China.
GYMNASTICS: The Soviet Union and Rumania, as expected, led the women's team competition after the compulsory exercises.


Bundesbank On Inflation
LEAD: West Germany's central bank today issued a warning about inflation, citing a weaker mark and the rising cost of imported goods.

To Build on a Good Deed in Turkey
LEAD: Turkey took on the unaccustomed role of championing human rights when it opened its borders to 60,000 desperate Kurds fleeing Iraq's army and poison gas.
This courageous action by Prime Minister Turgut Ozal is sure to damage relations with Baghdad and spotlight Ankara's repression of Turkey's own large Kurdish minority.

Coast Guard Aids in Searches in Mexico but future Role Is Unclear
LEAD: The United States Coast Guard continued searching today for people stranded by flooding in north-central Mexico, but the only person evacuated was a Texan trapped in the area by downpours that followed Hurricane Gilbert.


As Hirohito Fights Illness, Japan Keeps Vigil
LEAD: Emperor Hirohito became seriously ill late Monday night, and millions of Japanese stayed up until the early hours of the morning watching television as the Imperial Palace here bustled with activity and speculation.


Careers; Part-Time Jobs Beckon Retirees
LEAD: SOME retirees aged 60 and over have returned to the job market on a temporary basis, drawn by boredom, fears of rising inflation, a desire for extra money and attractive part-time wages.


21 Laid Off At Paine Unit
LEAD: Paine Webber has laid off 21 employees from its investment banking division, including 16 who were either managing directors or vice presidents.


Suits Planned Over Default Of U.S.-Insured Mortgages
LEAD: In a new policy, the Department of Housing and Urban Development plans to sue investors and homeowners who default on Government-insured mortgages in economically troubled regions and then buy new homes at lower prices at Government foreclosure sales, an agency official said today.

LEAD: David L. Dodd, who taught finance at Columbia University for four decades and who was the co-author of ''Security Analysis,'' a standard work in the investment field, died of respiratory failure Sunday at Maine Medical Center in Portland.
He was 93 years old and had homes in Falmouth Foreside and Chebeague Island,

KDI in Talks On a Buyout
LEAD: A group of senior managers of the KDI Corporation is negotiating a buyout of the Cincinnati-based company.
KDI makes electric and electronic components, swimming pools, industrial chemicals and gases and other products.


Mets' Future Clear; Johnson's Still Isn't
LEAD: With less than two weeks to go, the Mets stood on the brink of winning the Eastern championship of the National League for the second time in three years yesterday.
But Dave Johnson conceded that he still had no idea whether he would be back as manager next year.


Beene's Way: Always an Adventure
LEAD: In the beginning, Geoffrey Beene made clean, commercial dresses -the kind that Seventh Avenue has always done so well.
Gradually, as he perfected his skill and as his taste grew more sophisticated, he moved off the main thoroughfares of fashion and on to more adventurous designs.
He became a pathfinder in matters of hem length, fabric choice and the cut of clothes.


Hyatt Bid Spurned
LEAD: As expected, Ramada Inc. rejected an unsolicited $10-a-share cash offer from the HCC Corporation, a holding company controlled by Chicago's Pritzker family, which owns the Hyatt chain of hotels.
Ramada, which owns the Ramada Inn hotel chain, said its board had based its decision on an opinion by Salomon Brothers Inc., its investment banker, that called the offer ''grossly inadequate.


THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Gymnastics; Karolyi Cries Foul as U.S. Slips Into 4th
LEAD: The women's team compulsory round of the Olympic gymnastics tournament ended tonight with angry accusations by Bela Karolyi, one of the American coaches, that politics had cost the United States team half a point in the team score.

LEAD: IN all the tears and sympathy for Anthony Hembrick's disqualification from the Olympics for not getting to the ring on time, his coaches have taken the rap for misreading yesterday's schedule.
That's thoughtful and honest of the coaches.
But the 22-year-old middleweight is as much to blame as anybody else.

Name Change at IC
LEAD: The directors of IC Industries have approved a change in the company's name to the Whitman Corporation, effective Dec. 1. Isaac Rabinowitz, 79, Dead Sea Scroll Expert
LEAD: Isaac Rabinowitz, professor emeritus of biblical and Hebrew studies at Cornell University and an authority on the Dead Sea Scrolls, died Sept. 11 at Tompkins Community Hospital in Ithaca, N.Y., after a brief illness.
He was 79 years old and lived in Ithaca.

Alco Standard Corp., Valley Forge, Pa., which distributes office supplies and pharmaceuticals, said it had acquired T. Talbott Bond Co., Baltimore, which sells and leases office equipment.
The cash amount was not disclosed.


Evans Captures First Gold for U.S.
LEAD: Janet Evans stands 5 feet 6 inches and weighs 105 pounds, and if she has muscles she hides them well.
But she swims with boundless energy and single-mindedness, and on Monday she turned those assets into the United States' first gold medal in the Games of the XXIV Olympiad.

Safeway Purchase
LEAD: Safeway Stores Inc. said it was planning to raise its stake in the Vons Companies to 35 percent from 30 percent.
Last month, Safeway acquired 6.7 million Vons shares as part of a $410 million transaction in which Vons acquired Safeway's operations in Southern California.
Vons is a supermarket chain based in El Monte, Calif.

LEAD: Japan's powerful Zenchu agricultural union said today that it planned to seek support from American farmers in its fight to protect the Japanese rice market from imports.
A spokesman said Zenchu would send representatives to the United States to seek support from American farmers.
Last week, the United States Rice Millers Association filed a complaint with the United States Trade Representative's Office seeking retaliation against Japan for failing to give equal access to its rice markets.

LEAD: The Centel Corporation has bought back a 5.5 percent stake held by the investors Asher B. Edelman and George L. Lindemann, apparently ending a $2.68 billion takeover bid.
The 2.15 million shares were purchased for $43 each, or about $92.5 million.
Centel, based in Chicago, said the deal was a market-price repurchase made as part of a program to buy back up to five million shares.

Blast in Downtown Belfast
LEAD: An explosion tore through a complex in downtown Belfast today, the third blast to hit the downtown in the last month, the police said.
Officials said that the site, at Royal Avenue, was cleared after a telephone warning and that no one was hurt.
Security officials said the I.R.A. might be returning to the tactic of urban bombings that wrecked Belfast's commercial district in the 1970's.

LEAD: The Office of Reparations Administration is handling inquiries about restitution to people of Japanese ancestry interned by the United States in World War II.

The Games at a Glance
LEAD:  GYMNASTICS  The exercises may have been optional, but the rest of the competition had little choice but to watch in admiration as the Soviet Union won the gold medal in the men's team competition.
The Soviet athletes, the dominant force in men's gymnastics, put on a stunning display of individual talent and collective strength, garnering at least one perfect score in five of the six events and three from Dmitri Bilozerchev as they easily outpointed East Germany, which took the silver.

Newmont Sells Foreign Unit
LEAD: The Newmont Mining Corporation, one of the largest gold mining companies in the United States, said today that it had agreed to sell the foreign assets of its Newmont Oil Company subsidiary to the Dutch subsidiary of Clyde Petroleum P.L.C., a British oil exploration company, for $234 million.
Under the terms of the agreement, the Clyde subsidiary, Clyde Petroleum B.V., will assume $46.7 million in liabilities, including debt and taxes.

Customs Charge On Chip Imports
LEAD: The National Semiconductor Corporation disclosed in its annual report, released this week, that the District Director of United States Customs in San Francisco had charged the company with underpaying duties of about $19.5 million between June 1, 1979, and March 1, 1985, on chips it imported from foreign subsidiaries.

A Moral Test for Congress
LEAD: Will Congress go home without passing a congressional ethics law?
The Senate passed one four months ago, and a weaker version is ready for the House Judiciary Committee.
Many a legislator and staff member wouldn't mind if time ran out.
If that happens, Congress will have perpetuated a notorious double standard.

About New York; A Korean Feast Of Kimchi, Mook And Much Pride
LEAD: ''Gun-Bae!'' the Koreans exclaimed, hoisting glasses of ice-cold OB beer in their traditional toast.
Among the delicacies arrayed on the table were mook, a jelly made from acorns; hundreds of tiny marinated anchovies, heads still attached, and, most typically Korean, kimchi, a fiery pickled cabbage best marinated for months.

Close-Up: Team Handball
LEAD:  Two Sports in One  The game is a combination of soccer and basketball, played indoors on a varnished hardwood floor, with six players and a goalie on each side.
The object is to throw the ball, which is about the size of a cantelloupe, into the goal, either in the air or on a bounce.
Players dribble, pass and shoot with their hands, and cannot shoot from closer than 6 meters from the goal.

San Francisco
LEAD: VISITORS to other nations are often enchanted by their bustling markets, so distinct from this country's antiseptic supermarkets.

Note to Readers
LEAD: The Op-Ed page welcomes unsolicited manuscripts.
Because of the growing volume of submissions, however, we regret that we can no longer return articles unless accompanied by a self-addressed, stamped envelope.


L.I.R.R. May Add Double-Decker Coaches
LEAD: The Long Island Rail Road would operate a rush-hour train with double-decker cars by the end of 1990 under a pilot program the railroad's parent agency is expected to approve Friday.


Woman, 37, Is Slain; Student, 19, Arrested
LEAD: A 37-year-old Westchester woman who was known to jog regularly around the Somers High School track was found dead in nearby woods on Monday and a 19-year-old student at the school was charged yesterday with her slaying, the police said.


Parking Rules
LEAD: Because of Yom Kippur, the Jewish Day of Atonement, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today.
Other regulations remain in effect.


G.O.P. Chooses Gorton; Democrats' Race Is Close
LEAD: Slade Gorton, a Republican attempting a Senate comeback, coasted to a easy primary victory today while in the Democratic primary Representative Mike Lowry narrowly led Representative Don Bonker for their party's Senate nomination.


Japanese Plan on U.S. Chips
LEAD: Japan's chip makers disclosed a plan today that calls for closer relations with American chip suppliers.

LEAD: Interco Inc. began defending itself today against a hostile takeover attempt.

LEAD: They rode back to the Olympic Village in a taxi, a boxer and his coach, Army buddies, sitting silently, having difficulty making conversation.

LEAD: A United States-Soviet venture to open 18 print shops and a central printing plant in the Soviet Union was announced today.

Tests Show Shroud of Turin To Be Fraud, Scientist Hints
LEAD: A scientist associated with the Vatican-sponsored analysis of the Shroud of Turin hinted broadly yesterday that the reputed burial cloth of Jesus has been proved to be a medieval forgery.


Talking Deals; Ford and Nissan Take New Route
LEAD: IN announcing last week that they would jointly produce and sell a new mini-van in this country, the Ford Motor Company and Nissan Motor Company were trying to solve a common problem: how to introduce a new model without all the expense of developing it on their own.

LEAD: It may take time, but the news will eventually reach Bulgaria, Naim Suleymanoglu said.
He will call his parents, whom he hasn't seen in almost two years.

McCann-Erickson Wins Champion Plugs
LEAD: The Detroit office of McCann-Erickson, the agency for General Motors' Chevrolet, has been awarded the Champion Spark Plug Company business, which, trade sources say, could bill up to $15 million.


The Healing Power Of a Bit of Solitude
LEAD: WHENEVER Olinda Turturo, an aspiring actress in New York City, has an important audition, she schedules some time to be alone, either reading or watching television.


Federal Policy Against Discrimination Is Sought for AIDS Victims
LEAD: Since a Presidential commission urged a Federal ban against AIDS discrimination as its major recommendation in June, neither the President nor Congress has acted and the states remain divided over how to address the issue.
Some states still provide no safeguards against discrimination for its victims.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Hockey  Devils and Whalers Tie: The Devils scored twice 29 seconds apart but finished in a 2-2 tie with the Whalers in an exhibition game last night before a crowd of 11,234 at Civic Center in Hartford.
All the goals came in the second period of a game in which the Devils outshot the Whalers, 36-27.

Chicago Journal; Trap and Skeet Shooting: Is It Sport or Pollution?
LEAD: Fred Lappe pressed his cheek to the shotgun stock, barked the ritual command ''Pull!'' and took aim as a clay pigeon whirled over the Lake Michigan shoreline.
There was a sharp report and the target exploded over the water.


BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:  THE ECONOMY  The Treasury began an investigation of the savings industry in an attempt to develop an accurate estimate of the cost of resolving the status of the nation's 500 insolvent savings institutions.
Senator William Proxmire, the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, said the next Congress would have to appropriate at least $20 billion to liquidate and merge these institutions.

123-Pound Gold Medalist Fails Drug Test
LEAD: The first 1988 Olympic medalist to fail a drug test was stripped of his gold medal today, the day after his 24th birthday.


Reagan Backs Bush In Assailing Dukakis Over Issue of Pledge
LEAD: President Reagan, supporting Vice President Bush's attacks on Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis, said today that teachers should be required to lead students in reciting the Pledge of Allegiance because ''that's what they're there for.''


Bergen Paper Curbed On Delivery in Passaic
LEAD: A Superior Court judge has ordered a Bergen County-based newspaper to delay plans for morning home delivery in neighboring Passaic County.


Olympic Highlights
LEAD:  SWIMMING: One day after Matt Biondi's disappointing silver-medal finish in the 100-meter butterfly, the swimmer from Moraga, Calif., set an Olympic record in a heat of the 100-meter freestyle.


Digital Sets Pact to Buy MIPS Computer Design
LEAD: The Digital Equipment Corporation said today that it had entered a technology exchange agreement with MIPS Computer Systems Inc. for technology and designs developed by MIPS in reduced instruction set computing, or RISC.


Brazil Sets Oil Targets
LEAD: Brazil plans to double its crude oil production within a decade, nearly eliminating import needs, an official of the state oil company said Tuesday.
Brazil, which now produces about 630,000 barrels a day, has set goals of one million barrels a day in 1993 and 1.5 million in 1997, Milton Franke of Petroleo Brasileiro, told an international oil conference.

MOSCOW IMPOSES EMERGENCY DECREE IN ETHNIC CONFLICT
LEAD: The Soviet Union today declared a state of emergency in a disputed southern territory as the ethnic conflict between Armenians and Azerbaijanis worsened.


Africans Weigh Threat of AIDS to Economies
LEAD: The economic consequences of the AIDS epidemic in Africa could be so disastrous that the growth rates of already fragile nations could be reduced to zero, a gathering of scientists has been told.


Corrections
LEAD: A report in the Advertising column of Business Day yesterday about Global Information misidentified the previous magazine started by the creators of Global Finance.
It was Venture.


Brazil Will Sign Debt Pact
LEAD: Brazil will sign an $82 billion financial package with its international commercial bank creditors today, it was announced yesterday.
A preliminary accord was reached in July.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on the Health Page on Sept. 1 about possible dangers to elderly users of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs omitted information on the dosages involved.
The study indicated that chronic use of high-dose prescription versions of the pain-killing drugs, including ibuprofen, could cause ulcers and other serious disorders.


Suzuki '89 Models
LEAD: The Suzuki Motor Company introduced two automobiles for 1989, including a four-wheel-drive car.
The company also introduced its first car made specifically for the United States market.
The new models are the Sidekick, a slightly larger four-wheel-drive vehicle, and the subcompact Swift, Suzuki's first car for the United States market.


Rate of Diplomas and Degrees Is the Highest Ever, U.S. Says
LEAD: More Americans have high school diplomas and college degrees than ever before, the Census Bureau reported today.


Walsh May Go Pro
LEAD: Steve Walsh, the Miami junior who passed for a career-high 335 yards and 3 touchdowns to rally the top-ranked Hurricanes to a 31-30 victory over Michigan last Saturday, has led Miami to 14 straight victories as a starting quarterback.
But as Bernie Kosar did in 1985, Walsh is considering the possibility of forgoing his final year of eligibility as a fifth-year senior to turn professional.


Yankees Ready For Last Shot
LEAD: Even after their failure last weekend in Boston, the Yankees somehow convinced themselves they were not finished.
Apparently, it worked.


Open Positions on Short Sales Edge Up on the Big Board
LEAD: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that the number of shares sold short and not yet covered rose three-tenths of 1 percent in the four-week period ended Sept. 15.


Index for New York Area Shows Costs 0.5% Higher
LEAD: Prices in the New York-northeastern New Jersey area rose one-half of 1 percent in August, fueled by higher retail food costs and the yearly introduction of apparel lines, the Labor Department reported yesteray.
In July the area's prices rose four-tenths of 1 percent.

Still, it clearly appeals to enough ticket buyers to have become a perennial.

Dollar Moderately Higher; Trading Is Reported Light
LEAD: The dollar rose mildly against most key currencies yesterday, but analysts attributed the strength to internal market influences and said trading remained light because of the observance of Yom Kippur.


Protest Gets Ugly After Korean Loses
LEAD: South Korean boxing coaches attacked a New Zealand referee after one of their boxers lost a decision to a Bulgarian today in a 119-pound class bout.


Citicorp Backing Paper in Buyout
LEAD: The Capital Markets Assurance Corporation, a subsidiary of Citicorp, is guaranteeing $124 million in commercial paper for the Rhodes Financial Services Corporation, a special-purpose subsidiary of Rhodes Inc.
It marks the first time that commercial paper, backed by consumer receivables, has been used in the initial financing of a leveraged buyout.

Burton Benjamin Service
LEAD: A memorial service for Burton Benjamin, a former vice president and director of CBS News, who died on Sunday, is to be held at the Ethical Culture Society Meeting House, 2 West 64th Street, on Sept. 30 at 11 A.M.


Turkey Senses Boon to Image In Kurd Policy
LEAD: While insisting that it is a secondary consideration, Turkish Government officials see the recent influx of Kurdish refugees from Iraq as a welcome opportunity to improve a human-rights image that could stand some burnishing overseas.


Soviet Sweep In All-Around
LEAD: The Soviet Union's three best male gymnasts staged a sensational battle for the Olympic all-around championship tonight, with Vladimir Artemov winning the gold medal despite Dmitri Belozerchev scoring perfect 10.00's on his last three apparatuses.


Life in the 30's
LEAD: ONE of the most beautiful and most moving love stories I have read in a long time is contained in a new book titled ''Borrowed Time'' (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich).
It is about the devotion that two human beings have to each other, even in the maelstrom of death, and about how that devotion enobles and elevates both of their existences.

LEAD: An urban guerrilla group, the Red Army Faction, claimed responsibility today for an unsuccessful shotgun attack on a senior West German official.

LEAD: A futures trading firm with 17 offices in Florida, California, New York and Michigan has agreed to close as part of its settlement of fraud charges leveled by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration rebuked House Speaker Jim Wright of Texas today for discussing information about covert activities in Nicaragua, but it did not deny his statement that the Central Intelligence Agency had deliberately incited opposition activities there.

Parent &amp; Child
LEAD: LISA HEISER knows that in the next nine months she will see a lot of very anxious college students and, occasionally, hear from upset and frustrated parents.
As director of the career development office at the University of Minnesota College of Liberal Arts, Ms.
Heiser helps students figure out how they can earn a living once they're through with school.

Solarz's Long Shadow
LEAD: Washington takes little notice of some events that are big news in the far corners of the world.
The day after Representative Stephen J. Solarz, the Brooklyn Democrat, returned from Burma earlier this month, the House passed his resolution supporting democratic processes in that troubled nation.
The United States Information Agency distributed the text of the resolution to all but one of the six


Henley Plan On Splitting
LEAD: Henley Group Inc. yesterday provided details of its plan, announced in March, to split into two separate public companies.
The two companies would be Wheelabrator Group Inc., which would hold Henley's refuse-to-energy assets, and the new Henley Group, which would get the remaining assets, mainly in manufacturing and chemicals.

Campaign Trail; The Nominees Get Advice on Debates
LEAD: The Dukakis camp is swathing their candidate with advice and preparation for the upcoming debate.
There are videotapes of past debates available, if Mr.
Dukakis wants to watch them.
There is a briefing book, if he wants to read it.
The staff has even arranged for Mr.
Dukakis to campaign in a studio with cameras and lights, if he feels he needs it.


Campaign Trail; On the Soap Box, A Matter of Inches
LEAD: The Bush campaign has been scouting around for some hot new issues with which to deck the Duke.
The patriotism theme is running thin and, with hecklers carrying signs reading ''Patriotism Is the Last Refuge of Scoundrels,'' even the Vice President seemed to feel that mentioning the Pledge of Allegiance again might be edging into jingoism.


Families' Share of Households Has Shrunk
LEAD: The percentage of American households in which the people who live together are related - by marriage or otherwise - has declined by a fifth in the last 40 years, the Census Bureau has reported.


Metro Matters; Boerum's 'Law': Victim Arrested, Thief Goes Free
LEAD: When Barbara Sparhawk bought her 19th-century carriage house for $29,000 12 years ago, Boerum Hill in Brooklyn was on the frontier of gentrification.

Rights of the Mother Upheld in Settlement
LEAD: The Michigan court action this week in the first legal challenge to a law making it a crime to arrange a contract with a surrogate mother may mark an emerging consensus on the legal status of such arrangements.


Bush, Like Reagan in 1980, Seeks Tax Cuts to Stimulate the Economy
LEAD: Although supply-side economic theory has lost some of its luster since it helped Ronald Reagan get elected in 1980, the tenets of that philosophy are at the heart of Vice President Bush's proposals to keep the economy strong through a new round of tax cuts.


Tailback Ineligible
LEAD: Vince Workman, Ohio State's starting tailback, will lose his eligibility for the rest of his senior season because he signed with an agent, Athletic Director Jim Jones announced yesterday.
Workman played in both the 26-9 victory over Syracuse on Sept. 17 and the 42-10 loss to Pitt last Saturday.
Workman said he accepted $1,000 from a San Francisco-based agent, David Lueddeke, to help his kid brothers.


Mets Clinch Tie for Title but Lose Ojeda for Season; Pitchers Finger Severely Cut
LEAD: Bob Ojeda, the ace left-hander of the Mets, suffered a career-threatening injury yesterday when an electric hedge clipper nearly severed the upper part of his left middle finger as he was trimming the honeysuckle bushes at his home in Port Washington, L.I.


Fare Study Looks at T.W.A.
LEAD: A Congressional study concluded that Trans World Airlines' fares rose sharply at St.
Louis after T.W.A. became the dominant carrier there through a Government-approved merger.


Expensive Lobbying Pays Off for Rifle Association
LEAD: The National Rifle Association's costly lobbying effort played a far greater role last week in the House's rejection of a gun control measure than did the group's contributions to lawmakers' re-election campaigns, according to several politicians and strategists on both sides.


The Pepsico Summerfare Says Next Summer Will Be Its Last
LEAD: The Pepsico Summerfare, a music festival admired internationally for its freshness and quality, announced yesterday that it would cease operations at the end of next summer.
The festival has operated since 1980 out of the four-theater Performing Arts Center at the State University College at Purchase, N.Y.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on the Media Business page on Monday about United Press International included an erroneous account received from a U.P.I. executive about the news agency's relationship with SuperNews, an electronic information service.
SuperNews is marketed and sold over the Financial News Network.
U.P.I.


Aouita Is Prepared for a Big Challenge
LEAD: The Olympic track and field competition starts Friday after an exciting summer outdoor season, great expectations for Olympic if not world records and now the possibility that Said Aouita of Morocco will try an improbable triple, running the 800-, 1,500- and 5,000-meter races.


Fish Oil Pill Seen as Artery Aid
LEAD: Taking fish oil capsules dramatically reduces the chances that coronary arteries will become clogged again after angioplasty, a procedure in which doctors use a tiny balloon to open clogged arteries, according to a study.


Williams Stricken
LEAD: Doug Williams, the Washington Redskins quarterback, was hopsitalized after practice yesterday for tests after having experienced abdominal pains and later underwent surgery for acute appendicitis.
He is expected to be out at least for weeks, the team said.
In his place, the starter for Sunday's game against the Cardinals in Phoenix will be Mike Rypien, a second-year player from Washington State who has never taken a snap in a regular-season game.


Moscow Said to Suggest Separate Pact on Warheads
LEAD: Soviet officials have privately suggested that the United States and the Soviet Union complete a side agreement that would limit the number of warheads on nuclear missiles in advance of a new strategic arms treaty, American officials said today.


Japan Stake in U.S. Realty
LEAD: A Japanese life insurance company has bought 20 percent of LaSalle Partners Ltd., one of the nation's largest privately held corporate real estate companies.


Import Petition Rejected
LEAD: The International Trade Commission has rejected a petition for curbs on imports of automotive shock absorbers from Brazil.
The Federal agency voted, 5 to 0, Tuesday against the complaint, filed by the Monroe Auto Equipment Company, of injury to American producers.

Savings Bailout Warning
LEAD: The American Bankers Association said Tuesday that $74 billion would be needed to rescue the ailing savings and loan industry and that the use of taxpayers' funds ''now appears unavoidable.'' This estimate from the association, which represents 95 percent of the nation's 13,500 commercial banks, is about 50 percent greater than Federal projections.

Yom Kippur Affects Contests
LEAD: It does not seem fair, but because the ultimate responsibility for the rules in the Olympic Games rests with each international sports federation, athletes with identical problems can be treated very differently.
Today was Yom Kippur, the most solemn Jewish holy day, and observant Jews could not participate in competition until after sundown.


Smokers Urged to Quit To Reduce Radon Peril
LEAD: Since smokers are 10 times more likely to die of lung cancer caused by radon than are nonsmokers, the best way for many homeowners to cut the risk of developing radon-related cancer is not to undertake expensive home repairs, but to quit smoking, a former Federal environmental official has said.


Close-Up: Equestrian Dressage
LEAD:  Test of Style  Dressage is a test of a rider's and a horse's control, pace, seat, regularity and ease of movement.
Inseparable Teams  Competitors are given from 1 to 10 points in various categories.
Horses can be any breed, but must be at least six years old.
Horse and rider are an inseparable team; if either is unable to perform, the entry is scratched.

Orbit, an electronics concern in Hauppauge, L.I., has 9.5 million shares outstanding.

The demanding process most of them go through on their way to professional maturity has led to a high level of accomplishment.

Head of Irish Airline Faces New Challenges
LEAD: Aer Lingus has named Cathal Mullan chief executive, effective Dec. 1, as Ireland's national airline prepares for an expansion.


Construction Of Housing Down 3.3%
LEAD: Housing construction fell 3.3 percent last month, to an annual level of 1.44 million units, as a decline in apartment construction outweighed a small gain in the building of single-family homes.


Angry Americans Finish 4th
LEAD: One by one they said it was all right.
In their hearts, the six Americans who finished fourth in the women's gymnastics team competition tonight knew they had won the Olympic bronze medal, even if the final standing showed otherwise, even if their worst suspicions were true.

The Editorial Notebook; The Truth About Pacific Salmon
LEAD: Every schoolchild knows that after salmon spawn on Northwestern rivers, they die without returning to the sea.
But until a recent trip to Alaska, I never gave the matter much thought.
I assumed that having met their connubial responsibilities, the exhausted fish simply departed for salmon heaven somehow, leaving behind only the memory of their sleek muscular forms.

Needham's Flourishing Japan Link
LEAD: THE 12-year-old relationship between DDB Needham Worldwide of the United States and Dai-Ichi Kikaku of Japan continues to flourish and grow, with the latest venture being the biggest yet announced.


Japan Vehicle Output
LEAD: Japan's vehicle production fell 2.6 percent in August from a year earlier, the first drop since a 2 percent decline in January, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today.
An association official said the lower production of 782,895 was caused by fewer operating days in August and the remodeling of major cars.


Two Shot, One Fatally, As They Sit in an Auto
LEAD: A 19-year-old man and an 18-year-old woman were sitting in a car in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn last night when an unidentified man approached the car, pulled out a gun, and shot them both, killing the man, the police said.

LEAD: Nineteen people were wounded today when a mine exploded during the evening rush hour at a busy bus terminal, the police reported.

Putting a New Finish On Old Wooden Floors
LEAD: IF you want to refinish your wood floors, you need three things besides sanding equipment: time, energy and a very strong back.


Review/Opera; New Violetta And Germont In 'La Traviata'
LEAD: Sunday evening's ''Traviata'' at the New York City Opera brought two singers to their roles for the first time in the house.
Frances Ginsberg, the new Violetta, is a singer of temperament and vocal strength, and on her own terms she made an affecting statement in the role.
Those terms include a sensitivity to dynamic light and shade, a full tone around the top of the treble staff, and an enthusiasm for verismo-style effects in singing and deportment.


TREASURY SEEKING TO DETERMINE COST OF SAVINGS RESCUE
LEAD: Concerned about conflicting estimates of the cost of dealing with 500 insolvent savings and loan associations, the Treasury Department said today that it had begun its own investigation of the problem.


U.S. Averts Atom Agency's Ouster of Pretoria
LEAD: The Reagan Administration appears to have succeeded in its drive to stop South Africa from being expelled from the international organization that oversees the nuclear industry and tries to halt the spread of atomic weapons, American officials said today.

2 Hunts File for Personal Bankruptcy
LEAD: Nelson Bunker Hunt and William Herbert Hunt each filed for personal bankruptcy protection today to avoid having to post a $225 million bond required for appealing a Federal jury verdict against them.


Jury Has Mexico Murder Case
LEAD: The case of three men charged with the kidnapping and murder of a United States narcotics agent in Mexico went to a Federal jury Tuesday.
The prosecution says the defendants, one of whom is a former Mexican police officer, acted at the behest of a drug baron, Rafael Caro Quintero, because he feared assaults by Drug Enforcement Administration agents, like Enrique Camarena, who was killed, on his drug empire.

Rise in Farmland Prices
LEAD: A modest upturn in United States farmland values has been slowed by this summer's drought, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday.
Rural appraisers surveyed in August reported a 1.2 percent increase in nationwide farmland prices for the May-to-July period, lower than the 1.8 percent gain reported for the preceding three months, the agency said in its monthly agricultural report.

Jeep Output to Rise
LEAD: The Chrysler Motors Corporation said it would expand production at its two plants that make the popular Jeep line of sport utility vehicles.
Beginning in January 1989, annual production of Jeeps will increase by 55,000 units.
The Toledo Jeep plant, which has current capacity of 220,000 units, will increase its production of Jeep Cherokees, Wagoneers and Comanches by 23,000 units.

A Lesson From Suriname
LEAD: MATT BIONDI, the king salmon of this United States Olympic swimming team, never predicted he would splash to seven gold medals, the record total swept by Mark Spitz at Munich in 1972.
Seven medals were all Biondi thought about, not seven golds.
But when Biondi had to be satisfied with a bronze in the 200-yard freestyle earlier this week behind Duncan Armstrong of Australia and Anders Holmertz of Sweden, he no longer had even the opportunity to match


Costa Ricans Celebrate Medal
LEAD: Hundreds of jubilant residents spilled into the streets here Tuesday to celebrate Costa Rica's first Olympic Games medal, the silver won by Silvia Poll in the women's 200-meter freestyle swimming race.


Citizens' Holders Vote Acquisition
LEAD: Citizens Financial Group Inc.'s shareholders overwhelmingly approved the sale of the company to the Royal Bank of Scotland, the sixth-largest bank in Britain, for $440 million in cash.
If the $30.50-a-share deal is approved by regulators, it would be the first foreign takeover of a leading New England bank and would transform Citizens into one of the largest of the regional banking companies in the Northeast.

Haitian Struggles to Consolidate Power
LEAD: Lieut.
Gen.
Prosper Avril struggled today to consolidate power on his fifth day as President of Haiti, but a garrison north of the capital was reported in rebellion.
Elsewhere, enlisted men and junior officers were carrying out a purge against mid-level commanders.

Botswana Foils Jail Rescue
LEAD: Botswana said today that its police have arrested a black South African commando who planned to rescue two South African soldiers from prison.
A black Botswanan lawyer has also been arrested in the plot, which was intended to free a pair of soldiers captured in an abortive South African raid into Botswana in June.

LEAD: Leaders of Boston's police union endorsed George Bush for President in a unanimous vote today.
They said the Vice President would do a better job than Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts in meeting the needs of law enforcement.

Miller Lite Stays At Backer Spielvogel
LEAD: The heady sighs of relief from the gang at Backer Spielvogel Bates signals the fact the Miller Brewing Company, one of its primary accounts, has decided after a rigorous review to keep its Miller Lite brand aboard.
It is being called an $80 million account.

Home Improvement
LEAD: ROOF gutters protect buildings from serious damage resulting from poor drainage.
In late fall and early spring, gutters should be inspected, cleared of debris and repaired if necessary so that they continue to function efficiently.
But if you live where there are many trees, postpone cleaning your gutter until after the leaves have fallen.


Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q. My two-story pre-1930 house has a flat roof above the second-story apartment.
I want to insulate the roof to minimize heat loss in the winter, but am at a loss about how -or whether - this should be done.


Heavy Selloff Pushes Gold Price Below $400
LEAD: Gold prices in New York plunged below the important level of $400 an ounce yesterday for the first time in 19 months, as worries over inflation continued to ease.


Key Executive At Y.&amp;R. Quits
LEAD: John Ferrell, until recently the top creative man in the New York office of Young &amp; Rubicam, is leaving the agency because, as a staff memo from Arthur R. Klein, president, New York, says, he ''has decided that he does not want to accept the new assignments we had offered him.''


Latin Blood Money
LEAD: Latin American nations, already deeply in debt to private banks, are now also being drained by the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.
These institutions are siphoning about $2 billion annually from Latin America.
At their annual meetings next week in Berlin, the agencies must face the question of how to reverse this destructive trend.

Saul Bellow Tries a New Approach
LEAD: Saul Bellow has written a novella that will be published as a paperback original.
The book, ''A Theft,'' will be published by Penguin next March.
It is thought to be the first time a major American literary figure has elected to be published first in paperback.


The Bomb Maker Becomes a Bomb
LEAD: Decay hangs darkly over the manufacturing complex that makes America's nuclear weapons, an enterprise so vast it ranks with the 20 largest corporations.
Extended lack of maintenance and pollution control now endanger both national security and the environment.


Tyson vs. TV Camera
LEAD: A day after Mike Tyson ducked camera crews when he arrived at Kennedy International Airport at the end of his trip to the Soviet Union, a camera crew was said to be doing the ducking yesterday.


Thieves Prey on Aged Subway Turnstiles
LEAD: The archaic low-technology turnstiles of the New York City subway - built mostly in the 1930's and 40's to collect five-cent fares - are being plundered as never before by organized gangs and individual thieves who cruise the system and break the aging mechanisms faster than the Transit Authority can keep them repaired.

Review/Television; Barbs and High Praise From Justice Marshall
LEAD: An interview with a Supreme Court Justice is something of an event, which is a reason to watch ''Thurgood Marshall: The Man,'' on Channel 13 tonight at 9 o'clock.
Justice Marshall chats in folksy manner with the columnist Carl T. Rowan.
Few of Justice Marshall's views will astonish anyone acquainted with his long career as a fighter for civil rights, but they are delivered in pithy one-liners of a sort not often heard on the high bench.

LEAD: The Consumer Price Index, the nation's most widely followed inflation gauge, rose in August by four-tenths of 1 percent, the same as in July, the Labor Department reported today.

PERSONAL HEALTH
LEAD: Mammograms are extremely useful tools in the war against breast cancer, a disease that now strikes one woman in 10 in this country.
These low-dose X-ray examinations of the soft breast tissue can often reveal cancer even before the woman or her doctor can detect it as a lump or other physical abnormality.

Review/Film; A Family Stays Nervous Once You've Shot Dad
LEAD: Patrick Swayze, lately of ''Dirty Dancing,'' gets a chance in ''Tiger Warsaw'' to be brooding and boyish, soulful and shaky and to show off his chest.
He plays a fellow in his early 30's who returns home 15 years after having made a mess of the family household and tries to pick up the pieces.
What the young Charles (Tiger) Warsaw did, we gather through quick flashbacks, was shoot his dad after being caught peeping at his sister, who was in her undies at the time.


Space Agency Says Proper Nozzle Rings Are in New Rockets
LEAD: The space agency said today that the proper nozzle inlet rings were in the rockets attached to the space shuttle even thought it had been discovered that an outdated ring was used in the final test of the redesigned booster rocket for the shuttle.


Results PlusB. J. Scoot Triumphs: B. J. Scoot never trailed and won the 43d Little Brown Jug by 1 1/4 lengths over Threefold before a crowd of 47,218 yesterday at the Delaware County Fairgrounds in Delaware, Ohio. B. J. Scoot, driven by Michel LaChance, had times of 26 4/5 seconds for the quarter-mile, a Jug-record 53 4/5 for the half, and 1:23 for three quarters on the way to a winning time of 1:52 3/5 for the mile. The 3-year-old pacer, owned by Sybarite Stable of Islington, Ontario, was the first Ohio-bred horse ever to win the Little Brown Jug. Threefold, driven by Bill Fahy, finished two lengths ahead of Dare You To, driven by John Campbell. B. J. Scoot paid $6 for $2 to win. (AP)  Golf  4-Way Tie in B.C. Open: Ed Dougherty, Jim Simons and Roger Maltbie each shot six-under-par 65 yesterday morning and watched as their scores held up throughout the day for the first-round lead at the $500,000 B.C. Open in Endicott. N.Y. They were joined atop the leader board by Dave Rummells, who converted birdies on four of his last six holes at the par-71 En-Joie Golf Course.(AP)  Tennis  Mezzadri Eliminated: Eduardo Bengoechea of Argentina eliminated the defending champion, Claudio Mezzadri of Switzerland, 6-2, 6-2 yesterday in 79 minutes to advance to the quarterfinals of the $220,000 Geneva Open. Bengoechea will meet Jordi Arrese, seeded third, who beat Jesus Colas, 6-1, 6-3, in other second-round play yesterday.(AP)

THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Notebook; For Seoul's Mayor, A Rule to Regret
LEAD: After asking Seoul's 10 million citizens to reduce traffic congestion during the Olympic Games by alternating the days they drove their cars, Mayor Kim Yong Nae switched the license plates on his car so that he could be on the road every day.

LEAD: The huge man shot down as he raged murderously in St.
Patrick's Cathedral Wednesday evening was described yesterday as a severely disoriented street dweller who had been arrested at least 11 times and hospitalized as a mental patient 7 times.


WRIGHT IS DENYING SECRET DATA LEAK
LEAD: Jim Wright, the Speaker of the House, today categorically denied that he had revealed classified intelligence information this week when he told reporters that Congress had ''clear testimony'' that the Central Intelligence Agency was inciting opposition activities in Nicaragua.

MILITARY CABINET NAMED IN LEBANON
LEAD: President Amin Gemayel appointed a military government headed by a Christian general to rule Lebanon today after a deeply divided Parliament failed to choose a successor for him on the last day of his six-year term.

LEAD: As Emperor Hirohito lay seriously ill, Japan filed a formal diplomatic protest in London today over items in the British press that called the monarch ''a worse butcher than Hitler'' and said that ''he will surely be guaranteed a special place in hell.''

Unisys Loan of Computers Is Said to Be Under Scrutiny
LEAD: The Army and a Congressional committee are investigating whether the Unisys Corporation illegally supplied computers to the National Guard in 1986 without having received a valid order for the equipment, committee officials say.


MCI at Year's High On Rosy Forecast
LEAD: Shares of the MCI Communications Corporation, the nation's second-largest long-distance company, rallied yesterday to a 52-week high, aided by a bullish recommendation from a Paine Webber analyst.
MCI climbed 87.5 cents, to $19.50, in heavy over-the-counter trading.

It placed him seventh in the competition.

Review/Film; A Nuclear Cover-Up in Australia
LEAD: What connection can there be between a long-buried radioactive airplane and a smart young cinematographer who films dancing chili dogs for a living?
It's the kind of connection that's often found in taut, clever conspiracy-theory thrillers, of which the new Australian film ''Ground Zero'' is a prime example.


Honor Journal; Success Threatens Salmon Fishing
LEAD: For two decades the economy of this village of 300 has been tied to the three-year life cycle of the coho salmon that begins life in a hatchery here.
When nature returns the salmon to their natal stream each fall, so, inevitably, return the fishermen chasing the coho as they swim upstream to spawn and die.


How Robert Strauss Sinned
LEAD: Robert Strauss, the prominent Democrat, was speaking simple truth.
The way to shrink big budget deficits, he said, is to look for savings in the biggest programs, ''because that's where the money is.'' He hinted that the National Economic Commission, of which he is co-chairman, might cast its eye on Social Security.


Quayle, on Foreign Policy, Cites Monroe Doctrine
LEAD: Senator Dan Quayle of Indiana, the Republican Vice-Presidential nominee, delivered the most substantive foreign affairs speech of his 1988 campaign today, offering a vision of ''a century of peace'' and warning Communist countries that the Monroe Doctrine was still ''alive and well'' in the Western


Review/Theater; Writings of Passage
LEAD: The plays presented in the annual Young Playwrights Festival have often dealt with young people going through rites of passage.
In this season's festival (at Playwrights Horizons) there are indications that, at age 7, the series itself has reached its artistic maturity.
Each of the three new playwrights whose works are produced demonstrates a definite theatrical talent, as well as an ability to treat perceptively such subjects as religion, sex and suicide.

A Rite of Purification, A Plea for Forgiveness
LEAD: Wearing the purple vestments of a Mass for forgiveness, John Cardinal O'Connor strode rapidly up and down the aisles of St.
Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning, sprinkling holy water throughout the church in which two men were killed the evening before.


A Magician Breaks Out of the Mold (and the Pack)
LEAD: Prowling a cabaret stage, wearing a sorcerer's robe embellished with stars and moons, the magician Jeff McBride is definitely not David Copperfield: clean-cut is hardly the description that leaps to mind.
It is instantly apparent, too, that this magician is no cheery Doug Henning, as he peers through a forbidding whiteface mask and performs a show dense with drama, mystery and occult symbolism.


JOUSTING KNIGHTS AND ROVING JESTERS IN MEDIEVAL FESTIVAL AT THE CLOISTERS
LEAD: ''THIS is the renaissance of the Middle Ages,'' proclaimed City Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern, whose department is co-sponsoring a fanciful foray into the 15th century on Sunday in Fort Tryon Park in upper Manhattan.


Bush Proposes Defense Policy Based on Edge in Technology
LEAD: Vice President Bush proposed tonight that the United States seek to counter the Soviet Union's advantage in conventional forces by not matching Moscow ''bullets for bullets'' but by more effective strategic planning that would take advantage of this country edges in technology and some weapon systems.


NBC to Give Free Air Time
LEAD: NBC's ratings for the Olympic Games have been so disappointing during the first week that the network yesterday began the process of ''make-goods'' for most of its more than 70 sponsors.
That is the industry term for free advertising to compensate for lower-than-projected ratings.


Atlantic Hurricane Monitored
LEAD: Hurricane Helene's winds intensified to 100 m.p.h. today and forecasters warned Caribbean residents to keep a close watch on its movements even though it was still more than 1,000 miles east of Barbados, about four days' travel at the storm's current rate of speed.
Storm trackers said the hurricane was expected to maintain its westward course for at least the next 24 hours and then might veer onto a more northerly path, missing the Caribbean.


Restaurants
LEAD: In recent years, seafood prices have jumped higher than dolphins at a Florida marine park.
Almost extinct are the clattering old-fashioned fish houses, where simple, grilled fillets (usually dyed with paprika) were served up with a salad, boiled potatoes and cole slaw.
Today's seafood restaurants are more likely to be genteel places with French or Italian accents and princely prices.


Rent-Law Chief Held on Charges In Bribe Inquiry
LEAD: The state official in charge of enforcing New York City's rent-control and rent-stabilization laws was arrested yesterday in Manhattan on bribery and grand larceny charges stemming from an undercover operation organized by the Manhattan District Attorney.


Guitar, With Loops
LEAD: Doug Baldwin will play guitar solos, with tape loops, tonight at 9 at Lunch for Your Ears, 25 Prince Street (941-1774).
Admission is free.


When High Court's Away, Clerks' Work Begins
LEAD: While most of the Supreme Court's nine justices spent a good part of their three-month summer recess out of town, the lights in their chambers burned late as their 33 law clerks plowed through papers in the nearly 100 new cases filed each week.


K Mart Recalls Scissors Sets
LEAD: The K Mart Corporation is recalling 48,000 desk sets that could be dangerous to children, the Consumer Product Safety Commission announced today.
The School Days Scissors Desk Set includes a cutting knife that could injure children, the agency said.

Sam Woodyard Dies; Jazz Drummer Was 63
LEAD: Sam Woodyard, one of three major drummers who played in Duke Ellington's orchestra, died of cancer Tuesday in a Paris hospital, friends reported.
He was 63 years old and had lived in Paris since 1975.


Pop/Jazz; Saxophonists With More Than Be-Bob
LEAD: When Bobby Watson, the 35-year-old alto saxophonist appearing at the Village Vanguard this weekend, plays, he might as well be driving a gospel audience to salvation.
He's an old-style burner, someone who manages to turn every solo into an uproarious event.
Hunched over, he'll send blues phrases reeling into the audience; be-bop trickery shows up, and everything he plays swings.

Jets Will Try to Ground Lions
LEAD: The Jets and the Detroit Lions, who face each other Sunday in Pontiac, Mich., have played only four times since the realignment of the National Football League in 1970.
The last time was on Thanksgiving Day in 1985, and Jet memories are dim.

LEAD: The United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, came to South Africa today and offered his assurances that the United Nations would be impartial in assisting with the transition of Namibia to independence.

THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Gymnastics; All-Around Title To Shoushounova
LEAD: Combining the elegance of a prima ballerina with the stunts of a circus acrobat, Yelena Shoushounova of the Soviet Union commanded perfect 10s from the judges in the floor exercise and vault today to win the women's individual all-around gold medal in gymnastics.


College Football; Georgia Planning to Control South Carolina Passer
LEAD: Coach Vince Dooley and his Georgia team were not too pleased when they escaped with a 42-35 triumph over Mississippi State last week.
It should have been easier for the undefeated Bulldogs, who are thinking of a Southeastern Conference championship.


Election Panel Seeks Stiffer Rules on Spending for Candidates
LEAD: The Federal Election Commission today proposed new rules for a practice in which political parties channel millions of dollars that cannot be donated directly to candidates into efforts that benefit the candidates' campaigns.


Tax Act's Corporate Effect
LEAD: The landmark 1986 tax revision increased the total taxes paid by 250 of the nation's largest corporations by $9 billion last year, but 16 of the corporations surveyed legally paid no Federal income tax, a private research group said today.


Savings Industry Losses Fall a Bit, to $3.6 Billion
LEAD: Huge losses in the savings industry continued in the second quarter but at a slightly lower level, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today.


Fire Report Is Perplexing Main Street, Hackensack
LEAD: After five firefighters died when the roof of a burning car dealership collapsed last July, John R. DeNoy, the owner of John's Coffee Shop near the Bergen County Courthouse, could not understand why the firemen had gone into the building in the first place.


Verbatim
LEAD: Federal financing for the Legal Services Corporation, which provides lawyers for the poor, has diminished since President Reagan took office.
In 1981, Washington appropriated $321 million; in 1988, after seven years of inflation, the figure was $306 million.
In its Oct. 1 issue, The A.B.A.
Journal asked the Presidential candidates what they view as the proper balance between programs like the Legal Services Corporation and the use of private lawyers who volunteer their time.

Corrections
LEAD: A dividend listing in Business Day on Wednesday misstated the value of the regular quarterly stock dividend declared by the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation.
Stockholders of record on Oct. 1 will receive 82 cents a share on Oct. 25.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the Henley Group's plan to split into two companies, the Henley Group and the Wheelabrator Group, misstated the distribution of shares in the new Henley.
For each 100 shares in the existing company, stockholders will receive 22 shares in the new Henley Group, as well as one-half share that will be redeemed in cash.

LEAD: Nicaragua announced tonight that President Daniel Ortega Saavedra would not visit the United States as planned in the coming days because the State Department had refused to grant visas to all members of his 60-member delegation.


Curbside Concert
LEAD: Michael Feinstein, the pianist and Gershwin expert, will give a curbside concert on Sunday at 3 P.M. on Fifth Avenue between 56th and 57th Streets, as part of the ''Love Your Landmarks'' block party.
His repertory will consist largely of songs about New York.
The festivities are sponsored by several preservationist organizations.
