LEAD: Bond prices fell broadly but narrowly yesterday in subdued trading activity.


Review/Film; Schrader's 'Patty Hearst'
LEAD: Patty Hearst, a k a Tania, a member of the self-styled Symbionese Liberation Army, and two of her S.L.A. comrades sit on a bed in an anonymous Los Angeles motel room and watch a ''live'' telecast as the police storm their S.L.A. hideout in another part of the city.
Everyone in the house is finally killed.


'Plow' and 'Butterfly': New Leads, New Light
LEAD: Though David Mamet's ''Speed-the-Plow'' and David Henry Hwang's ''M.
Butterfly'' were among the most highly acclaimed productions of last season, the praise was balanced, at times even drowned out, by dissonant strains of ridicule.
Gregory Mosher, the director of ''Speed-the-Plow,'' took his lumps for the seemingly hypocritical casting of Madonna in a play that mocks the kind of cynical Hollywood moguls who wouldn't think twice about casting Madonna as Eleanor Roosevelt.


THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Swimming; Evans and Biondi Win Gold Again
LEAD: The Matt and Janet show continued Thursday night in Olympic swimming, giving the United States two gold medals in 30 minutes.


Beds in the Street
LEAD: Beds are the competition in an offbeat race to be held Sunday at the South Street Seaport, starting at noon.
Five-person teams, in costume, will roll decorated beds down Water Street in an effort to reach the finish before an alarm clock rings.
Live music will be played along the way.
Awards for the fastest team, best costumes, decorations and team spirit will be presented during a cruise aboard the steamboat De Witt Clinton, which will leave the Seaport at 4 P.M.


FUNDS FOR BURMA SUSPENDED BY U.S.
LEAD: The United States decided today to halt $12 million in aid to Burma to underline its displeasure over the shooting of unarmed protesters by the country's armed forces, a State Department official said.

LEAD: As President Reagan prepares to address the United Nations General Assembly, the Administration is trying to share credit for the United Nations' recent successes, arguing that its earlier criticism and the withholding of the United States' dues has brought results.

LEAD: The president of a Brooklyn demolition company was convicted yesterday of giving payoffs to a Federal inspector to overlook violations of rules for asbestos removal and disposal.


Brazil and Its Creditors Sign Debt Agreement
LEAD: Brazil and its foreign creditor banks signed a sweeping debt agreement yesterday that provides $5.2 billion in new loans and restructures $62 billion worth of medium- and long-term bank debt at sharply lower interest rates.

Ivan, her longtime lover and a male-chauvinist rat, walks out on her, leaving only a bland message on her answering machine.
Planning suicide, Pepa spikes a blenderful of garden-fresh gazpacho with sleeping pills, but forgets to drink it.

And it's hurting Mr.
Dukakis.
Now, some Democrats are saying so publicly.

LEAD: Nine people were injured when a metal piece from an engine sheared off a Pan Am Express airplane and punctured the skin of the aircraft as it approached the Albany County Airport Wednesday night, officials said yesterday.


Bridge
LEAD: There was a time when players would travel to a tournament and be content to play bridge for 7 hours in each 24.
Nowadays, however, many enthusiasts choose to add morning or late-night games, or even both, to the normal afternoon and evening sessions.
Team events are popular, in part because a group with five or six members is slightly better off in terms of sleep.

Haiti's Hopes and General Avril
LEAD: Haiti suffered through another coup last weekend only to sink into new turmoil.
One general had barely replaced another when soldiers mutinied, workers struck and killing returned to the streets.
Yet the soldiers who engineered the coup appear to share with the public a wish to rid Haiti of the brutal, arrogant daily lawlessness.


Program Trading Dwindles
LEAD: Program trading dwindled in August to 8.1 percent of average daily volume on the New York Stock Exchange, from 10.1 percent in July, Big Board officials said yesterday.

LEAD: Last week, a band of thugs who are widely being referred to as Tontons Macoute invaded a Roman Catholic mass here with machetes and guns.
They killed a dozen parishoners, wounded 77 others and set the church afire.

Dining Out Guide: French, Downtown
LEAD: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times.
Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars.
Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.
Au Troquet  ** (April 5, 1985), 328 West 12th Street (924-3413) - Au Troquet, with its lettered awning and patterned lace curtains, captures the style of a neighborhood haunt on the Left


Strangers On a Train, In 'Kansas'
''Kansas'' sets itself up as a suspense story entangled with the people and values of America's heartland.
Here is what happens in one supposedly sleepy little town.
A wheat field-wholesome young man named Wade (Andrew McCarthy) is on his way to New York City.
After his car burns up, he jumps on a freight train where he meets a drifter named Doyle (Matt Dillon) and is so unfazed by his sinister looks - the gold tooth and the panther tattooed on his forearm might have made most folks suspicious - that he hops off the train with his new friend.
Following Doyle's lead, the impressionable Wade breaks into a house, goes to a parade where he spots the girl of his dreams and robs a bank.
But while he is fleeing the bank, a car carrying the Governor's small daughter falls into the river, so Wade saves the child from drowning, runs away and hides the money - all this before lunchtime.
Soon he finds work at a farm owned by the father of the girl of his dreams, a convenient place to roll in the hay, literally, while the town searches for the mystery hero.
The plot slows down after that, but does not get less incredible.
The characters never become intriguing, though we're supposed to wonder about Wade's moral direction when he hangs onto the money, lies to Doyle and is uncovered as the hero.


Police Ruse at Kennedy Airport Trips Up High-Charging Cabbies
LEAD: Twenty of 50 medallion cabdrivers who picked up undercover investigators posing as Asian tourists were arrested yesterday for overcharging their passengers by as much as $75 on trips from Kennedy International Airport to the World Trade Center.


Fannie Mae Plans World Fund Effort
LEAD: The Federal National Mortgage Association, also known as Fannie Mae, said yesterday that it wants to expand its efforts to raise capital in world markets.


Boston U. Relents on Schools
LEAD: Boston University has backed down in its quest for near-total control over Chelsea's schools by agreeing to let the city's School Committee retain some power.


Xerox Unit Offers Notes Set at 9.35%
LEAD: The Xerox Credit Corporation, a unit of the Xerox Corporation, tapped the corporate debt market yesterday with a $100 million issue of notes due 1993.


Former Florida Official Is Guilty in 3 Slayings
LEAD: A former Franklin County Commissioner was convicted Wednesday of killing a judge, a lawyer and his former sister-in-law at an alimony hearing in a courthouse last year.

Sports People; Pallone Part of Inquiry
LEAD: E. Stewart Jones Jr. of Troy, N.Y., an attorney representing Dave Pallone, has confirmed that the former National League umpire was questioned yesterday in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., as part of an investigation of a sex ring involving teen-age boys. ''There is an investigation under way.
The D.A.'s office has not confirmed or denied that, but in fact it is involved,'' Jones said.


Chicago Man Kills 4 and Wounds 2 Before Dying in a Shootout
LEAD: A man ''who never said a word'' shot and killed two people in an auto parts store here today, then fatally wounded a police officer and a custodian at a nearby school before the police killed him.


OLYMPIC HIGHLIGHTS
LEAD:  GYMNASTICS: Yelena Shoushounova of the Soviet Union, with a perfect 10 in the vault, won the women's all-around gold.
She edged Daniela Silivas of Rumania by .025 point.
TRACK: Jackie Joyner-Kersee set an Olympic record in the first event of the heptathlon, the 100-meter hurdles.
Carl Lewis and Ben Johnson, the world record-holder, reached the 100-meter dash semifinals.

LEAD: W. R. Higginbotham, a former correspondent and news executive for United Press, died Wednesday at District of Columbia General Hospital.
He was 74 years old and lived in Fort Worth.

Lewis and Johnson Are Ready
LEAD: They have been running against each other since 1980, and Carl Lewis holds a 9-6 edge outdoors over Ben Johnson, the 100-meter world-record holder.
But on Saturday morning here in the Olympic Stadium, they will burst out of the starting blocks in a 100 that each hopes to burn into track-and-field history.

LEAD: Macmillan Inc. said yesterday that its board had withdrawn its recommendation that shareholders accept the $85-a-share offer from Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts &amp; Company, the buyout firm.
The Kohlberg, Kravis bid is lower than a subsequent bid of $86.80 a share from Robert Maxwell, the British financier.

LEAD: For the second time in three years, the Mets marched to the championship of the National League's East last night, and they did it with a fury as they won their 8th straight game, the 13th in their last 14 and the 23d in their last 28.

The Games at a Glance
LEAD:  Track and Field  After running more than 26 miles, Rosa Mota won it in a walk.
Mota, the world champion from Portugal, easily won the women's marathon, jogging the final 100 meters with a raised fist and shining smile.
Mota, who finished third at the Los Angeles Games in 1984, completed the course in 2 hours 25 minutes 39 seconds.

House Panel Seeks to Penalize Iraq for Gas Use
LEAD: Over the objections of the Reagan Administration, the House Foreign Affairs Committee approved legislation today that would impose economic sanctions on Iraq as a penalty for the use of chemical weapons against Kurdish guerrillas.

LEAD: An explosion and fire tore through an American-operated oil-drilling rig in the North Sea today, but all but one of the 67 people aboard appear to have been rescued, the Coast Guard said.


U.S. Pupils Get Low Mark in Science
LEAD: American pupils' understanding of science has improved slightly, but it remains ''distressingly low'' and threatens American economic and social progress, a major new educational study concludes.


Democrats in the Bronx Nominate 3 for Court
LEAD: Assemblyman George Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader who lost control of a Democratic judicial district convention last year, staved off another challenge last night and succeeded in nominating three of his choices for the State Supreme Court in the Bronx.


Sports People; Leyland Seeks Security
LEAD: Manager Jim Leyland, who has guided the Pittsburgh Pirates to second place this year, has let it be known that he is seeking the longterm security of a two-year contract when the third of his one-year agreements runs out at the end of the season.
Management seems completely receptive to the idea. ''He's done a marvelous job,'' said Carl Barger, the Pirates' president.


Inquiry Demanded In Gold-Mining Bid
LEAD: Britain's opposition Labor Party demanded a Government inquiry into a huge takeover bid for the British gold-mining giant Consolidated Gold Fields P.L.C. as the stock exchange looked into possible insider trading in its shares.
Luxembourg-based Minerals and Resources, known as Minorco, which is 60 percent owned by Anglo American and De Beers Consolidated Mines of South Africa, made the biggest takeover bid in British history Wednesday, valuing Consolidated at $:2.9 billion ($4.9 billion).


Seabrook Plant Faces New Test
LEAD: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission said yesterday that the Seabrook nuclear plant could not conduct low-power tests until its principal owner, which has filed for bankruptcy protection, could demonstrate its ability to pay for decommissioning the plant if no operating license was granted.


Close-Up
LEAD:  Fencing  Simple yet Complex Game  It is a simple game to understand, but a difficult one to master: touch your opponent and avoid being touched.
Five touches decide a match in early rounds, 10 in later rounds.
Bouts are fought on a piste, a strip of metallic mesh 2 meters wide and 14 meters long for foil and 2 meters by 18 meters for epee and sabre.

LEAD: The sleek, icy elegance of ''Dead Ringers,'' David Cronenberg's film about twin gynecologists teetering on the brink of madness, is unexpected.
Both the director, whose past films include the much gorier ''Scanners'' and ''Videodrome,'' and the highly unusual subject suggest a more lurid approach.

LEAD: To the Editor:


POPE TO KEEP BAN ON WOMEN PRIESTS
LEAD: In a long-awaited document on women's issues, Pope John Paul II will reaffirm his opposition to the ordination of women as priests, Vatican officials said today.
The text is to be issued next week.
The Pope also offers a vigorous defense of women's dignity as equal to men's, the officials said.
The document was described by the officials as a theological and anthropological meditation on the roles that women play in the Roman Catholic Church and in secular society.


'Messing With Their Turnstiles'
LEAD: All the improvements in New York subway service brought by Robert Kiley and David Gunn are imperiled by a new trend: seizure of turnstiles by thieves and thugs.
The heads of the Transit Authority need to respond as forcefully as they did to the defacing of cars with graffiti.


Yanks vs. Red Sox in Revival
LEAD: Outside, under a setting sun, the faithful at Fenway Park rose together and cheered; the Yankees had been left in a heap.
Inside, the Boston Red Sox gathered in the comfort of their clubhouse and smiled.
If there had been champagne somewhere, corks surely would have popped.

Savings Unit Acquired
LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board has announced that the Loves Park Federal Savings Bank of Loves Park, Ill., has been acquired by the Home Federal Savings and Loan Association of Rockford, Ill.
Loves Park is the 106th troubled savings institution to be disposed of this year.
Home Federal received $4.9 million in assistance from the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation.

At The Bar
LEAD: When Lesley Friedman grew fed up with life in her large Manhattan law firm, she sought out kindred spirits last year to work for her fledgling temporary placement service for lawyers.
The young lawyer had no idea how many others were looking for an alternative to conventional careers, but in four days she received more than 1,000 resumes.


4 Suspects in Killing Freed
LEAD: Four suspects in the killing of a 19-year-old man and the wounding of an 18-year-old woman in Brooklyn Wednesday were released yesterday.
The police recovered a 9-millimeter pistol, which they believe was used to shoot Robert Nepolitano of Brooklyn and Lisa Ciullo, also of Brooklyn, who was hit in the leg.

LEAD: An article on Tuesday about Annin &amp; Company, a flag manufacturer in Roseland, N.J., misidentified the union that represents its production workers.

LEAD: Carl Frederick Farbach, a retired lawyer and former Federal counsel, died of cardiopulmonary arrest Sept. 15 at Sibley Memorial Hospital in Washington.
He was 87 years old and lived in Washington.


Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 452 money market mutual funds increased $654.2 million, to $267.24 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 126 institutional funds rose $496.9 million, to $69.06 billion.
The 223 general purpose funds fell $102.4 million, to $84.82 billion.

LEAD: A group led by the San Francisco investment firm Richard C. Blum &amp; Associates Inc. has offered to purchase Envirodyne Industries for $32 a share in stock and debt, but the Chicago-based food-packaging concern rejected the bid.
No reason for the rejection was included in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosing the offer.

LEAD: The trapped housewife was replaced by superwoman, who somehow managed to rear her children while catapulting ahead in a career.
Now, with legions of superwomen worn out and discontented, a new model has been suggested for married professional women: ''the sequencer.'' Some experts are already warning that the sequencer is just another doomed variation of women trying to do it all.

LEAD: A late rally pushed prices of grain and soybean futures higher yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.
In other markets, copper surged and livestock were mixed.

LEAD: The Government of Iraq has failed to conclude a contract with the USX Corporation to buy an idle steel works in Texas and ship it back to Iraq, the company said today.

LEAD: Southeast Asian nations, suspecting that the well-armed and brutal Khmer Rouge are preparing to seize control of Cambodia again, are planning new action at this year's United Nations General Assembly aimed at forestalling a Khmer Rouge return to sole power, according to diplomats from these countries.

LEAD: For the second time in three months, Honeywell Inc. has surprised investors with news of substantial write-offs.

The Life of a Weight Lifter Can Be Solitary and Painful
LEAD: Before the American weight lifters came to Seoul, they gathered in a Los Angeles hotel room to drink beer and have their hair cut.
A barber came to the room, set up shop in the bathroom and gave each of them the same punk coif, long on top, bristly on the sides.
The lifters wanted the barber to cut little barbell-shaped patterns in their hair, but he told them he did not have the tools for custom work.

LEAD: After months of a backstage struggle for control of the world's largest luxury-goods conglomerate, LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton, shareholders today accepted the nomination of a 12-member supervisory board that will name a new management board on Monday.

Wider Deficit In Soviet Trade

Review/Film; Saving Africa's Gorillas
LEAD: When Sigourney Weaver, as the naturalist Dian Fossey, is first seen arriving in Africa, she towers over everyone else in view.
A trim, impatient, utterly confident white woman, she is instantly at home giving orders to the impoverished black tribesmen who gather around her.
This supreme self-assurance of Miss Weaver's, sometimes less than helpful in other films, is perfect for ''Gorillas in the Mist,'' the story of a smart, determined, well-bred and physically commanding woman who brooks no frailty in others.


Bush And the Courts
LEAD: Does it make any difference who's elected President in November?
Of course it does, but not perhaps on as broad a range of issues as the candidates and their most fervent supporters would have you believe.


Ojeda Faces Long Road Back
LEAD: Bobby Ojeda sat in his hospital room yesterday and remembered how it happened: He was shearing the hedges with an electric clipper about 11:15 Wednesday morning, happy and healthy, earning $750,000 at the age of 30 and scheduled to pitch the fourth game of the playoff for the Mets.


Dollar Up While Gold Falls Abroad and Rises in U.S.
LEAD: The dollar gained ground yesterday in quiet trading despite a round of central bank intervention.
Gold prices fell overseas but recovered somewhat in domestic dealings.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery rose 90 cents, to $399.30 an ounce.
On Wednesday, gold fell below $400 an ounce for the first time in 19 months.


Chrysler Forecast
LEAD: Chrysler Corporation officials said they did not expect sales to increase in 1989, despite the introduction later of three new car models.
Bennett E. Bidwell, president for marketing at Chrysler Motors, said he expected sales of about one million cars and the same number of trucks next year, about even with projected 1988 sales.

LEAD: After winning another battle this summer, the world's industrial democracies are beginning to offer convincing evidence that, more than before, they can influence the course of the volatile foreign-exchange markets.

He was 89 years old.

'Yankee Panky'
LEAD: ''Manifest Destiny: An Evening of Yankee Panky,'' is a musical comedy about United States involvement in the Philippines at the turn of the century, written by someone with definite expertise on the subject.

The aim of this policy, he says, is to undermine the Sandinista Government and undercut the peace negotiations with the contras.


U.S. Budget Deficit Up 6%
LEAD: The Federal Government posted a $23.08 billion deficit for August, up almost 6 percent from a year earlier, the Treasury Department said today.


Pan Am Matches Deals Offered By American Air
LEAD: The airlines' battle for North Atlantic passengers grew more intense yesterday as Pan American World Airways lowered advance-purchase requirements and cancellation penalties to match moves made by American Airlines.

THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Sports of The Times; The Breakfast Club
LEAD: AT an hour when big-time athletes in the States would usually still be shifting their REM cycles, fists were flying and so were chairs and plastic bottles at the sweet science known as boxing yesterday.


As Bush Collects a Political Windfall, Dukakis Counterpunches in Boston
LEAD: Vice President Bush swooped into Michael S. Dukakis's territory today to revel in the endorsement of a Boston police union, but Mr.
Dukakis counterpunched by mustering law-enforcement officials from around the nation for a red-white-and-blue rally on the Statehouse lawn.


Seymour R. Kaplan, Professor, 66
LEAD: Dr.
Seymour R. Kaplan, a professor at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, died of a heart attack Tuesday at his office in the Bronx.
He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.


THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Women's Marathon; Mota of Portugal Runs to the Gold
LEAD: Rosa Mota of Portugal increased her stature as one of history's best female marathoners by winning her speciality today in 2 hours 25 minutes 39 seconds and earning the first gold medal in the track and field phase of the Summer Olympics.


A Soviet Sweep


70,000 Serbs Vent Anger at Officials
LEAD: About 70,000 Serbians braved a steady rain and fields of mud after the factories closed in this Serbian industrial town this afternoon to cheer speakers and shout slogans.


FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
LEAD: The Unisys Corporation yesterday priced $200 million of 9 percent notes, due 1993, through competitive bidding.


Review/Concert; Brass Sounds, From Medieval To the Modern
LEAD: Solid Brass, an ensemble composed mainly of players in New York's dance and opera orchestras, played a concert at Alice Tully Hall Sunday afternoon and proved itself not only virtuosic but also imaginative.
In a suite of medieval pieces that opened the concert and in a Wagner excerpt that began the second half, the 11 players were deployed in several groups -onstage, in the wings and in the hall's corridors - but their coordination was unfailingly precise.


Victory for McDonnell: Big Order From Delta
LEAD: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation won a badly needed victory today when it beat out the Boeing Company for most of a huge aircraft order from Delta Air Lines.


22 Held in New Pretoria Crackdown
LEAD: At least 22 black trade unionists and anti-apartheid organizers have been detained and the activities of five others have been restricted in a nationwide security crackdown this week.


Papers Filed by 2 Hunts Give Glimpse of Wealth
LEAD: Personal bankruptcy documents filed here by William Herbert Hunt and Nelson Bunker Hunt offer glimpses into the assets now held by the two Texans who once controlled enough oil, real estate, silver and sugar to make them among the world's wealthiest men.


In Absence of Widespread Standards, Local Officials Decide the Programs
LEAD: Pilots and the airline industry are controlled by the Federal Aviation Administration.
Nuclear power plants are overseen by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.
Teachers, barbers, accountants, architects and electricians need licenses or certificates to work in most states.


Ottawa Will Pay Compensation To Uprooted Japanese-Canadians
LEAD: The Canadian Government agreed today to pay the equivalent of $17,325 in compensation to each of about 12,000 surviving Japanese-Canadians who were forcibly uprooted from their homes in British Columbia, interned and deprived of their property in World War II.

Witness Says I.R.A. Suspects Were Killed as They Gave Up
LEAD: A witness to the shooting deaths of three unarmed Irish Republican Army members in March swore before a coroner's inquest today that British soldiers shot two of them as they raised their hands to surrender.


Philip Glass and David Hwang on a Science Fiction Excursion
LEAD: Philip Glass has been accused, with some justification, of fulfilling his numerous commissions by cannibalizing his earlier material.
Indeed, listening to the clusters of scores Mr.
Glass unleashes periodically, one is often struck not only by the presence of the composer's trademark moves, but also by the fact that specific chord progressions and effects are frequently grafted from one work onto another and that harmonic turns that were striking in their original context seem lazily derivative the second or third time.


Recalling Jean-Pierre Ponnelle, Who Brought Opera to Millions
LEAD: To the Editor:


French Deficit Widens
LEAD: French officials said Thursday that France's August trade deficit had more than doubled, to 9 billion francs ($1.4 billion), from July.
The deficit with West Germany alone jumped to 5.07 billion francs ($800 million), from 3.97 billion ($630 million).
The gap with the European Community almost doubled, to 7.03 billion francs ($1.1 billion), but the shortfall with Japan narrowed slightly, to 2.24 billion francs ($350 million).


The Games at a Glance
LEAD:  Track and Field  Everything else had been broken -the world record, the Olympic mark, the American standard - so Ben Johnson completed the amazing collection of physical performances by cracking something really surprising: a smile.
Johnson, the superb sprinter from Canada, left Carl Lewis in his tailwind and his world record in the past when he won the men's 100-meter dash in a breathtaking 9.79 seconds.


It's Showtime for Baby Whale
LEAD: A Sea World killer whale went into labor minutes before showtime today and delivered her baby to the shouts and cheers of thousands of people who witnessed the birth.
Park officials knew that the mother was pregnant but the baby arrived about a month sooner than they had expected.


Bill on Alternative Fuels Gains
LEAD: Legislation intended to spur development of motor vehicles that can operate on fuels other than gasoline was passed by the House of Representatives today and sent to the White House.


Attack on Priest Called Haiti Catalyst
LEAD: Many here trace the decision last week by young noncommissioned officers to oust Haiti's President, Gen.
Henri Namphy, to one event that stands out even amid a long string of atrocities against civilians committed here before the eyes of unconcerned generals.


Olympic Highlights
LEAD: SWIMMING: Matt Biondi of the U.S. picked up his third gold medal and fifth medal of the Games, but he was being overshadowed by Kristin Otto of East Germany, who ran her gold total to four.
In the 100-meter backstroke, David Berkoff of the United States bettered his world record in his qualifying heat.


THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Track and Field; Johnson Sets World Mark and Tops Lewis in the 100
LEAD: Ben Johnson of Canada won the Olympic 100-meter final today in a stunning 9.79 seconds to lower his world record and defeat his greatest rival, Carl Lewis of the United States, the defending Olympic champion.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Deaver Is Sentenced To Suspended Term And $100,000 Fine
LEAD: Michael K. Deaver, a close friend of President Reagan who was once one of the most powerful officials in the White House, today was given a suspended three-year prison sentence, placed on probation and fined $100,000 for lying about his lobbying activities after leaving the White House.


Baxter Stock Falls; '88 Estimate Cited
LEAD: Baxter International Inc.'s shares fell yesterday in very heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange as word spread that the company has lowered its estimate of 1988 earnings.
Shares in the Deerfield, Ill. hospital supply company closed at $18.125, down $1.625, as almost eight million shares were traded.

LEAD: Standard sports can still generate attention from inventors.


Haitians See Financial Crisis and Plead for Aid
LEAD: As calm settled over Haiti today, a week after a coup d'etat, leading businessmen declared that the country was in a severe economic crisis and appealed to the United States and other nations for emergency financial aid.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on Sept. 1 about an American warning to the Soviet Union over a disputed radar station described the American complaint incorrectly.
The Reagan Administration contends that the radar, near Krasnoyarsk, is not on the periphery of the Soviet Union and oriented outward, as such installations must be under the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Secrecy Reigns as Debaters Prepare
LEAD: At Vice President Bush's mock debates at his Victorian home here, Richard Darman mimicked Michael Dukakis with relish.
At the end of Wednesday's 90-minute session, Mr.
Darman, the former Treasury Department official who is now an investment banker, reached behind a curtain in the dining room that had been converted into a studio.


Koch Staff Reports Tax-Revenue Shortfall
LEAD: The Koch administration, already urging fiscal restraint on the City Council, said yesterday that New York City was facing a ''substantial decline'' in projected tax revenues.
It said the decline may represent a threat to budgetary reserves and city programs.


Yellowstone, and Its Sales Pitch, Undergo Rebirth
LEAD: At sunset, Electric Peak still lives up to its name, all pink in the natural neon of alpenglow.
In the valley below, elk chomp on aspen branches, bison slurp from the Yellowstone River and a lone eagle prowls for rabbit.


This Is Heavy: If 'the Dead' Is the 60's, Can the 60's Be Dead?
LEAD: Commuters come and commuters go, but the Grateful Dead has endured for more than 20 years, pursued by a hardy group of followers called Deadheads.
And for the last 10 days, those followers, who wear their hair long and their shirts tie-dyed, have been lounging around Penn Station.

LEAD: Senate Democrats failed today on a second attempt to stop a Republican filibuster of a bill that would increase the minimum wage by $1.20 over the next three years, to $4.55.

LEAD: Niels Lan Doky on piano, Niels Henning Orsted-Pedersen on bass and Billy Hart on drums will play trios tonight and tomorrow at Fat Tuesday's, 190 Third Avenue, at 17th Street (533-7902).
Sets begin at 8 and 10 P.M. and midnight tonight, at 8 and 10 P.M. tomorrow.
There is a $12.50 cover and a $7.50 minimum.

LEAD: Lonrho P.L.C., the British mining and hotels conglomerate that is under pressure from the United States corporate raider Asher B. Edelman, said it would not rule out a management buyout or selling of assets to defend itself.
Mr.
Edelman, a New York-based stock speculator, disclosed a 3.79 percent stake in the group Tuesday.

LEAD: Because of Succoth, the Jewish Feast of Tabernacles, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended in New York City Monday and Tuesday.

LEAD: Federated Department Stores Inc., a unit of the Campeau Corporation, has cast some doubt on its ability to repay the bank loans and interest payments used to finance its $6.6 billion acquisition earlier this year by the Toronto-based concern.


South African Denied Refuge
LEAD: United States officials said today that they turned away a black fugitive seeking refuge in the American Consulate, which is sheltering four escaped detainees.
The man, Max Mankazana, 22 years old, was later arrested.
An American spokesman did not say why the man's case was treated differently.

LEAD: Like some American athletes at the Summer Olympic Games, the National Broadcasting Company is finding that the competition is tougher than expected.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Thursday about the Shroud of Turin incompletely described the pope who was told in 1389 that the shroud was a fraud.
He was Clement VII, a claimant to the papacy who sat in Avignon in the 14th century, a time of schism in the church.
His claim to the papacy was disputed, and he has been widely considered an ''antipope.


Rape Victim's Cries Unheeded
LEAD: Several people watched as a 36-year-old woman was raped under a commuter-train platform during rush hour, but nobody moved to help her, the police said today.


City Manager Cites Failure of Government in Fatal Jersey Fire
LEAD: The City Manager today attributed the deaths of five firefighters here last July to a failure of government, agreeing with a report's finding that the five died needlessly when the roof of a burning car dealership collapsed.


THE SEOUL OLYMPICS


COPING: With the Common Cold
LEAD: Cold season is here.
Starting in late September, rhinoviruses, which live in the nose, leave millions of Americans coughing, sneezing and blowing their noses.
There is no way to cure the common cold, of course, but there are some simple things you can do to help reduce the chance of becoming infected.


Control Data Earnings Outlook
LEAD: The Control Data Corporation said it expects third-quarter results to be in the range of break-even to a modest loss, joining several computer companies that have recently downgraded their expectations for the quarter.
Control Data also said its net earnings for the year will be ''significantly lower than expectations at midyear.


Senate Votes Bill for Study Of F.S.L.I.C.
LEAD: In an effort to address the growing crisis in the savings industry, the Senate today passed legislation that would create a national commission to study how to bail out the beleaguered Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation.

Answers appear on page 35.


Fax It Your Way
LEAD: What makes fast food faster?
A fax machine.
There's one spewing out orders at the Burger King at 66 Newtown Road in Danbury, Conn., thanks to Fujitsu Imaging Systems of America.
The company, whose headquarters are nearby, allows the restaurant to use a Fujitsu facsimile machine at no charge.


Coniston May Make Bid for TW Services
LEAD: Solving a 10-day-old Wall Street mystery, Coniston Partners said yesterday that it might seek to acquire TW Services Inc., a food services company based in New York.


South Africa clash Kills One
LEAD: A black guerrilla wounded four South African soldiers with gunfire and a grenade before he was shot dead near the border with Mozambique and Swaziland today, the authorities said.

Jets to Start Criswell at Tackle
LEAD: It appeared today that Jeff Criswell is going to be the Jets' starter at left tackle against the Detroit Lions on Sunday.


Elia and Rojas Out
LEAD: With 10 days to go in baseball's regular season, the game of managerial changes has begun on both coasts.
In Philadelphia, Lee Elia was dropped as manager of the Phillies.
In Anaheim, Calif., Cookie Rojas was let go as manager of the California Angels.
In both cases, interim managers were named, meaning that there will be another change before next season.


France and China Allow Sale Of a Drug for Early Abortion
LEAD: France and China this week approved marketing of a new drug that induces abortion early in pregnancy, and two family planning experts said they believed an American company would soon apply for permission to market the drug in the United States.

LEAD: Two captions in highlights sections of the Television section last Sunday misidentified Michael Naranjo, who is featured in ''Bodywatching'' tonight at 9 on CBS.
He is a sculptor from New Mexico.

LEAD: William H. Shaw, a retired economist for E.I. du Pont de Nemours &amp; Company who was an Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Economic Affairs in the Johnson Administration, died of cancer Sept. 10.
He was 79 years old and lived in Annapolis, Md..


From Afar, Both Candidates Are Environmentalists . . .
LEAD: Some say we can have either a clean environment or a thriving economy, but not both.
But I see our challenge very differently.
We can't have sustainable economic development without careful and sensitive protection of our natural resources.

LEAD: The young people, the polls all showed, did not care anymore.

LEAD: When Angel Cordero Jr. was handed a 10-day suspension for careless riding in the closing days of the Saratoga meeting, the jockey immediately appealed the ruling and the ban was stayed.
He said at the time that he was not merely trying to ride out the Saratoga meeting, where he eventually won his 13th riding title, but that he believed the suspension was unjust.

The Candidates And Fun Power
LEAD: As potential party animals, George Bush and Michael S. Dukakis rate about the same, although Mr.
Dukakis would be more fun on a long trip and Mr.
Bush would make a better dinner host, according to a poll taken for MTV, the music video cable network.


GOING FOR THE INGOTS
LEAD: Professional money managers have stepped up their emphasis on gold as part of a diversified investment portfolio.
For the small investor, investments in gold can come in the form of mutual funds, gold stocks, coins or ingots.
The rate of return can be attractive, but experts say fortunes change quickly and advise a conservative 5 percent investment in precious metals during stable economic periods to about 10 percent if inflation is heating up.


Pretoria Will Let U.N. Send Transition Team to Namibia
LEAD: South Africa said today that it would allow a United Nations technical team into Namibia to start planning the deployment of United Nations military and civilian personnel there once the territory's transition to independence begins.

Janice Shatton Is Wed To Frederick G. Tate
LEAD: Janice O'Brien Shatton and Frederick G. Tate were married yesterday by Justice Richard W. Wallach in his chambers at the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in New York.


Mr. Gorbachev's Asian Serenade
LEAD: Fresh from a month's vacation, Mikhail Gorbachev has launched his second major initiative toward Asia.
His speech last week in Siberia, like his 1986 Vladivostok address, featured some headline-grabbing hokum.
But it also had other layers and audiences.
Together with other recent gestures, the speech affirms his eagerness to strengthen Soviet ties in Asia much as he has improved his relationships in the West.

LEAD: The family of Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee, has allowed the Drug Enforcement Administration to use its Texas ranches and other properties in anti-drug operations, the agency said today.

LEAD: Kathleen Collins Prettyman, a film maker, playwright and professor of film history and production at the City College of New York, died of cancer Sunday at Memorial Hospital.
She was 46 years old and lived in Nyack, N.Y.


Rural Ohioans Back Bush Despite the Quayle Factor
LEAD: They ran the Little Brown Jug for the 43d time at the Delaware County Fair Thursday, and more than 47,000 people came from all over the Middle West on the first day of autumn for one of the reassuring rites of rural America, a race that forms part of the Triple Crown for three-year-old pacers.

LEAD: Dorothy Stimson, a retired dean of Goucher College, died of arterial sclerosis on Monday at her home in Owls Head, Me.
She was 97 years old.

Eric G. James, 78, Professor and Consultant
LEAD: Eric G. James, a professor and consultant, died of a heart attack Thursday at Our Lady of Mercy Hospital in the Bronx.
He was 78 years old and lived in the Riverdale section and Dix Hills, L.I.


Commission Plans to Alter Taxi Meters
LEAD: The New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission plans to overhaul the electronic meters in the city's 11,787 yellow medallion cabs in an effort to cut down on overcharging, the commission's acting chairman said yesterday.


Youth Given 6-Month Term In Attack Case
LEAD: A prime assailant in the Howard Beach racial attack was sentenced yesterday to six months in jail as the final step in a plea bargain in which he received leniency for cooperating with prosecutors.


Battle of Brains
LEAD: A human brain will compete against an electronic one this weekend in a chess match at the New School, 66 West 12th Street.
The Hitech computer, which can evaluate 165,000 chess positions a second and which has been ranked among the 100 top chess players in the United States, will accept the challenge of Arnold Denker, a chess grandmaster.

LEAD: Maximilien Cardinal de Furstenberg, former head of the Vatican's Sacred Congregation for the Eastern Churches, has died in a clinic in his native Belgium, the Vatican reported today.

Orders Up By 6% for Durables
LEAD: Orders for durable goods rose 6 percent in August, suggesting to analysts that recent signs of sluggishness in the economy were probably temporary.


Former Nazi Guard Deported
LEAD: A 78-year-old Chicago man was deported to West Germany for concealing his pre-World War II service as a lieutenant colonel in the Nazi SS at two concentration camps, the Justice Department said today.
Conrad Schellong, deported Thursday, had been the target of a 7 1/2-year legal effort by the Justice Department's Office of Special Investigations, which said he served in SS guard companies at the Sachsenburg and Dachau camps from 1934 to 1939.


Navy Instructor Found Guilty In Recruit's Drowning Death
LEAD: A court-martial today convicted a Navy instructor of negligent homicide in the drowning of a panic-stricken recruit who was forced under water in a training exercise here last winter.
He was also found guilty of conspiracy to commit battery.

LEAD: Jose Canseco became the first player in major league history to hit 40 homers and steal 40 bases in one season tonight when he stole two bases during the Oakland Athletics' game against the Milwaukee Brewers.

State Legislator Faces 5 Charges In Fraud Inquiry
LEAD: State Senator Richard E. Schermerhorn of Newburgh was indicted today by a Federal grand jury on five counts of mail and bank fraud after officials investigated allegations that the Senator had accepted campaign contributions from organized-crime figures.


Trump-Griffin Pact
LEAD: Donald J. Trump will pay about $29 million more for the unfinished Taj Mahal hotel-casino and Merv Griffin will contribute an additional $25 million in equity when he buys Resorts International Inc., the two men announced late Thursday.
The two moves taken together will increase the amount of cash and reduce the amount of debt that Resorts will have after the various transactions are completed.


Sleep Loss Said Not to Hurt Work of Medical Residents
LEAD: A new study indicates that medical residents' work is not affected by their getting little sleep.


Roll-Call Vote in House on Tightening of Import Curbs
LEAD: Following is the roll-call vote of 248 to 150 by which the House of Representatives today approved tightened curbs on textile, apparel and shoe imports.
A ''yes'' vote was a vote for the restrictions.
Voting ''yes'' were 186 Democrats and 62 Republicans.
Voting ''no'' were 49 Democrats and 101 Republicans.


Man Is Arrested in Brooklyn Auto Break-In
LEAD: A Brooklyn man has been arrested and charged with breaking into the automobile of a woman who had been arrested two weeks earlier by a patrolman as she tried to retrieve her belongings from the man.

LEAD: Thousands of motorists were trapped for hours today on an elevated southbound section of the New Jersey Turnpike after an asphalt truck overturned and dumped liquid tar on two lanes of the three-lane road.

Nigerian Debt Accord
LEAD: Nigeria has accepted terms of a deal to reschedule payment on $5.2 billion of its debt that delays principal repayments for up to 20 years on medium-term loans, Barclays P.L.C. of Britain said today.
Barclays, with Citicorp, heads a group of creditor banks that has led negotiations on Nigerian debt.

Mother Margarita Maria, Hospital Administrator, 85
LEAD: Mother Margarita Maria, a Roman Catholic nun who founded a religious order of Carmelite nuns and turned a farmhouse sanitarium into Santa Teresita Hospital here, died Wednesday.
She was 85 years old.
She became administrator of Santa Teresita after founding it as a tuberculosis sanitarium in 1930.

Patents; New Designs For Sports Equipment: A Lighter Football
LEAD: Rod G. Martin of San Jose, Calif., has invented a polyurethane football that is lighter and softer than a standard pigskin.
Designed primarily for young players who have trouble gripping and passing a standard ball, Mr.
Martin's ball comes with a set of curved grooves in which players can plant their fingers for passing.


On Refugees: Generous but Clumsy
LEAD: Secretary of State George Shultz has promised to open America's doors to more refugees next year.
This is welcome news, reaffirming the nation's commitment to help those seeking asylum.
But there's a catch.
Because Congress has already set a ceiling on financial aid, the new refugees will receive less help getting started than did many of their predecessors.

LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, said today that they had made some progress toward resolving differences that are holding up new talks on reducing conventional weapons.


Olympics Worth Watching
LEAD: The Olympics haven't captured America's attention this year the way they did in 1984, and not just because NBC's cameras flit around too much.
Seoul can't hope to duplicate the excitement, or the hype, of games at home in California.
And U.S. athletes can't hope to match the gold they got when the Russians stayed away.

Fun for Young
LEAD: Clowns, mimes, face painters, fortune tellers, musicians and rope jumpers will provide entertainment for children at the 1988 version of the Union Square Park Carnival, starting at noon today at Union Square Plaza, 17th Street between Broadway and Park Avenue South.
The event will end at 5 P.M. with a parade.


Bridge; Missouri team wins Royal Viking Pairs with 76 percent score.
LEAD: The Royal Viking Pairs, the second of an annual series with instant match points, was played Thursday night at clubs throughout North America.
Provisional winners, according to the American Contract Bridge League, were Virgil Anderson of Springfield, Mo., and Dale Burns of Rogersville, Mo., with a 76 percent score.


Comings and Goings
LEAD: David Palmer, whose season with the Phillies ended Aug. 30 because of a torn rotator cuff, has had arthroscopic surgery on his ailing right shoulder and is expected to recuperate by the beginning of spring training.
Palmer had a 7-9 record and a 4.47 e.r.a. . . .
Bryan Harvey, a rookie right-handed relief pitcher with the Angels, has also undergone successful arthroscopic surgery to remove two bone chips in his right elbow.

A South African Thief And His Radicalization
LEAD: The insouciant lead character in the South African film ''Mapantsula,'' a thief named Panic, is as talented as he is cool.
Panic is such an unflappable pickpocket that he can steal a man's wallet and then stand there, switchblade in hand, rifling through the wallet's contents while silently daring the victim to challenge him.


Olympic Memory
LEAD: Rod Woodson, the left cornerback for the Pittsburgh Steelers, is having a little trouble with his concentration these days.
His thoughts keep drifting to Seoul, South Korea, and the upcoming competition in the Olympic hurdle events.
Woodson was a four-time Big Ten Conference 55-yard indoor hurdles champion at Purdue, but never competed outdoors until his senior year because of spring practice.


Louis D. Gualandi, 63, An Interior Designer
LEAD: Louis D. Gualandi, an interior designer and a co-founder of Waterloo Village, a restoration in northwestern New Jersey, died of lung cancer yesterday at Morristown Memorial Hospital in New Jersey.
He was 63 years old and lived in Waterloo.


THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Close-Up; Weight Lifting
LEAD:  Different Strokes  In the clean and jerk and the snatch, the bar must be held overhead for two seconds.
In the snatch, the lifter cannot turn his wrists over until the bar is overhead, or extend his arms unevenly or incompletely.
Top lifters can usually lift 100 pounds more in the clean and jerk than in the snatch.


Sears-Postal Deal
LEAD: Sears, Roebuck &amp; Company and the United States Postal Service said in Chicago that Sears will open post office units in 10 Sears stores throughout the Chicago area and at one store in Madison, Wis., starting Oct. 7.
If the one-year test proves successful, more postal units may be opened in other Sears stores.


Patents; New Designs For Sports Equipment: A Softer Baseball
LEAD: Few balls can do as much injury as a baseball.
This week, a California company, Incrediball Inc., won patent approval for a softer, safer ball made with a core of densely packed polyu rethane foam.
Incrediball says the ball will rebound almost as well as a regulation hard ball but is safe enough to use indoors and has never been known to cause an injury.

SENDING THE GAMES ROUND THE WORLD
LEAD: The room is dark except for the rows of small television monitors filling the front wall, making it look like a giant flashing checkerboard of bright images, blinking soundlessly: swimmers splashing, runners running, horses jumping, boxers punching.
Eight or nine people mill about the room, chatting quietly and sometimes stopping to watch a small, harried-looking woman seated at a console with a telephone at her ear.


Radon: Making the Public Pay Attention
LEAD: The Government recently told Americans that their homes may be collecting dangerous amounts of odorless, tasteless, invisible radon gas, which causes about 20,000 lung cancer deaths a year in the United States.
As disturbing as the warning was, communication specialists say most people will ignore it unless the message is reinforced with credible publicity and extensive education.

NONFICTION
LEAD:  FISHING WITH JOHN.
By Edith Iglauer. (Farrar, Straus &amp; Giroux, $19.95.) When Edith Iglauer, a frequent contributor to The New Yorker, went to British Columbia in 1974, she knew nothing of salmon fishing or the rigors of a fisherman's life.
A year later, having met and married an eccentric local fisherman named John Daly, she began what was to become a four-year adventure, until his death, aboard a 41-foot troller.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  N.H.L  Rangers Top Devils: Tomas Sandstrom and Ulf Dahlen scored first-period power play goals yesterday to lead the Rangers to a 3-2 victory over the Devils in an exhibition game at Byrne Meadowlands Arena in East Rutherford, N.J.
Sandstrom opened the scoring at 9 minutes 43 seconds with a 10-foot shot over the stick of the Devils goaltender, Sean Burke.


Miss Selden Has Wedding

George Lord Selden of New York, was married yesterday to Taylor Chapin Gray, a son of Mrs.

Parke H. Gray of Greenwich, Conn.


Mexico City and the Loss of Innocence
LEAD: I carried a manual typewriter and a certain Olympian innocence to Mexico City 20 years ago.
I didn't fully understand that the Games I was covering were not the only games being played.
I thought that Bob Beamon's great leap forward and the black power salutes of Tommie Smith and John Carlos were entirely separate incidents, one a sporting event, the other a political statement, and that the Olympic Movement itself was so swollen with pretension and hypocrisy that it would soon explode in the atmosphere like one of its ceremonial balloons.


Comforting the Afflicted in an Intolerant World
LEAD: FROM its beginnings just after World War II, United Cerebral Palsy of Nassau has been guiding the helpless toward as normal a life as is possible and teaching them to cope with a largely uncaring, if not intolerant, world.


Homelessness at a Remove: An Urge to Stare
LEAD: There are certain newsworthy subjects - war, natural disasters, starvation - that the camera can illuminate with relative ease.
Their effects are apparent to the eye, and their causes can be readily deduced.
Other issues of public concern - the national debt, for example, or radon gas - seem to resist any form of photographic interpretation.


FLAUNTING SUCCESS
LEAD: NOTHING IN HER CREAM-COLORED OFFICE - WITH the exception of the Financial News Network reports flickering on the television screen - hints at her occupation.
And Elaine M. Garzarelli likes it that way.
Settling back on the plump sofa and fanning out her hair, the Manhattan-based securities analyst for Shearson Lehman Hutton (she clinched her reputation by predicting last October's market crash a week in advance, on Cable News Network's ''Moneyline'') says she has always avoided working in a place that looks too obviously ''officey.

LEAD: JAZZ is king at Syosset's Cafe Royale.
Food is secondary.

After the talented jazz trio (piano, bass and saxophone) began to play, we had lots of company.

LEAD: When this writer was a student accompanying in vocal studios at Northwestern University, there came to the music school a talented undergraduate, not a music major, who sang countertenor and wanted lessons.
Nobody knew what to do with him; a tenor on the faculty taught him for a while, but concluded that countertenor singing was beyond the ken of the conventional instructor, and remanded the young man to the liberal arts.

Florence's Artistry in Wood
LEAD: FIORENZO BARTOLOZZI, say his friends, is a mixture of Geppetto, the carpenter who created Pinocchio, and Einstein.
When the ancient Benedictine abbey of Monte Cassino was reduced to rubble by Allied bombs during World War II, it was to the workshop of Bartolozzi &amp; Maioli in Florence that the monks came for help in restoring and carving the wooden choir stalls.

Disregard the technicalities that say Mr.
Jefferies does not have enough times at bat.
Not only do you have the rookie of this year, but the rookie of last year, the year before, and next year as well.

A Sleek New Hybrid Enters the Marketplace
LEAD: FOR the last two years I've been writing about two basic types of 35-millimeter cameras.
There are single-lens reflexes (SLRs), which let you compose, meter and focus through an interchangeable-mount lens.
And there are point-and-shoots, a.k.a. lens/shutter cameras, which have separate viewfinders beside their fixed-mount lenses.

TRISKAIDEKAPHILIA
LEAD: J. IRA HARRIS OF Chicago, a 50-year-old partner at Lazard Freres, is simply crazy about the number 13.

A French Port Via England
LEAD: WITH its busy waterfront, outstanding food shops and picturesque 13th-century Old Town, Boulogne is the most attractive of the French Channel ports convenient for day trips from England.
The trip takes 35 minutes by Hovercraft from Dover, an hour and 50 minutes by ferry from Folkestone.
If you rise early and stay late you can have seven hours ashore.

When You Need to Send Cash in a Flash
LEAD: THERE are numerous reasons why someone may need to transmit cash in a flash.
A son or daughter is stranded with a broken-down car and not enough money to get it fixed.
A spouse extends the length of a trip because of unforeseen circumstances.
A wallet is lost on a vacation or a business trip.
These are just some of the unfortunate situations requiring money to be sent immediately.

Concerns About Coverage
LEAD: I have many problems with the Olympic Games, namely the unnecessary hype of the television coverage and the participation of seasoned professionals such as Chris Evert.
But what I viewed last Saturday afternoon took the cake.
In order to be comical and to show the poor caliber of athletic abilities of some of the countries, NBC played a portion of the basketball game between Egypt and the People's Republic of China in fast forward with humorous music.

Hydraulic Door Closers
LEAD: HYDRAULIC door closers, the metal tubes mounted horizontally on the interior side of most lightweight storm and screen doors, seldom break, but they sometimes malfunction and their mounting brackets often come loose.
Repairing them is usually not difficult.


When Hunters Are Hunted
LEAD: ''JACKING'' deer - hunting them at night by shining a spotlight into their eyes to make them ''freeze'' -is illegal, but the odds of catching violators are slim.
Delaware wildlife officers were reported lowering the odds early this year by using decoys - styrofoam deer covered with deerskins and equipped with antlers and reflective glass eyes.


A Traditional Japanese Menu
LEAD: If you expect the new Sakura in Stamford to be a clone of its parent restaurant in Westport, you are in for a surprise and a pleasant one.
Not only is the new offspring more attractive, spacious and authentically Japanese in decor, but the food is better and more attractively presented, the sushi is fresher and the menu is considerably expanded and more interesting.

The race is ''dead even,'' Kitty Dukakis insisted with a steely smile.

LEAD: Tom Pugh scored three touchdowns, all on 1-yard runs, as Wagner routed District of Columbia, 61-14, yesterday at Fisher Field on Staten Island.
Pugh's 3 touchdowns raised his career total to 30.


Outdoors; Season for Waterfowl Hunting Is Near
LEAD: Most waterfowlers have long known that the drought that has plagued breeding habitat in Canada and this country has resulted in a near-record low in duck production this year.
They also knew that seasons and bag limits would be reduced and that there would be no special or bonus seasons for such species as teal and scaup, that the highly prized canvasback would be off limits across the nation, and that shooting hours would be shortened from sunrise, instead of a half-hour before, to sunset.

Opera in Which Solos Are Pre-Eminent
LEAD: Handel's operas have suffered strange vicissitudes.
Many of them enjoyed great success in their day, yet they were soon so completely forgotten that between 1754, when Handel was still living, and 1920 not one of them was staged anywhere.
Even after the publication of the scores more than a century ago, no attempt was made to revive them, though anyone could see that they were full of superb music.

LEAD: Even though it was far away, Hurricane Gilbert, which devastated Jamaica, has had an impact in New York, delaying the state's apple harvest.

APPEARANCE ANXIETY
LEAD: Four years ago, my husband told me he was offended that I was rejecting - and altering - the face that he called beautiful.
Beauty is in the eye of the beholder, he argued.
But I couldn't hide from the fact that, although love might be blind, I wasn't.
I forsook Henry V in favor of Hamlet's Polonius, and to my own self was true: there was nothing ''pretty'' or ''dear'' about the excess cartilage on the tip of my nose or the absence of a discernible chin.

SCENARIO FOR A NEW AGE
LEAD: FOR THE EMPLOYEES OF THE Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation, it was the worst of times.
On Aug. 28, 1986, the company announced a massive restructuring plan to foil a takeover threat mounted by Sanford C. Sigoloff, chairman of the Wickes Companies.
In the months that followed, Owens-Corning sold off some of its divisions and reorganized others; the work force was cut from 28,000 to 17,000.

THE WORLD: Two Views; For Chileans, It's Finally Yes or No On Pinochet
LEAD: CHILEANS will vote Oct. 5 on whether to extend Gen.
Augusto Pinochet's presidential tenure for eight more years.
If he does not win a majority in the one-man plebiscite, he is supposed to call free elections by the end of next year.
For outsiders, the decision seems self-evident: The Government is repressive and has been linked to political killings and torture.

LEAD: To the Editor: Speaking of horchata (Fare of the Country, May 1), mine was an amusing little experience.

Drawing himself up and looking down his long Spanish nose, the waiter said, ''Madam, that is a drink of the streets!

The Political Epilogue To Jamaica's Disaster

Seaga defeated in 1980, are openly trying to capitalize on the disaster.

THE SEOUL OLYMPICS CLOSE-UP: Judo; 'The Gentle Way'
LEAD: The Japanese developed judo, ''the gentle way,'' as an alternative to the more violent jujitsu.
One competitor, a judoka, is allowed per country in each of eight weight classes.
The strategy is to use an agressor's weight and momentum to your advantage (pushing when being pulled, pulling when being pushed) and defeat him through a series of holds and throws.

THE NATION  Three Views: The Troubled Savings and Loan Associations; On the Future, if There Is One, of the Thrifts
LEAD: GRIM news for the savings and loan industry keeps coming.
American thrifts lost $3.6 billion in the second quarter of this year, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported last week, bringing losses for the last 12 months to $13.5 billion.
Congress is moving toward consideration of a Federal bailout to close down or merge the industry's insolvent institutions: Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin and chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, said last week that a $20 billion bailout would be in order.

It was also a learning experience.
The costs were $725,000 to buy a five-story, walkup of railroad flats at 1214 Washington Street and $700,000 to turn it into the Patrician condominium.

LEAD: She could not recall who the father of her son was, Sarah Bernhardt wrote in her memoir, but she placed Victor Hugo on a short list of possibilities.
She once announced she was having a leopard's tail grafted into herself.
She continued acting well into old age, a star and a scandal because she adored theatricality on stage and off.

Money for U.N. Peacekeeping
LEAD: President Reagan is asking Congress to divert up to $150 million in defense or foreign aid money to help launch new United Nations peacekeeping operations in the coming months.
The funds would be transferred to the State Department to meet ''urgent requests that may arise'' before March for contributions to peacekeeping and truce operations planned in Afghanistan, between Iran and Iraq and possibly in Angola, South-West Africa, Cambodia and the Western Sahara.

Question Of the Week; Is Gregg Jefferies The Rookie Of the Year?
LEAD: Gregg Jefferies should not be the Rookie of the Year because he has not played enough.
He has not proven himself yet.
This year he was in the minors and hit .286.
Then he comes up to the majors, gets some home runs, some doubles, and a game-winning r.b.i.
Yes, this is good, but the award should go to either Mark Grace or Chris Sabo.

LEAD: The Pentagon, facing an apparent cash shortage as it nears the end of the Federal Government's fiscal year next Friday, is delaying payments to suppliers until October, industry and Government officials say.


Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. We recently had our kitchen cabinets refinished with a Formica veneer.
Several months later, we noticed that the veneer on one five-foot-long cabinet door was starting to come loose in the middle, forming a blister or ''balloon'' about six inches long.
The adhesive above and below this is adhering tightly.

LEAD: A LANDMARK HOME The most advanced techniques have been employed in the $500,000, 4-year restoration of the Stanley-Whitman House at 37 High Street in Farmington, a colonial home with National Landmark status.
An open house will be held from 1 to 4 P.M.
Saturday.
Admission is free.

LEAD: LEROY A. PESCH, M.D., HAD A dream.
Simply put, he wanted to create an empire that would deliver comprehensive medical care from the cradle to the grave.
He had the credentials: a career as professor, medical school dean, Federal official and president of Chicago's Michael Reese Hospital and Medical Center.

LEAD: A freshman at Columbia University plunged to his death from his 14th-floor dormitory room in an apparent suicide early yesterday, the third student in New York City to die that way in the last week, the police said.

A Takeover Battle In the Gold Fields
LEAD: Two gold-mining giants began a takeover battle.
A division of the Anglo American Corporation of South Africa offered $4.9 billion for Consolidated Gold Fields, a London-based company with huge mines in South Africa.
Anglo American, the Western world's largest gold producer, is controlled by the Oppenheimer dynasty of South Africa, which runs the De Beers diamond operations.

Burleson was charged with planting a destructive ''virus'' program in the company's computer, destroying 168,000 payroll records and holding up checks to company employees for more than a month.

POSTINGS: On the Housatonic; Milford Condos
LEAD: Kevin Bartlett recently completed 24 condominium apartments and 103 condominium boat slips in Milford, Conn.
Now, he is starting on 24 more apartments and 120 more slips there.
But Mr.
Bartlett contends he is more a home than a marina builder.
And, despite waiting lists up and down Long Island Sound for slips and the imbalance of his own development, he insists that condominiums measured by the square foot are as much in demand as those measured by the linear foot.

Review/Music; A Night of Leonard Bernstein in a Solemn Mood
LEAD: When Leonard Bernstein composed his Symphony No. 3 (''Kaddish'') in 1963, he assigned to a woman the central role of the Job-like Speaker who upbraids God for creating an imperfect world.
In his 1977 revision of the score, Mr.
Bernstein permits either a male or female to take the part, an ambiguity entirely consistent with the composer's ecumenical view of life and art.


From Italy, 'La Maschera,' A Story of Hidden Identities
LEAD: ''La Maschera'' is the sort of sublimely silly movie that somehow finds its way into every film festival.
It is prettily photographed, solemnly acted and so supremely and vacuously irrelevant that it prompts serious thoughts about revolution.
Any society that can take it seriously must be in the last stages of decadence.

Making Garbage 'Disappear Like Magic'
LEAD: THE movement to ban many categories of plastics unless they degrade in the environment is not founded strictly on logic.
After all, plastics make up only about 7 percent of the garbage in waste dumps.
But to the casual observer, that is a highly visable 7 percent.  ''What the public is reacting to is the fact that the first plastic clam shell that was ever thrown out is still lying there,'' said John Angus, a director of the Eco Corporation, a Canadian maker of additives that make plastics degrade.

Half the Nation's Children: Born Without a Fair Chance
LEAD: To talk about the condition of children is by definition to talk about the families in which they live.
That is why we are going to have to learn to talk about two kinds of children, because - of a sudden, in a flash - we have become a society divided into two kinds of families.
Call it a dual family system.


Westerner Is Crowned Lama
LEAD: Catharine Burroughs, a 38-year-old mother of three, today became the first adult in the Western world to be crowned as a reincarnate Buddhist lama.
The lamas, teachers with an obligation to help rid the world of suffering, are venerated by Tibetan Buddhists because they are believed to return to this world voluntarily to enlighten others.

The Time Has Come for Seasonal Chores
LEAD: SINCE fall is officially here, the rush is on to keep up with planting especially conifers, broadleaved evergreens and new selections of containerized perennials.
Finish dividing established clumps of perennials and share viable roots with friends.
Continue planning bulb displays and select first choices from garden center bins; bulb planting continues until early November, but the sooner the better so new roots can grow.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Fontainebleau: Grand Palace, Magical Forest
LEAD: FRANCOIS I, who brought the Renaissance to France, began building it; his successors added to it; Louis XIV loved it; Marie Antoinette found it came close to her ideal of a country palace.
Throughout the centuries, Fontainebleau remained a favorite residence of the kings of France.
It is still a rich and diverse building, full of treasures and memories, set in a park linked to a mysterious forest that once was home to wood nymphs and a ghostly hunter visible only to the kings of France.

Hitters Could Have Problems In National League Playoff
LEAD: The National League cannot have a pennant winner if neither of the teams in the pennant playoff scores a run.
The problem for the hitters of the Mets and the Los Angeles Dodgers, then, will be to figure out how to score runs against the Dodgers' and the Mets' pitchers.

A pop superstar from the Soviet Union who has reportedly sold 150 million records, Mrs.
Pugacheva wound up her first American tour with a sold-out concert at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night that offered a fascinating glimpse of mainstream Soviet pop.

LEAD: IT WAS AN EARLY SPRING.
I remember stopping to smell the blossoms on a neighbor's plum tree while out walking with my husband during the early hours of my labor.
An earlier pregnancy had ended in miscarriage, but our hopes had grown again when my doctor picked up a strong heart-beat three months into this pregnancy.

LEAD: HYDRAULIC door closers, the metal tubes mounted horizontally on the interior side of most lightweight storm and screen doors, seldom break, but they sometimes malfunction and their mounting brackets often come loose.
Repairing them is usually not difficult.

LEAD: More than 60 years after Jerome Kern and Oscar Hammerstein 2d's ''Show Boat'' galvanized Broadway by injecting serious dramatic music into a lighthearted popular art form, a major new recording of the show has been churning up the waters of the musical-theater world.


39 Injured in Texas Collision Of 3 School Buses on Outing
LEAD: Three buses carrying a high school band and drill team collided Friday night, injuring at least 39 people, nine seriously.


THE CASE OF PAUL DE MAN
LEAD: I must correct James Atlas's informative article ''The Case of Paul de Man'' (Aug. 28) on one point.
I never stated that members of the comparative literature department at Yale ''knew all about'' Paul de Man's past.
On the contrary, most of Mr. de Man's colleagues, including myself, knew nothing about his wartime past.


A Charity To Revise Practices
LEAD: CHALLENGED by the Better Business Bureau of Metropolitan New York, a small national charity based in Bergen County says it is revising its fund-raising practices.


THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: The Best in the World; Fastest Runs Even Faster
LEAD: If he had snookered the world, he laid the groundwork more than a year ago.
After Ben Johnson of Canada lowered the world 100-meter record to 9.83 seconds in the world track and field championships in Rome in 1987, he said the time would probably stand another 50 years.
He was off by 49.
So what is the world to make of his miscalculation?


Jury Hears Testimony on Klan Attack on Marchers
LEAD: A Federal jury has begun hearing testimony in a lawsuit seeking damages from members of the Ku Klux Klan who were part of a violent confrontation with civil rights marchers on a rural Georgia road last year.


Heirs of Sol Goldman Battle Over Estate
LEAD: ON Oct. 20, 1983, Lillian Goldman moved out of the Waldorf-Astoria suite she shared with her husband, Sol, and began a divorce proceeding.
She asked for half of Mr.
Goldman's $1 billion in assets, New York City's largest private real-estate empire.

LEAD: New York City's jails, already overcrowded, are seeing a wave of new prisoners this fall that made the inmate population jump to a record 17,128 last week.

Alcohol Treatment And Its Cost
LEAD: This is in response to the recent article ''Panel Finds Excesses in Drug and Alcohol Care.'' As the chief executive officer of Sunrise House Foundation, a freestanding alcohol treatment center in Sussex County, New Jersey, I note my objection to the generalizations concerning ''typical inpatient programs'' as extremely costly.


'All's Well': What Does She See in Him?
LEAD: IT'S easy to mistake one of Shakespeare's less accessible plays, ''All's Well That Ends Well,'' for one of his less appealing ones.
The memorable Royal Shakespeare Company staging, transposed by the director Trevor Nunn to the Edwardian era and produced on Broadway in 1983, proved, however, that the play's interpretive possibilities are boundless.

Torah Scrolls: Sacred History and Knowledge
LEAD: THEY are called ''People of the Book,'' and Jews lived up to their name last week at an extraordinary funeral service in Brooklyn for five Torah scrolls destroyed by vandals.
As rabbis delivered eulogies over the plain pine coffin holding the charred scrolls, it was almost as if the People of the Book had made a person of the Book.


Correction
LEAD: A brief obituary by The Associated Press last Sunday about Harold Eugene Davis, a Latin American scholar and professor at American University, misstated the cause of death.
His widow, Audrey, says it was pneumonia, not cancer.

LEAD: She invested four years of hard work, testing her will and physical endurance as well as the patience of the coach who became her husband.

Headliners; Valuable 'Trial'
LEAD: Franz Kafka might well be as bemused as some of his improbably situated characters to learn that the coming sale of one of his manuscripts is the talk of the rare-book set.
Sotheby's, which is handling the gavel on this one, says Kafka's handwritten version of ''The Trial,'' written in 1914 and published in 1925, the year after the author's death, is the most important modern literary manuscript ever to be auctioned.

HOROWITZ AT 85: STILL PLAYING FREE
LEAD: There will be no festivals, tributes or gala concerts to commemorate Vladimir Horowitz's 85th birthday on Saturday.
This is the way he wants it.
His plans are to spend the day as he spends most days, at home.
During the recent heat spell he stayed inside for six weeks reading the letters of Mozart, which have become a near obsession, listening to recordings, receiving friends, anything but practicing the piano.

Mortadella
LEAD: To the Editor: In ''Mortadella: Bologna's Bologna'' (Travel, Aug. 7), the name mortadella is explained by a bit of etymological guesswork as shortened from mortaio della carne di maiale, much as Americans shorten maitre d'hotel to maitre d'.

Transplant in Rats Cures Disease Blamed for Blindness
LEAD: In a major advance, two groups of scientists have successfully transplanted cells from the eye of a rat to the retina of another rat and cured a disease that would otherwise cause blindness.
The work, the first successful retinal cell transplant, is the first time that researchers have been able to cure a degenerative disease of the central nervous system.

LEAD: Thousands of Israelis were inoculated against polio today as Health Ministry officials tried to decide whether to vaccinate the entire nation.
Seven cases of the paralyzing virus were confirmed in the north of the country this month, causing concern among many Israelis.

LEAD: IT was the first and only time I have ever gambled.

Iraq's Dark Victory
LEAD: BY THE EMERALD rush of the Habur River, on the Turkish frontier, the Iraqi armies of Saddam Hussein raised their banners in late August to signal their victory over the Kurds.
But the message of triumph went much further than that.
Throughout the eight years of Baghdad's war with Iran, guerrillas from Iraq's Kurdish minority had stubbornly resisted the Baghdad regime's successive campaigns to crush a revolt that had spanned almost seven decades.

Higher Cost of Newsprint Is Part of an Odd Equation
LEAD: NEWSPRINT, the kind of paper on which this article appears, is going up in price again this winter if the people who produce it can make a 6.9 percent increase stick with the newspaper companies that are their customers.
That will be the third increase since late 1986, after five years of almost no change at all.

There is a limit of eight tickets per person.

LEAD: American farmers this year are likely to harvest the lowest number of acres in this century, the United States Agriculture Department said Friday.

Dollar Is Strong in Tokyo
LEAD: The dollar edged up against the yen early today, while stock prices recovered earlier losses.
The dollar opened at 134.80 yen, up 0.33 yen from Thursday's close.
The Nikkei Stock Average gained 39.45 points from last Saturday to finish the morning session at 27,429.57.
Dealers said the dollar's strength followed a reaffirmation among monetary authorities from seven major industrialized countries, meeting in West Berlin over the weekend, that they would continue to coordinate economic policies targeting stable exchange rates and control of inflation.

Outdoors: Counting Deer
LEAD: THE white-tailed deer population of New York and the rest of the Northeast is growing by leaps and bounds.
Ten years ago there were 450,000 deer in New York State.
As the new hunting season begins tomorrow, the big game experts of the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation said there are almost twice as many, 800,000, a record number.

LEAD: Marc Blitzstein was one of the more contradictory musical personalities of significance that this country has produced.
An ardent left-wing populist during the Depression, his music sought to refine a vocabulary that engaged the masses with a rugged tunefulness and hearty language while also acknowledging the sophisticated modernism of Stravinsky and others.

GLOBAL BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Brazil's President vowed to wage ''a war without quarter'' on the country's triple-digit inflation rate, now that a new agreement has been reached with the nation's commercial bank creditors.
The president, Jose Sarney, did not announce any new measures, however, and Finance Minister Mailson Nobrega has repeatedly said he would resist political pressure to begin ''shock measures'' like a wage and price freeze.


Hurricane Wanders North
LEAD: Hurricane Helene strayed farther from land today, pushing northward over the central Atlantic and heading toward chillier water that will eventually sap its strength, the National Hurricane Center said.
The storm, with top sustained winds of 115 miles per hour, turned from north-northwest to north and was moving at 8 m.p.h.

Research Studies Tobacco-Breast Cancer Link
LEAD: AN analysis of cancer rates throughout the world has suggested that exposure to tobacco smoke might induce breast cancer in women decades later.
The analysis, by Dr.
A.
Wesley Horton, a public health specialist at the Oregon Health Sciences University in Portland, found that a a rise in tobacco consumption was followed by a rise in lung cancer rates and the incidence of breast cancer.

Close-Up: Archery
LEAD:  Pointing the Way  Three men and three women from each country can be entered in individual events.
In the preliminary round, men shoot 36 arrows, from 90, 70, 50 and 30 meters; women shoot from from 70, 60, 50 and 30 meters.
After that, all but the top 24 scorers are eliminated.
Six more are eliminated after each of two 36-arrow rounds, and four more after another round of 36.

LEAD: A veteran politician and seasoned foe of the outlawed trade union Solidarity, Mieczyslaw Rakowski, was chosen as Prime Minister today by the Communist Party Central Committee.
