LEAD: ''It's a six-ring circus, a six-floor-ring circus,'' said Lyn Gastevich of Chicago, summing up opening day of the new Bloomingdale's store at 900 North Michigan Avenue.
It was 10:30 Saturday morning and she was buying a handbag while hordes of customers inched their way through tap dancers, clowns and mimes.

LEAD: Time magazine, the largest United States news magazine, will make several editorial changes, starting with its Oct. 17 issue.

LEAD: Two Federal appeals judges suggested today that business considerations and not union-busting tactics motivated Eastern Airlines' decision to lay off 4,000 workers.

Seeking the Gold beat Happyasalark Tomas by a neck in the Super Derby.
Does this mean that Alysheba, a champion who has won nearly $5 million, is only two necks and a nose a better horse than the obscure and unaccomplished Happyasalark

Michael S. Dukakis hurled piles of complicated figures, obscure names, tongue-twisting acronyms and seemingly irrefutable facts at each other in their debate Sunday night.


Failure Admitted By OPEC
LEAD: After five years of trying to reverse the drop in oil prices, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries said today that the effort had failed and that it had to search for ''a new approach'' or face the possibility of another collapse of prices next year.


Kay Sugahara Is Dead; Ship Executive Was 79
LEAD: Kay Sugahara, a Japanese-American who was interned on the West Coast after the Pearl Harbor attack and who later built a worldwide ship-owning business and worked for better relations between the United States and East Asian nations, died of liver cancer Sunday at his home in Pelham Manor, N.Y.
He was 79 years old.


Inquiry Begins Into Police Cadets' Hospitalization
LEAD: Investigations began today at a police academy into whether strenuous exercise contributed to the exhaustion and dehydration that hospitalized 16 cadets, including one who was undergoing a liver transplant.


Drexel Drive to Oust Judge Is Said to Cite Wife's Deal
LEAD: In an attempt to remove a tough Federal judge presiding over their case, lawyers for Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and other defendants in a large securities fraud lawsuit have asserted in sealed court papers that the judge has a conflict of interest involving his wife's family business, several people who have seen the papers said yesterday.


Police Informer Is Slain in Idaho Prison Uprising
LEAD: An inmate who was identified in court papers as a police informer was killed in his cell Sunday while other prisoners went on a rampage, the authorities said.


Farewell Comments
LEAD: The San Diego Padres' clubhouse was subdued after the club's president, Chub Feeney, announced his resignation less than 24 hours after an obscene gesture to two unappreciative fans.
Club officials were silent after Sunday's announcement.
Players didn't seem too surprised or concerned, and some were relieved.


Louganis Wins In Final Round
LEAD: Greg Louganis became the first man to earn two diving gold medals in consecutive Olympics when he won a dramatic battle with Xiong Ni today by overtaking the Chinese teen-ager on the final dive of the 10-meter platform competition.


Study Finds Ways to Fight Career Malaise
LEAD: A new study of professionals who were intensely dissatisfied with their careers, feeling bored or trapped in roles that did not meet their expectations, has identified traits that seem to help some people emerge from these periods of malaise with renewed happiness and satisfaction in their lives.


After The Debate; Round One Undecisive
LEAD: Many politicians looked to Sunday night's televised debate between Michael S. Dukakis and Vice President Bush as an opportunity for one of the candidates to gain a clear advantage in the 1988 Presidential race.
That didn't happen.
Instead, the contest was left more muddled than before and as open as it has been at any point since last spring.


Games of Chance
LEAD: ACTUALLY wagering your own money while you are learning how to play a game can be painfully expensive.


U.S. ASKS STIFF BAN ON CHEMICAL ARMS
LEAD: In a farewell speech that was his most laudatory toward the United Nations, President Reagan called today for a new international effort to stiffen the ban on using chemical weapons.


2 Koreas Are 2 Pieces In a Developing Puzzle
It's a shrewd director who knows the effect of his work as well as Lee Chang Ho.
At a press conference after ''The Man With Three Coffins,'' the first South Korean film to be shown at the New York Film Festival, he said through an interpreter, ''Thank you for your patience'' - a bluntly honest remark. ''The Man With Three Coffins'' is the kind of film that must be seen twice before it makes sense.
But only the most committed and curious students of world cinema may feel that Mr.
Lee's artistic rigor is reward enough for struggling through the film's taxing narrative strategy and its obscurity to most Western viewers.
In summary, the plot sounds compelling.
Three years after his wife's death, a man travels north to her hometown to scatter her ashes.
Along the way he crosses paths more than once with a nurse also heading north with her elderly charge and encounters a prostitute who dies soon after he sleeps with her.
All three women, including the wife seen in flashbacks, are played by the same actress, creating mysterious echoes.
Is the hero imagining this similarity?
Or are the women reincarnations of the wife?


East German Cyclist Sprints To Victory in Last 300 Meters
LEAD: Olaf Ludwig, an East German cyclist, took the lead with 3 kilometers left and outsprinted Brend Groene of West Germany in the final 300 meters today to win the men's 197-kilometer road race.

LEAD: Interco Inc. has given confidential financial information to the Rales brothers of Washington about the proposed sale of its Ethan Allen furniture division.

Louis-based company's restructuring, with a stated value of $76 a share.
The effort is intended to thwart a hostile offer from the brothers, Steven M.

LEAD: Vice President Bush said in the debate Sunday that he would favor full financing of legislation already approved by Congress to aid the homeless.


Steel Output Up 0.4%
LEAD: Steel production rose to 1.957 million tons in the week ended Saturday, an increase of four-tenths of a percent from the previous week's 1.949 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
The industry's production amounted to 91.8 percent of capacity during the week, compared with 91.4 percent in the previous week.

LEAD: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes dipped in very light trading yesterday, as market participants reacted negatively to firmer oil and gold prices and to a successful effort by major central banks to stem a rally in the dollar.

LEAD: An investment group led by Sid R. Bass, Lee M. Bass and Perry R. Bass, three members of the wealthy Fort Worth family, have lowered their stake in the Standard Brands Paint Company to 2.7 percent, from 4.5 percent.
In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, the Bass group said it sold 108,082 shares for $14.38 to $15.60 each.

LEAD: Despite police protection that was stepped up after a deranged man bludgeoned an usher to death last week, a thief at St.

Bridge
LEAD: Be wary if someone approaches you, shows you a pair of bridge hands and asks, ''What contract would you like to play?'' There may indeed be a straightforward answer, but frequently your response should be one or more questions: ''Will the defense be perfect, on a double-dummy basis?
If not, will the bidding help the opposition find the best opening lead?

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q. When a cormorant catches a fish, it appears to swallow it alive.
What kills the fish?
Does the same thing happen to a python's victims?
A.
The cause of death is, 'in all probability, suffocation,'' according to Dr.
Emil Dolensek, chief veterinarian of the New York Zoological Society.


Paul Cowan, Village Voice Writer And Author of 5 Books, Dies at 48
LEAD: Paul Cowan, a journalist of strong social passions whose book ''An Orphan in History'' influenced thousands of assimilated Jews like himself to recover their Jewish heritage, died of complications from leukemia yesterday at New York University Hospital.
He was 48 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: To the Editor:


A Comet in the Making?
LEAD: Chiron, whose diamter of 150 miles makes it one of the largest asteroids, has increased its brightness 2 1/2 times, leading some specialists believe it is shedding gas in the manner of a huge comet.
Some day, in the distant future, it may be thrown into the inner solar system, they believe, producing a spectacular display.

LEAD: The slowdown on Wall Street after last year's market slump has sharply reduced the need for new space in New York by financial firms, according to a study released yesterday.

LEAD: The investor Asher B. Edelman has confirmed that he owns 4.74 percent of the British conglomerate Lonrho P.L.C., up from 3.79 percent.

Edelman had complied with a request to disclose his holdings and that he had been cleared by the British High Court to increase his stake.

LEAD: Under the pressure of a symbolic anniversary this week, negotiators from Angola, Cuba and South Africa resumed talks today to set a timetable for the withdrawal of 50,000 Cuban troops from Angola.


Fedders Sees Sales Surge
LEAD: The Fedders Corporation, which makes air-conditioners, said today that it expected sales for 1988 to approach $200 million, up about 50 percent from 1987 sales of $129 million.
Fedders also said it expected an additional 50 percent gain next year, bringing 1989 sales to about $300 million, assuming normal summer weather and a stable United States dollar.


A Fair Chance for the Baby; An Issue for the No-Issue Campaign
LEAD: Picture a hospital nursery: rows of healthy infants, some of them sleeping, some of them crying and most of them plump as pigeons.
Now picture the neonatal intensive care unit in the same hospital: rows of skinny, stiff-legged little creatures trembling nervously, squalling fitfully.
Were these children born equal?


Patterns; Hue and Cry
LEAD: Color, like fashion, runs in cycles.
After recent seasons that emphasized ruffles, poufs and a psychedelic clash of colors, designers have reacted with strong, simple silhouettes and bright solid tones.
Taking the designers' lead, fashion magazines emblazon the new season's message in their headlines: ''Fall Flash,'' ''Full-Throttle Fuchsia,'' ''Shocking Shearlings,'' ''Color for a Change.

LEAD: Behind a squeaky door here, in a courtroom that barely seats 20 people, 58 farmers and other large landowners from rural Orange County are taking on the New York Power Authority in an emotionally charged case that could result in a landmark decision for the nation's utilities.

LEAD: IT is among nature's most dramatic scenes: fire that sounds like a jumbo jetliner, yellow, red and blue flames soaring hundreds of feet into the air, lighting the night sky for miles, throwing leg-sized embers hundreds of yards ahead and consuming all the cabins, cars and towering trees in its path.

LEAD:  DIVING: Greg Louganis became the first man to win both diving events in consecutive Olympics.

Dow Joins Venture To Recycle Plastics
LEAD: The Dow Chemical Company and Domtar Inc. of Montreal will form a company to recycle plastic bottles.
The 50-50 venture will retrieve from the trash of the two countries polyethylene terephthalate and high-density polyethylene plastics, which make up about 90 percent of the plastics used in bottles for milk, soft drinks and other products.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  GOLF  Two Tied in Metropolitan: Rick Meskell of the Century Country Club and Scott Dietrich of the Brayburn Country Club were tied for the lead yesterday in the opening round of the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association championship at the Inwood (L.I.) Country Club.
They both were at two-under par 70.


Population Is Surging In U.S. Pacific Islands
LEAD: Populations of the Pacific islands under United States jurisdiction are skyrocketing, but departures from Puerto Rico are holding down growth there, , the Census Bureau reported Sunday.


Rest of the Jets Following O'Brien's Lead
LEAD: ''Mistakes are killing us!'' Coach Weeb Ewbank used to groan about a young Jet team of an earlier era.


Mr. Reagan, the Multilateralist
LEAD: ''The United Nations is a better place than it was eight years ago and so too is the world. . . .
We see not only progress, but also the potential for an increasingly vital role for multilateral efforts and institutions like this United Nations.''


Nathan H. Gates; Lawyer, 78
LEAD: Nathan Henry Gates, a lawyer, died after a stroke Sunday at Southampton (L.I.) Hospital.
He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan and Bridgehampton, L.I.


Market Place; K Mart Rumors: Some Skepticism
LEAD: AFTER a week of rumors about a possible takeover of the K Mart Corporation, investors became more skeptical yesterday.
The stock fell by $1.25, to $38.25, in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange, after having run up by $3.125 last week.


Dermott F. McCarthy;Advertising Executive, 68
LEAD: Dermott F. McCarthy, a retired advertising executive at Young &amp; Rubicam, died of a stroke Wednesday at his home in Albuquerque, N.M.
He was 68 years old.


Golden Hammer Throw


The Smearing of the Olympics
LEAD: THE world's fastest human has been convicted of speeding on steroids.
And the Olympics has been smeared by drugs as never before.


BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:  INTERNATIONAL  OPEC acknowledged that it had failed to bolster oil prices and said it would seek ''a new approach.'' OPEC's Secretary General said the move was a ''signal to the oil market'' that OPEC is searching for serious solutions to its lack of discipline.
Oil prices have fallen by a third in the last year.


2 Drug Companies End Name Dispute
LEAD: Two pharmaceutical companies -Schering A.G. of West Germany and the Schering-Plough Corporation of the United States - have settled a dispute over the use of ''Schering'' in North America.
The West German company said it would pay Schering-Plough $8 million under the pact.


Schools Plan New Assault On Drug Use
LEAD: Before the end of December, the Board of Education will require every public school in the city to provide some form of education about drug abuse to students from kindergarten through the 12th grade, the Schools Chancellor, Dr.
Richard R. Green, said yesterday.


A Stellar Career Abruptly Clouded
LEAD: The story goes that when Ben Johnson was 12 years old, he and a friend were walking down a street in Jamaica.
From the dark recess of a doorway, an old man who was a fortune teller stepped out.
After examining Johnson's hand, the fortune teller said, ''One day you will be famous and travel the world.


Sweep Of Long Jump For U.S.
LEAD: The United States had its best performance so far in Olympic track and field Monday, winning six medals, with Carl Lewis leading a sweep in the men's long jump and Roger Kingdom winning the men's 110-meter hurdles.


Salvador TV Dares to Tell the News
LEAD: Barreling past sleepy sentries at the crack of dawn, a caravan of foreign journalists and Salvadoran television reporters sped into the mountains a few months ago to rendezvous with senior commanders of the guerrilla movement fighting the Government.


G.A.O. Warns on Jobless Insurance Reserves
LEAD: The unemployment insurance system has enough reserves to last only five months in a severe recession and would have to borrow billions of dollars from the Federal Government to keep paying benefits, the Congressional overseeing agency said today.


Best Products Spurns Offer of $520 Million
LEAD: The Best Products Company, the large catalogue-showroom company, said yesterday that it had rejected a $520 million offer from an unidentified suitor but was considering selling the company or taking other steps to increase shareholder value.

LEAD: Most of the people at Veterans of Foreign Wars Post 6691 Sunday night to watch the Presidential debate came there as avowed partisans of Vice President Bush.


Auto Executive Predicts Payroll Cutbacks
LEAD: The head of Renault, the large European auto maker, predicts that stiffening competition and a trend toward relying more on outside suppliers will lead automobile companies to make sharp reductions in employment in the next few years.

Allied-Signal Inc., Morristown, N.J., and Lucas Industries P.L.C., London, said Lucas would purchase the Utica Power Systems unit of Allied, which makes engine power transmission products, for $40 million.


Evidence Points to Deceit by Brawley
LEAD: A seven-month New York State grand jury inquiry has compiled overwhelming evidence that Tawana Brawley fabricated her story of abduction and sexual abuse by a gang of racist white men last year, according to investigators, witnesses and official summaries of evidence presented to the panel.


Tate &amp; Lyle Sets Deal To Buy Amstar Sugar
LEAD: The Amstar Corporation, which makes Domino sugar and is the nation's largest refiner of cane sugar, agreed yesterday to sell its Amstar Sugar unit to Tate &amp; Lyle P.L.C. for $305 million.

After the Debate; The Man With No Money To Buy Health Insurance
LEAD: Charles Strickland's name was not used, but his story was told twice in the debate Sunday night between the Presidential candidates.


Is Sentenced In Theft of Jury's Minutes
LEAD: A 49-year-old Manhattan resident who once worked as a printer in the office of the State Attorney General, Robert Abrams, was sentenced yesterday to three years' probation for stealing the minutes of a Dutchess County grand jury that initially investigated the case of Tawana Brawley.


Chess
LEAD: The 55th Soviet championship ended last month in Moscow in a tie for first place between the world champion, Gary Kasparov, and his perpetual challenger, Anatoly Karpov.
The two giants of the chess world topped an impressive field with identical 11 1/2-5 1/2 scores.


James Boatwright 3d, Editor, Is Dead at 54
LEAD: James Boatwright 3d, editor of the literary review Shenandoah, died of AIDS on Sunday at his home in Key West, Fla.
He was 54 years old and also lived in Lexington, Va.


26 Demonstrators Arrested After Blocking Capitol Road
LEAD: Twenty-six demonstrators, protesting the lack of affordable housing, were arrested today when they blocked a road on the grounds of the United States Capitol, the police said.


Review/Television; Snoopy's Brother Loves A Human, Charlie Brown
LEAD: Nearly 40 years have flitted by since Charles M. Schulz created ''Peanuts.'' Keeping the comic-strip characters remarkably fresh, Mr.
Schulz has adroitly parlayed Charlie Brown and the gang into a stage musical, animation television specials, greeting cards and hundreds of other tie-in products.
It's a remarkable success story.


Talking Business with Furlaud of Squibb; Betting the Farm On Research
LEAD: The Squibb Corporation predicts that Capoten, its blood pressure and heart disease drug that is a member of the ACE inhibitor family of pharmaceutical agents, will have worldwide sales this year in excess of $1 billion, about 40 percent of the company's revenues.
Only two other drugs, Glaxo's Zantac and SmithKline Beckman's Tagamet, are in the billion-dollar club.


Minister Sentenced to Death
LEAD: A minister convicted of shooting and killing a church handyman before beheading him and leaving the man's body in a burning church has been sentenced to death by electrocution.

LEAD: Fourteen thousand years before the Cold War, the peoples of Siberia and Alaska had considerably more contact than they do today.

LEAD: The sluggish pace of retesting potentially dangerous pesticides that are now used by the American public would be substantially speeded if legislation approved by the House of Representatives last week is enacted.

LEAD: Stock prices fell moderately yesterday in lethargic, directionless trading.

LEAD: A gunman walked into an elementary school today and opened fire, killing an 8-year-old girl and injuring 10 other people, the authorities said.

3 U.S. Trainers in Salvador Exchanged Fire With Rebels
LEAD: Three American military trainers stationed in El Salvador fired on guerrillas when the Americans were caught in a crossfire two weeks ago between the rebels and Salvadoran Army troops, a Pentagon spokeswoman said tonight.

Bank Board's Admission: Rescues Rushed Needlessly
LEAD: After weeks of rushing to complete rescues of savings institutions before Oct. 1, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today that it had misunderstood the budgetary process and had not been under deadline pressure to complete deals.


Jam or Jelly? What's What
LEAD: THE Federal Government lumps jams and preserves into one category for regulatory purposes, mandating a fruit content of at least 45 percent.
There are, however, distinct differences.


Sports People; Eagles Get Kicker
LEAD: The Philadelphia Eagles have signed a free-agent kicker, Luis Zendejas, to a two-year contract.
Terms were not announced. ''Luis has experience in the N.F.L. and has a very strong leg,'' said Bill Davis, the Eagles' vice president for player personnel.
Zendejas, a second-year pro, started the season with the Dallas Cowboys, where he was 5 for 5 on extra points and 1 for 3 on field goals.

LEAD: The consumer advocate Ralph Nader contended today that workmanship on the Cadillac sedan has steadily slipped since the early 1970's.

Elders Has Stake In Anheuser-Busch
LEAD: Elders Investments Ltd., an affiliate of the Australian brewer Elders IXL Ltd. disclosed today that it holds almost 1 percent of the Anheuser-Busch Companies, the St.
Louis-based maker of Budweiser beer.
John D. Elliott, the chairman of Elders, confirmed that the company still held the stake - about 0.84 percent - but would not comment on its intentions toward the company.


Bipartisan Group Agrees on Drug Bill to Be Offered in Senate
LEAD: A bipartisan team of Senators reached agreement today on key provisions of a drug bill, but the Senate as a whole was divided on whether to permit amendments that some members consider a threat to civil liberties.


Sports People; Coach's Pact Extended
LEAD: The Portland Trail Blazers have extended the contract of Mike Schuler, one of only eight coaches in National Basketball Association history to win 100 games in his first two seasons, for three years through the 1990-91 season.
No financial terms were disclosed.
Schuler's Trail Blazers had a 49-33 record in his first season and were 53-29 last season.

Toys 'R' Us Insider Case
LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission has charged a former official of Toys ''R'' Us Inc. with illegal insider trading of options on the toy retailer's stock while he possessed a confidential forecast of better-than-expected sales in the 1986 Christmas season.


THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Close-Up
LEAD:  Canoeing and Kayaking  One Blade or Two  Canoeists use a single-bladed paddle in an open boat, which is usually made of wood.
Kayakers paddle in a closed boat with a double-bladed paddle.
Races are either 500 or 1,000 meters, in singles, doubles and fours.
Women only race kayaks in singles and pairs.

Trade Gap With Japan
LEAD: The United States trade deficit with Japan will probably shrink but never be eliminated entirely, a Congressional expert told the House Committee on Foreign Affairs today. ''Under any scenario, we're going to have a trade deficit with Japan,'' said Allan Mendelowitz, a senior associate director with the General Accounting Office, the research branch of Congress.

DeLoach Dashes Lewis's Bid in 200
LEAD: Carl Lewis lost his chance to win four Olympic gold medals today when Joe DeLoach, a training partner, edged him at the finish line in the 200-meter final.


Books of The Times
LEAD:  Anything for Billy  By Larry McMurtry  382 pages. Simon &amp; Schuster. $18.95.


OLYMPIC HIGHLIGHTS
LEAD:  TRACK AND FIELDCarl Lewis's bid to repeat his sweep of four gold medals, revived after the disqualification of Ben Johnson, was ended in the final strides of the 200-meter dash as a teammate, Joe DeLoach, sprinted past him to win the gold medal.
In the 400-meter run, the United States swept the first three places, with the winner, Steve Lewis, timed in 43.87 seconds.


Review/Television; Behind the Munich Pact
LEAD: The 1938 Munich Agreement, by which Britain and France gave Hitler the go-ahead to take over the Sudetenland, stands as one of the more shameful episodes leading to World War II.
Nothing in ''The Peace of Paper'' is designed to change that estimate, but it helps us to understand the play of forces behind what is called here ''a symbol of diplomatic naivete and military weakness.


Agency's Loan Role In Danger
LEAD: In the closing days of the 100th Congress, an initiative supported by organized labor could block renewal of an operating charter for the 19-year-old Government agency that insures American investment overseas.


Fewer Businesses Affected by Parental Leave Bill
LEAD: Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, today won Senate approval to modify his bill that would require employers to offer unpaid leaves to workers so they could care for newborn, newly adopted or seriously ill children.

SmithKline's Revamping to Cut 1,600 Jobs
LEAD: The SmithKline Beckman Corporation announced a restructuring yesterday that includes spinning off its Beckman Instruments division and dismissing 1,600 employees.

New Look at Scaasi Is Slim
LEAD: THERE are, of course, a few big, rounded ball gowns in the fall collection of custom-made clothes by Arnold Scaasi; his clients insist on them for extravagant parties, he said.
His strongest design direction, however, is to slender evening dresses that show off the body.
Yet the reduced sweep does not mean the clothes are quiet and unassuming.


Centel Capital Sets Offering Of $400 Million in Securities
LEAD: The Centel Capital Corporation, a unit of the Centel Corporation, a telephone, electronics and communications system company, is offering $400 million of debt securities in two parts through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley &amp; Company.


Determining The Winner, And the Time
LEAD: One of the enduring images of the 1988 Olympics is likely to be Ben Johnson, the Canadian sprinter, left, winning the 100- meter dash, his arm triumphantly aloft.
Two days later, he lost the medal to Carl Lewis of the United States after tests showed he had used an anabolic steroid.


Rita Develin, Teacher, 74
LEAD: Rita Develin, a retired New York City teacher, died of cancer Wednesday at her home in Sedona, Ariz.
She was 74 years old.


Conferees Approve Welfare Revisions; Moynihan Lauded
LEAD: House and Senate conferees tonight approved a compromise that would overhaul the nation's welfare laws and provide the first federally mandated work requirement for welfare recipients.


WASHINGTON TALK: The Senate; For Lugar of Indiana, the Torch Passes to a New Generation
LEAD: Senator Richard G. Lugar sat in a rocking chair in his Capitol Hill office, sipping coffee and recalling the times he was not chosen as a Vice-Presidential nominee.


Hurricane Helene's Winds Fall
LEAD: The once-mighty winds of Hurricane Helene have fallen from 140 miles per hour to 85 m.p.h. as the storm continues to push north over colder mid-Atlantic waters.
Forecasters are predicting that the storm will be downgraded to tropical storm status within the next two days. ''It's just barely a hurricane right now,'' Jim Gross, a forecaster at the National Hurricane Center, said today.


Sports People; Indians Rehire Edwards
LEAD: They finished the 1987 season with the worst record in baseball, and they stand solidly in sixth place this year, but the Cleveland Indians obviously think that Manager Doc Edwards has turned things around enough to justify being rehired.
So yesterday they extended Edwards's contract a year, through next year.


Commerce Savings Buyout Talks Held
LEAD: The American Century Corporation, the parent of Commerce Savings Association, has discussed a buyout of the Texas savings institution with the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.
The disclosure of the talks was contained in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing by a Dallas investor, G. H. Stool, who is a director of American Century.


Steeped in Tradition, Stepping Toward the Future
LEAD: IT happens now and then when one turns onto the noble, tree-lined avenue leading up to the great portico of Chateau Margaux.
For a fleeting moment, the perception and the reality of Bordeaux become one: a harmonious blend of nature, tradition and refinement, a singular way of life.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Soccer Stars in Jersey
LEAD: A game involving a number of the world's legendary soccer players will be staged at Giants Stadium Oct. 29.


A Time-Warner Merger Was Reportedly Studied
LEAD: In an attempt to make their companies so big that they would be almost invulnerable to a takeover, executives of Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc. came close to a $10 billion merger last month but then broke off the deal, an industry expert familiar with the talks disclosed yesterday.


NEWS SUMMARY
LEAD:  INTERNATIONAL A3-13  The I.M.F. was criticized by Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady for not doing more to collect debts.
He also balked at its efforts to bolster its finances and made what was seen as an attack on a Japanese proposal to help debtors.
Page A1


The Games At a Glance
LEAD:  Basketball  This game was taken from the Americans, too.
Only it was taken from them both early and legally.
No, the Soviet Union didn't need chaos to defeat the Americans.
Its court order and strategic discipline were more than enough.
As a result, the Soviet Union, which moved to a 10-point lead by intermission, had little trouble fending off a belated and erratic American comeback to beat the United States, 82-76, and move into the final of the men's competition.


Reagan Signs Law on Film
LEAD: Legislation establishing a national film commission was signed by President Reagan yesterday.
The National Film Preservation Act, part of a Department of the Interior appropriations bill, creates a 13-member panel that could name up to 25 movies a year to be included in a national registry of classic films.


Panamanian Accuses U.S. of a 'War'
LEAD: A Panamanian leader today accused the United States of waging ''economic war'' against his country and declared that his Government had ''grave reasons'' to fear military aggression.


About New York; Doctor's Dream: Healthy Profits From Sore Feet
LEAD: Canadians like Ben Johnson and Wayne Gretzky have no trouble getting their names in the paper.
Were it so simple for Dr.
Glenn Copeland, a Toronto podiatrist with a dream.

Bush Proposes Savings Plan In Bid for Middle-Class Vote
LEAD: Vice President Bush attempted to bolster his appeal among middle-class voters today by proposing a tax-deferred saving plan that aides said would encourage young families to save.


Bush and Noriega: Examination of Their Ties
LEAD: Throughout the 1988 Presidential campaign and again in the televised debate Sunday, opponents of Vice President Bush have invoked the name of Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega, the Panamanian ruler, as shorthand for questioning Mr.
Bush's judgment.


Concern Grows Over Steroids
LEAD: Anabolic steroids are compounds that cause the body to build up muscle and other tissue.
As growing numbers of athletes have begun using them in recent years, medical experts have expressed deep concern about their dangers.

Film Festival; Glimpses of a Depressing Future
LEAD: Surely Derek Jarman's ''Last of England'' is the longest and gloomiest rock video ever made.
Its manifold images of annihilation and misery are assembled in free-associating fashion, without any concern for narrative but with the quick, vigorous, flashy pacing that video audiences understand.
The energy level of ''The Last of England'' is much too high for monotony, but the film's expressionistic leaps are determinedly obscure.


Thornburgh Criticizes F.B.I. for Lobbying Against Gun Legislation
LEAD: The Justice Department issued a rare public criticism today of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, ordering the F.B.I. and all other law-enforcement agencies in the department to speak with one voice before Congress.


Rashad al-Shawa, 79, Ex-Palestinian Mayor
LEAD: Rashad al-Shawa, a Palestinian Mayor of Gaza for 11 years until he was deposed by Israel in 1982, died today at home of a heart attack, his family said.
He was 79 years old.


WASHINGTON TALK: Briefing; Long and Short of It
LEAD: The Senate majority leader, Robert C. Byrd, had a ready answer yesterday when he was asked to comment on the Administration's position on a bill: ''floccinaucinihilipilification.''


U.S. Backs Trainers in Salvador Who Fired
LEAD: Commenting on a firefight involving guerrillas and United States military advisers in El Salvador, President Reagan said today that he would never deny the advisers ''the right to defend themselves.''


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error in some copies, an article yesterday about talks in Brazzaville, Congo, about southern Africa misstated a timetable.
At the Moscow summit meeting last spring, Sept. 29 was set as a goal for a settlement of differences on Angola and Namibia, including establishment of a timetable for a Cuban withdrawal from Angola.

United Nations of Athletes Protected by Tight Security
LEAD: The tall buildings reminded her of a nice housing project, Pam Shriver said, each one taking on the identity of the athletes who are staying there.
The Dutch, for instance, have placed the orange umbrellas they carried in the opening ceremony on their balconies.
Others hang their colorful warm-ups or perhaps laundry there to dry.


Sports People; Name Game
LEAD: The Jackson County Legislature in Kansas City, Mo., has unanimously voted to rename Royals Stadium for Ewing Kauffman, the co-owner of the Kansas City Royals, and his wife, Muriel.
But Kauffman, the millionaire founder of Marion Laboratories, a Kansas City-based pharmaceutical company, says no change will be made at least until next year.

Patrick Sang of Kenya and Domingos Castro of Portugal rank among the world's leading distance runners.

Political Sparring Erupts at Economists' Meeting

Republican and Liberal And Proud to Be Both
LEAD: To the Editor:


Compaq Laptop
LEAD: The Compaq Computer Corporation is expected to introduce its first laptop personal computer next month, marking its entry into a fast-growing segment of the computer business, industry sources said.
The small, lightweight PC will fill an important gap in Compaq's product line.
The laptop will be based on the Intel Corporation's 80286 chip.


Morgan Dix Wheelock, Realty Executive, 79
LEAD: Morgan Dix Wheelock, a real-estate agent and former chairman of the Children's Aid Society of New York, died of respiratory arrest Monday at his home in Darien, Conn.
He was 79 years old.


Scientist Says Low Radon Levels May Be Harmless
LEAD: Although exposure to high levels of the radioactive gas radon causes lung cancer, exposure to low concentrations of the gas may present no hazard at all, an environmental physicist asserted today at the annual meeting of the American Chemical Society.


When Effort Matters
LEAD: To The Living Section:


One Day in Seoul
LEAD: They wept for sadness in Seoul when Ben Johnson, ''the world's fastest human,'' tested positive for steroids and was stripped of his gold medal.
Hours later, Greg Louganis wept for joy as the narrow victor over a spectacular Chinese teen-ager in diving from the high platform.
These two episodes showed the best and the worst of


23 Charged in Drug Sales
LEAD: Twenty-three employees of the United States Postal Service have been arrested on charges of selling small amounts of cocaine and heroin in or near post offices in Manhattan and the Bronx, the Federal authorities said yesterday.
Also arrested were three suspects not working for the Postal Service.
Nine other suspects, including seven postal employees, were being sought.


Texaco Goes Outside To Pick a Top Officer
LEAD: Texaco Inc. reached outside its ranks yesterday and named Allan J. Krowe, a top executive at the International Business Machines Corporation, as its chief financial officer.


U.S. Issues Fall in Light Trading
LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds slipped again in light trading yesterday as dealers pared positions to place bids on an auction of $8.75 billion of new two-year Treasury notes.


FOOD NOTES
LEAD:  Blend of Two Worlds


Sports People; Demotion Time
LEAD: The first-year Pittsburgh Penguins coach, Gene Ubriaco, said yesterday that the left wing, Wayne Van Dorp, was demoted to Muskegon because he failed to aid the All-Star defenseman, Paul Coffey, during a fight in an exhibition game last Saturday.
The 6-4, 225-pound Van Dorp, obtained from Edmonton last season as an enforcer in the same deal that brought Coffey to Pittsburgh, stood by as Steve Martinson of Montreal threw several punches at Coffey.(


Muskegon Journal; A Centennial in Honor Of All Things Jewish
LEAD: These days the Star of David is appearing all over this western Michigan town, first settled in the mid-1800's by Dutch lumberjacks who wore crosses and sang carols at Christmas.





McDowell's Slump Extended by Phils
LEAD: Roger McDowell came gliding past the Mets' dugout on a pair of purple roller skates before tonight's game and whizzed to a stop in front of an unappreciative audience of one: his manager.

Review/Film; Hands Across the Channel
LEAD: Can a young woman from the British middle class find happiness in France with a working-class youth of radical disposition?
That is the question posed and answered in ''Nanou,'' which opens today at Film Forum 1.
Produced in French and English, it introduces the work of Conny Templeman, a young British director and writer.

Debate Forces Playoff Switch
LEAD: The starting times for baseball's League Championship Series games Oct. 5 have been changed to accommodate the telecast of the Vice Presidential debate that night, the Commissioner's Office announced yesterday.


THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Women's Basketball; Yow Tries to Restrain Her Joy
LEAD: She began thinking about this game two years ago when she was named the Olympic women's basketball coach.
Reaching the final, though, has only heightened her expectations, Kay Yow said today.
It would be of little consolation to come this far and not leave with the gold.


THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Diving; Louganis At Best In Test Of Will
LEAD: These Olympics tested his courage and, ultimately, his will to succeed.
At the age of 28, 12 years after he made his first splash in diving - winning a silver medal in Montreal - Greg Louganis today gave what was probably the finest performance of his career in Seoul, overcoming adversity and his heir apparent, to earn a place among the great champions of the Summer Games.


Pound Up as Trade Deficit In Britain Narrows by 31%
LEAD: The dollar was mostly lower yesterday as the British pound dominated the foreign-exchange markets after the release of trade-deficit figures in London.


Officials Deny Abuse In Academy's Training
LEAD: Training at a state-run police academy that left 16 cadets hospitalized last week was strenuous but not abusive, officials said today.


New School Is Reviving Course on 'Great Books'
LEAD: The New School for Social Research in Manhattan plans to offer a modified version of the Western civilization course that the faculty of Stanford University scuttled recently.


Austen Manuscript Is Sold
LEAD: An important Jane Austen manuscript containing two early novels was purchased at auction today by the British Library, ending weeks of speculation that it would leave Britain.


Campaign Trail; Baseball Steps Aside For Omaha Debate
LEAD: Because of the debate between the Vice-Presidential candidates, Senator Dan Quayle of Indiana and Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, baseball fans will now have to reshuffle their schedules.

Edward White, 79, Retired Civil Engineer
LEAD: Edward E. White, a civil engineer who retired in 1975 as president of Spencer, White &amp; Prentis, a contracting concern, died of complications of Parkinson's disease Monday at United Hospital in Port Chester, N.Y.
He was 79 years old and lived in Mamaroneck, N.Y.


Real Estate; Fifth Avenue Rejuvenation Is Expanding
LEAD: THE commercial rebirth of Fifth Avenue from the Empire State Building at 34th Street north to the New York Public Library at 42d Street is well under way, with a total of 1.5 million square feet of office space under construction or in the planning stages.


2 Pay Dearly For Affront To Hirohito
LEAD: One of Japan's largest newspaper groups demoted its editor in chief today and dismissed another senior editor after an English-language edition of the newspaper mistakenly published an editorial lamenting the death of Emperor Hirohito.


Stocks Retreat Broadly as Dow Drops 2.84
LEAD: Stock prices ended broadly lower yesterday as investors continued to shun a directionless market.

2,000 Missing in India Floods
LEAD: About 2,000 people are missing in devastating floods in four states in northern India, flood control officials said today.
They said five days of nonstop monsoon rains caused floods over huge areas of Punjab, Himachal Pradesh and Haryana states and flashfloods in mountainous Jammu and Kashmir.
The official death toll in the four states stood at 330 today, but the figure is expected to rise.

U.S. BALKS AT PLAN BY MONETARY FUND FOR MORE REVENUE
LEAD: In a surprisingly hard-hitting speech, the United States' new Treasury Secretary, Nicholas F. Brady, today balked at efforts by the International Monetary Fund to bolster its finances and criticized it for not doing more to collect its debts.


Mrs. Friedman Given Privileges In Rikers Visits
LEAD: Stanley M. Friedman's wife received special privileges to visit him at a city prison on Rikers Island after he had been transferred from a Federal prison in Missouri, the Department of Correction acknowledged yesterday.


Saying 'I Had to Shoot Him,' Writer Testifies on Intruder
LEAD: First, Carl T. Rowan said in testimony today, came the long string of callers threatening to kill him for his writings against the Ku Klux Klan.
Then a series of nighttime intrusions at his home.
Then the sound at his bedroom window that awakened him at 2 A.M. last June 14.
And finally, the stranger who just kept coming at him in the dark.


Washington Law Firm Suffers New Defections
LEAD: More than a dozen lawyers from a commercial Washington firm, Lane &amp; Edson, will soon be leaving to join the Washington and New York offices of a major Manhattan firm, lawyers involved in the move said yesterday.


Lightning Underscores NASA Weather Rules
LEAD: Bolts of lightning struck within five miles of the space shuttle launching pad at the Kennedy Space Center today, slowing preparations for launching the shuttle Discovery and threatening to delay the countdown.
The problem underscored the importance of new weather rules that could postpone the liftoff.


Education; About Education
LEAD: The phone rings. ''Hello, it's me,'' a boy says, ''I need help with my homework.'' Maalfrid Grude Flekkoy says she is sorry, but that's something to take up with his teacher or parents.

Book Notes
LEAD:  New Post for Seaver


Moody's Raises Ratings for Delta
LEAD: The rating on more than $1.1 billion of debt issued by Delta Air Lines Inc. has been raised by Moody's.
Moody's said the action reflects the likelihood of further improvement in the airline's earnings, cash flow and debt-protection measurements despite growing capital spending requirements.
Delta has quickly absorbed the operations of Western Airlines Inc., which it acquired in December 1986, and is beginning to realize the benefits of a larger, more cost-effective airline with expanded routes,

Corrections
LEAD: An article on May 20 about Stefan Olszowski, a former Polish politician who immigrated to the United States in 1986, described some of Mr.
Olszowski's continuing Polish ties incorrectly.
He says he did not meet in May 1987 with Jozef Czyrek, who is now Foreign Minister of Poland.

Hyster Seeks Japanese Curb
LEAD: The Hyster Company is contending that its Japanese competitors are ''dumping'' forklift parts in the United States in an effort to evade new customs duties imposed on them for selling complete forklifts below cost.

LEAD: The Presidential rivals are now focusing on Illinois, a crucial state where polls show a close race.


Review/Opera; Luciano Pavarotti and Eva Marton In 'Il Trovatore' as the Met Opens
LEAD: Opening night at the Metropolitan Opera is traditionally first of all a social ritual and second, if at all, a musical performance.
That is why, for many years, it has been the company's custom to begin with a heavyweight production calculated to persuade even the novice that he is attending an important cultural event.


Education; Government Delays Tougher Loan Default Rules
LEAD: The Department of Education's proposal to cut off Federal aid to colleges and trade schools whose former students have high rates of defaulting on loans has drawn such concerted opposition that the department has essentially agreed to let the next Administration decide how best to reduce the total of $1.6 billion in defaults.

Scouts Plan a National Food Drive
LEAD: The Boy Scouts of America plans a food drive that the organization says will be the largest in United States history.


ISRAEL REAFFIRMS A STERN RESPONSE AS VIOLENCE GROWS
LEAD: Three Palestinians died of gunshot wounds inflicted by Israeli troops today, bringing to six the number of deaths in a little more than 24 hours, and Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin said demonstrators in Israel's occupied territories could expect more of the same.


COMPANY NEWS;
LEAD: The Data General Corporation said it would take a $45 million fourth-quarter charge to consolidate manufacturing, repair, distribution and other functions - a move that would save the company about $50 million annually.
The computer concern will move manufacturing of its high-end minicomputers from Portsmouth, N.H., to underused sites in Durham, N.H., and Apex, N.C., it said.


A Retirement At Northrop
LEAD: Welko E. Gasich, one of several officials of the Northrop Corporation subpoenaed in a Federal investigation of the company's business dealings in South Korea, retired today.

Review/Theater; Life and Love at the Laundromat
LEAD: ''Leader of the Pack,'' ''The Taffetas'' and now ''Suds'': nostalgia for the songs and sentiments of the 1950's and 60's is apparently insatiable. ''Suds: The Rocking 60's Musical Soap Opera,'' at the new Criterion Center theater, is a musical for those who cannot get enough of their favorite period.


Bilzerian Seeking Fortune Financial
LEAD: Paul A. Bilzerian, the Florida financier, said he had sent a letter to Fortune Financial Group Inc. seeking talks on a possible $157.8 million buyout of the savings and loan company.
Mr.
Bilzerian already owns 9.9 percent of the company, based in Clearwater, Fla., and his offer would be $35 a share for the rest of Fortune Financial's shares.


Philip H. Dougherty, 64, Is Dead; Advertising Columnist for Times
LEAD: Philip H. Dougherty, advertising columnist of The New York Times, died in his sleep yesterday at his home in Queens.
He was 64 years old.
His wife, Dorothy Patt Dougherty, said his death was apparently due to heart failure.


A Communist Of Many Hats: Mieczyslaw Rakowski
LEAD: The selection of Mieczyslaw Rakowski as Prime Minister of Poland appears to reflect a calculation that the Communist Party badly needs an aggressive new brand of leadership.


A Shift at USA Today
LEAD: USA Today today outlined its plan of succession for the retirement of its editor, John C. Quinn, in 1990.
Peter Prichard, 43 years old, a senior editor, will become editor on Oct. 1, as Mr.
Quinn, 63, moves up to editor in chief.
The changes were announced by John J. Curley, president of the Gannett Company, which publishes USA Today.


Transactions
LEAD:  Baseball


Maxwell's Plum Auction
LEAD: The eccentric furnishings of the Maxwell's Plum restaurant are to be auctioned Jan. 21, 1989, everything from the Tiffany glass ceiling to ceramic tigers and monkeys, said Warner LeRoy, the owner.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about clashes between Palestinians and Israeli forces misstated the location of the Jabal Mukabeh neighborhood in some copies.
It is in East Jerusalem.


Bentsen Seeks More Technology Aid for Business
LEAD: In a bid for support for the Democratic ticket from business, Senator Lloyd Bentsen called today for an aggressive partnership between the Federal Government and American industry to restore the nation to world leadership in technology.

Moscow's Foreign Minister enlarged on an offer on a disputed radar, inviting Washington to turn over radars for international research.

New Episcopal Bishop  Bishop Richard F. Grein of Kansas was elected coadjutor of the New York Diocese, to succeed Bishop Paul Moore Jr.


2 Czechoslovak Delegations Will Soon Be Sent to Israel
LEAD: Czechoslovakia, which has had no diplomatic relations with Israel since 1967, will soon send two delegations to that country to deal with consular and economic matters, an Israeli spokesman said today.


Burma Opposition Names Leader
LEAD: U Aung Gyi, a retired army officer who broke with the country's longtime ruler, U Ne Win, and became the country's leading dissident, today was named chairman of a newly formed opposition alliance.

Burger King Corp., the fast-food chain that is a subsidiary of the Pillsbury Co., named Kevin Moriarty executive vice president and manager of the North Central division.

LEAD: It was 16 years later and a new generation of players, but defeat wasn't any easier to accept.
Their voices were subdued, eyes glazed and egos crushed.
There were no excuses this time, either, no claims of being cheated as the United States felt it was in Munich, West Germany, in the 1972 Games.

Diva Not Ill, Just Disgruntled
LEAD: Licia Albanese, the retired star soprano whose traditional attendance and traditional high note in ''The Star-Spangled Banner'' were missed at the Metropolitan Opera opening on Monday night, wants all her friends and admirers to know that she was not ill, but just disgruntled.


Ex-Detective Denies Firing A Shotgun in the Davis Raid
LEAD: A retired Bronx detective testified yesterday that he never carried a shotgun or fired a shotgun at Larry Davis during a shootout with him in a Bronx apartment in 1986 in which the detective was wounded.


Sports People; Nets Player Arrested
LEAD: Under the terms of the league's drug policy, Duane Eddy Washington, who joined the Nets in the final weeks of last season and played in 15 games, faces expulsion from the National Basketball Association if he is convicted of possession of cocaine.
According to Capt.
George Dickscheid of the Newark Police Department, the 24-year-old Washington, a guard, was arrested by two policemen in Newark last Sunday after they investigated a car that was parked on the wrong side of the street with Washington in the driver's seat.


Editors' Note
LEAD: An article in Business Day on Monday about The Chicago Sun-Times reported concerns about the future of the newspaper and described several of its setbacks.
Through an editing lapse, the article omitted reference to some positive developments at the newspaper since it was taken over by an investor group.


Providence Chefs, Husband and Wife, Share an Ideal
LEAD: THE seductive fragrance of wood smoke mingles with the aroma of roasting garlic and drifts across the waterfront in Providence, R.I., these crisp autumn evenings.
Hungry diners trace the scent down South Main Street toward the banks of the Providence River.
There, in a former commercial stable that has been converted into a restaurant optimistically called Lucky's, the owners and chefs, George Germon and Johanne Killeen, are confirming a reputation for hearty portions of good food with gutsy, assertive flavors.

Irwin Novograd, 81, Longtime Stable Owner
LEAD: Irwin Novograd, who with his family has operated the Claremont Riding Academy on West 89th Street in Manhattan for 45 years, died of a stroke Monday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.
He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.


U.S. Panel Lays Denver Air Crash To Failure to De-ice Second Time
LEAD: The National Transportation Safety Board said today that the crash of a Continental Airlines jetliner in Denver nearly a year ago resulted from the captain's failure to have the plane de-iced a second time after it stood in a steady snowfall for 27 minutes.

Gen.
James A. Abrahamson of the Air Force had resigned as director of the research program to develop a space-based anti-missile defense.

Education; Lessons
LEAD: Arthur Wise remembers vividly how his Great Idea came to him, because he was in bed at the time.
It was the spring of 1964, and Mr.
Wise was a 22-year-old graduate student at the University of Chicago trying to come up with a quick and dirty topic for a term paper.


60-MINUTE GOURMET
LEAD: THE first dish I ever made for a customer as a cook's teen-age apprentice in France was an omelet.
Making the perfect omelet - smooth and lightly browned outside, moist and well seasoned within - is a technique about which I have written often over the years.
Italians have their own version of an omelet, called frittata, and it can be equally delicious.

LEAD: ''It is extremely both bold and prophetic at this time for the Soviet Union to have a leader who comes right to the top and says, look, for 70 years Communism hasn't produced the hopes and dreams that we had for it.
Those hopes and dreams crumbled.
And we've got to go in the direction of freeing up speech, the discussion, freeing up responsibility.

LEAD: New York State's top health official said today that about half the neighborhoods abandoned around the Love Canal toxic-waste dump nearly a decade ago could be reinhabited.

LEAD: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company yesterday renewed its offer to buy the Delchamps Inc. supermarket chain of Mobile, Ala., with a offer of $30 a share, $3 higher than an offer made last year.


Genentech Sees Lower Drug Sales
LEAD: Genentech Inc. said today that sales of its flagship product, tissue plasminogen activator, or TPA, would be lower than expected in the third quarter and that as a result, its earnings would be flat, compared with the corresponding period a year ago.

The Yankees keep winning and keep wondering.

A New Way to Get Rid of Old Tires
LEAD: For several decades America has been struggling with the disposal of old tires.
They number about two billion and are growing by 240 million a year.
Most methods for dealing with the problem have either been too expensive or have run into environmental barriers.

Reagan's Plan for Chemical Arms Parley Is Called a Stopgap
LEAD: President Reagan's call for an international meeting to discourage the use of chemical weapons is a stopgap response to delays in eliminating the weapons altogether, Administration and Congressional experts and arms control analysts say.

LEAD: THE banishment of Ben Johnson - say it ain't so, Ben - is a gloomy affair, the world's fastest human slinking out of town on a jet plane, still insisting he had been framed.


Botha and Mobuto to Meet Saturday on Angolan Peace
LEAD: President P. W. Botha of South Africa is expected to travel to Zaire on Saturday to meet with President Mobutu Sese Seko, in the latest move to bring peace to Angola, diplomats said today.


1990 Census May Face A Shortage of Workers
LEAD: The 1990 census, which could cost as much as $3 billion, may have problems hiring enough workers to do the massive national head count, the director of the census, John G. Keane, said today.


Citicorp Rates Rise at Auction
LEAD: For the first time in four weeks, interest rates rose yesterday at Citicorp's auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper.


Rape Victim Gives Up On Collecting Award
LEAD: A rape victim whose attacker cut off her arms with an ax has reluctantly given up efforts to collect a $2.56 million judgment from the man after he disclosed he was nearly broke, her lawyer says.


60 Days of Missiles and Middle-Class Life for Soviet Inspectors
LEAD: Anatoly Samarin loves pickup basketball, Fanta Orange and weekend cookouts around the pool with his neighbors.
Like 4,000 other workers who punch in each day at Magna's sprawling Hercules missile factory, he enjoys knowing that his job has vital military importance.

Legal-Service Group Files Suit Against Segregating Inmates With AIDS
LEAD: Lawyers for New York State prisoners are battling the state's corrections department over what they contend is the department's unconstitutional policy of segregating some prisoners who tests show are infected with the AIDS virus but are not yet ill.


The Victims of the Brawley Case
LEAD: After seven months of investigation, a grand jury seems ready to offer persuasive evidence that Tawana Brawley's claim of racial and sexual victimization was a lie.
Welcome as it is, that report will only begin to vindicate the real victims in this case - the people and institutions abused by Miss Brawley's ''advisers.


EATING WELL
LEAD: IT is getting difficult to find the standard garden variety of ice cream in the supermarket today.
Light, low-calorie, low-fat, no-cholesterol, lactose-free alternatives are crowding out the familiar products.


Taylor Reinstated, N.F.L. Tells Giants
LEAD: Lawrence Taylor, the Giants' All-Pro linebacker, completed his 30-day suspension for substance abuse today and was expected to rejoin the team in time for practice.

LEAD: Almost half the high schools whose students take the Scholastic Aptitude Test now offer special preparation courses, according to the College Board.


Police Detain 3d American
LEAD: Johnny Gray, a member of the United States track team, became the third American athlete to be detained by South Korean police when he was arrested and charged with kicking a taxi.

There is a joke about melted butter.

LEAD: The days of the big slab of beef are over, replaced by bite-size pieces common in some ethnic cuisines and more palatable to health-conscious Americans, said cooks at the National Beef Cookoff here.

LEAD: As Gerry Griffin and his brother, Larry, watch the liftoff of the space shuttle Discovery on monitors at Mission Control at the Johnson Space Center near here Thursday morning, they will probably see more than just a hefty white machine flying into orbit.


FINANCE BRIEFS
LEAD:  Common Stock


Belgian Inflation Rises
LEAD: Belgium's annual inflation rate stood at 1.21 percent in September, the highest this year, the Government reported today.
The Belgian Ministry of Economy said the rate compared with 0.91 percent in August and 1.01 in July.


Review/Music; Philadelphians Open Carnegie Season
LEAD: The Philadelphia Orchestra opened its New York series and Carnegie Hall's season last night with a strongly played program of Soviet music: Shostakovich's First Violin Concerto with Viktoria Mullova as soloist and Prokofiev's dramatic cantata ''Alexander Nevsky.'' Riccardo Muti, the orchestra's music director, is in his element in almost every way with these scores, and there was no mistaking the audience's vociferous reaction to the combined impact.


House Approves Sanctions Against Iraq
LEAD: The imposition of economic sanctions against Iraq became virtually certain today as the House of Representatives followed the Senate in voting to punish Iraq for use of chemical weapons against Kurdish guerrillas and civilians.

U.S. Olympic Reporting Hits a Raw Korean Nerve
LEAD: Charges that American television coverage is unfairly focusing on this nation's dark side during the Olympics are prompting a spasm of anti-Americanism here.


Tandy's Earnings Estimate Lowered
LEAD: Shares of the Tandy Corporation were traded furiously and closed at $39.625, down 87.5 cents, after analysts at Salomon Brothers Inc. and Paine Webber Inc. issued lower earnings estimates for the computer maker.
The analysts said they had lowered their first-quarter projections because the Fort Worth-based company is experiencing a softness in sales volume and has yet to ship its new models, which had been expected in stores by mid-September.


Dodgers Get One Job Done
LEAD: The big scoreboard in right-center field listed final scores for each of the other games in the major leagues late Monday evening.
The Cincinnati Reds, the closest thing to a competitor that the Los Angeles Dodgers have had for the National League West championship, had won in San Francisco.


Man Held in School Shooting Is Depicted as Jobless Recluse
LEAD: A young man accused killing an 8-year-old girl and wounding 10 people in a shooting attack Monday was in and out of a hospital psychiatric ward several times over the past eight months, relatives say.


Review/Television; Marriage According to Martin Mull
LEAD: Martin Mull has found modest fame and some fortune dipping into the tribal patterns of white America.
Beginning in 1985, his periodic ''History of White People in America'' comedy specials have been so popular on Cinemax that the pay-cable service is giving Mr.
Mull an opportunity to flex his satire further in a feature-length film, ''Portrait of a White Marriage,'' which can be seen on Cinemax today at 10:30 A.M.


37-Year-Old Lafleur Signed by Rangers
LEAD: It may be premature to term this a successful comeback, but Guy Lafleur's survival at the Rangers' training camp was made official yesterday when he was signed to a one-year contract by Phil Esposito, the team's general manager.


Chrysler Is Testing Car-Return Programs
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation has begun test-marketing two programs that give customers the right to return vehicles they do not like within 30 days or 1,000 miles, whichever comes first.


Grocery Merger Delayed Further
LEAD: A Federal judge extended his temporary order blocking the purchase of the Lucky Stores Inc. supermarket chain by the American Stores Company, which owns the Alpha Beta grocery chain.
Federal District Judge David Kenyon said he needed more time to consider the merits of a challenge to the merger by California's Attorney General, John Van de Kamp.

LEAD: Comparing her own experience in Britain to Mikhail S. Gorbachev's attempt to reshape the Soviet Union, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said today that it was ''in the Western interest'' for Mr.
Gorbachev to succeed in his effort.


Suit Filed to Recover Money Stolen From Parking Meters
LEAD: The Brooklyn District Attorney, who with Mayor Koch unsuccessfully sought jail sentences for 26 former parking-meter collectors as well as restitution of the money they stole from meters, filed suit yesterday to recover $50,000 from them.


The Long History of a Toxic-Waste Nightmare
LEAD: 1894 - William T. Love begins building a ''model industrial city'' along a canal linking the Niagara River with Lake Ontario.
The invention of the alternating-current motor makes it unnecessary for industry to be near water power, and the project is dropped.


Power Authority Nominees Stalled by Shoreham Fight
LEAD: As part of the battle over the deal to close the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station, the State Senate refused today to confirm two members of the New York Power Authority.
Several senators acknowledged, however, that the move would have no material impact on the deal.


More Journalists Converge on Cape Canaveral
LEAD: By last night the press office at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida had processed more than 5,000 requests from journalists for credentials to cover scheduled liftoff of the Discovery tomorrow morning, more by far than any launching since the first space shuttle took off in 1981.

LEAD: When Senator Dan Quayle, the Republican Vice-Presidential nominee, awoke here this morning, he found his picture top-center on the front page of The Times-Picayune, three columns wide, in full color, hands gesturing authoritatively as he spoke to workers at a nearby plant that produces space shuttle parts.


A Fair Chance, Even Before School; An Issue for the No-Issue Campaign
LEAD: In 1970, Dr.
Arnold Hutschnecker, once Richard Nixon's personal physician in New York, sent a memo to the President that quickly became notorious.
He urged that all 7- and 8-year-olds be psychologically tested for ''violent and homicidal tendencies.'' Those found in need of corrective treatment would get it in day care centers, after-school programs and special counseling.

LEAD: William V. Shannon, a journalist and college professor who served as United States Ambassador to Ireland under President Carter, died today of cancer.
He was 61 years old.

LEAD: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, today enlarged on an offer by Moscow to turn a disputed Soviet radar into an international space research center by inviting the United States to do likewise with two American military radar stations.

LEAD: Crude oil prices fell below $14 a barrel early yesterday, but they later rebounded to end the day with only small losses.

Datalease Is Sold
LEAD: Atlantic Computer Systems Inc., the United States subsidiary of Atlantic Computers P.L.C., said that it had bought for an undisclosed amount of cash the Datalease Corporation of Westport, Conn., a computer-leasing company that had $25 million sales in 1987.
London-based Atlantic Computers, owned by British and Commonwealth Holdings P.L.C., said the deal had been approved by the Federal Trade Commission and Britain's Bureau of Competition and was made final today.


Ward Is Allowed to Carry a Banned Pistol
LEAD: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward is licensed to carry a controversial pistol that is banned in New York City.


Felice Jarecky Louria, Labor Advocate, 88
LEAD: Felice Jarecky Louria, long active in social issues in New York and California, died of congestive heart failure Monday at the Orange Park (Calif.) Nursing Home.
She was 88 years old and lived in Santa Ana, Calif.


Mobutu's Village Basks in His Glory
LEAD: Lost in the Central African rain forest, this languid village of mud huts and dugout canoes changed radically after Mobutu Sese Seko, a native son, became President.


3d Body in Mexican Collapse
LEAD: Rescue workers today recovered a third body from a six-story apartment building that collapsed here and continued to search for three other people believed trapped in tons of rubble.
The rescuers, aided by dogs, found the body of a woman.
Soon after the building collapsed on Tuesday, the body of a man and an infant were found.


Talks on Angola Fight Are to Continue Today
LEAD: Citing progress ''in overcoming a number of obstacles,'' American diplomats said today that talks here over the withdrawal of 50,000 Cuban troops from Angola would continue on Thursday, a day beyond schedule.

LEAD: China's Foreign Minister will visit Moscow this year and meet with the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman announced today.

LEAD: William V. Shannon, a journalist and author who was Ambassador to Ireland in the Carter Administration, died of lymphoma Tuesday at University Hospital in Boston.

LEAD: The use of animals in research is appropriate despite the pain suffered by the animals, the National Academy of Sciences has concluded.


Children's Museum: New Ways to Play
LEAD: THE Brooklyn Children's Museum has begun a $4.5 million renovation that is to be completed in five years.
The museum, designed in 1976 by Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer Associates of Manhattan, was built as a large open space, which museum staff members have found inefficient.
In the renovation, rooms are being built so visitors can focus on single activities.

Growth in Aquaculture
LEAD: Aquaculture production in the United States, which includes fish farming, has grown by 20 percent a year since 1980, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday.
Production includes food and non-food fish, shellfish and aquatic plants, the department's economic research unit said.
The report by the agency was the first in six years.

Europe Limits Steel Aid
LEAD: Despite producers' fears that a boom in steel may not last, the European Community said today that it planned to extend curbs on state aid to the industry for three years beyond the end of 1988.
The community's executive commission said it would propose extending rules that allow producers to draw state aid only to promote research and development, support environmental protection or ease the social impact of factory closings.

New Sony Camera
LEAD: The Sony Corporation of Japan has introduced a compact still-image video camera to be sold in the United States sometime next spring and in Europe by next summer.
The camera uses a two-inch floppy disk instead of conventional film.
The disk takes 50 frames that can be viewed individually on a television set through a player.

LEAD: Charles A. Mills, a former independent consultant to the Navy, today settled civil charges that he illegally traded in the stock of Airship Industries Ltd., while in the possession of nonpublic information that the company would most likely win the contract on which he was working.

LEAD: Adolph Maffie, the last survivor of those convicted in the $2.7 million Brink's robbery of 1950, died Sunday after a long illness.

LEAD: Genes transplanted into animal cells can make them resistant to a virus infection, scientists have reported, describing a research advance that they believe might eventually be applied to the treatment of AIDS patients.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on Monday about a chess grandmaster's defeat by a computer listed the moves incompletely.
Those in the second column of the table were Black's and those in the third column were White's.
In addition, Black's second move was given incorrectly; the correct move was d5.

Paradzhanov before, ''Ashik Kerib'' portrays the buffetings that the artist takes at the hands of philistines and despots before being rescued by the magic of his art.

The killing of Giovanni Bontade and his wife, Francesca, both 42 years old, were the latest in a rash of gangland murders.

LEAD: Officiating errors were made during the Clemson-Florida State football game Sept. 17, according to Bradley Faircloth, the supervisor of officials for the Atlantic Coast Conference.
But Faircloth declined to specify the errors or which officials made them.
Clemson lost to Florida State, 24-21, at its home field.


Review/Opera; Kathleen Battle Sings Cleopatra In Handel's 'Giulio Cesare' at Met
LEAD: If anyone with an ear attached to either side of his head still questioned Kathleen Battle's place among the singing elite of this century, her portrayal of Cleopatra in Handel's ''Giulio Cesare'' at the Metropolitan Opera on Tuesday evening should have swept away all doubt.
Miss Battle proved herself a mistress of Handelian bel canto worthy of mention in the same breath as Joan Sutherland and Beverly Sills, if not earlier divas of hazy legend.

Pontiac Projects Sales of '89 Models
LEAD: The Pontiac division of the General Motors Corporation, said it expects to sell 800,000 cars in the new model year, up from 738,000 cars in the 1988 model year.
At a preview of 1989 models, Michael Losh, general manager for Pontiac, also said in a statement that the division expects to increase its market share in 1989 to 8 percent from its 7.1 percent share in the 1988 model year.

LEAD: The New York City police have put a new spin on an old parental dictum: Be nice to those you meet because you never know who they might turn out to be.


Corrections
LEAD: A brief Reuters article in Business Day Monday about the opening of a new store in Zurich by Tiffany &amp; Company incorrectly described the concern's ownership.
Tiffany is a public company of which Investcorp owns only about 10 percent.

Bell Atlantic Agency
LEAD: The Bell Atlantic Corporation has named J. Walter Thompson/New York its agency of record for media buying and planning for its Yellow Pages, Mobile Systems units and all Bell Atlantic's companies.
The budget is $35 million, bringing the total of all Bell Atlantic business handled by the agency to $95 million.

LEAD: The decision to launch the shuttle Discovery will be made under a tightly disciplined process designed to correct weaknesses that led to the Challenger disaster.
Explicit recommendations will be made by key officials in recorded votes, with final authority to launch given to Navy Capt.
Robert L. Crippen, right, an experienced shuttle astronaut.

LEAD: The Ashton-Tate Corporation has confirmed that shipments of the latest update of its flagship product, dBase IV, will be further delayed.
Originally scheduled for release on July 31 and delayed until Sept. 30, the new version of dBase is now expected to ship within two to three weeks, the company said.

LEAD: Once again, Peter F. Vallone, the New York City Council majority leader, has chosen to challenge Mayor Koch in a fiscal tug of wills he seems destined to lose.
Ostensibly the fight is over how to pay for the Mayor's $110 million anti-drug program, of which the police Tactical Narcotics Team is the centerpiece.


Corrections
LEAD: A headline yesterday on an article about a suit by New York state prison inmates against the state corrections department incorrectly characterized the inmates who say they are being segregated.
The inmates have tested positive for the AIDS virus but are not ill with AIDS.

All the issues are offered at a price of 100 through various securities dealers.

LEAD: THE reopening of the Royalton Hotel on Oct. 10 is one of the most-awaited design events of the year in Manhattan.
Philippe Starck, the current superstar of French design, has completely restructured the 90-year-old neo-Georgian limestone building on 44th Street, aiming to turn it into a home away from home for well-traveled sophisticates.

Workers Ousted for Drug Use
LEAD: Six workers were dismissed after an investigation into accusations of drug use at the Point Beach nuclear power plant, officials said today.
The Wisconsin Electric Power Company said its investigation began after a tip that employees had used marijuana or cocaine in off-duty hours.
All six workers were described as working in maintenance and other support jobs at the plant.

LEAD: GARDENERS love tinkering with Mother Nature.
Not far from downtown Portland, two large wholesale nurseries specialize in clipping, bending and bonding plants together.
For the past few years, they have been taking advantage of Oregon's temperate climate, which accelerates the growth of such complex trained plants.

Larry Gallagher, 41, Creator of a Musical
LEAD: Larry Gallagher, the creator and director of the Off Broadway musical ''Beehive,'' died Tuesday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 41 years old.
He died of encephalitis, according to his brother Steven Gallagher.  ''Beehive,'' a revue of 1960's pop music, began at the cabaret Sweetwaters and moved to the Top of the Gate, where it played more than 600 performances.


Study Reports Flaws in Federal Workplace
LEAD: The Federal Government is becoming a frustrating place to work, with salaries low, prestige falling, offices seedy, and workers subjected to humiliating experiences and sapped of initiative, says a study ordered by Congress.


Mother Jailed in Baby's Death
LEAD: A teen-age mother has been sentenced to six months in jail for the death of her 6-month-old son despite pleas from her lawyer that she had suffered enough.
The mother, Rhonda Cassan, 18, pleaded guilty last month to negligent homicide.
Her son, Michael, died in May, five months after the mother admitted that she had shaken him to stop him from crying.

LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board has begun internal discussions on how to tap new funds if its resources fall short of resolving the savings industry's problems, the agency's chairman, M. Danny Wall, said today.

LEAD: The 71 families who stayed in the abandoned neighborhoods around Love Canal here waited almost a decade for state health officials to decide their fate.
Today Love Canal is a neighborhood of winners and losers.

Bush has still showed himself careless and superficial on what may be the most perilous subject in politics.

LEAD: A Sarasota man said today that he would have his 9-year-old daughter tested to determine if she is actually the biological child of another couple.

The Games At a Glance
LEAD:  Track and Field  For those who watch Florence Griffith Joyner run, the Olympics have been a blur.
Already the gold-medalist in the 100-meter dash, Griffith Joyner ran to a world record on the 200-meter semifinals with a time of 21.56 seconds.
Her sister-in-law, Jackie Joyner-Kersee fouled in her final jump and her last attempt to set a world record in the long jump.


Review/Music; The Choir of Westminster Abbey
LEAD: One would be hard pressed to find a choir with firmer historical connections than those the choir of London's Westminster Abbey can claim.
The Abbey itself has been the site of England's coronations and other state rites of passage since 1066, and although its records do not say when the choir was established, it is known that three-part polyphony was sung there by the mid-13th century.

J.C. Heard Dies at 71; Long a Jazz Drummer
LEAD: James Charles (J. C.) Heard, one of jazz's most recorded and widely traveled drummers, died of a heart attack on Tuesday.
He became ill at a friend's home in Southfield, Mich., and was taken to William Beaumont Hospital in Royal Oak, Mich., where he died.
He was 71 years old and lived in Troy, Mich.

Review/Art; Calling The Roll Of Latinos
LEAD: There have been ''los tres grandes'' - Diego Rivera, David Alfaro Siqueiros, Jose Clemente Orozco - and a small handful of other artists from Latin America whose names sound, or whose paintings look, familiar to much of the art public in this country.
It is the admirable goal of ''The Latin American Spirit: Art and Artists in the United States, 1920-1970'' that the list of names grow longer.

LEAD: The Indian Government today deflected pleas from Bangladesh for an international approach to flood control in South Asia and announced instead that there would be another joint Indian-Bangladeshi study of river waters.

Back in Space; Challenger Kin at Launching
LEAD: Relatives of two of the astronauts killed in the Challenger disaster watched from a guarded location at the Kennedy Space Center as the Discovery lifted off today, a space official said.
Scott Smith, son of the Challenger pilot, Michael J. Smith, and Claude Onizuka, brother of Ellison S. Onizuka, a mission specialist, gathered with the families of the five Discovery astronauts to view the launching, said Arnold Richman, a spokesman for the space agency.

Review/Music; American Jazz Orchestra
LEAD: The opening concert of the American Jazz Orchestra's third season illustrated the place a permanent jazz orchestra should fill in the city's cultural life.
Not only did it bring out rare pieces, but it also recast - simply by playing them well and swinging hard - pieces that had at one time been big-band hits.

LEAD: Carolyn Waldo of Canada scored a perfect 10, five 9.9s and a 9.8 in the final round to win the gold in solo synchronized swimming today over Tracie Ruiz-Conforto.
