Close-Up: Synchronized Swimmming
LEAD:  Underwater Choreography  Synchronized swimming, which made its debut as a medal sport in 1984, is a series of choreographed maneuvers, some with aquatic names such as swordfish, heron, albatross and flamingo.
Competition is in singles and duet and is comprised of compulsory figures, done without music (55 per cent of the score), and routines, with music (45 per cent).


College to Select Art-Collection Trustee
LEAD: A new trustee for the board of the Barnes Foundation in Merion, Pa., one of the world's greatest collections of 19th- and 20th-century European art, will be appointed by Lincoln University, a small but distinguished liberal-arts college with a predominantly black student body near Oxford, Pa.


Texaco-Saudi Deal
LEAD: Texaco Inc.'s chief executive, James W. Kinnear, said the third-largest United States oil company hoped to complete the agreement for its $800 million oil refining joint venture with Saudi Arabia as early as November.
The new venture involves refining and marketing oil in the Eastern and Gulf Coast regions of the United States.

LEAD: Electronic Data Systems, a unit of the General Motors Corporation, acquired a smaller company, General Data Systems of Philadelphia, that specializes in computer services for the property-and-casualty insurance industry.
Terms of the transaction were not disclosed.


Stage Designers Are Stars at Gallery
LEAD: ''Broadway: A Survey of Works by Scenic and Costume Designers,'' an exhibition featuring the work of more than two dozen designers in many media, is on view through Oct. 15 at Gimpel Weitzenhoffer Ltd. &amp; Harold Reed, 724 Fifth Avenue, near 57th Street.
The exhibits include set-design models by Tony Walton (''The Front Page,'' ''I'm Not Rappaport''), John Napier (''Les Miserables''), Robin Wagner (''Dreamgirls'') and David Jenkins (''The Elephant Man'').

The budget is $10 million.


Clinton Art Show
LEAD: In an effort to correct what it considers an undeserved reputation for crime, the Clinton section of Manhattan is having an outdoor art show on Sunday, from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M.
The area is between Eighth Avenue and the Hudson River, from 57th to 23d Street.
There will be artworks on display and for sale, food, entertainment, community service information tables and visiting politicians.

LEAD: Charles Addams, the cartoonist whose macabre humor brought a touch of ghoulishness to The New Yorker's glossy pages for five decades, died yesterday at St.
Clare's Hospital and Health Center, 415 West 51st Street.

Addams died in the emergency room after being brought to the hospital by ambulance.

LEAD: Acupuncture appears to be a surprisingly effective way to treat crack addicts and help them stay away from crime and out of jail, the New York City Probation Commissioner and drug-treatment experts said yesterday.


Fiscal Experts Give Dukakis More Credit Than Bush Does
LEAD: Vice President Bush takes glee in terming ''the Massachusetts miracle,'' a slogan adopted by Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis for the state's economic upturn, ''the Massachusetts mirage.'' He calls his Democratic opponent the nation's leading taxer, spender and borrower, saying that Mr.
Dukakis is presiding over the erosion of his state's manufacturing base.


Our Towns; How Mt. Vernon Avoided Racism: It Voted Yes
LEAD: Whites on Yonkers's East Side say their opposition to low-income housing is not black or white, it's green. (They're not racist; they're protecting property values.) A bit farther north, whites in the Mayfair section of Greenburgh aren't being racist either.
But when the Town Council approved a homeless facility in their area, they filed petitions to secede and form their own village.


At The Bar
LEAD: Not long ago a law student making the rounds of New York firms spent a day at Anderson, Russell, Kill &amp; Olick.
After meeting with several partners, some scarcely older than she, the law student appeared thoroughly perplexed. ''I don't know what to make of this place,'' she lamented. ''Everyone I spoke to seems happy.

LEAD: The Eveready Battery Company announced the first lithium battery in the widely used AA size, a development that was hailed as a breakthrough by scientists and security analysts.
The pencil-thin AA batteries make up about half of all batteries sold and are the fastest-growing segment of the industry, said the St.

Chrysler Agrees to Pay On Lemon-Law Resales
LEAD: The Chrysler Motors Corporation, which repurchased 400 defective automobiles under the New York ''lemon law,'' allowed dealers to resell them without warning purchasers about the past problems, Attorney General Robert Abrams said yesterday.


U.S. Honda Prices Rise
LEAD: The American Honda Motor Company said today that it had raised the prices of its 1989 car models by 1.7 percent, or $211 a vehicle, in the case of the Honda division, and by 2.6 percent, or $485 a vehicle, in the case of Acura, its luxury division.
Honda prices now range from $6,385 for the Civic hatchback to $17,690 for the Prelude Si, which has four-wheel steering.

A Look At the U.N.'s Peacekeeping Forces
LEAD:  U.N.
Iran-Iraq Military Observer Group  Created Aug. 9, 1988  Location: Iran-Iraq war front, with headquarters in Teheran and Baghdad  Mission: Observe cease-fire that took effect Aug. 20, monitor troop withdrawals, and assist in the exchange of war prisoners.
Participants: About 350 observers from Argentina, Australia, Austria, Bangladesh, Canada, Denmark, Finland, Ghana, Hungary, Indonesia, India, Ireland, Italy, Kenya, Malaysia, New Zealand, Nigeria, Norway, Poland, Senegal, Sweden, Turkey, Yugoslavia and Zambia.

LEAD: A mistrial was declared today in the gun-possession case of Carl T. Rowan, the syndicated columnist and television commentator, after the jury reported that it could not reach agreement.


Campaign Trail; Reading the Signs Of Quayle Campaign

No Charges in Theft of Statue
LEAD: No charges will be filed against two American gold medal swimmers for taking a marble carving from a hotel, a South Korean Government prosecutor said today.


Bring Minimum Wage Into the World of 1988; Subsidizing Employers
LEAD: To the Editor:


Review/Film; 'Elvira,' a Friendly Witch
LEAD: Elvira's jet-black wig shoots up in a giant beehive shape, then falls like a veil to her waist.
Her eyes are so heavy with makeup it's a wonder she can blink.
And her slinky black dress might make Cher jealous or Frederick of Hollywood blush.
Cut up to her thighs and down to her navel, it is designed to expose Elvira's proudest comic prop, a gravity-defying bosom more believable on Jessica Rabbit than on any real-life woman.


Craft Festival
LEAD: The American Arts and Crafts Alliance will hold its autumn festival tomorrow and Sunday from 10 A.M. to 6:30 P.M., on Columbus Avenue between 77th and 81st Streets.
Jewelry, blown glass, gold and silver sculptures, painted silks, leather, ceramics, masks, quilts, toys and fantasy clothing will be on display.


Police Lift Ban on Gun Ward Carries, a Glock
LEAD: A day after it was disclosed that Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward had been licensed to carry an Austrian-made handgun that is banned in New York City, the Police Department announced that it had dropped its prohibition and would allow officers and private citizens to purchase and carry the pistol.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Du Pont Plans New Coolant
LEAD: The Du Pont Company said today that it would begin commercial production in 1990 at Corpus Christi, Tex., of a substitute refrigeration chemical for one of the significant chlorofluorocarbon compounds that destroy ozone.


Dukakis Faults G.O.P. for Savings Crisis
LEAD: Trying to bring into the Presidential campaign what many think will be a pressing economic issue next year, Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis today placed the blame for the savings and loan industry crisis on Vice President Bush and the Reagan Administration.

Parking Rules
LEAD: Because of the Jewish holidays of Shemini Atzereth and Simhath Torah, which conclude the harvest festival of Succoth, alternate-side parking will be suspended in New York City on Monday and Tuesday.
Other regulations remain in effect.


Israeli Parties Clash on Ruling Over Enclave
LEAD: Israel accepted today's decision on the Taba border dispute with resigned sorrow, but the ruling set off bitter recriminations between political parties.


Report Faults Loopholes in Campaign-Fund Law
LEAD: There are so many loopholes in New York City's new campaign finance law that they ''undercut the promise of reform held out to New York voters,'' a state commission has concluded.

LEAD: Vice President Bush hailed the successful launching of the space shuttle Discovery today and said that he hoped to travel to Edwards Air Force Base in California for the landing.

Senate Votes to Extend An AIDS Drug Effort
LEAD: The Senate today approved a six-month extension of a Federal program that provides the drug AZT to victims of AIDS who cannot afford the costly treatment.


Symbol Agrees To Buy MSI Data
LEAD: Symbol Technologies Inc., the dominant maker of bar-code scanning equipment, has agreed to buy one of its major customers in a friendly acquisition.
The $23-a-share cash deal to buy the MSI Data Corporation values MSI at $120 million and saves the company from a hostile tender offer by a rival, the Telxon Corporation, which had raised its offer on Wednesday to $20 a share.

He was 59 years old and lived in Tuxedo Park, N.Y., and Lawrence, L.I.

Taiwan Share Prices Fall
LEAD: Panic selling sent Taiwan share prices plummeting today after the Government announced a tax on stock market profits.
Investors streamed into brokerages to dump shares, pushing the weighted index down 175.96 points, to 8,613.82.
Taiwan's Finance Minister, Shirley Kuo, said on Saturday that, to cool Asia's fastest-growing stock exchange, profits on sales exceeding $3 million (Taiwan), or $105,000 (United States), would be taxed starting Jan.

Mastercard Fee Increase
LEAD: Mastercard International, the credit card company, this week announced a rate increase affecting the banks that handle the transactions for a merchant after a consumer makes a Mastercard purchase.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Sunday about the election of the Rev.
Barbara C. Harris as a bishop in the Episcopal Church misstated the position taken by Anglican leaders this summer on consecrating women as bishops.
The conference proposed ways for the 27 autonomous churches of the Anglican Communion to minimize conflict over different policies on the issue, but it did not formally approve or disapprove the consecration of women.

LEAD: Whitney North Seymour Jr. served justice well as independent prosecutor in the Michael Deaver case.
Having persuaded a jury that the former top White House aide committed perjury, he tried without success to persuade a Federal judge that lying to Congress and a grand jury called for some prison time.

Al Sharpton and C. Vernon Mason, advisers to Tawana Brawley, and nine other demonstrators were arrested in Brooklyn yesterday evening after street protests that briefly blocked the Manhattan and Brooklyn Bridges and the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway.


Corrections
LEAD: An article yesterday about a news conference given by Tawana Brawley incorrectly characterized an earlier account in The Times about a grand jury's investigation in the case.
The earlier article was based on summaries of evidence presented to the grand jury; the grand jury has not released any conclusions.

Accord on a 24-Month Angola Pullout Reported
LEAD: Negotiators from Angola, Cuba and South Africa agreed in principle here today on a 24-month timetable for the withdrawal of all Cuban troops from Angola, diplomats said.


John L. Davenport, 82; Directed Cancer Labs
LEAD: John L. Davenport, who directed the cancer research laboratories of Pfizer Inc. before his retirement in 1967, died of cancer Wednesday at Boca Raton (Fla.) Community Hospital.
He was 82 years old and lived in Boca Raton.
He had formerly lived in Westwood, N.J.

LEAD: Though the cold atrium is empty, the muffled cacophony of pianos, trumpets and voices and the echo of heels clacking somewhere on a marble floor seem today to be almost a theatrical prelude to a fateful scene - like the one staged here a half-century ago.


Second Victim Dies After School Shooting Incident
LEAD: A second victim of a gunman's shooting spree at an elementary school died today, a few hours after students and teachers returned to class for the first time since Monday.

Glen E. Covington, Singer, 61
LEAD: Glen E. Covington, a singer and pianist who performed with his trio in supper clubs around the country, died on Sept. 18 after suffering a heart attack in Cleveland.

Bring Minimum Wage Into the World of 1988; Scrap It Altogether
LEAD: To the Editor:


Fires Force Evacuations
LEAD: Two brush fires in the foothills about 60 miles east of Los Angeles forced the evacuation of about 250 houses and four elementary schools today.
A Forestry Department spokeswoman, Holly Kress, said the fires, which began on Wednesday, covered 6,000 acres and may have been deliberately set.
She said they were being fueled by hot, dry desert winds that made it difficult to predict when firefighters would have the fires under control.


Chemical Offering Backed By Credit Card Receivables
LEAD: Chemical Bank Credit Card Trust 1988-B is offering $500 million of securities backed by credit card receivables.
Chemical Bank is the underwriter for the offering.

LEAD: David Seltzer's ''Punchline'' is a tepid romantic comedy about two aspiring stand-up comics, Steven Gold (Tom Hanks), a failed medical student who can only express himself in one-liners, and Lilah Krytsick (Sally Field), an otherwise happily married New Jersey housewife who dreams of stardom on television and the nightclub circuit.


Mitterrand Urges Sanctions Against Users of Poison Gas
LEAD: President Francois Mitterrand told the United Nations General Assembly today that a wide range of international trade sanctions should be imposed on any nation using poison gas or other chemical weapons against its own citizens or another country.


Salomon Says U.S. Seeks $311 Million in Oil Penalties
LEAD: Salomon Inc. said yesterday that the Department of Energy was seeking $311 million in payments for suspected oil pricing violations by its Phibro Energy subsidiary from 1978 to 1980.


California Savings Unit Gets $281 Million Rescue
LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today that it had reached an agreement to merge the insolvent Butterfield Savings and Loan Association of Santa Ana, Calif., with a healthy California institution.
The bank board will provide $281.1 million in assistance.


Soviet Parley Called 'No Threat to Gorbachev'
LEAD: Soviet officials said today that a meeting of the Communist Party Central Committee hastily scheduled for Friday did not signal that Mikhail S. Gorbachev was in political trouble.

Back in Spasce; NASA Turns to Seasoned Crew of 5 Shuttle Veterans for Crucial
LEAD: For the flight of the Discovery, the first space shuttle mission since the Challenger disaster 32 months ago, the space agency chose a seasoned crew.
Four of the crew members have backgrounds in the military as fighter or test pilots, while the fifth is a civilian scientist.
For the first time in the history of the shuttle program, every member of the crew has flown on previous shuttle flights.


Hurricane Benefit
LEAD: The singers Melba Moore, Jocelyn Brown and Sylvester, the rap performer Doug E. Fresh and the calypso artists Swallow and Blue Boy will be among the performers taking part in a benefit concert tonight at 7:30 at New York City Technical College, Klitgard Auditorium, 300 Jay Street, in downtown Brooklyn.


Coaches Alert Devils About Job Security
LEAD: Jim Schoenfeld, the Devils' coach, is worried that last season's success may make his players think that they will have jobs this season.
That judgment, he said, would be up to the coaching staff.

Grand Met Hotel Sale Indicated
LEAD: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the owner of the Inter-Continental Hotels Corporation, may be close to a deal to sell the luxury chain to the Seibu Saison Group of Japan for substantially more than $2 billion in cash, Japanese and American investment bankers said yesterday.


Trail Blazers Blamed
LEAD: Coach Mike Schuler said efforts by the Portland Trail Blazers to help rehabilitate injured the Soviet basketball star, Arvidas Sabonis, had nothing to do with the Soviet Union's semifinal victory over the Americans in the Olympics.
Sabonis, a Trail Blazer draft pick in 1986, had 13 points and 13 rebounds in the 82-76 victory.


OLYMPIC HIGHLIGHTS
LEAD:  TRACK AND FIELD: Two sisters-in-law, Jackie Joyner-Kersee and Florence Griffith Joyner, each won a second gold medal.
Kersee became the first American woman to win the Olympic long jump.
Joyner set a world record in the 200-meter sprint.
BASKETBALL: The Soviet Union captured the gold medal with a 76-63 victory over Yugoslavia.

G.O.P. Assembly Edge Shrinks
LEAD: The Republican advantage in the Assembly narrowed to two today, when John Villapiano was sworn in to succeed Anthony Villane, who joined the Kean administration.
Mr.
Villapiano, 36 years old, won a special election Sept. 15 to represent the 11th District in Monmouth County.
There are now 39 Democrats and 41 Republicans in the Assembly.


SENATORS OPPOSE VISA FOR ARAFAT
LEAD: Fifty-one senators, including the two Vice Presidential nominees, Lloyd Bentsen and Dan Quayle, today urged the Reagan Administration to deny an expected request for a visa for Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization.


3 on Plane Safe In Hudson Landing
LEAD: A pilot and his two passengers escaped serious injury last night when their single-engine plane was forced to land in the Hudson River, the New York City police said.

About Real Estate; Low-Cost Housing Need: Early Cash
LEAD: The shortage of low-cost housing in New York is acute, everyone agrees, and there is a fair amount of money available from city and state agencies and from private groups to help rebuild decaying houses for the homeless and for those unable to pay market rents.

LEAD:  Debt


Frank Caplan, 77, Toy Developer
LEAD: Frank Caplan, an educator and a pioneer in the development of educational toys for children, died of pneumonia Wednesday at the Medical Center at Princeton.
He was 77 years old and lived in Princeton, N.J.


For Children
LEAD:  Shows, Nature, Museums  ''THE TALES OF THE BARDS: STORIES IN MUSIC AND ART,'' a one-hour gallery program focusing on storytelling in medieval music and art,with music by the Ensemble for Early Music, 1 P.M. tomorrow, at the Cloisters, Fort Tryon Park.
The program is free with museum admission; donation: $4.50 for adults; children under 12, free.


Gacy Death Sentence Upheld
LEAD: The Illinois Supreme Court today upheld the convictions and death sentence of John Wayne Gacy in the sex-related killings of 33 boys and young men.
The execution was scheduled for next Jan. 11, but that is almost certain to be delayed by further appeals.

Superman?
Or, as opined by the slick and sometimes amusing new comedy ''Heartbreak Hotel,'' is it Elvis Presley?


Reagan Links Nuclear Arms Cuts to Testing Need
LEAD: President Reagan has told Congress that the United States might have a greater need to carry out an extensive nuclear testing program if Moscow and Washington agree to cut their strategic arsenals.


Review/Art; Kosuth Takes a Turn For the Psychological
LEAD: Joseph Kosuth is becoming the eminence grise of Conceptual art while remaining its enfant terrible -still capable of confounding his audience with new twists and turns in his work.
Mr.
Kosuth's art has always been analytical, but in recent years he has moved away from the analysis of language and images toward the psychological, specifically Freudian, kind.

Kurdish Refugees in Turkey May Have Fled the Lion for the Fox
LEAD: To the Editor:


Money Fund Assets Fall
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 452 money market mutual funds fell by $267.6 million, to $266.97 billion, in the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The assets of the 223 general purpose funds fell by $140.8 million, to $84.68 billion; those of the 103 broker-dealer funds rose by $28.2 million, to $113.38 billion, and the assets of the 126 institutional funds fell by $155 million, to $68.91 billion, the institute said.


Dokes Arrested
LEAD: Michael Dokes, the former World Boxing Association heavyweight champion, was jailed Wednesday after he was arrested on a charge of assaulting his live-in friend during a quarrel, a Sheriff's Department spokesman in Los Angeles said.
The woman, Michelle Woods, 30 years old, suffered bruises and other injuries in the incident, but refused treatment, according to Sgt.


Cast-Iron Buildings and a Patch of Green
LEAD: Duane Street, a five-block hyphen between Lafayette and Greenwich Streets in lower Manhattan, begins amid the jungle of municipal buildings north of City Hall and proceeds westward into the heart of TriBeCa, a neighborhood whose early-1980's avant-garde edge is giving way to gentrification.
All the while, this little street - named for James Duane, New York's first mayor after the Revolution - never strays far from the amorphously defined financial district and its glitzy new adjunct, the World Financial Center of Battery Park


Radio Executive Chosen
LEAD: Lewis D'Vorkin, a former front-page editor of The Wall Street Journal, will become managing editor of a new radio network that will begin Jan. 12 with business news broadcasts 24 hours a day.
The network is owned by Business News Broadcasting Inc.
Mr.
D'Vorkin, 36 years old, resigned from The Journal in June.


Small Lead For Bush
LEAD: A Gallup Poll made public yesterday showed Vice President Bush leading Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, although more Americans thought Mr.
Dukakis had won Sunday's debate.


Once Just Chemicals, and Now Bombs
LEAD: The discovery of an explosive cylinder of deadly hydrogen cyanide at an abandoned plant here has thrown into sharp focus a potentially serious threat, posed by deteriorating chemicals, to communities across the country.

840 New Jail Cells Planned in Nassau
LEAD: Nassau County plans to build 840 new cells at the county jail in East Meadow to relieve overcrowding, a spokesman for the County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, said yesterday.

LEAD:  INTERNATIONAL A3-11  Egypt's border dispute with Israel was resolved in Egypt's favor by an international arbitraion panel, but it is still up to the two sides to work out a final section of the boundary which has been their major unresolved issue since 1979.

2 Added To Fed List Of Dealers
LEAD: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday named another Japanese securities firm and another British one as primary dealers, a status that allows the firms to deal directly with the central bank.


Real Estate Company to Buy Lyle Stuart
LEAD: The Carol Management Corporation, a privately held real estate company that owns the Doral hotel chain, said yesterday that it would acquire Lyle Stuart Inc., the book publisher, for a price it said exceeded $10 million.


Elma Stuckey, 81; Poet Wrote About Blacks
LEAD: Elma Stuckey, a former schoolteacher who won acclaim late in life with her poetry about black Americans from the time of slavery to the present and who published her second volume of poems last year at age 80, died of a heart attack at Washington Hospital Center on Friday.
She was 81 years old and lived in


Oh Quits as Manager
LEAD: Japan's legendary home-run hitter, Sadaharu Oh, admitted yesterday what many ballplayers discovered before him: Great hitters do not necessarily make great managers.
At a news conference in Tokyo, Oh said that he would resign as manager of the Yomiuri Giants next week after another disappointing season by the team that once dominated Japanese baseball.


THE GAMES AT A GLANCE
LEAD:  Track and Field  The Games are nearing completion, but for Florence Griffth Joyner, it's all been a blur: a glorious, glamorous blur.
Griffith Joyner, who sets world records with all the evident effort of someone going to the corner for milk, won her second gold medal when she took the women's 200 in a world-record time of 21.34 seconds.

Back in Space; Boosters Are Monitored And There Isn't a Flaw
LEAD: Shuttle booster rockets, whose disastrous failure 32 months ago caused the explosion that destroyed the Challenger and killed its crew of seven people, apparently functioned flawlessly this morning aboard the shuttle Discovery.


Long Hiatus Ends
LEAD: The space shuttle Discovery, picking up the baton from the fallen Challenger, raced into orbit Thursday carrying five experienced astronauts and the nation's hopes for revival of its civilian space program.


Restaurants
LEAD: It is easier to snag trout with your bare hands than to get a table at the new Docks in midtown on short notice.
You don't need to be a restaurant critic to see why.
This gleaming brasserie serves just what people want: uncompromisingly fresh fish that is minimally fussed over, in a congenial atmosphere and for a reasonable price.

House Backs Rise in World Bank Funds
LEAD: The House today voted, 303 to 90, to authorize American support for a huge increase in resources for the World Bank, ending a year of wrangling over a lender that commits nearly $20 billion a year in the developing world.


Back in Space; U.S. Signs Pact to Build Space Station
LEAD: On the day the United States returned to space, it and 11 other countries signed agreements to build the next major space project, a permanently manned station to orbit the Earth by the late 1990's.


Foe Slowed by Weicker's 2-Party Appeal
LEAD: At a Free South Africa conference here last weekend, a crowd of liberals applauded the arrival of the senior Senator from Connecticut, Lowell P. Weicker Jr.
They nodded when the rambunctious Republican from Greenwich reminded them that he was the first, and so far the only, Senator to be arrested at an anti-apartheid demonstration.


Olivetti To Divide Into 3 Units
LEAD: Two days after reporting lower quarterly profits, Olivetti, the Italian computer giant, today announced a broad corporate reorganization to bolster its competitiveness.

Corrections
LEAD: An Executive Changes listing in Business Day yesterday about the Sherwood Group incorrectly reported the status of Fredric W. Rittereiser, the firm's chief executive.
He remains chief executive, but will be leaving if negotiations for sale of a large part of Sherwood succeed.
The company announced on Wednesday that it had authorized the sale of a block of stock to Arthur Kontos, a managing director of Spear, Leeds &amp; Kellogg, another securities concern.


Citing Drug Use, Olympic Official Proposes a Ban on Weight Lifting
LEAD: An Olympic official said Thursday that he would recommend that weight lifting be dropped from future Olympic Games because of drug use by some athletes.

Americans Top Brazil, 3-0, to Gain Final
LEAD: One look at the faces on the United States basketball players back at the Olympic Village after their semifinal loss to the Soviet Union on Wednesday, was enough of a reminder for the American men's volleyball team, the defending gold medalists.


Ramada Is Quoted On Restructuring
LEAD: The Pritzker family of Chicago disclosed in a Federal filing that the top official of Ramada Inc. had said the hotel chain was considering a restructuring in light of the unsolicited $10-a-share , or $368 million, unsolicited Pritzker bid.
Richard Snell, Ramada's chairman, told Jay Pritzker, whose family controls the Hyatt chain of hotels, on Monday that Ramada was reviewing alternatives.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Sept. 8 about the aftermath of floods in Bangladesh misidentified the language in which ''pani'' means water.
The word exists in Hindi and Urdu.


Anchors Away
LEAD: All was well at Cape Canaveral yesterday.
The shuttle, looking like a huge Taj Mahal, soared off satisfyingly into space.
On television, Peter Jennings narrated for ABC, Dan Rather narrated for CBS and Tom Brokaw narrated for NBC.
Tom Brokaw?
Isn't he in Korea?

Braves Obtain Davis
LEAD: With four days left in the season, the last-place Atlanta Braves began remodeling the team for next season by acquiring the catcher Jody Davis from the Chicago Cubs yesterday in exchange for the rookie pitchers Kevin Coffman and Kevin Blankenship. ''We've been working on this deal for two months,'' General Manager Bobby Cox said.


Soviets Say U.N. Group Ignores Pakistani Acts
LEAD: The Soviet Union sharply criticized the United Nations peacekeeping operation in Afghanistan today for failing to investigate what it called Pakistan's flagrant violations of the Geneva peace accords.

Mr.
Gaisford's technical and interpretive gifts are considerable, as are those of his pianist, William Gugala

LEAD: In the belief that the biotechnology industry is about to become a major source of important new drugs, the big pharmaceutical companies are racing to strengthen their ties to the industry's most promising members.

U.S. Issues Post a Modest Gain
LEAD: The price of Treasury securities rose modestly yesterday after dealers learned of a $1 billion note sale by Italy, which was accompanied by an interest-rate swap agreement and large-scale purchases of Treasury securities.


U.N. Peacekeeping Forces Named Winner of the Nobel Peace Prize
LEAD: The United Nations peacekeeping forces, which for 40 years have been deployed to reduce tensions in the world's trouble spots, were named here today as the 1988 winner of the Nobel Peace Prize.


Bring Minimum Wage Into the World of 1988
LEAD: To the Editor:


Court Rejects Bar by G.S.A. To Perot Pact
LEAD: A Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that the Board of Contract Appeals of the General Services Administration did not have the authority to void a contract that the United States Postal Service awarded without bidding to the Perot Systems Corporation.


Power Panel in Making: The Hispanic Caucus
LEAD: The Congressional Hispanic Caucus is but a shadow of its role model and ally, the Black Caucus, but that is changing as Hispanic residents grow toward becoming the nation's largest minority.


A Freedom Update
LEAD: By the end of this year, 53 more political prisoners who have been locked up in Soviet jails or psychiatric wards may be free men.
Moscow has just promised that to the United States and delivered the names.


Dukakis Turns Attack on Bush To Environment
LEAD: Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis today shifted his attack on Vice President Bush from Social Security, ethics and taxes to the environment, charging that his opponent's role has been ''hazardous to our health.''
